editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: THE COMPLEAT BODY OF The Art Military. The Fir≈øt BOOK.
CHAP. I. A di≈øcour≈øe of the Po≈øtures, and handling of Arms.
div.p: HE that will be a compleat Souldier, mu≈øt fir≈øt begin to learn the u≈øe of his Arms, laying that down in his thoughts for his fir≈øt foundation. But this hath been the neglect of many in our times, who have ≈øtrived to know high thoughts in the Art Military, before they can well perform their Po≈øtures. Therefore, my advice ≈øhall be unto all ≈øuch that de≈øire to thrive in this Art, that they will not ≈øoar too high: but fir≈øt learn the A, B, C thereof, after which they may proceed by degrees to pronounce to the Souldier with boldne≈øs their proficiency therein. He therefore that with ≈øafety, ea≈øe, and delight de≈øireth to handle his Arms, mu≈øt ≈øet times apart frequently to practi≈øe him≈øelf therein. And here I cannot but much blame the Officers of our Trained Bands in London, of two great neglects: The fir≈øt, in making men File-leaders either out of re≈øpect or favour they bear unto them, or el≈øe becau≈øe one man hath a better Buff-coat than another: I ≈øpeak not this to encourage any man to come ≈ølovenly habited when he ≈øhall march forth with his Captain, but rather advi≈øe all Souldiers to fit them≈øelves with the be≈øt array they can; and could wi≈øh all the Serjeants in drawing up their Files, to pitch upon ≈øuch Gentlemen to be File-leaders, as may take charge of his File, and ≈øhall be able, willing, and ready upon all convenient times, to in≈øtruct and teach his File in all their Po≈øtures, and neat handling of their Arms; which if carefully ob≈øerved, they would reap the benefit of much ea≈øe to them≈øelves and the private Souldiers: readine≈øs in the performance of the Po≈øtures, would much redound to the honour of the Captain that ≈øhall lead them. But for the farther ≈øatisfaction of the ingenious Souldier that ≈øhall enquire what Po≈øture is, I ≈øhall briefly re≈øolve them thus:
Po≈øture, as I conceive, is a garbe or figure that a man ≈øtands in, in the handling of his Arms; which he u≈øeth for the better grace and becoming of them.

There are ≈øeveral motions belonging to each Po≈øture, which ≈øome call Po≈øtures, but they much deceive them≈øelves, as ≈øhall appear clearly unto them (by the ≈øurvey) as they ≈øhall be ≈øet down in order. And fir≈øt, we will begin to ≈øet down the Po≈øtures of the Pike.

div.head: CHAP. II. Several Rea≈øons why the Pike is the more honourable Arms.
div.p:
FIr≈øt I ≈øhall begin to ≈øet down the po≈øtures of the Pike, before the po≈øtures of the Musket, for the≈øe rea≈øons following, as conceiving, Fir≈øt, They are the more honourable Arms, in re≈øpect the Colours flying upon the head of them, and upon the drawing up of the Company there is the mo≈øt propere≈øt place for the Captain to be, either upon a Stand or upon a March, provided he have ground ≈øufficient to March them all abre≈øt. If upon a Stand the Captain ≈øhall have occa≈øion to engage again≈øt an Enemy, thither his Officers may repair unto him upon the head of the Pikes,
there to receive directions. And if the Captain ≈øhall cau≈øe the Serjeants to draw off part, or all the Muskettiers from the Body of Pikes to fire again≈øt the enemy, the Gentlemen of the Pikes in the mean time ≈øtand undauntedly to undergo the cruel ≈øhot of the Cannon from the contrary part for to pre≈øerve their Colours, who are likewi≈øe a place of Randezvous for the Muskettiers to repair unto when they ≈øhall retreat from fight. Farther, it hath been the ambition of many Gentlemen, both in Holland, France, and in the≈øe our late unhappy Wars in England, to trail Pikes with ≈øeveral Commanders whom they ≈øhall think fit. And la≈øtly, to conclude all, that the Pike is the more honourable Arms, it is ≈øo in re≈øpect of antiquity; for there hath been the u≈øe of the Pike and Spear, many hundred years before there was any knowledge of the Musket, as in many Hi≈øtories you ≈øhall find. And ≈øo for pre≈øent I will conclude this di≈øcour≈øe of the Pike, de≈øiring the Muskettiers to have a favourable cen≈øure of me: for I intend not by it to per≈øwade all Souldiers to the handling of the Pike, and none to be Muskettiers, for that cannot be; I ≈øhould rather advi≈øe all Captains that have occa≈øion to rai≈øe their Companies, to have two thirds of Muskettiers, and but one of Pikes: that is to ≈øay, if they ≈øhould have 18 Files, to cau≈øe twelve of them to carry Muskets, and the other ≈øix files Pikes. And in my judgment they ≈øhall perform the better ≈øervice unto any Nation where they ≈øhall be employ'd: and I ≈øhall farther de≈øire the Souldiers (e≈øpecially tho≈øe that be of low ≈øtature) to handle and take delight in the u≈øe of the Musket; for it is an exceeding great honour to him ≈øo to handle his Musket, as that he doth it with ea≈øe, and in a comely manner; and he that ≈øhall become expert therein, I have often ob≈øerved this commendation to follow him, by the report of others; Such a one is a good Muskettier, and an able Souldier: concluding thereby, he that will take the pains to be a good Muskettier, certainly cannot be idle, but hath gained ≈øomething more to make him capable of ≈øuch prai≈øe. To conclude, I ≈øhall de≈øire the Gentlemen of the Pikes and the Gentlemen of the Muskettiers to go hand in hand in love like dear Brothers, and neither of them to envy each other; and in ≈øo doing, God will give a ble≈ø≈øing to their undertakings. But now fearing I have dwelt too long upon this di≈øcour≈øe of the Arms, I ≈øhall next proceed to ≈øet down, fir≈øt the po≈øtures of the Pike, then the po≈øtures of the Musket, with all the words of command tending to their Motions; after collect them in order in a brief way, and then ≈øet forth unto you the equality of number that the one Arms hath with the other in the po≈øtures, as followeth.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Po≈øtures of the Pike.
div.p:
THE Pike lying on the ground, the fir≈øt word of Command will be, Stand to your Arms.
Handle your Pike to your Open Order,
Handle your Pike to your Order,
Rai≈øe up your Pike to your Clo≈øe Order.
Charge with the But-end of the Pike, at the in≈øide of the right foot, your Pike in the left hand, drawing your Sword over your left arm.
Charge to the
Front
Right Flank,
Left Flank,
Reer,
Order your Pikes, and put up your Swords.
This way of charging to the Hor≈øe, I have ≈øet down, as being practi≈øed ≈øometimes among≈øt us in our private Meetings; but I conceive it to be of little u≈øe to receive a de≈øperate charge of the Hor≈øe, for by the≈øe charges the Souldiers are in ≈øo lame and weak a po≈øture, that the Hor≈øe cannot choo≈øe if they come on with a full career, but beat the Pikes and Pike-men down to the ground: Therefore in my opinion, the be≈øt way of oppo≈øing the Hor≈øe-charge, is that which we learned of our ever-honoured Captain, Major Henry Tillier, in the Military Garden; which was, Files clo≈øing to the mid≈øt to their clo≈øe≈øt Order, in≈øomuch that there was not above half a foot interval of ground between File and File, the Pikes Porting, and after clo≈øing their Ranks forwards ≈øo clo≈øe, that they locked them≈øelves one within another, and then
charged on. Which in my judgment is ≈øo ≈øecure a way from routing, that it is impo≈ø≈øible for any Body of Hor≈øe to enter therein: and farther, to my be≈øt remembrance, I never could meet with any Souldier that hath been a broad upon any ≈øervice, that ever ≈øaw any charging of the Pikes at the Foot; therefore I will further proceed.

div.p: Here is to be ob≈øerved by this Method an endeavouring to perform all the po≈øtures of the Pike, from each particular po≈øture, only ≈øhortning it by degrees, leaving out what was before commanded until we come unto the Trial. Yet notwith≈øtanding I ≈øpared not the charges, but have ≈øhewn them from every po≈øture, in their due order. Next followeth the po≈øtures of the Musket, wherein, in an≈øwerablene≈øs to the Pike, I ≈øhall lay them down in full, and afterwards contract them in a ≈øhorter way.

div.head: CHAP. V. The Po≈øtures and Charges of the Pike, to be performed in a ≈øhorter way, all things acted in order, and nothing done twice.
div.p:
THE Pike lying on the ground, the fir≈øt word of Command will be,
Stand to your Arms,
Handle your Arms,
Rai≈øe up your Pikes to your
Open Order,
Order,
Clo≈øe Order,

Front

After lay the narrow end of the Pike to the ground, face about to the left to your fir≈øt Front, and move forward with the butt-end of your Pike on your right ≈øide in your Funeral po≈øture. After face about to the right, rai≈øe up your Pike, face then again to your fir≈øt Front, you may lay down the Pike to the ground, and march from your arms, having ended all the po≈øtures & charges in their due cour≈øes. And here Fellow-Souldier, whoever thou art, thou mai≈øt perceive that there are no more then eight Po≈øtures of the Pike, and four Charges, that is to ≈øay, to the Front, Reer, and both Flanks. There are ≈øome would fain have another posture added to the≈øe, which they call the Lazie po≈øture, which ≈øomtimes I have perceived upon a Stand, that then the Pike-man lets ≈ølip his Pike from the ≈øhoulder, until the butt-end re≈øt upon the ground; then laying his right arm over it, he ≈øtands in an ill-favour'd lazie way. Such po≈øtures as the≈øe are not fit to be ranged among the former, but rather to be condemned, in regard the Souldier will be apt enough to find out ≈øuch po≈øtures as the≈øe of him≈øelf, if not prevented by the di≈øcretion of the careful Officers; for upon a Stand, the Souldiers propere≈øt po≈øture is to Order his Pike. And thus much in brief concerning the po≈øtures of the Pike.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The Po≈øtures of the Musket collected in a brief way.
div.p:
ACcording to my former promi≈øe, I ≈øhall endeavour to give the be≈øt ≈øatisfaction I can to the Muskettiers, as well as to the Pikes, that there is an an≈øwerablene≈øs of number in the proper po≈øtures of the Musket to them of the Pike: and they are eight (as I conceive) and may be proceeded on in order, from the taking up, to the laying down of the Musket, and nothing acted twice: The words of Command for the po≈øtures followeth,
Stand to your Arms,
Handle your Arms.

Now you are to take notice, that in taking up the Bandiliers, putting them on, taking up the Re≈øt, putting the ≈øtring about the left wri≈øt, the taking up of the match, placing of it, the taking up of the musket; the≈øe, or the like, are no po≈øtures, but motions to the fir≈øt po≈øture. Therefore I will proceed upon them all in order as they lie, leaving out the words of command tending to the Motions.

list.item: 1 Order your musket,

4 Shoulder your musket,

6 Trail your Rest, and ballance your musket on the left ≈øide with the barrel downwards,
7 Recover your musket, and perform your Sentinel-po≈øture.
8 From this perform your funeral-po≈øture.

div.p: This being ended, a man may recover his musket and rest, that knows how to perform this la≈øt po≈øture, without bringing him again upon the Rest; and may lay down his Arms again, ob≈øerving the former Rule, where the po≈øtures of the musket are ≈øet down at large.

div.head: CHAP. VII. There is al≈øo a conformity of Po≈øture with the Musket to tho≈øe of the Pike, and Words of Command to be given, as may in many things be received by both Arms.
div.p:
THe musket and pike lying on the ground, the≈øe words of Command may properly be imployed to both; That is to ≈øay,
Stand to your Arms,
Handle your Armes.
The butt-end of the musket ≈øtanding, or re≈øting on the ground, at the out≈øide of right foot, is conformable to the Pike ordered.
The musket poy≈øed; to the pike advanced.
The musket ≈øhouldered; to the Pike ≈øhouldered.
The musket porting; to the pike porting.
The musket rever≈øt; (as in the funeral-po≈øture) to the Pike trailing.
The musket re≈øted, to the pike cheeked; which is his proper ≈øentinel-po≈øture.
The musket pre≈øented; to the pike charged.

As for the motions of po≈øture, which conduce to the lading and priming of the
musket, as to ca≈øt about, trail, recover, and the like; they are all included in that general word of Command, properly to the muskettiers belonging, which is to make ready.

Now, methinks, I hear ≈øome ingenious Souldier begin to ask me, What are the u≈øe of the≈øe po≈øtures ≈øo fully laid down by you? To whom I ≈øhall be ≈øo courteous, as to ≈øatisfie them, according to my former Method, beginning with the Pike, as followeth.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The u≈øe of the Po≈øtures of the Pike.
div.p: The u≈øe of Ordering the Pike.THe Pike being ordered is the proper po≈øture of a Souldier upon a ≈øtand, which he ought ever to mind upon any ≈øuch occa≈øion, ≈øo to make u≈øe of it. And I have likewi≈øe ≈øeen in many places, in the day-time, this po≈øture to be u≈øed by the Souldier ≈øtanding ≈øentinel.

The u≈øe of Advanceing the Pike.The Pike advanced, is u≈øeful for the Souldier upon a Troop, when they are to march ≈øwiftly, either for the relieving of ≈øome Court of Guard, or to repair to their place of Randezvous, or upon ≈øome ≈øudden approaching to an Enemy to make a Charge; for then he will be in a fit capacity to clap down quickly his pike upon the brea≈øt of the Enemy. It is likewi≈øe very u≈øeful in the time of exerci≈øe to the half-files and bringers up, upon any doubling to the Front, for then they are always to be advanced in re≈øpect of a longer march in their doublings, then tho≈øe that double ranks and files; but having doubled, they mu≈øt always conform in po≈øture to the part doubled.

The u≈øe of Porting.The u≈øe of Porting was invented for the ea≈øe of the reer half-files, upon a charge; for the front half-files are only for to charge; the reer half-files in the mean time are to port. It is likewi≈øe very u≈øeful at ≈øuch times when the ≈øouldiers are marching through a gate or ≈øally-port, from whence I conceive it doth derive its name porting.

The u≈øe of Shouldering.The u≈øe of ≈øhouldering the pike is only propere≈øt upon the march, & in ≈øome kind very u≈øeful upon a ≈øtand in time of Fight, provided they are at convenient di≈øtance from the Enemy. For it much pre≈øerveth the pikes and pike-men from the danger of the ≈øhot, the bullets then gliding off from their Arms; which if they ≈øtood at ≈øuch times, either ordered, or advanced, the bullets would make ≈øuch a clattering among≈øt the Pikes, that what with breaking of them, and the ≈øhivers flying from them, may much endanger the ≈øouldiers which carry them.

The u≈øe of Comporting.The comporting of the Pike is only u≈øeful to the ≈øouldier marching up a hill; for if then he ≈øhould be ≈øhouldered, the butt-end of the Pike would always be touching of the ground, to hinder him in his march, and much endanger his fellow-≈øouldiers that ≈øhall come after him. Neither can he march advanced; for if there ≈øhould be any wind, it would be ready to blow him down. Therefore as above, that which is mo≈øt commodious for the ≈øouldiers marching up a hill, is to comport his pike.

The u≈øe of Trailing.The Trailing of the Pike is ≈øeldom u≈øed, but when the ≈øouldier ≈øhall march ≈øtraight forward through a Wood, the File-leader before he enters in, trails his pike, and con≈øequently all the re≈øt in his file: then ≈øtooping down, they take up the butt-end of their leaders pikes, which they may ea≈øily gripe with their own in their right hands, and after march forward through the bu≈øling leaves in a ≈øtraight line, every file ≈øingle by him≈øelf, but as neer each other as po≈ø≈øible they can march, for more ≈øecurity ≈øake; that when they are clear, they may find each other, and be in a condition to rally up again, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require. The trailing of the Pike may al≈øo be of excellent u≈øe in a Trench, that at ≈øuch time when they ≈øhall have intelligence where the Enemy are preparing to make a breach, they may then move forwards unto that place undi≈øcovered, and may defend the ≈øame.
The u≈øe of CheekingThe cheeking of the Pike is the proper ≈øentinel-po≈øture, and then to be u≈øed.

div.head: CHAP. IX. The u≈øe of the Po≈øtures of the Musket.
div.p: I Conceive it will not be material to go over every po≈øture of the musket, to de≈øcribe the u≈øe of them, in re≈øpect the greater part of them have conformity to the Pike. Tho≈øe that ≈øhall remain, and of the chiefe≈øt con≈øequence, I ≈øhall not be wanting to ≈øatisfie the ≈øouldier in.

The ballancing the musket, and rest, on the right ≈øide,The u≈øe of ballancing the Musket on the right ≈øide. with the barrel upward, is one of the chiefe≈øt po≈øtures belonging to the musket; from thence he begins to make ready, as to open, clear, and prime the pan, all being motions to this po≈øture.

To traile the rest, and ballance the musket on the left ≈øide with the barrel downward, is a po≈øture likewi≈øe of as great con≈øequence;The u≈øe of ballancing the Musket on the left ≈øide. for there are ≈øeveral motions belonging al≈øo to this po≈øture, as to find out the charge, to open it, to charge with powder, to take bullet out of the bag and to charge with bullet; with divers other motions before you can recover your musket and rest again.

div.head: How a Muskettier ≈øhall perform the Sentinel-po≈øture.
div.p: THe Sentinel-po≈øture is to be performed after this manner; fir≈øt, the musket is to be laded with powder and bullet; afterwards he is to cock his match, and to ≈øtand with his pan guarded, his musket being upon his rest, until ≈øuch time he is relieved: but as concerning him, I ≈øhall more fully ≈øet forth his duty, treating upon the duty of the Sentinel.

div.head: CHAP. X. The manner and way to do the Funeral-po≈øture.
div.p: NExt followeth to ≈øhew how to do the Funeral-po≈øture: the propere≈øt and the be≈øt way to begin this po≈øture, is when the musket is re≈øted, and is to be performed after this manner: You mu≈øt fir≈øt ≈ølip up your musket upon the rest, ≈øo high, until the fork of the rest be within a handful of the cock; after you mu≈øt bring your right hand under the barrel of the musket, clo≈øe to the fork of the rest, and then lift him off, and after ca≈øt your Re≈øt backward, trailing him on the left ≈øide, and bring your Musket under your left arm, with the barrel downwards, bearing the butt-end upward, with your two fore-fingers and your thumb, holding off the pan, and that with the left hand. Now if you begin to be weary in the march, by rea≈øon of the weight of the musket, you may to ea≈øe your ≈øelf, bring your right hand backward, and there take hold of the musket, keeping ≈øtill your left hand in its fir≈øt place, until you ≈øhall reduce him to the Re≈øt again.

div.head: The reducement of the Musket from the Funeral-po≈øture.
div.p: FIr≈øt, rai≈øe up your Musket a little with your two fingers and thumbs of the left hand, as you formerly held him; then turn the Musket until you perceive the barrel to be upward; after lay your right hand upon the barrel, much about the lazie pin; and then taking him, bring him up forward on the out-≈øide of the Re≈øt: recover your Re≈øt, fall back with the right legge, you may with ea≈øe bring your Musket again upon the Re≈øt, as at fir≈øt. This po≈øture being ≈øo ≈øeldome u≈øed, makes the Souldier much to ≈øeek in performance of the ≈øame; but he that takes plea≈øure in handling of the Musket, and ≈øhall exerci≈øe him≈øelf therein, cannot chu≈øe but find it very ea≈øie, and much delightful to him: And I know no po≈øture more becoming a Muskettier then this, if it be near, and well performed by him. And here I ≈øhall conclude, and end di≈øcour≈øing of the po≈øtures.

div.head: CHAP. XI. The Souldiers de≈øire to know every particular place of Dignity, as they ≈øtand in Rank and File.
div.p:
THe Souldier now having obtained ≈øome pretty knowledge, skill, and ready aptne≈øs in the managing and performing the po≈øtures, begins to look about him≈øelf what next is needful for to fa≈øten upon, to make a further progre≈øs in this Art; and ≈øtraight he meets with ≈øome that whi≈øpers to him, That it were a gallant thing to know the Dignity of a File true and rightly ≈øtated: To which he an≈øwers, But where can it be found? the opinions of ≈øouldiers are ≈øo various and differing therein, that none knows where for to attain it. My Captains eye (≈øaith he) is upon me, becau≈øe I do the po≈øtures well, which cau≈øeth the Serjeants to make me a File-leader, and that I know to be the chiefe≈øt and fir≈øt place of Honour in the File; the ≈øecond place to be the bringer-up; the third, the half-file-leader; the fourth, the bringer-up of the Front half-files. Thus far, no ≈øouldier of any known judgment can deny: but now a-dayes our Files being drawn up ≈øix deep, makes me altogether
ignorant of the honour of the re≈øt; neither know I the Dignity of a File eight or ten deep, which ≈øtill in ≈øome places they do retain, drawing them up ≈øo deep. If my ambition were but now fully ≈øatisfied herein, I ≈øhould in time come for to know the Dignity of the Captains, as they are drawn up all in a Regiment; by which Rule I am informed they walk. And in my judgment, there cannot be a truer ≈øtating the Dignity of a Rank and File, then that which ≈øhall conform to the Dignities of the Captains, as they are drawn up abre≈øt all in a Regiment. Now for as much as many Regiments con≈øi≈øt of ≈øeveral numbers of Captains, and Companies in them; as ≈øome ≈øix Companies, others eight; ≈øome greater, as ten, and twelve Companies: It is expedient therefore, not only for my ≈øelf, but for every ≈øouldier that will be truly knowing, to be re≈øolved herein concerning tho≈øe ≈øeveral numbers; and as occa≈øion ≈øhall alter to any other, they may inform them≈øelves by the≈øe how to fit their purpo≈øe. And therefore not to keep the apt and forward ≈øouldier longer in ≈øu≈øpence, but that he may proceed, I ≈øhall among≈øt the re≈øt, declare my thoughts therein, and ≈øet it forth unto their view, ever hoping from my fellow-≈øouldiers a favourable cen≈øure of my good meaning to them and to my Country, for to imploy that little talent which lately my endeavours have obtained to do them ≈øervice: And ≈øhall forthwith ≈øet down unto them four Tables of Dignity, both of Ranks and Files, which ≈øhall be fir≈øt of twelve abre≈øt, and twelve deep. Secondly, ten abre≈øt, and ten deep. Thirdly, eight abre≈øt, and eight deep. And la≈øtly, ≈øix abre≈øt, and ≈øix deep: wherein every ingenious ≈øouldier ≈øhall ea≈øily know his particular place of Honour and Dignity, both in Rank and File, wherein he ≈øtands.
