div.p: The Table being thus ≈øet forth unto the ≈øouldiers view, as is before expre≈øt, methinks I hear ≈øome ≈øay, Sir, we like the drawing forth, and the manner of your Table very well; we ≈øee cleerly there the particular places how every man ≈øtands in his Dignity both in Rank and File, according to your ≈øeveral Figures; but we be≈øeech you, Sir, be ≈øo favourable as to make us under≈øtand it by a farther demon≈øtration of the ≈øame, and be plea≈øed out of your courteous nature to explain your ≈øelf a little farther therein; and to afford us ≈øome rea≈øons to confirm and back the ≈øame, that it may clearly appear to our judgments the truth thereof, and that we may ≈øit down and re≈øt our ≈øelves with fulle≈øt ≈øatisfaction therein. To an≈øwer, methinks it ≈øhould be ≈øtrange to make denial here to the mode≈øt de≈øire of any ingenious ≈øouldier, and clear repugnant to my wonted cu≈øtome; and therefore without any more delay, I ≈øhall farther let them know

div.head: CHAP. XII. Rea≈øons for the places of Dignity both in Rank and File, for the fir≈øt four in a File eight deep.
div.p:
THat which gives mo≈øt life for the true explaining of the former Table is, to ≈øhew the ≈øeveral places of Honour and Dignity of the Captains, how they are drawn up abre≈øt all in a Regiment. Be plea≈øed therefore to go along with me, and you ≈øhall under≈øtand that the Colonel hath the fir≈øt place of honour, as being Commander in chief, who≈øe Company ≈øtands upon the right, which makes the figure (1). The ≈øecond place of honour in the Regiment is the Lieutenant-Colonel, who≈øe Company is drawn up upon the left, as being the outmo≈øt there, and is de≈øcribed
by the figure (2). The third place of honour is the Majors Company, which is drawn up upon the right of the left half Ranks, who≈øe place is de≈øcribed by the figure (3). The fourth place of honour is the elde≈øt Captains Company, which is drawn up upon the left of the right half Ranks, and is ≈øet forth by the figure (4). And now we have proceeded thus far, we will make Alt, and begin to examine whether we have rightly hitherto proceeded, or no; therefore, for the more cleering and under≈øtanding herein, you mu≈øt take notice, it is the di≈øcretion of every knowing Commander, ≈øo to aim and ≈øtate his Battail, as that he makes his Front equivalent in worth, ≈øtrength, and dignity to that of the Reer, and with equal proportion of number; and in like manner ≈øo to order his right half Ranks, as that they may carry an equal ballance in worth, number and dignity with the left half Ranks. Now therefore to begin to make ≈øome trial or experiment herein, by examining the fir≈øt worth with the fourth, and that will make the number (5) and then put to trial the ≈øecond worth and third, and you ≈øhall ea≈øily di≈øcern it to carry the ≈øame proportion of number. So that it may appear cleerly in the judgment of any di≈øcreet ≈øouldier a true and equal proportion, the Front with the Reer, the right half Ranks ≈øutable to the left half Ranks, and that both in number, honour, and dignity.
Having thus far entred into the di≈øcour≈øe, it remains to de≈øcribe and ≈øhew the rea≈øons of the other four of their places and dignity as they ≈øtand.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Rea≈øons of the places of the ≈øecond four, as they ≈øtand in Rank and File, the File being eight deep.
div.p: NOw for the further re≈øolution herein, there is to be taken notice of, That the general drawing up of Regiments, when they con≈øi≈øt of ≈øo few Companies as 8, 6, or 7, is commonly in two grand Divi≈øions, that is to ≈øay, two bodies or two ≈øtands of Pikes which are flanked with Muskettiers. Therefore you may ob≈øerve, the di≈øcretion of the Major, who commonly is appointed to draw up the Regiments, doth ≈øo order the places of the Captains, that they may aptly fall into their due places of honour, upon a ≈øtand and upon a march; and doth ≈øo order their dignities as before is expre≈øt, as to make both the Front, Reer, right and left half Ranks equal in number, ≈øtrength, and dignity. And therefore he draws up the third and fourth Captain between the Colonels Company and the elde≈øt Captain, which makes their number (13) and in like manner he draws the ≈øecond Captain and the younge≈øt Captain between the Lieutenant-Colonels Company and the Majors, who≈øe number likewi≈øe carries equal proportion to be (13). Now if you plea≈øe to examine the whole number of the right half Ranks, and that makes (18) make trial likewi≈øe of the left half Ranks, in ca≈øting up of his accompt, and you ≈øhall find the ≈øame proportion of number as is clearly ≈øet forth within the Table, both of Ranks and Files; for as the honour of every ≈øouldier ≈øtands in the Rank, you will find the ≈øame to ≈øtand ≈øo in the File.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Other Rea≈øons to cleer it further to the Souldier.
div.p:
TO give you farther ≈øatisfaction, and Rea≈øons for the placing of the ≈øecond four, in re≈øpect it is contrary to the Rule and Judgment of ≈øome Souldiers, therefore farther ob≈øerve with me this, When a Regiment is drawn up in the true Order of a Regimental way, there, is as before expre≈ø≈øed, two bodies, or ≈øtands of Pikes, flanked with Muskettiers; and it is the Office of every Major to give forth in writing notes of paper unto every Captain, and Lieutenant, where their place ≈øhall be upon a Stand, and where upon a March, that he may with more readine≈øs know where to lead, and where to fall in, or to bring up, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require. Now, for as much that it hath been the practice here in England, and in mo≈øt Countries al≈øo be≈øides, as I have been informed by very able knowing ≈øouldiers, that the fir≈øt place of honour that is appointed out unto the Captains, is fir≈øt unto the elde≈øt, who alwayes leads the Colonels Colours, or fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion of Pikes, which is the greate≈øt honour that can be appointed out unto the Captains, and therefore mo≈øt propere≈øt and due to him as being elde≈øt: If ≈øo, as
that it is then generally granted, that the leading of the Colonels Colours, or the fir≈øt body or ≈øtand of Pikes in the Colonels grand Divi≈øion, is the fir≈øt and chiefe≈øt place of honour among≈øt the Captains; why then, certainly, I mu≈øt conclude the ≈øecond Captain, which carries the number (5) would be infinitely wronged and injured, if he were denied, and not brought into the left half Ranks, for there he aptly ≈øtands to fall in, to lead the Lieutenant-Colonels Colours, or the ≈øecond body or ≈øtand of Pikes, which is the ≈øecond place of honour. Now having re≈øolved, that it is cleerly the due and right for the ≈øecond Captains place, to lead the ≈øecond body of Pikes; we mu≈øt then of nece≈ø≈øity bring in the younge≈øt Captain into the left half Ranks likewi≈øe, who carries the number (8) and that will make up an equal proportion, as before expre≈øt, to the third and fourth Captains, carrying with them the figures (6 and 7) which are drawn up in the right half rank.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Rea≈øons given for the la≈øt Table of every particular Place of Honour and Dignity, as they ≈øtand.
div.p:
I Conceive what formerly hath been expre≈øt of the middle Table, may give full re≈øolution of the particular places of Honour and Dignity as they ≈øtand both in Rank and File. It further now remains to ≈øpeak ≈øomewhat of the re≈øt, and therefore I ≈øhall go downward, cleering ≈øtill the fir≈øt four places of honour; which being rightly under≈øtood, the re≈øt will naturally fall into the capacity of any ingenious ≈øouldier. Therefore further pray ob≈øerve with me this again in examining of the ≈øutablene≈øs and equal proportion of worth and number of the fir≈øt and fourth worth, carrying unto that of the ≈øecond and third. And thus far you may re≈øt, and ≈øatisfie your ≈øelf therein. We have therefore now no more to place and ≈øettle, but the fifth and ≈øixth worth, and then our work in this Table will be quickly fini≈øhed. Therefore of nece≈ø≈øity, as formerly expre≈ø≈øed, we mu≈øt bring in the fifth worth into the left half Ranks, as being the ≈øecond Captain, who≈øe proper place, as I ≈øaid before, is to lead the Lieutenant-Colonels Colours, or the ≈øecond body or ≈øtand of Pikes. He being there thus fixed, we have no more to place but the ≈øixth worth, which is the la≈øt, or younge≈øt Captain; and we have no other place to bring him in, but between the fir≈øt and fourth worth; or if you will have it more cleer, between the Colonel and elde≈øt Captain. But, here by the way, I am like to meet with ≈øome Objector that will ≈øay, Sir, What's become of your equal proportion here? Your right half Ranks, with your left, as you have ≈øo formerly ≈øtated them; your right half Ranks carrieth or exceedeth one more in number then your left half Ranks doth; and where we find the greater number, we mu≈øt conclude the le≈ø≈øer dignity; and if ≈øo, Why do you not rather contrive it on the left, then upon the right? To which I an≈øwer, fir≈øt, That in rai≈øing up of Companies into a Regiment, tho≈øe that are the Field-Officers by right ≈øhould have the mo≈øt men, and greater Companies, then the private Captains have: therefore if you will ob≈øerve in the ≈øtating of this Dignity of a Rank ≈øix abre≈øt, you will find in the left half Rank two Field-Officers, who≈øe Companies are the greater then any private Captains; certainly, they mu≈øt needs countervail with any number of men with the right half Ranks; for although the Colonels Company is, or ought ever to be the greate≈øt, yet there is no more Field-Officers, but him≈øelf in his Divi≈øion. And again, ≈øecondly, where there cannot be an equal dividing of number (as here you will find it of ≈øix abre≈øt, or ≈øix deep) but that there will fall out ≈øome odd, either on the right half Ranks, or on the left; and likewi≈øe the ≈øame either in the Front half files, or Reer half files, as by example in the trial you will ea≈øily find, by ca≈øting up the whole number as they ≈øtand abre≈øt, and they will fall out to be (21) divide this number into two parts, and you cannot but mu≈øt ca≈øt the odd either on the right or on the left: Therefore to conclude, ≈øince that there is a great po≈ø≈øibility that there will be an equality of number of men in the left half Ranks ≈øutable to that of the right, where there ≈øhall fall out an odd number, that you cannot ca≈øt it into the left half Ranks, but that you mu≈øt remove the fifth worth; in this extremity I ≈øay you may not do it,
but rather place it on the right. For the Major having no certain place to march in a Regiment, it is the proper place of the ≈øecond Captain to walk along with the Lieutenant-Colonel, taking his due place of honour in his Divi≈øion, as the first ≈øhall do by marching with his Colonel; And thus much ≈øhall ≈øuffice to be ≈øpoken of the la≈øt Table.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Rea≈øons likewi≈øe to be given for the Table 12 abrest, and 12 deep.
div.p: FOr as much as formerly hath been ≈øpoken, That it is the di≈øcretion of every Commander ≈øo to order his men, as to make an equal ballance throughout the battel, that his Front carry with it an equal proportion of worth, number, and dignity with that of the Reer; and likewi≈øe ≈øo to ≈øteer and order his right half rank, or right flank, ≈øutable to that of the left: The next way then to receive further ≈øatisfaction herein, is by an examination thereof as it lies, and is ≈øet open to view.

Compare now the worth & dignity of the right half Ranks, & you ≈øhall quickly perceive them to carry a like proportion of number and worth with the left. To make it a little more clear unto tho≈øe that ≈øhall de≈øire to be more ≈øatisfied herein, you may take notice, and ob≈øerve a true qualification throughout the whole rank. As fir≈øt, begin with the Colonel, who is the chiefe≈øt man of honour in the Regiment; and next to him is placed the ninth or younge≈øt Captain, to qualifie his dignity, and makes his number (13). The Lieutenant-Colonel being the ≈øecond man of honour, hath placed to him the eighth, which qualifies him in like manner to the Colonel, and makes his number (13). Next come we to the Major, and next to him is placed the ≈øeventh Captain, which makes him ≈øutable with the re≈øt in his figure and qualification, and to bear the number (13). After we are to ≈øpeak of the elde≈øt Captain, who hath the ≈øixth Captain joyned unto him, and makes his number (13). And ≈øo comparing all the re≈øt, dividing them by two's, they will ≈øtand as followeth.

Thus much, I conceive, may give a right under≈øtanding to any coming-on Souldier of the true and right ≈øtating of a Rank twelve abre≈øt, being a thing very needful for to know, in re≈øpect that there are many Regiments which do con≈øi≈øt of twelve Companies; and when in cour≈øe, as in the ≈øequel of this Book, when as I ≈øhall ≈øhew the manner of drawing up of twelve Companies; there will a little more light appear unto them to their farther knowledge of the ≈øame. But thus much for the pre≈øent, as concerning a Rank twelve abre≈øt: And now I ≈øhall come to ≈øpeak or to touch a little of a Rank ten abre≈øt, and a File ten deep.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Brief rea≈øons to be given of the Dignity of places of a Rank ten abrest, and of a File ten deep.
div.p: WHat hath been formerly declared concerning a Rank twelve abre≈øt, as before ≈øhewed, by every particular place of honour, as they ≈øtand with the rea≈øons for the ≈øame; it may give a cleer under≈øtanding by the ≈øame rule to find the Dignity of places ten abre≈øt. For walking by the ≈øame way and rule of examination, and you will find them to carry by dividing by two's, being added to the four fir≈øt places of honour, and they will carry ≈øutable proportions, as underneath is ≈øet forth.

But for as much that in this Range of ten abre≈øt, there will fall out ≈øome odd; we mu≈øt then of nece≈ø≈øity-≈øake place it upon the right, and not on the left, for the rea≈øons as formerly for a File ≈øix deep declared. I might now here conclude with other flouri≈øhing Tables, which might be little profitable unto the ≈øouldier, though holding out di≈øcour≈øe more fuller in an Arithmetical way. But I have no de≈øire to fill this ≈øubject with plenty of unprofitable words and frothy flouri≈øhes, but rather driving really in a ≈øouldierly way, to make all things both plain and ea≈øie to every courteous Reader that ≈øhall be plea≈øed for to peru≈øe the ≈øame. And therefore, here for pre≈øent, I ≈øhall conclude, what more might here be ≈øpoken by Dignities of Ranks and Files, leaving what ≈øhall remain until ≈øuch time in cour≈øe I ≈øhall again meet with them by the way in drawing up of Regiments.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. What Di≈øtance is, and the rea≈øons for the fir≈øt beginning of the ≈øame, with all their ≈øeveral u≈øes.
div.p: HAving thus now pa≈ø≈øed over ≈øeveral rea≈øons, and with as much brevity as I could, to ≈øatisfie the longing de≈øire of the young ≈øouldiers reque≈øt of every particular place of honour as they ≈øtand in dignity both in Rank and File; which being pa≈ø≈øed over, the next will follow by cour≈øe, before we come to joyn the Files into a Body, to ≈øatisfie the ≈øouldier of each particular Di≈øtance, with the ≈øeveral rea≈øons and u≈øes of the ≈øame: for next to the Po≈øtures it is the fir≈øt thing or part of the Military exerci≈øe, and mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øouldier to be knowing in. Yet I mu≈øt confe≈øs no Commander is ≈øo tied up or limited in the exerci≈øing of his men at all times to begin with Distances fir≈øt, ≈øo as to ≈øhew them all throughout; but neverthele≈øs, in all and every one of the motions in the exerci≈øing of a Body, care mu≈øt be taken that the ≈øouldier have his proper di≈øtance for performance of the ≈øame. Neither can any Leader exerci≈øe his men, but fir≈øt he mu≈øt command them to ≈øome di≈øtance ≈øutable to what he will begin. As ≈øome I have ≈øeen begin their exerci≈øes with Facings, ≈øome other with Doublings, others with Counter-marches and with Wheelings. Yet neverthele≈øs, whoever they be that will ≈øo begin, as I ≈øaid before, mu≈øt command his ≈øouldiers to ≈øome Di≈øtance, which may be proper for the ≈øame. But for my own part, my purpo≈øe is to go throughout all parts of the Military exerci≈øe of Foot, and therefore will go on in order as they lie; and fir≈øt, as mo≈øt propere≈øt, I ≈øhall begin with Di≈øtances, to ≈øhew them all throughout, and what the nature of them be.

Di≈øtance therefore really con≈øidered in it ≈øelf, is no Motion; but there are ≈øeveral motions to the attaining of each particular Di≈øtance, both in length and depth. Therefore briefly thus: Di≈øtance is a place or interval of ground between every particular File and File, and betwixt every Rank and Rank as they ≈øtand, and attained by the ≈øeveral motions of Ranks and Files, and con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeveral proportions of ground, as ea≈øily may be under≈øtood by their ≈øeveral words of command as they follow.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. The ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Di≈øtances which are fit and proper for the Souldier to be exerci≈øed in.

list.item: CLo≈øe≈øt Order, Which is both in Rank and File Half a foot,
Clo≈øe Order, Which is both in Rank and File One foot and half,
Order, Which is both in Rank and File Three foot,
Open Order, Which is both in Rank and File Six foot,
Double Di≈øtance, Which is both in Rank and File Twelve foot,
Twice double Di≈øtance, Which is both in Rank and File Twenty four foot.

div.p: Having thus ≈øet down every Di≈øtance with their ≈øeveral proportions of ground, I ≈øhall next proceed to the words of command to the opening of the Ranks and Files from their clo≈øe≈øt Order, and after ≈øatisfie the Souldier with Rea≈øons, and the u≈øes of every particular Di≈øtance, as they go along in order.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Words of Command for the opening of Ranks and Files to all their Di≈øtances, with their clo≈øings again.
div.p:
THe Commander craving ≈øilence, and that they be commanded to clo≈øe Ranks and Files to their clo≈øe≈øt Order, the words of command for Di≈øtances are as followeth,
Files open to the right, to your Clo≈øe Order,
Ranks open backward to your Clo≈øe Order,
Files open to the left, to your Order,
Ranks open backward to your Order,
Files open to the right and left to your Open Order,
Ranks open backward to your Open Order,
Files open to the left, to your Double Di≈øtance,
Ranks open backward to your Double Di≈øtance,
Files open from the mid≈øt, to Twice double Di≈øtance.
Ranks open backward to Twice double Di≈øtance.

The Ranks and Files being thus opened unto their twice double Di≈øtance from their clo≈øest Order, I conceive it to be a more ≈øouldierly-like way in the Opening and Clo≈øing of Files, that the di≈øcretion of the Commander do vary, and alter the hand in the commanding of them, then alwayes from every Di≈øtance to tie him≈øelf to any particular hand; as to open to the right, and clo≈øe to the right. But as concerning the opening of Ranks, the propere≈øt way in my judgment is to open them alwayes to the Reer, in re≈øpect it is performed with more facility: For every Rank from the fir≈øt takes his due Di≈øtance as he is commanded, without any further trouble, or to a half-facing to the right, by taking it from the Reer, if from that place they ≈øhall be opened; and ≈øo likewi≈øe it were a great deal better in the clo≈øing of Ranks, to clo≈øe them forwards, in re≈øpect it is for the more conveniency of their clo≈øing, then to the Reer. For then, again, they mu≈øt perform a half-facing, which is not only unhand≈øome, but trouble≈øome to the ≈øouldier. All that can be ≈øaid to maintain it, (as I conceive, in opening Ranks forwards) is becau≈øe they have not room in the Reer; which ≈øeldome happens ≈øo in any exerci≈øe, if di≈øcreetly ordered by him that leads them. As for clo≈øing of the Ranks backwards, I cannot conceive any ≈øolid rea≈øons to confirm the ≈øame, and therefore will pa≈øs over it, and come to clo≈øe our Ranks and Files to ≈øuch Di≈øtance, from whence they fir≈øt were opened.

list.item: Files clo≈øe to the right and left inward, to Double Di≈øtance.
Ranks clo≈øe forwards, to Double Di≈øtance.
Files clo≈øe to the right, to your Open Order,
Ranks clo≈øe forwards to your Open Order,
Files clo≈øe into the mid≈øt to your Order,
Ranks clo≈øe forwards to your Order,
Files clo≈øe to the left to your Clo≈øe Order,
Ranks clo≈øe forwards to your Clo≈øe Order,
Files clo≈øe to the right to your Clo≈øe≈øt Order.
Ranks clo≈øe forwards to your Clo≈øe≈øt Order.

div.p: Concerning the words of Command for Di≈øtances, in the openings and clo≈øings of Ranks and Files, what before is ≈øet down, may be ≈øufficient for any ≈øouldier to u≈øe in time of his exerci≈øe: But now it will be expected to give ≈øome rea≈øons for every one of the≈øe, to ≈øhew them in their proper u≈øes.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. The u≈øe of each particular Di≈øtance, and at what time to be u≈øed.
div.p:
WHerefore, fir≈øt note, that your di≈øtance of clo≈øe≈øt Order, is of chiefe≈øt u≈øe unto the Pike, in the≈øe particulars; as fir≈øt, Charging again≈øt the Hor≈øe, for that the Ranks then clapping in their left legs behind their Leaders right, locking
them≈øelves ≈øo firm and ≈øtedfa≈øt, one within another, which 'twere impo≈ø≈øible for any Body of Hor≈øe to enter in among≈øt them. Secondly, it is of excellent u≈øe for to maintain a breach, and to keep out an enemy. Thirdly, it is very u≈øeful to both Arms, at ≈øuch time when a Commander hath any thing of con≈øequence to di≈øcover unto his Company, which he may have many occa≈øions ≈øo to do; as before his Exerci≈øe, to advi≈øe them to ≈øilence, to ob≈øerve their words of command, and their directions; and when they are to fight again≈øt an Enemy, to per≈øwade and keep them off from fear, by a≈ø≈øuring them good rea≈øons of hopes of overcoming. The≈øe, or ≈øuch-like ≈øpeeches, many times a Captain may have ju≈øt occa≈øion to expre≈øs him≈øelf unto his Company; and being at ≈øo clo≈øe a Di≈øtance, they may more aptly hear his words, and obey his Commands. But here now by the way, too much preaching upon the head of a Company concerning matters of Exerci≈øe, is too much a dulling of the ≈øouldier, who rather would fall into action, then ≈øo to be confounded with much talking.

Clo≈øe Order may be of very good u≈øe al≈øo for mo≈øt things which have been ≈øpoken of the clo≈øe≈øt Order; only here the ≈øouldier hath a little more liberty in the handling of his arms by being at a wider di≈øtance. This di≈øtance al≈øo is of good u≈øe, before wheelings, becau≈øe many times upon their moving, they are apt to flie out to their proper di≈øtance of Order, which they alwayes ≈øhould be at in their wheelings; where note, if fir≈øt they were at Order, they would flie out to wider di≈øtance.

Order is the di≈øtance which the ≈øouldier doth fight upon, and is to be u≈øed skirmi≈øhing again≈øt an enemy; it is al≈øo u≈øeful at ≈øuch a time, when the Drum ≈øhall beat a Troop, and that the ≈øouldiers are marching to relieve ≈øome Court of Guard, or making ≈øome expedition again≈øt an enemy, for then they are in a fit capacity of di≈øtance for to fight. It is al≈øo very u≈øeful, and to be ob≈øerved upon facings, for all intire doublings, and for wheelings; Order likewi≈øe in File, and open Order in Rank, is to be u≈øed at ≈øuch time when the Drum ≈øhall beat a March, and the Body upon the moving or marching.

Open Order is the di≈øtance proper for all doublings of Ranks and Files, by the half-files or by the bringers-up, wherein they have interval of ground ≈øufficient to move in. It is al≈øo a very proper di≈øtance for facings, and ever to be ob≈øerved in time of Counter-marches. It is the propere≈øt di≈øtance for the Ranks to be in upon a march, but the Files are then to be at Order, as is before expre≈øt.

The u≈øe of double Di≈øtance is to be ob≈øerved at ≈øuch times when the ≈øouldiers ≈øhall ≈øtand, or happen to be in ≈øome eminent danger of the Cannon-≈øhot from the Enemy; for ≈øtanding then ≈øo thin, they may be much pre≈øerved from danger: it is likewi≈øe very good for Inver≈øion, and Conver≈øion.

You may take notice of the≈øe brief directions, in openings of Ranks and Files; when the Files are commanded to Open to the right, the left-hand File ≈øtands, and all the Files take their di≈øtance from the left; ob≈øerving alwayes in the motions of Files, their Leaders, and to move altogether along with them. If it be an opening of Files to the left, then contrary-wi≈øe the right-hand File ≈øtands, and they take their di≈øtance from the right. So likewi≈øe for clo≈øings unto what hand ≈øoever they be commanded to clo≈øe, the out-mo≈øt File is to ≈øtand, the re≈øt are to move and clo≈øe to that. In opening or clo≈øing of Ranks, the fir≈øt Rank is alwayes to ≈øtand, the re≈øt are to move either opening or clo≈øing, according as is commanded; alwayes ob≈øerving in their motions their right-hand-men, and moving altogether.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Directions of the way and manner of drawing up a private Company.
div.p:
THe Po≈øtures being formerly de≈øcribed forth, the dignity of places in a File, and words of Command made known unto the ≈øouldier for their ≈øeveral di≈øtances; It next followeth to ≈øhew the joyning of Files, and drawing up a Company; where fir≈øt pray mind at ≈øuch times when the Drums are beating about the Quarters, and in ≈øeveral places make Proclamation, (as by order from their Captain) for all Gentlemen Souldiers that are under his Command, to repair unto his Randezvous, unto ≈øuch a place, and at ≈øuch an hour; then it mu≈øt be the immediate care
of every Officer under his Command, punctually at that hour and place, thither to repair, for the more incouraging of the ≈øouldiers as they ≈øhall come in, and not to ≈øtir them≈øelves from thence, without ≈øome order from their Captain, for fear of giving bad examples unto others. And when they ≈øhall perceive ≈øome con≈øiderable number of men to come in, the Serjeants then may take advice with their Lieutenant and En≈øign, which of them they will appoint out to draw forth the Muskettiers, and which the Pikes, and whom they ≈øhall make the right-hand File-leader of the Muskettiers, and who ≈øhall be the left; and again, who ≈øhall be the leader of the right-hand File of Pikes, and who ≈øhall be the left: For the≈øe four, being ≈øuch remarkable places of Honour unto the knowing ≈øouldier, that ≈øpecial care mu≈øt be had in placing de≈øerving men to be there. Now it is, or ought to be the di≈øcretion of every Lieutenant, and En≈øign, (as being Commi≈ø≈øion-Officers) to re≈øolve the Serjeants herein, that they may with more alacrity go on to draw the re≈øt up between; and ≈øo to order unto each of them their particular duties, as to carry equal pains in drawing forth the Files. Therefore in re≈øpect that for the mo≈øt part in every Company, they have three Serjeants, two of them ought to take charge in drawing forth the Muskettiers, (being helpt by the advice of their Lieutenant,) and the other to draw forth the Files of Pikes, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted in coun≈øel by their En≈øign: for at ≈øuch times the Officers ought not to be idle, and to ≈øtand gazing upon each other; but every one, according to his particular place and relation, ≈øhould be very active and a≈ø≈øi≈øting to each other. In the drawing up the Company, the propere≈øt way will be then, as you may under≈øtand, in perfecting up a Company, to draw them forth into Files, and to make them fix deep; as being our cu≈øtome here in England: and farther to have care in choo≈øing able ≈øouldiers to be File-leaders, who having ≈øpent ≈øome time and pains in their Files in ≈øhewing them their Po≈øtures, they may be called to joyn into a body.

For farther direction herein unto the Serjeants (who≈øe proper place it doth belong unto) to ob≈øerve this order in drawing up their Files, that they may ingro≈ø≈øe the Pikes into one body by them≈øelves, and the Muskettiers into another, and not to flank the Pikes until ≈øuch time they ≈øhall perceive that in both Arms they are compleat: There are likewi≈øe ≈øeveral places of honour that the Serjeants ought to take notice of, and to be informed of placing of men of worth and de≈øert in both Arms, that is to ≈øay, in the body of Pikes, and of the Muskettiers, which underneath by figures I ≈øhall ≈øet forth for farther ≈øatisfaction therein.

Here I have ≈øet down the manner how the Serjeants ≈øhould draw up their Files in each Arms apart by them≈øelves, and have figured forth unto them the four chief places of honour in both Arms. It concerns them therefore very much to mind and have regard to the≈øe particular places, and to order ≈øuch men of worth there, which may be well de≈øerving of the ≈øame; and tho≈øe Gentlemen whom they ≈øhall think fit after to be worthy of File-leaders places, they are to draw them up between the figure (1) and the figure (4), and between the figure (3) and the figure (2) and that Rule to ob≈øerve in both Arms; and to be careful to place good ≈øouldiers in the Reer, and ≈øuch who may be able ≈øouldiers for half-File-leaders, becau≈øe there may be much occa≈øion by Doublings to bring them up for to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Front.

Thus much, I do confe≈øs, may be ≈øufficient for the pre≈øent to give directions to the Serjeants for the drawing up the Files, and joyning them together. Next, after I have ≈øhewn how to flank their Pikes with Muskettiers, I will ≈øet forth unto
them and the Drums, where their places are upon a ≈øtand, and where to be put upon a march.

Next followeth to flank the ≈øtand of Pikes with the Muskettiers; command the Gentlemen of the Pikes to face to the right, and left half-Ranks of Muskettiers to Face to the left, and then to march and interchange ground, facing after to their leaders, and clo≈øing Files inward to order, they will ≈øtand as underneath is ≈øet forth.

Having thus ≈øtated to them all their proper places, next it will be convenient for the Captain to command them to ≈øhoulder their Arms, both Pikes and Muskettiers; and the Officers and Drums taking all their places, as before directed, they may begin to move and draw forth into a long march, as here you ≈øee.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Several rea≈øons given for the placing of the Serjeants after this manner.
div.p:
WHen a Body is drawn up in manner as before expre≈ø≈øed; the Captain being Commander in chief, his di≈øcretion is to ballance the Officers as near as he can with equal dignity and worth, his Front proportionally with the Reer. To which purpo≈øe he takes unto him≈øelf the younge≈øt Serjeant, and places him on the right Angle in the Front, whereby he may be there ready to march down into the Body or el≈øewhere, according unto the di≈øcretion of the Captain, to fulfil his commands; as al≈øo to ≈øtand there as a ≈øpectator of the Captains actions, and an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant, which may be much improvement to him. And in like manner he commands
the third Serjeant to the left Angle in the Reer; as being the ≈øecond younge≈øt, and may be a help unto his Lieutenant there, as the fourth is to him in the Front. The elde≈øt Serjeant he orders to the left Angle in the Front, as being the mo≈øt honourable place for him, being there ready to lead upon a march the Van of the Reer-Guard; and the ≈øecond Serjeant he is appointed to ≈øtand on the right Angle of the Reer, to make them equal in dignity unto the Front. Now if you plea≈øe to examine the dignity of the Serjeants in the fir≈øt place, as the fir≈øt Serjeant and the fourth, making the number (5) and after take a view of the ≈øecond place, or Reer, and there you ≈øhall ob≈øerve that the ≈øecond Serjeant, and third, may every way ballance them≈øelves, to be equivalent in the worth with the fir≈øt and fourth, carrying with them alike the ≈øame number. So that it is clearly evident, that the Serjeants are rightly ≈øtated in number and dignity, the Front proportionably with the Reer, in the judgement of any knowing Souldier. Something more may be ≈øpoken of the ≈øecond Serjeants place, which you may take notice in his march, to lead the ≈øecond Divi≈øion of Pikes, which is the mo≈øt honourable≈øt place of leading that is appointed forth unto the Serjeants, the fir≈øt only excepted; and upon a ≈øtand, when they ≈øhall lead up their Divi≈øions, every Serjeant is to betake him unto his place, as they were at fir≈øt placed, and to continue there until ≈øuch time they ≈øhall receive further order from their Captain. Thus much, I conceive, may give ≈øatisfaction unto the di≈øcreet Souldier in the≈øe particulars, leaving them liberty to judge according unto their own be≈øt thoughts, while we endeavour to draw up our Divi≈øions all abre≈øt again, and to make ≈øome de≈øcription of a Body.

The Captain upon his March having attained ≈øome convenient place to draw up his Company, makes Alt, and commands the Serjeants to lead up their Divi≈øions upon the left, and cau≈øes the Muskettiers to open from the Pikes, making ≈øufficient intervals for the Drums, to beat two abre≈øt, even with the Front, the fir≈øt two between the right-hand-File-leader of Pikes, and the Muskettiers upon the right; the ≈øecond two Drums doing the like upon the left. And always the Captain ought to march his company after this manner all abre≈øt, provided he have ground ≈øufficient for the ≈øame. And being far more graceful ≈øo to do, then to march them ≈øtragling upon a long march, for it doth repre≈øent in ≈øome kind the manner of marching of a Regiment; and at ≈øuch times the Serjeants are to march upon the Angles, as is before de≈øcribed, moving to and again ≈øometimes upon the Flanks, and cau≈øing the Souldiers to keep their Di≈øtance of order in File, and open order in Rank, and to march all even abre≈øt, and after to return again unto their places.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Before I come to make de≈øcription of a Body, I ≈øhall ≈øhew ≈øome further Rea≈øons of the Serjeants places of le≈ø≈øer Companies, with the placing of the Drums.
div.p: IT happens many times ≈øome Companies falls not out ≈øo large, as is before ≈øet forth, and that they have but three Serjeants, and therefore it would be known, when that they have but one Divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the Van, two Divi≈øions of Pikes, and one Divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the Reer, which is the Reer-Guard, where then the placing of the≈øe three Serjeants, and three Drums ≈øhall be upon their long March, and where to be marching all abre≈øt. To which, I an≈øwer, in the fir≈øt place, the younge≈øt Serjeant is always to attend the Captain, and having no Divi≈øion to lead, he is to be upon the right Angle of the Front, there expecting his Captains plea≈øure and commands; and the ≈øecond Serjeant is to lead the ≈øecond Divi≈øion of Pikes, and the elde≈øt Serjeant to lead the la≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, or the Reer-Guard: here are their places upon the long march.

But when they are drawn up, and ≈øo march even abre≈øt, the younge≈øt Serjeants place, as is before expre≈øt, is to march upon the right Angle in the Front, and the elde≈øt upon the left, the ≈øecond Serjeant is to march in the right Angle in the Reer. They having their places thus ≈øtated, are to move ≈øometimes up and down upon the Flanks in their marching, cau≈øing the Souldiers to keep their due di≈øtance of order in File, and open order in Rank, and to march even abre≈øt, and after they may return to their places again.

But here, methinks, I meet with ≈øome Objector by the way, who ≈øaith, the elde≈øt is much wronged herein; for that it is his proper place to be upon the right; that when Forlorns are drawn off again≈øt an Enemy, he is there ready fir≈øt to lead them on, claiming it as his due to give the fir≈øt on ≈øet, and therefore far more honour for him to be on the right then on the left, and the elde≈øt Serjeant rather placed on the left then on the right. As for the ≈øecond Serjeants place, 'tis fit he ≈øhould be in the Reer, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Lieutenant there, he having none but he to help him, if any occa≈øion ≈øhould require. To which I an≈øwer, that it is the younge≈øt Serjeants place to be upon the right Angle, either upon a Stand, or upon a March, and not the elde≈øt, for the≈øe rea≈øons following. The younge≈øt Serjeant is not placed there for any honour that it is to him, for he hath no Divi≈øion at all to lead upon the March (except the Company be very great) and if ≈øo, he is placed ≈øo near the Captain, to be ≈øerviceable to him, to carry and convey his plea≈øures unto all the re≈øt of the Officers. As for the leading of the Van-guard upon the March, the Captain takes that place unto him≈øelf; and it is far more honour unto the elde≈øt Serjeant to be a Leader of the Reer-guard, or entirely the left Flank, then to lead a Subdivi≈øion of Pikes. And be≈øides that, it is propere≈øt for his place to be upon the left, when they are all drawn up upon a bre≈øt, for the≈øe two rea≈øons; as fir≈øt, he is thereupon in readine≈øs to take his due place, upon the ≈øub-dividing on the long March; and again, upon a Stand, when they are all drawn up, and ready to engage again≈øt an Enemy, and the Forlorns to be drawn forth, equally alike from both Flanks, he is then as ready in the Front to execute his Captains Commands, the younge≈øt Serjeant being likewi≈øe ≈øent to be ≈øomething helpful to him, and attending after for further order from his Captain, to ≈øend him relief by the ≈øecond Serjeant, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require. So that in my judgement, take it either upon the long March, or otherwi≈øe, when drawn all up even abre≈øt, all things are ≈øo ≈øtated, for his due honour and place, that he hath no rea≈øon to complain, nor any of the re≈øt, having all their due and proper places which doth belong unto them.

As for the placing of the Drums upon the long March, every Divi≈øion ought to have his Drums fall between ≈øuch Ranks as before expre≈øt; excepting only the ≈øecond Divi≈øion of Pikes, which may be excu≈øed, when they are to beat a March, as being all drawn up, they are to fall in two, to beat even abre≈øt upon the right, and one upon the left, as is before ≈øet down. If it ≈øhould chance further in a Company, to be ≈øo ≈ømall to have but three Divi≈øions, that is to ≈øay, one Divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the Van, the Body of Pikes in the mid≈øt, and another Divi≈øion of Muskettiers to bring up the Reer-guard, and having but two Serjeants and two Drums; the younge≈øt Serjeants place will be as before mentioned, upon the right in the Front, and the elde≈øt Serjeant upon the left, and to take his place to lead the la≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers upon the long March; and the fir≈øt Drum to beat in the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, and the ≈øecond to beat and to march along among≈øt the Pikes. I have a little more enlarged my ≈øelf in this Di≈øcour≈øe of placing of the Serjeants, then I at fir≈øt intended; but meeting many times with ≈øeveral Souldiers, de≈øiring ≈øatisfaction in every one of the≈øe particulars, I ≈øhall perhaps undergo here the hard cen≈øure of ≈øome, for this my tedious Di≈øcour≈øe; but ≈øuch others which de≈øire to be knowing herein, I hope they will have a more favourable opinion of my good meaning unto them. And here I ≈øhall conclude for the pre≈øent, concerning the particular places of the Serjeants in every private Company; and now ≈øuppo≈øing, as by order from the Captain, the Serjeants have brought up their Divi≈øions, ≈øtanding again, as before, expecting ≈øomething more to be ≈øpoken unto them, they ≈øilently ≈øtand to hear what follows.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. A De≈øcription of a Body of men throughout, with all their ≈øeveral parts and kinds.
div.p:
IT is very nece≈ø≈øary knowledge to every particular Souldier, to be acquainted throughout with all the parts of a Body of men drawn up, with their ≈øeveral extents and bounds, and with the true under≈øtanding of the ≈øame.
Where fir≈øt note the De≈øcription of Files; a File is a Sequence of men, con≈øi≈øting of Leaders and Followers, from the fir≈øt unto the la≈øt; the joyning of Files flank-wi≈øe maketh Ranks, and is the compleating up of a Body: for one File alone cannot be ≈øaid to have any Ranks in it, but joyning two or more Files together unto one, you may account them (provided they be ≈øix deep) to have ≈øo many Ranks for number, as doth extend from their Leaders to their Bringers-up. And further know, that a Rank is a Row of men, ≈øtanding ≈øhoulder to ≈øhoulder, in an even line from the left Flank to the right; or from the outmo≈øt man upon the left, unto the outmo≈øt man upon the right; ≈øtanding all in a row File-wi≈øe. Neither can it be ≈øaid of one Rank, to have any Files in it; for as the clo≈øing of Files to Files, makes Ranks; ≈øo the adding of Ranks to Ranks, makes Files.

As for the Depth of Files, they have in the≈øe latter Ages much varied therein; ≈øometimes making them ≈øixteen deep, others ten, and eight deep, and now lately, they have brought them unto ≈øix deep, as being the cu≈øtom of the Swedes and the French, and altogether now the practice here in England. In which form and way, I purpo≈øe to walk. But to proceed to my former promi≈øe to the Souldier: There is in every Body of men drawn up, con≈øi≈øting of Pikes and Muskettiers, whether of greater or ≈ømaller number, it makes no matter; A Front, a Reer, a Right-flank, and a Left-flank; there is al≈øo Front-half-files, and Reer-half-files; there is a Right-half-ranks, and a Left-half-ranks; and there is a Length and Depth of the Battail: and of every one of the≈øe in their ≈øeveral kinds. They have their particular extents and bounds, according to their number of men.

Therefore, take notice in the fir≈øt place, that the Front is the fir≈øt Rank, or Row of men, which are the File-leaders, and chief men of their Files, who properly ought to take charge of their Files, being as it were their Captains, and leads them fir≈øt on in the Brunt again≈øt a furious Enemy. The extent of the Front is from the left-hand File-leader, unto the Leader of the right-hand File.

The Reer is the la≈øt Row or Rank of men, being the Bringers-up of the Files, who next the Leaders are the chiefe≈øt men of honour in the File, and are as it were unto them, their Lieutenants; and in the ab≈øence of their Leaders, they are to take charge of the File, and to in≈øtruct them in their po≈øtures: the extent of the Reer, is from the Bringer-up of the left-hand File, unto the place of the Bringer-up of the right.

The right Flank is the outmo≈øt File upon the right, where always ought, by the way, to be very able Souldiers placed, becau≈øe they fir≈øt give on≈øet, or fire again≈øt the Enemy, if on that part they ≈øhall be charged; the extent of the right Flank is from the Leader of the right-hand File, unto the Bringer-up of the ≈øame.
The left Flank likewi≈øe is the outmo≈øt File upon the left, and his extent is from the Leader of the left-hand File, unto the Bringer-up.

The Front half-Files extent or bounds, reacheth no farther then from the Front, unto the mid≈øt of Ranks, or to the Bringers-up of the Front half-files, which being but ≈øix deep, is the third Rank from the Front; and the length of the ≈øame reacheth from the outmo≈øt part of the left Flank, until you come unto the right.

The Reer half-Files beginneth from the mid≈øt of Ranks, or from the fourth Rank from the Front, and runneth downward in his depth to the Bringer-up of the whole File; and the Length of the ≈øame is to be taken ≈øide-wi≈øe, as they ≈øtand ≈øhoulder to ≈øhoulder, from the outmo≈øt man upon the left, unto the outmo≈øt man upon the right.

The right half-Ranks in their Length runneth no farther, then from the outmo≈øt man upon the right, unto the mid≈øt of Files, or to the left-hand File-leader of the right half-Ranks; the Depth of the right half-Ranks reacheth from the Front, running down unto the Reer.

As for the left half-Ranks, as much may be ≈øaid, to take his Length from the mid≈øt of Files, or from the right-hand File-leader, of the left half-Ranks unto the outmo≈øt Files upon the left; the Depth of the left half-Ranks, may be under≈øtood in form and manner conformable to the right.

Next come we to ≈øpeak of the Length and Depth of the whole Battail: the
Length of the Battail is ever to be accounted of the number of men in a Rank, and not in a File; for the Files perhaps may not be above ≈øix deep, when that there may be hundreds in a Bre≈øt in the Ranks: and farther, the Length of any Battail is to be taken from the outmo≈øt point of the left Flank, or left-hand File-leader, ≈øtretching it ≈øelf forth by an even Line along, until you come to the outmo≈øt point of right Flank, or right-hand File-leader; the Depth of the Battail always is to be taken from the Front or fir≈øt Rank, and going down backward in a ≈øtraight Line down to the Reer, to the la≈øt Rank, or to the Bringers-up of the Files. For as the Length of the Battail is to be taken from the left Flank, going along in Front unto the right; ≈øo the Depth of the Battail is to be taken from the Front, going backward down to the Reer.

There is al≈øo to be under≈øtood, that in every Battalia drawn up, there are other parts and Denominations, very con≈øiderable to be known, that is, in every ≈øuch an one, there is a Van-Guard, a Reer-Ward, and Main-Battail. The Van-Guard are the Muskettiers upon the right, or the right Flank; or as mo≈øt commonly called among≈øt us in the≈øe days, the Right-wing, or the Left-wing, which are the Muskettiers, and the Flankers of the Body of Pikes; the rea≈øon, as I conceive, the Muskettiers are accounted and called Wings, is becau≈øe they are fir≈øt drawn off, as by flying motions in Forlorns, to engage again≈øt an Enemy; but of this by the way. To proceed: the Reer-Ward or Reer-Guard, are the Muskettiers on the left Flank; and the Battail is the Body of Pikes; and here I ≈øhall conclude concerning the de≈øcription of a Body.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. Directions to all ≈øuch as ≈øhall de≈øire to exerci≈øe a Foot-Company, with ≈øome admonitions to the Souldiers as ≈øhall be exerci≈øed by them.
div.p:
HE that intends to exerci≈øe a Body of men, mu≈øt truly know what he ≈øhall command, and ≈øo to give his directions unto the Souldiers, as they may aptly make ready execution of the ≈øame. He mu≈øt at ≈øuch times above all the re≈øt, a≈ø≈øume unto him≈øelf the confidence and pre≈øence (as near as he is able) of a compleat Souldier. He is al≈øo to ≈øtretch out his voice ≈øo, as he may conveniently be heard, and under≈øtood by the inferior Officers and Souldiers; which will cau≈øe them more readily to obey his commands. He ought to carry a chearful countenance unto them, provided they do well; but otherwi≈øe, if carele≈øly di≈øregarding his Commands, he may look har≈øhly upon them. His eyes ought to be quick and nimble, ob≈øerving all their motions, whether it be to the right or left, to the Front or Reer, and nimbly ≈øtepping to them, to ≈øtay them, if di≈øorderly they ≈øwerve awry from what he fir≈øt intended. He mu≈øt likewi≈øe order all his words of Command ≈øo, as that they may be proper, and clearly pronounced forth unto the Souldier, without any faltering. And in every one of the≈øe, to ≈øee the Souldier lea≈øurely and ea≈øily perform the ≈øame in a compleat manner. He mu≈øt not be too quick in his words of Command, but carefully ≈øee what before commanded well done, and then he may proceed unto the next. In time of his Exerci≈øe, he mu≈øt ≈øeriou≈øly mind what he is to do, and not to have his thoughts extravagantly carried away upon any other Subject, for fear he be out; but if any ≈øuch thing ≈øhould happen through forgetfulne≈øs, he ought not to be daunted, but to pull up the ≈øpirit of a Souldier as well as he can, and endeavour to reduce them again. For it is a rare thing to be found, for a Leader to be ≈øo exqui≈øite in his Exerci≈øing, as not to be ≈øometimes out; and in my ob≈øervation of mo≈øt, at one time or another, I have found them ≈øo to be. His di≈øcretion al≈øo ought to be ≈øuch, as to cull out, and chu≈øe tho≈øe things that be chiefe≈øt, as flowers out of a Garden, to fit and compleat up his Exerci≈øe in a Souldier-like way; which may be mo≈øt propere≈øt for ≈øervice and u≈øe, which will bring to him far more commendations and prai≈øe in the judgement of every knowing Souldier, then to ≈øpend his time upon unnece≈ø≈øary toyes; but yet ≈øometimes, to plea≈øe the fancy of the curious, at their private meetings he may u≈øe ≈øome things for delight, to ≈øupport and uphold their private Exerci≈øes, which have nur≈øt up here in London many able Souldiers and Commanders, who have been ≈øerviceable to our Nation. It
is a very nece≈ø≈øary thing likewi≈øe that a Leader ≈øometimes do acquaint the Souldiers of the u≈øe of their ≈øeveral Di≈øtances, Facings, Doublings, Counter-marches, and Wheelings, and of all things el≈øe he ≈øhall command; but in ≈øuch a manner, that he dwell not too long upon any thing he ≈øhall declare unto them, for dulling of the Souldiers, who rather would be plea≈øed with more actings, then by too much talkings; which ≈øpins out the time, as ≈øometimes ordered, to very little purpo≈øe. He mu≈øt be very careful of every word of Command he gives, that the Souldiers be ordered in their due Di≈øtance, ≈øutable to the ≈øame, of what kind ≈øoever it be; and if it ≈øhall be lo≈øt in their movings or marchings, he mu≈øt endeavour to bring them to it again. He is likewi≈øe to acquaint the Souldiers when they are drawn up, to look about them, and to mind their ≈øeveral places, how they ≈øtand in the Body, whether they be in even Ranks from the Front, or odd; if even, and upon any doubling of Ranks, they are the men to double the odd; if half-file-leaders, that they be commanded to double the Front; they mu≈øt advance their Arms, and are Leaders of that Motion to come up to double the Front; if Bringers-up commanded to double, they are alike to do the ≈øame; if Bringers up of the Front-half-files, and that they be commanded to double the Reer, they likewi≈øe are to advance their Arms, to face about, and are to begin to lead them down to the Reer. They ≈øhould likewi≈øe take notice how they ≈øtand in their Files, whether even from the right, or no; if even, and there be any command to double Files to the right, they all are to move, and double the odd; if commanded to double to the left, they then ≈øtand odd; and the others are to move, and double them. They likewi≈øe are to mind their places, who are upon the Flanks, for a doubling either to Front or Reer by the half-Files; they fir≈øt begin to march, and how they ≈øtand there as right and left-hand men in even Ranks; for by any doublings of Ranks entire, or by Divi≈øion, they likewi≈øe are the Leaders of the Motion. There ought al≈øo advice be given to the middle File-leaders, to know their places; for if there ≈øhould be any doublings of the half-Ranks, they then are fir≈øt to move, and to begin the motion.

This caution being ≈øometimes quickly run over in advi≈øing of the Souldiers, that they ≈øhould ever mind when they are fir≈øt drawn up into a body the≈øe particular places, they would not ≈øtand ≈øo carele≈ø≈øy and ≈øo ignorantly in a Body, as many times they do, not knowing which way to move without a great deal of pains and directions from their Leader; for there being ≈øo many occa≈øions of doublings of the≈øe kinds, that it is a nece≈ø≈øary thing for every Souldier to be acquainted with the ≈øame.

Yet it is not only ≈øufficient that the Souldiers do mind their places as they ≈øtand in a body, according to the direction of their Leader, as before ≈øet forth unto them, but that they be likewi≈øe, in the time of their Exerci≈øe, very ≈øilent in the body, and helpful unto their fellow-Souldiers, by pointing out unto them with ≈øigns with the hand, where they ≈øhould march, to perform what was before commanded, and to be very civil and orderly in their carriage to each other, and to mind their Exerci≈øe ≈øo as a matter of great weight, and high con≈øideration in the well regarding of the ≈øame. And if a word of command (as ≈øometimes may happen) ≈ølip out of order, as by the mi≈øtaking of a hand or the like, yet neverthele≈øs it ≈øhould be their mode≈øt care, if not prevented by their Leader, to be ready to execute what they conceive he intended; and walking along in this civil and re≈øpective way unto him that ≈øhall lead them, it will not only be a great encouragement unto him, but they will al≈øo reap much benefit unto them≈øelves.
And thus much briefly may be ≈øpoken in way of advice unto every Leader before his beginning of his Exerci≈øe, and unto each particular Souldier as ≈øhall by him be exerci≈øed.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of Facings, of their ≈øeveral kinds, and of their u≈øe, with the words of command for performance of the ≈øame.
div.p:
FAcing is the altering or turning of the A≈øpect to either hand upon the ground they ≈øtand, according to the words of Command, whether it be to the right,
left, Front or Reer, or to the mid≈øt of Files or Ranks, or to any of the outward or inward Angles, or to the Center.

The manner of execution of the ≈øame, it is a particular turning of every Souldiers countenance unto each of tho≈øe hands or places as above expre≈øt, and to be performed after this manner. The left foot is always to be kept fixed like the hinge of a door, and unto what hand or part they ≈øhall be commanded to face, every particular Souldier is immediately to turn his body upon the Ball or Centre of his left foot by wheeling, until he hath brought his A≈øpect unto the place commanded.

Facings is one of the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary and u≈øefulle≈øt motions among≈øt all the re≈øt: for when the body ≈øhall be in ≈øuch a ≈øtreight that they cannot bring their faces again≈øt an enemy by Counter-march, or by a Wheeling, to bring their be≈øt Souldiers there to fight; and likewi≈øe being debarred of room that they cannot double it, neverthele≈øs Facings are of ≈øuch excellent u≈øe, that they may with ea≈øe, although ≈øtanding at clo≈øe Order, turn every particular face to charge upon that part where they ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øaulted by an enemy: and farther, this motion is performed with more facility then all the re≈øt of the motions. For in the others they alter the form of the Battail, or changeth the place, but in this they pre≈øerve both, and it is ready for any attempt of an enemy: if they ≈øhould be charged all at once in Front, Reer, right and left Flanks, they may be commanded ≈øo to face, as to an≈øwer them all in every one of their charges.

Facings likewi≈øe are ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, that they can hardly be ≈øpared in any other of the motions, having relation in one kind or other to them all for to be u≈øed. There is likewi≈øe farther to be under≈øtood, that there are Entire-Facings and divi≈øional. Entire Facings are when they turn their A≈øpects all one way: Divi≈øional Facings are when they divert or turn their faces ≈øeveral ways, as to the Front, Reer, and both Flanks, all at one in≈øtant of time as ≈øhall be commanded.

There are likewi≈øe facings to the Front and Reer Angles, that is to ≈øay, of their outward and inward Angles. Outward Angles are when they are commanded to face to the right Angle or to the left, or both facing to the inward Angles, as when they are commanded ≈øo, as to face to the inward Angles towards the mid≈øt of Files. There is likewi≈øe facing to the inward Angles towards the mid≈øt of Ranks as to the Center; where note, when there is any u≈øe of the≈øe Facings unto the inward Angles, it is occa≈øioned by ≈øome former words of command, that hath made ≈øome large intervals in the mid≈øt of Ranks or Files, and therefore they may give them ≈øuch commands as the≈øe for to open or ≈øtand ≈øo, that they may march and clo≈øe again as at fir≈øt.

This Facing to the Center, I do conceive to be very u≈øeful, when the Captain or Leader hath any thing of importance to ≈øpeak unto the Company; they ≈øtanding at clo≈øe order, he may ≈øide-wi≈øe move down into the mid≈øt of the Ranks and Files, and command them to face all to the Center; they ≈øtanding all round about him ≈øo clo≈øe, cannot chu≈øe but hear and know what his plea≈øure and command will be, and in obedience thereunto, be very ready in performance for the execution of the ≈øame.

But before I come to ≈øet down the words of Command for Facings, I ≈øhall de≈øire all Leaders not to tye them≈øelves up ≈øo as not to begin in their Exerci≈øe to command Facings, until they have brought the Souldiers to ≈øtand at open order, both in Rank and File, as if it were not proper for them to command them to face till then. Therefore rather, for the rea≈øons before ≈øet forth, command them to chu≈øe upon ≈øuch clo≈øe Di≈øtances to face, that they may know the true u≈øe of them, and at ≈øuch times when they want ground that the other motions cannot be performed.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII. The words of Command for Facings.
div.p:
Face to the
RIght,
Left,
To both Flanks,
Right about,
Left about,
To Front and Reer,
Mid≈øt of Files,
Mid≈øt of Ranks,
Right Angle,
Left Angle,
Outward Angles in the Front,
Inward Angles in the Front,
Right Angle in the Reer,
Left Angle in the Reer,
Outward Angles in the Reer,
Inward Angles in the Reer,
Inward Angles of the right Flank,
Inward Angles of the left Flank,
Outward Angles both of Front and Reer,
Inward Angles both of Front and Reer,
Inward Angles of both the Flanks to the Center,
Front, Reer and both Flanks from the Center,
To the outward Angles of Front and Reer from the Center,
As you were, or, To your Leader.

Having concluded the words of Command for performing of plain Facings, there mu≈øt be notice taken, when any word of Command ≈øhall be given to face to any of the Reer-Angles, they mu≈øt be fir≈øt faced to the Reer, and they will make more ea≈øier performance of the ≈øame; and likewi≈øe, if any word of Command be given to face to the inward Angles upon the Flanks, they mu≈øt face them there likewi≈øe fir≈øt, and it will be ea≈øier fulfilled: and likewi≈øe if any command be given to face to the four Angles, or to Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt from the Center, care mu≈øt be fir≈øt had that they may be fir≈øt faced to the Center.

I might have proceeded a great deal farther in this place upon this Subject of Facings, to have ≈øhewn ≈øeveral figures of Battail that might be produced and drawn forth, affording much variety of forms and number, and with much ea≈øe to be performed upon their ≈øeveral marchings, according as they are ordered to face, which might be very u≈øeful for ≈øervice, and affording much matter for any particular Exerci≈øe, to u≈øe ≈øeveral firings upon the ≈øame. But I ≈øhall have occa≈øion in another place to make u≈øe of divers of them, and ≈øetting them forth in the view, when I ≈øhall begin to ≈øet down in any particular Leadings of my own, which I have performed in our private meetings at Town-Ditch in London, every Thur≈øday-morning, for the ≈øatisfaction of tho≈øe loving Gentlemen who ≈øtill do Exerci≈øe there, and to ≈øuch which ≈øhall come after.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX, The many variety of Doublings, with their parts and u≈øes ≈øet forth for the practice of any Commander, to make u≈øe of according unto his own di≈øcretion.
div.p:
SInce there is in the true account, no other dimen≈øion of a Battail, but the Length and Depth, ≈øo likewi≈øe it is to be under≈øtood, that the Length of the Battail is doubled by the doublings of Ranks and half-Files; and the Depth of the Battail is doubled by the doubling of Files, and of the half-Ranks. Now there are ≈øeveral Words of Command for the performance of each of the≈øe, as to double Ranks and Files, which do con≈øi≈øt either of the doubling of number of men and per≈øons, and not of place, or el≈øe the doubling both of number and place. As for Example, command either the Ranks, the half-files, or Bringers-up to
double the Front to the right; here only is the doubling of number of men, and not of place, for it adds but one man more to that hand, whereunto they were commanded, and gains but his particular place. Again, double Ranks to any hand entire or double, the Front by the half-Files to the right entire, it will be not only a doubling of the number of men, but a doubling of the place, and the Length of the Battail. The u≈øe of doubling the Length of the Battail may be for two Rea≈øons, the one to over-wing an Enemy, the other to avoid over-winging our ≈øelves. Yet there mu≈øt be care taken, that in doubling of the Length, that we fail not, or be too weak in our Depth: for the want of both, either Length or Depth, may be very dangerous to our ≈øelves, and may give great advantage to the Enemy. For if there ≈øhould want a ≈øufficient Depth, by gaining much Length in the Front, we may perhaps be ≈øo weak there, that an Enemy may quickly break through, whereby much danger may en≈øue upon the ≈øame, if not timely prevented by the di≈øcretion of the Commanders.

There is likewi≈øe in the doubling of Files, or the half-Ranks doubling to either Flank, a doubling of number of men, and not of place, carrying much variety of words of Command; but the doubling of Files, and of the left half-Ranks entire, the Depth of the right Flank is not only a doubling of the number, but a doubling of the place and Depth of the Battail. In this doubling of the Depth care likewi≈øe mu≈øt be had, that we make not the Front too narrow, le≈øt we give opportunity to the Enemy to encircle, and encompa≈øs it. To conclude therefore, take notice that Doublings were invented to ≈øtrengthen any part of the Body that ≈øhall be weak, whether in the Front, or Reer-right-flank, or left, whether it be in number of men or place, Length or Depth, it is to be u≈øed according to the di≈øcretion of the Commander. There is likewi≈øe farther to be con≈øidered in Doublings, whether they double the number or place, Length or Depth, it is to be performed by one of the≈øe two, either entire, or divi≈øional Doublings: therefore I ≈øhall proceed, and go on to ≈øhew what I conceive to be the propere≈øt way in the progre≈øs of them in a right order; and therefore I will begin to ≈øet down the words of Command; Fir≈øt, to double the Front, and ≈øo farther proceed to ≈øhew the Doublings of the Flanks. And fir≈øt of entire Doublings, and next of the divi≈øional; and in the mean time, I ≈øhall crave pardon from the courteous Souldier, that I put not down ≈øeveral Pricks or Figures to ≈øet forth the ≈øame, endeavouring rather to give him the words of Command for each particular Doubling, with directions for performance of the ≈øame, together with their ≈øeveral Reducements, leaving it to his ingenious ≈øtudy and practice, to make u≈øe of what he plea≈øeth, where he may cull and chu≈øe out ≈øuch as ≈øhall be convenient and fit, either for ≈øervice or delight; by the way advi≈øing him to retain in his memory, what he intends to practi≈øe, and not to meddle with any thing, but what he a≈ø≈øuredly knows will carry ≈øuch weight and able rea≈øons for their u≈øe and ≈øervice, as ≈øhall admit of no controlment from the judicious Souldier.

div.head: CHAP. XXX. The words of Command for all Entire Doublings to the Front, to be performed one time or other in time of Exerci≈øe.
div.p: Command. RAnks to the right double.

Command. Ranks to the left double.

Direction. Half-files advance forwards to the right and left, from the mid≈øt, and move up into the Front.
Reducement. Files double your Depth to the right and left inward; or, half-Files as you were.
Command. Half-files double your Front to the right and left inward.
Direction. Half-files move forwards from the Flanks inward into the Front.
Reducement. Files double your Depth to the right and left outward; or, Half-Files as you were.
Command. Bringers-up double your Front to the right.
Direction. Bringers-up advance your Arms, and move forwards with the right leg into the Front.
Reducement. Files double your Depth to the left, every man falling behind his Bringer-up.
Command. Bringers-up double your Front to the left.
Direction. Bringers-up advance forward to the left into the Front.
Reducement. Files double your Depth to the right, every man falling behind his Bringer-up.
Command. Bringers-up double your Front to the right and left outward.
Direction. Bringers-up advance forward from the mid≈øt of the Reer, to the right and left into the Front.
Reducement. Files double your Depth to the right and left inward, every man falling behind his Bringer-up.
Command. Bringers-up double your Front to the right and left inward.
Direction. Bringers-up advance forwards from the Flanks, inward into the Front.
Reducement. Files double your Depth to the right and left outward, every man falling behind his Bringer-up.
Command. Double your Ranks to the right entire.
Direction. Every even Rank from the Front face to the right, march forth, and double the odd.
Reducement. Right half-Ranks double your left Flank; or, Ranks as you were.
Command. Double your Ranks to the left entire.
Direction. Every even Rank from the Front, face to the left, march forth, and double the odd.
Reducement. Left half-Ranks double your right-Flank; or, Ranks as you were.
Command Double your Ranks inward entire.

Reducement. The inmo≈øt Files double your Flanks to the right and left outward, and after clo≈øe.

Reducement. Left half-Ranks double your right-Flank, every man placing him≈øelf on the in≈øide of his right-hand-man.

Reducement. Right half-Ranks double entire the Depth of your left-Flank.

The≈øe are, as I conceive, the propere≈øt and plaine≈øt Doublings for any Souldier to u≈øe in his Exerci≈øe, out of which he may chu≈øe as many of them, as he ≈øhall think fit, being all entire Doublings to the Front. Next follows to ≈øhew ≈øome Divi≈øional Doublings to the ≈øame.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. Divi≈øional Doublings to the Front.
div.p: Command. DOuble your Ranks to the right and left by Divi≈øion.
Direction. Every even Rank from the Front face outwards, march forth and double the odd.
Reducement. The outmo≈øt Files upon each Flank that moved, face inward, march in and ≈øtrengthen the Body.
Command. Double your Ranks to the right and left by Divi≈øion, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right and left-hand-man.
Direction. Every even Rank from the Front, move forth to the right and left outward, and double the odd, placing your ≈øelves on the out≈øide of your right and left-hand-men.
Reducement. The outmo≈øt Files upon each Flank that moved, double the inmo≈øt Files to the right and left inward, every man placing him≈øelf on the in≈øide of his right and left-hand-man.

Reducement. The outmo≈øt Files upon each Flank that moved, double entire the Depth of the inmo≈øt Files.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII. Entire Doublings to the Front by Wheelings.
div.p: Command. WHeel off your Reer half-Files, and double your Front to the right entire.
Direction. Half-Files face about, and wheel about to the left; march up and even the Front.

Reducement. Wheel off your right half-Ranks, and double your left Flank entire to the left. Face outward, and right half-Ranks wheel about to the right, moving forward until they range even abre≈øt with their left Flank; to your Leader.
Command. Wheel off your Reer half-Files, and double your Front to the left entire.
Direction. Half-files face to the Reer, and wheele about to the right, move forwards, and double the Front to the left entire.

Reducement. Wheele off your left half-Ranks, and double your right Flank entire to the right. Face outward left half-Ranks, wheel about to the left, and move forward until you have doubled the right Flank, to your Leader.
Command. Wheel your Reer half-files inward into the mid≈øt, and double your Front inward entire.

Direction. Front-half-files open from the mid≈øt, until you be clear of the ≈øtanding part, then face to your Leader; half-files face about, and wheel your Reer inward into the mid≈øt, move forward until you have doubled the Front.

Reducem nt. The inmo≈øt Files that doubled,The inmo≈øt Files mu≈øt have di≈øtance from the outmo≈øt Files, before they can begin to wheel. wheel about to the right and left outward, and double entire the Depth of the outmo≈øt Files, after face to your Leader, and clo≈øe Files to the mid≈øt to Order.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. A divi≈øional Doubling to the Front by Wheeling.
div.p: Command. WHeel off your Reer half-files, and double your Front by Divi≈øion.
Direction. Half-files face to the Reer, and wheel about to the right and left, move forward, and double the Front.

Reducement. The outmo≈øt Files upon each Flank that doubled, wheel about to the right and left inward,Here likewi≈øe mu≈øt convenient di≈øtance be given from the mid≈øt, for the outmo≈øt Files to wheel about. and double entire the Depth of the inmo≈øt Files, face to your Leader.

Here endeth the Doublings that properly belong unto the Front according to the practi≈øe of the≈øe times, whether they be Entire or Divi≈øional, and of their ≈øeveral kinds; as fir≈øt, take them of them≈øelves in the plain way, after by Counter-marches, as by the Bringers-up. La≈øtly, by Wheelings, and that fir≈øt by Entire, after by Divi≈øional. But here by the way, no Leader is tied to do all the≈øe Doublings in his Exerci≈øe at once, but to u≈øe part of them what he ≈øhall think fit. Yet, again, if he de≈øire to be throughly knowing in all the Doublings of Front, Reer, and both Flanks, and to ≈øhew them unto the Souldiers, he may then begin fir≈øt to go over all the words of Command for Doublings to the Front, informing his Souldiers of their ≈øeveral u≈øes for ≈øervice, at one time or another, and then proceed to ≈øhew the u≈øe of the ≈øeveral Doublings to the Flanks, and next to the Reer, which in this place I hold needle≈øs to give words of Command for the Doubling thereunto, in regard the former words of Command u≈øed to the Front, with ≈ømall alteration will ≈øerve to the Reer.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV. Entire Doublings to the right Flank.
div.p: Command. FIles to the right double.
Direction. Every even file from the right by a half-turning at three ≈øteps double the odd.
Reducement. Ranks to the left double; or, Files as you were.
Command. Files to the right and left, double outward.
Direction. Every even File from the Flanks move, and by three ≈øteps double the odd.
Reducement. Ranks to the right and left double inward; or, Files as you were.
Command. Double your Files to the right and left inward.
Direction. Every even File from the mid≈øt move inward ≈øide-wi≈øe, and double the odd.

Command. Double your Files to the right advancing.
Direction. Every even File from the right move forwards, and by three ≈øteps double the odd.
Reducement. Ranks to the right double.
Command. Double your Files outward advancing.
Direction. Every even File from the Flanks, move forwards, and by three ≈øteps double the odd.
Reducement. Ranks to the right and left double outward.
Command. Double your Files to the right and left inward advancing.
Direction. Every even File from the mid≈øt move forwards, and by three ≈øteps double the odd.
Reducement. Ranks to the right and left double inward.

Reducement. Front and Reer half-files double your Ranks entire to the left-Flank, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right and left-hand-man. Front half-Files face about, and every even Rank from the mid≈øt move forth to the left-Flank, and double the odd, placing your ≈øelves on the out≈øide of your right-hand-men, and every even Rank from the Reer half-Files move forth, and double the odd, placing your ≈øelves on the out≈øide of your left-hand-men: face to your Leader.

Reducement. Front and Reer half Files double your Ranks entire to the left-Flank, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right and left-hand-man; half-Files face about, and every even Rank from the Reer, move forth to the left-Flank, and double the odd, placing your ≈øelves on the out≈øide of your right-hand-men, and every even Rank from the Front move forth, and double the odd, placing your ≈øelves on the out≈øide of your left-hand men; face to your Leader.

Reducement. Bringers-up double your Front to the left.

Direction. Left half-Ranks march ≈øtraight forth, until you are clear of the ≈øtanding part, after move to the right (being fir≈øt faced there) and double the right-Flank; face to your Leader.
Reducement. Front half-Files double your Reer to the right entire, face to the left, and move clear of the ≈øtanding part, after face to the Reer, move down, and even the Reer; face to your Leader.

The three fir≈øt, and the three la≈øt Ranks double the ≈øix middlemo≈øt Ranks entire to the right-Flank; the three fir≈øt, and the three la≈øt Ranks face to the right, and march untill you are clear of the ≈øtanding part, after face inward; march, and clo≈øe your Divi≈øions, and face to your Leader.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. Divi≈øional Doublings to the right Flank.
div.p: Command. DOuble your Files to the right by Divi≈øion.

Direction. Half-files of the even Files from the right, face to the Reer; even Files march clear of the ≈øtanding part, after move to the right and left, and double the odd Files; face to your Leader.

Reducement. The three fir≈øt, and the three la≈øt Ranks, double the three middlemo≈øt Ranks to the left; the three fir≈øt Ranks face about, and march down by your own right hands into the mid≈øt of Ranks; and the three la≈øt Ranks move forwards to the mid≈øt, to your own left hands; face to your Leader.

The three fir≈øt, and the three la≈øt Ranks, double the ≈øix middlemo≈øt Ranks to the left, every man placing him≈øelf before his Leader, and his Bringer-up; the three fir≈øt Ranks face about to the left, and move down to the mid≈øt of Rrnks by your own right hands, placing your ≈øelves before your Bringers-up; and the three la≈øt Ranks march forwards unto the mid≈øt, placing your ≈øelves before your Leaders; to your Leader.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI. Entire Doublings to right Flank by Wheeling.
div.p: Command. WHeel off your left half-Ranks, and double your right Flank entire to the right.
