Reducement. In wheeling the ≈øix middle Ranks from the right Flank, they mu≈øt have ground ≈øufficient for them to wheel about. Wheel off from the right Flank the ≈øix middlemo≈øt Ranks, and double your Front and Reer entire to the left Flank: the ≈øix middle-Ranks face to the right, and wheel about to the right and left, moving forward until they are clear of the ≈øtanding part; and after facing to the Front and Reer, they move again, and double the Front and Reer toward the left Flank; face all to your Leader, march forwards, and clo≈øe your Divi≈øions.

Or if they continue their A≈øpect to the right Flank, then command the ≈øix middlemo≈øt Files to wheel off to the right and left, and to double entire the depth of the outmo≈øt Files, then face to their Leader, and clo≈øe their Divi≈øions.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII. A Divi≈øional Doubling to the right Flank by Wheeling.
div.p: Command. WHeel off your left half-Ranks, and double your right Flank by Divi≈øion.
Direction. Face outward, and left half-Ranks wheel off to the right and left about, and move forward until you have ranged even, and doubled the right Flank; to your Leader.

Reducement. Wheel off the three fir≈øt, and the three la≈øt Ranks, and double the ≈øix middlemo≈øt Ranks entire to the left Flank the three la≈øt Ranks face about, and wheel to the right about, moving up towards the mid≈øt of the left-Flank, and the three fir≈øt Ranks at the ≈øame time wheel about to the left, and move down to the mid≈øt of the left Flank; face to your Leader.

Or if they continue their a≈øpect to the right Flank, then command the outmo≈øt Files too that doubled to wheel about to the right and left inward, and double entire the Depth of the inmo≈øt Files, to your Leader.

Here endeth all the plain Doublings to the right Flank, performed by ≈øeveral Counter-marches and Wheelings, which to any ingenious Souldier are ≈øufficient directions to know how to double the left Flank, only altering the hand by the words of Command.

And here fellow-Souldier endeth all the ≈øeveral kinds of Doublings, which if any ≈øhall ≈øeem hard or difficult unto thee, either in their Commands, Directions, or Reducements, thou may≈øt (care being taken) with much ea≈øe and delight perform the ≈øame. And here the Captain is to take ≈øpecial notice, when he comes to the point of Doublings, that his propere≈øt way will be fir≈øt to double the Front, as being the mo≈øt honourable part of the Body, and next the Reer, and after either to the right or left Flank, leaving it to his di≈øcretion to u≈øe as many of them as he ≈øhall think fitting, and convenient for his Exerci≈øe. And although I have ≈øomewhat varied from the practi≈øe of former times in u≈øing more plenty of words of Command, the ripene≈øs and curio≈øity of Wits in the≈øe our days, enforced me unto it; for they having much refined the Military Di≈øcipline, will not be plea≈øed with ordinary ≈øtuff (as to ≈øay, As you were) which, I confe≈øs, would ≈øave the Captain a great deal of pains, and be more ea≈øie to the apprehen≈øion and capacity of every private Souldier, for his returning back unto his place again. Yet if Command ≈øhould be given to double any part of the Body, that Leader would quickly lie under a hard cen≈øure, and be judged in mo≈øt mens opinions in≈øufficient, that could not find out ≈øome other words of Command to reduce them again. Endeavouring therefore to give full ≈øatisfaction to both parties, I have taken the pains to ≈øet down other words of Command for Reducement, whereby tho≈øe which ≈øhall profe≈øs them≈øelves curious, may cull out ≈øuch plenty as may be≈øt plea≈øe their genius; advi≈øing them withal not to pre≈øume in the exerci≈øing of their private Companies, before them≈øelves be fir≈øt well ver≈øt, and truly knowing in all and every of the ≈øeveral Commands, Directions, and Reducements before mentioned; which being obtained, they may confidently and boldly proceed, ≈øo to inure their Souldiers in the practi≈øe thereof, that their own knowledge in a ≈øhort time will reduce them to their former places without u≈øing the≈øe thred-bare words, As you were; variety being more profitable and delightful unto them, (provided they under≈øtand it) then to accu≈øtom them in an ordinary and plain way of reducing.

But here ≈øome men will be ready to carp and ≈øay, that I have troubled my ≈øelf to little purpo≈øe, in ≈øetting down more Doublings then are u≈øed abroad upon ≈øervice. To whom I an≈øwer, that there are none (if rightly under≈øtood) but are of ≈øingular u≈øe one time or another, either in private Meetings, or in tho≈øe great Nur≈øeries of Military Di≈øcipline, the famous Academies of this our I≈øland, the Artillery and Military Gardens, who for Field-≈øervice have train'd up, and ≈øent forth many worthy, able and gallant Souldiers into the Armies lately rai≈øed in our Nation between the King and Parliament, whom I pray God happily to reconcile. But, ≈øuppo≈øe many of the≈øe Doublings have not been ≈øeen by ≈øome to be u≈øed in the field; Are they not therefore u≈øeful? perhaps not at ≈øuch time they have had no occa≈øion for to u≈øe them all; which if not, mu≈øt they be rejected? I an≈øwer po≈øitively, that being rightly enquired into, they have in them very u≈øeful and ≈øerviceable things again≈øt an Enemy, whether it be in the Field, or in Garri≈øon. As for Example; the Muskettiers being brought either all into the Front or Reer, or upon one of the Flanks, which often hapneth, an Enemy appearing there, then they would be of ≈øigular good u≈øe for our advantage, and very di≈øadvantageous to the Enemy. The like may be ≈øpoken of the Pikes, who are by ≈øeveral of the≈øe Doublings brought into tho≈øe places, being there very ≈øerviceable to receive a de≈øperate Charge of Hor≈øe, if upon any of the≈øe parts they ≈øhould fall on. Ob≈øerve, further, that in many of the≈øe Doublings, as the one arms ≈øhall face or charge again≈øt an Enemy, ≈øo contrariwi≈øe the other lies more ≈øecure in ≈øafety to be pre≈øerved from danger of the ≈øhot. Moreover, (according unto the number of men either in Length or Depth) a Leader may by the≈øe words of Command or the like, at the ≈øame time double his Front, Reer, or Mid≈øt, by doubling of Ranks; and may farther make u≈øe of them at one and the ≈øame time to double by Files his right, left Flank and Mid≈øt, all at one in≈øtant. But I ≈øhall not need to ≈øet down words of Command for the doubling Front, Reer, Flanks and Mid≈øt, after this manner, but leave that unto the apt Souldier to make u≈øe of ≈øuch words of Command formerly ≈øhewen, and to frame them ≈øuitable for any ≈øuch purpo≈øe ≈øo intended. But before I ≈øhall conclude concerning the u≈øe of the≈øe Doublings, as I ≈øaid before, there are many of them, which by command will bring any men in the Body to fight, unto that part which ≈øhall be mo≈øt weak, or a≈ø≈øaulted by an enemy. And again, he may ca≈øt them ≈øo into the Body by a doubling, as ≈øhall pre≈øerve from danger whom he ≈øhall think fit. And to ≈øay more, there is no part of the Body or Arms but by words of Command in doublings may be brought forth as Frontiers again≈øt the enemy, and may be placed again into the mid≈øt of the Body for more ≈øecurity, and others in like manner may be brought forth for their relief. Therefore it much concerns all Souldiers and Commanders to be truly knowing in all the ≈øeveral kinds of Doublings, out of which he may make ≈øingular good u≈øe according to his di≈øcretion, at all ≈øuch times as need ≈øhall require, whether it be in Field, or otherwi≈øe in Garri≈øon.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII. Of Inver≈øion and Conver≈øion.
div.p:
NOt to omit any thing which may be beneficial for the knowledge of all them that intend to be good proficients in the Art of Military Di≈øcipline, my ≈øubject in this Chapter ≈øhall be of Ranks filing, and Files filing, and Ranks ranking, and Files ranking, which are by ≈øome called Inver≈øion and Conver≈øion; yet ≈øeldom mentioned by any Leader in the time of his Exerci≈øe, for this rea≈øon, as I ≈øuppo≈øe, becau≈øe the Souldiers for the mo≈øt part are unacquainted with them; which cau≈øeth all our Leaders in our private Meetings here in London, to deliver forth unto their Souldiers ≈øuch words of Command as may readily and aptly be under≈øtood by them, which are, Ranks, File to the right or left; or, Files, File to any hand; which is no other then Inver≈øion. And again, Ranks, rank to the right or left, either in equal or unequal parts, or entire to the Front; or Files to rank in the like kind, may be termed Conver≈øion: And, in my opinion, they do the better that ≈øhall thus expre≈øs them≈øelves to the capacity of every Souldier, then for to puzzle them with the words Inver≈øion & Conver≈øion. I intend therefore without
curio≈øity plainly to ≈øet down their ≈øeveral Commands, Directions, and Reducements, keeping my former method concerning Doublings. For in all and every one of them, they do either double the length or depth of the Front, Reer, Mid≈øt, or Flanks; no part of the Military Exerci≈øe affording more plenty of matter then they, carrying always along with them many things of excellent u≈øe. For example, ≈øuppo≈øe a Prince, General, or any other per≈øon of quality were to pa≈øs thorow the Company, a di≈øcreet commander would pre≈øently command their Ranks to invert, or file to the right and left outward, which immediately becomes (as it were) a Street or Gallery, for the honouring and ≈øecuring of their per≈øons. Moreover, it is of u≈øe for the lodging of the Colours, or upon Funeral-occa≈øions, or taking their leave from their Captain, where they may pour forth their Volleys of ≈øhot all at one and the ≈øame time. To be ≈øhort, being nece≈ø≈øitated to march again≈øt a Battery, it avoids the danger of the great Ordnance, and likewi≈øe ≈øecures the Front of the Battalia from the imminent danger of any great ≈øhower of ≈ømall ≈øhot poured forth by the Enemy. As likewi≈øe it is of excellent u≈øe to march over a narrow Bridge, or thorow a Lane, Thicket, or Salliport, or ≈øuch like difficult pa≈ø≈øages; or if any Commander have a de≈øire to u≈øe ancient Figures, by it he may make the Saw, Sheers, or Diamond; or being in one File, they may aptly be drawn into a Ring, where he that is an able po≈øture-man ≈øtanding in the mid≈øt, may ≈øhew unto them their ≈øeveral po≈øtures, and after ea≈øily reduce them again: and thus much briefly of Inver≈øion, or Ranks filing.

Next come we to ≈øhew the excellent u≈øes and ≈øervices which may be performed by Conver≈øion, as fir≈øt perceiving any man of worth to ≈øtand before the Front of the Battail, or to pa≈øs by either of the Flanks, then Ranks ranking, or Files ranking into the Front, or Ranks wheeling to either of the Flanks, by the≈øe Commands the Souldiers a≈øpects are thither brought to pre≈øent unto him a volley of ≈øhot. It is likewi≈øe very u≈øeful for the making of a Line again≈øt a Brea≈øt-work, or lining of Hedges, carrying it ≈øelf ≈øeveral ways ≈øecretly to lie in Ambu≈øcado, whereby they may fire upon the Enemy as he marcheth by. Or approaching again≈øt any Fort or place of danger, they may daringly make a large Front and firing upon them; after filing to the right or left, making large Intervals, they much pre≈øerve them≈øelves from the danger of the great ≈øhot proceeding from the Enemy. Again, Ranks ranking either in equal or unequal parts, is of ≈øingular good u≈øe upon a narrow pa≈ø≈øage, where they can march but two, three, four, or ≈øix abre≈øt; the Commander, notwith≈øtanding they marched before twenty abre≈øt, may by it bring them to ≈øuch ≈ømall numbers, whereby he may much pre≈øerve them in time of imminent danger and peril. To dwell no longer upon this di≈øcour≈øe, Inver≈øion and Conver≈øion many times require larger di≈øtance then any other of the Motions, as ≈øometimes double di≈øtance: or twice double di≈øtance, wherefore being ≈øo many occa≈øions for the u≈øe of them both, I hold it requi≈øite for a Leader frequently to practi≈øe his Souldiers in them; no part of the Art Military affording more commendations to the Souldiers that ≈øhall readily and hand≈øomly perform the ≈øame. Briefly therefore pa≈ø≈øing over what might be more ≈øpoken concerning them, I ≈øhall in the next place ≈øet them all forth in their full view, leaving every di≈øcreet Souldier to his own liberty, to make u≈øe of as many of them as he ≈øhall think fit, and to u≈øe them after what manner he plea≈øeth.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX. The words of Command for Ranks ranking, and Files ranking to the Front, they being twelve abre≈øt, and ≈øix deep.
div.p: Command. RAnks, rank to the right 2, 3, 4, or 6, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require.

Direction. If to two, the two outmo≈øt men upon the right are to move away, the next two to fall behind them until the fir≈øt Rank hath made ≈øix Ranks, and the re≈øt doing the like until the fir≈øt ≈øix Ranks are become thirty ≈øix.

Reducement. Ranks, rank twelve to the left; the fir≈øt Rank is to ≈øtand, the re≈øt are to move away two and two, until they have made up twelve in one Rank, and the re≈øt are to do the like until they are made up all again as at fir≈øt; or, command, Ranks, rank as you were. The ≈øame rule is to be ob≈øerved if you rank to any of the other numbers, to divide them accordingly.
Command. Ranks, rank three to the left.

Direction. The fir≈øt three men upon the left are to move away, the next three are to fall in behind toward the left, until the fir≈øt Rank have made four Ranks; the re≈øt are to do the like, until they have made them 24 Ranks.

Reducement. Ranks, rank 12 to the right: the fir≈øt Rank is to ≈øtand, the re≈øt are to move forth by three and three, until they have made twelve in one Rank; the re≈øt are to do the like, until they be as they were at fir≈øt; or, Ranks, rank as you were.
Command. Ranks, rank three to the right and left outward.

Direction. The three outmo≈øt men of the fir≈øt Rank upon the right, and the three outmo≈øt men upon the left, move away; the next three of each hand in the ≈øame Rank are to do the like, and every Rank throughout to follow ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, dividing them≈øelves three to one hand, and three to the other, until they have made twelve Ranks in each Divi≈øion, and falling in the Reer ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to each hand of the fir≈øt Rank.
Reducement. Ranks, rank 12 to the right and left inward; or, Ranks, rank as you were.
Command. Ranks, rank intire to the right into the Front.
Direction. The fir≈øt Rank ≈øtand, the re≈øt face to the right, and move away, every Rank placing it ≈øelf ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to the right, until they ≈øtand all in one Rank in the Front.

Reducement. Ranks, rank 12 to the left; the fir≈øt 12 men upon the left are to ≈øtand, the next 12 are to face to the left, and to move and fall in the Reer of the fir≈øt, and ≈øo con≈øequently all the re≈øt; or el≈øe to command, Ranks, rank as you were.
Command. Ranks, rank intire to the left into the Front.
Direction. The fir≈øt Rank ≈øtand, the re≈øt face to the left, and move until they have ≈øucce≈ø≈øively placed them≈øelves, and made one intire Rank into the Front.
Reducement. Ranks, rank 12 to the right, the 12 outmo≈øt men upon the right ≈øtand, the re≈øt face to the right and move, making 12 in every Rank: or, Ranks, rank as you were.
Command. Ranks, rank outward into the Front.
Direction. The fir≈øt Rank ≈øtand, the re≈øt face outward, and place your ≈øelves ≈øucce≈ø≈øively into the Front, facing after to your Leader.

Reducement. Ranks, rank 12 to the right and left inward; the 12 middlemo≈øt men ≈øtand, the re≈øt face inward, and move, ranking 12 ≈øucce≈ø≈øively behind the fir≈øt Rank, and after facing to their Leader, and to even their Ranks.
Command. Ranks, rank inward into the Front.

Direction. The fir≈øt Rank is to move away to the right and left, the next Rank moving up into his ground, doing the like, and con≈øequently ≈øo all the re≈øt, until the la≈øt Rank be come up intire into the Front.

Reducement. Ranks, rank ≈øix to the right and left outward, the fir≈øt ≈øix upon the right, and the fir≈øt ≈øix upon the left ≈øtand, the re≈øt move outward, falling in the Reer of the fir≈øt Rank, ranking ≈øix to the right and left, and after clo≈øing their Divi≈øions.
Command. Files, rank to the right into the Front.
Direction. Files, open to the left to your double Di≈øtance, and Ranks clo≈øe forwards to Clo≈øe Order, and move up to the right into the Front.

Reducement. Ranks, file ≈øix to the left; the fir≈øt ≈øix upon the left are to fall into a File, the re≈øt doing the like, until you have made 12 Files, as at fir≈øt: or command, Ranks, file as you were.
Command. Files, rank to the left into the Front.
Direction. Every man is to move forward to the left into the Front, beginning from the Leader of the Files, and moving up ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, making one intire Rank.
Reducement. Ranks, file ≈øix to the right; the ≈øix outmo≈øt men upon the right are to fall into a File, the re≈øt in like manner are to do the ≈øame: or, Ranks, file as you were.
Command. Files, rank outward into the Front.
Direction. Right and left Half-ranks clo≈øe into the mid≈øt, to Clo≈øe order; after move to the right and left outward, until they be come up into the Front.

Reducement. Ranks, file ≈øix to the right and left inward: the middle men are to ≈øtand, the re≈øt are to move ≈øide-ways to the right and left inward, and to file as before commanded; or, Ranks, file as you were.
Command. Files, rank inward into the Front.
Direction. Right and left Half-ranks open from the mid≈øt to twice double di≈øtance, and Files move up to the right and left entire into the Front.
Reducement. Ranks, file ≈øix to the right and left outward, the outmo≈øt men ≈øtand, the re≈øt move to the right and left outward, filing according to Command, and after to clo≈øe their Divi≈øions.

div.head: CHAP. XL. Ranks ranking into the Front by Countermarch.
div.p: Command. RAnks, rank entire into the Front, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right-hand-man.
Direction. The fir≈øt Rank ≈øtand, the re≈øt move away to the right ≈øucce≈ø≈øively into the Front, placing them≈øelves on the out≈øide of their right-hand-men.

Reducement. Ranks, rank twelve to the left, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his left-hand-man; the fir≈øt twelve upon the left are to ≈øtand, the re≈øt are ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to fall in behind the fir≈øt Rank, placing them≈øelves as before commanded; or, Ranks, rank as you were, placing your ≈øelves on the out≈øide of your left-hand-men.
Command. Ranks, rank entire to the left into the Front, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his left-hand-man.
Direction. The fir≈øt Rank ≈øtand, the re≈øt move away to the left ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, placing your ≈øelves on the out≈øide of your left-hand-men.
Reducement. Ranks, rank twelve to the right, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right-hand-man; or, Ranks, rank as you were, every man placing him≈øelf as before.
Command. Ranks, rank outward into the Front, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right and left-hand-man.
Direction. The fir≈øt Rank ≈øtand, the re≈øt move forth to the right and left, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to fall into the Front, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right and left-hand-man.

Reducement. Ranks, rank twelve to the right and left inward, every man placing him≈øelf on the in≈øide of his right and left-hand-man; the twelve middle men are to ≈øtand, the re≈øt are to move to the right and left inward, ≈øix to one hand, and ≈øix to the other, making twelve in Rank, and falling behind the fir≈øt.
Command. Ranks, rank inward into the Front, every man placing him≈øelf on the in≈øide of his right and left-hand-man.

Direction. Right and left Half-ranks open from the mid≈øt to twice double Di≈øtance; the fir≈øt Rank of each Divi≈øion is to ≈øtand, the re≈øt are to move ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to the right and left inward into the Front, making one entire rank.

Reducement. Ranks, rank ≈øix to the right and left outward, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right and left-hand-man; the fir≈øt Rank of each Divi≈øion ≈øtand, the re≈øt move to the right and left outward, ranking as before commanded, falling ≈øucce≈ø≈øively in the reer of the fir≈øt rank, and after to clo≈øe their Divi≈øions.

div.head: CHAP. XLI. Files ranking into the Front by Wheeling.
div.p: Command. FIles, rank to the right into the Front by wheeling.The Files are to be at double di≈øtance, and ranks at clo≈øe a Order.
Direction. Face to the right, and wheel to the left, until they ≈øtand even abre≈øt in one entire Rank in the Front.

Reducement. Ranks, file ≈øix to the left by wheeling; face all to the Reer, and the fir≈øt ≈øix men then upon the right, wheel to the right, and ≈øo con≈øequently all the re≈øt wheeling by fixes to the right, their Leaders that were before, being the hinges of the motion, and after face to their Leader.
Command. Files, rank to the left into the Front by wheeling.
Direction. Face to the left, and wheel to the right, until they make all one entire Rank in the Front.

Reducement. Ranks, file ≈øix to the right by wheeling; face to the Reer, and the ≈øix outmo≈øt men upon the left, wheel to the left, the next ≈øix are to follow, and con≈øequently all the re≈øt, until they have made twelve Files as at the fir≈øt, and after face to their Leader.
Command. Files, rank outward into the Front by wheeling.
Direction. Right and left half-Ranks clo≈øe into the mid≈øt to Order, and face outward, wheeling to the right and left, until you are one entire Rank.

Reducement. Rank, file ≈øix to the right and left inward by wheeling, face about to the right; and the twelve middlemo≈øt men are to wheel to the right and left inward, and the re≈øt are likewi≈øe to do the ≈øame by Sixes, until they have made them≈øelves into twelve Files; after face to their Leader.
Command. Files, rank inward into the Front by wheeling.
Direction. Right and left half-Ranks open from the mid≈øt to twice double di≈øtance, after face inward, and wheel to the right and left inward, until they are all in one Rank in the Front.

Reducement. Ranks, File ≈øix to the right and left outward, face all about, and wheel by Sixes to the right and left, the Leaders being the hinges of the Motion; after face to the Front, and right and left half-Ranks may clo≈øe into the mid≈øt again to their double di≈øtance.

Here endeth the ranking into the Front, with all their ≈øeveral kinds: the Reer challengeth next place, but I ≈øhall ≈øpare the pains and labour to ≈øet them down, in regard that he who hath a mind to rank his men thither, may, if he plea≈øe, make u≈øe of all the former words of Command for the performance of the ≈øame, facing them upon every Command to the Reer. I come therefore in the next place only to mention the ranking into the mid≈øt by Ranks and Files, which may likewi≈øe be performed by the former words of Command, provided they have convenient di≈øtance, and be faced to the mid≈øt, and after the Command is executed, to face them to their fir≈øt Front. Yet there is remaining a ranking unto all the≈øe places at once; for the performance of which, ob≈øerve the≈øe few words of Command following.

div.head: CHAP. XLII. Ranks ranking, or Files ranking at one and the ≈øame time into Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt.
div.p: They are to ≈øtand at Order in Rank and File. Command. RAnks, rank outward into the Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt.

Direction. The two la≈øt Ranks are to face about; the fir≈øt Rank, and the la≈øt Rank, and the third Rank from the Front, are to ≈øtand; the other three are to move forth, ≈øix to the right, and ≈øix to the left, until they have ranked unto all the≈øe places, after face to the Front, and the la≈øt Rank moving f r ward to open Order.

Reducement. Ranks, rank twelve to the right and left inward; the la≈øt Rank face about, the twelve middlemo≈øt men of each Rank are to ≈øtand, the ≈øix outmo≈øt men of each Rank are to face inward, to move and fall into the right and left behind the middlemo≈øt men, after the two la≈øt Ranks are to face to the Front.
Command. Ranks, rank inward into the Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt.

Direction. Right and left half-Ranks open from the mid≈øt to twice double di≈øtance, the two la≈øt Ranks face to the Reer, the fir≈øt and la≈øt Rank, and the third Rank from the Front ≈øtand, the re≈øt move to the right and left inward, ranking into Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt; after that the la≈øt Rank is to face to the Front, and to clo≈øe forward to open Order.

Reducement. Ranks, rank ≈øix to the right and left outward, the la≈øt Rank face about, and the outmo≈øt ≈øix men upon each Rank are to ≈øtand, and the middle men are to divide them≈øelves ≈øix to the right hand, and ≈øix to the left, and to fall in the Reer of the fir≈øt, la≈øt, and middle Rank; after the la≈øt Rank is to face to the Front, and then to clo≈øe Ranks and Files to their Order.
Ranks ranking by Countermarch Command. Ranks, rank outward into the Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right and left-hand-man.

Direction. The two la≈øt Ranks face about, the fir≈øt and la≈øt Rank, and the third Rank from the Front ≈øtand, the re≈øt move forth to the right and left, ranking into Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt, placing them≈øelves on the out≈øide of their right and left-hand-men; face to your Leader.

Reducement. Ranks, rank twelve to the right and left inward, placing your
≈øelves on the in≈øide of your right and left-hand-men, the la≈øt Rank face about, the twelve middlemo≈øt men in each Rank are to ≈øtand, and the outmo≈øt ≈øix men in each Rank are to move to the right and left inward, placing them≈øelves in the Reer of the former Ranks, and on the in≈øide of their right and left-hand-men, facing to their Leader.
Command. Ranks, rank inward into the Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt, every man placing him≈øelf on the in≈øide of his right and left-hand-man.

Direction. Right and left half-Ranks open from the mid≈øt to twice double di≈øtance, ≈øtanding then at Order in each divi≈øion in Rank and File; the two la≈øt Ranks face about, and the fir≈øt, la≈øt, and third Rank from the Front ≈øtand, the re≈øt move inward, placing them≈øelves on the in≈øide of their right and left-hand-men; after the la≈øt Rank may face about, and move forward to open Order.

Reducement. Ranks, rank ≈øix to the right and left outward, every man placing him≈øelf on the out≈øide of his right and left-hand-man, the la≈øt Rank face about, the ≈øix outmo≈øt men of each Rank ≈øtand, and the twelve middlemo≈øt men in each Rank are to divide them≈øelves ≈øix to the right, and ≈øix to the left, falling in the Reer of the outmo≈øt men, placing them≈øelves on the out≈øide of their right and left-hand-men; after face to the Front, and Ranks and Files clo≈øe to the mid≈øt to Order.

div.head: Of Files ranking into Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt.
div.p: Command. FIles, rank outward into Front, Reer, and Mid≈øt.

Direction. div.head: CHAP. XLIII. Of Files ranking by Wheeling.
div.p: Command. And thus much of Conver≈øion, or Ranks ranking, or Files ranking, they having more variety in them, then many times can be u≈øeful, except it be to pre≈øent unto the Souldiers ≈øome things that are new in the Motions, which many times they love to ≈øee. I could upon this Subject have much more enlarged my ≈øelf; but conceiving what is already ≈øet down may be ≈øufficient for the knowledge of any intelligible Souldier, I come therefore briefly to treat of Inver≈øion, or of Ranks filing, and Files filing.

div.head: CHAP. XLIV. Of Ranks filing, or of Files filing, or of Inver≈øion, with their ≈øeveral ≈øorts and kinds.

ling by way of Counter-march.

Having dwelt thus long upon this ≈øubject of Inver≈øion and Conver≈øion (occa≈øioned thereunto by their great variety and difficulty in the performance of them,) I hold it convenient to give a breathing ≈øpace unto the wearied Souldier, whil≈øt I in the mean time prepare further matter for his longing de≈øire.

Yet before I enter in any other di≈øcour≈øe of the Art Military, I hold it requi≈øite to give ≈øome admonitions to tho≈øe that ≈øhall venture upon them. For being very difficult, they are not ea≈øily under≈øtood by every puny; my advice therefore is, to wave ≈øuch things in time of Exerci≈øe, which the Souldiers are unacquainted with, providing for them ≈øuch matter as is both plain and ea≈øie; and being frequently practi≈øed in ≈øuch, he may after drill them on to harder, till by degrees he hath brought them unto ≈øuch perfection and knowledge, that they ≈øhall be able to perform and execute what is commanded; not gazing upon one another, (as I have often ob≈øerved) neither knowing their Leaders meaning; or if they did, they are altogether ignorant how to fulfil his commands. Frequent practice therefore makes the Souldier expert, witne≈øs our gallant Souldiers and Citizens of London, who are mo≈øt of them ≈øo well grounded (by frequent practice) that their Leaders can ≈øcarce give a word of Command, which is not ea≈øily apprehended by them, they being in their exerci≈øes ≈øo often inured to ≈øuch difficult expre≈ø≈øions as the≈øe of Inver≈øion and Conver≈øion.

div.head: CHAP. L. Of Counter-marches, with th ‚Ä¢ ir ≈øeveral ≈øorts and kinds, affording much variety in time of Exerci≈øe.
div.p: THo≈øe which have a longing de≈øire to be throughly knowing in this part or branch of Military Di≈øcipline, mu≈øt take notice of the≈øe four ≈øorts, (viz.) Counter-marching of Files, next of Ranks, after the Front and Reer-half-files, and la≈øtly, of right and left Half-ranks: all which are performed either by intire or Divi≈øional Counter-marches, or el≈øe by the intire changing of ground; and that by many ways, the Front-half-files with the Reer, the right Half-ranks with the left: So that an expert Leader may venter ≈øo far in them, as to continue his Exerci≈øe (without reducing) almo≈øt for an hour, and not to expre≈øs him≈øelf twice in any one word of Command; they affording ≈øuch plenty and variety in them, that with plea≈øure, u≈øing but four words of Command, he may bring each Souldier into his proper place again; ob≈øerving the≈øe directions following. As fir≈øt, to look down in the Body, where his File-leaders are, and where his Bringers-up: & likewi≈øe marking the ≈øeveral places of his Half-file-leaders, & the Bringers up of his Front-half-files, together with his Flankers & his middle Files: this ≈øpecial care being taken, he may begin and proceed to the Reducement, after this manner.

If by ≈øome former Counter-marches his File-leaders are in the place of his Half-file-leaders, and that his Bringers-up are in the room of the Bringers-up of the Front-half-files, then he may proceed in this, or the like kinde,
commanding them to countermarch their Front and Reer into the mid≈øt; which being performed, they will ≈øtand in ≈øome pretty way of reducing; after facing them to the Front, where he meets with his Bringers-up, in ≈øtead of his File-leaders; which by one Counter-march will bring them up again into the Front. Yet perhaps the Flankers have inter-changed ground with the middle File-leaders: if ≈øo, then Counter-march their Flanks into the mid≈øt, and face them to the Front: and if it happen that the right Flank is become the left, and the left the right; then Counter-march their Ranks to any hand, and after face them to the fir≈øt Front they are reduced. And farther, take this for a general rule, that when Files or Ranks Counter-march to any hand, command them to Counter-march to the contrary, and it will reduce them; or countermarching your Front and Reer into the mid≈øt, counter-marching of them back again from the mid≈øt will bring each man into his proper place again. The ≈øame rule being ob≈øerved, reduceth the Flankers, or Front and Reer-half-files, counter-marching of them from the mid≈øt.
Counter-marches rightly con≈øidered, branch them≈øelves forth into the≈øe three particulars.

The
Macedonian.
Lacedemonian.
Chorean.

The Macedonian is a Counter-march of gaining ground, for that it leaveth the ground it formerly ≈øtood upon, and in lieu thereof taketh the ground before the Front, and turneth their A≈øpects unto the Reer.

The Lacedemonian is a Counter-march of lo≈øing ground, for that it leaveth the ground it fir≈øt ≈øtood upon, and in room thereof, taketh the ground which is behind the Reer; thither likewi≈øe altering the Souldiers A≈øpects.
The Chorean is a Counter-march maintaining ground, keeping the ground the Battalia formerly ≈øtood upon, every Souldier taking anothers place; it likewi≈øe turns the A≈øpect towards the Reer.

Thus you ≈øee (for all their great variety which latter ages have invented) they con≈øi≈øt but of three ≈øorts or kinds, either maintaining, gaining, or lo≈øing of ground; and may be performed (as I ≈øaid before) either by intire or divi≈øional Counter-marches.

It may now be expected that I declare unto the Souldier the meaning of each particular Counter-march; briefly therefore, thus: Files counter-marching is, when every Souldier followeth his Leader; Ranks counter-marching is, when every Souldier followeth his ≈øide-man, whether it be to the right-hand or to the left: Front and Reer-half-files counter-marching is, ≈øometimes when every particular Souldier followeth his Leader or Bringer-up; or el≈øe when they follow their Half-file-leaders, or their Bringers-up of the Front-half-files, or the like: Right and left Half-ranks counter-marching is, when every Souldier in the Rank followeth the outmo≈øt men upon the right and left; or when they ≈øhall follow their in≈øide right and left-hand-men, or the like. What hath hitherto been ≈øpoken may be ≈øufficient, both for the in≈øtruction and direction of any di≈øcreet Souldier: I come in the next place to ≈øet them all before them as they lie in Order.

Thus much may ≈øuffice to be ≈øpoken of all the ≈øeveral ≈øorts and kinds of Counter-marches; which if any ≈øhall conceive my pains fruitle≈øs in culling out ≈øuch plenty and variety, there being ≈øo few of them practi≈øed among able and knowing Souldiers; my be≈øt apology will be, The high and venerable e≈øteem I had of Antiquity nece≈ø≈øitated me thereunto; as al≈øo to give full ≈øatisfaction to the Leaders of our private Meetings, who of late have laboured to inure their Souldiers in the full practice thereof, made me the willinger rather to undergo the cen≈øure of ≈øome, then to incur the di≈øplea≈øure of many. Yet by the way, give me leave fully to declare my ≈øelf concerning the u≈øe of them: for my opinion is, that of all the Motions tending to Martial Di≈øcipline, the≈øe may the be≈øt be ≈øpared, as being of little u≈øe, and not ≈øo much as practi≈øed abroad upon ≈øervice; and therefore the fewer of them any Leader ≈øhall u≈øe in his Exerci≈øe, in my judgement he doth the better, not ≈øpending time in needle≈øs ≈øpeeches, telling of his Souldiers that this is the Macedonian, this is the Lacedemonian, or Chorean Counter-march. Not to lie under the cen≈øure my ≈øelf of mi≈øpending time, I come therefore briefly in the next place to treat of Wheelings, being a ≈øubject more profitable for the intelligible Souldier.

div.head: CHAP. LV. Of Wheelings, with their ≈øeveral u≈øes.
div.p: HAving proceeded thus far in ≈øhewing all the ≈øeveral ≈øorts and kinds of Military Motions, it will now in the next place be expected that I ≈øpeak ≈øomewhat of Wheelings, and as formerly, ≈øo now, to ≈øet before the Souldier their ≈øeveral kinds and u≈øes. Wherefore take notice of two ≈øorts, Wheelings Angular, and VVheelings on the Center, (which latter is commonly called the Prince of Orange his VVheeling) being acted or performed by the Souldier two ≈øeveral ways; that is to ≈øay, Intire or Divi≈øional.

Intire VVheelings to the Angles, are when the Souldiers turn their A≈øpects from the Front proper to either of the Flanks or Reer, whereby they may gain the VVind or Sun, or ≈øome like advantage, bringing their be≈øt Souldiers thither for to encounter an Enemy. For the better performance of this Motion, it will be convenient to clo≈øe Ranks and Files into the mid≈øt to order, and to keep their due di≈øtance both in Rank and File, ob≈øerving in their Ranks their right and left-hand-men, & following their Leaders, always conforming them≈øelves in their Motion to the mo≈øt commendable Po≈øture, which is Pikes advanced, & Muskets poy≈øed. Wheeling the Battail on the Center, is when they are ≈øo ≈øtraightened with ground, that they have not room to wheel to the right or left, as in the former, which
gaineth as much more ground before the Front, as formerly they ≈øtood on. This Wheeling brings their be≈øt Souldiers to either of the Flanks or Reer. I could wi≈øh that this Wheeling were more often practi≈øed among≈øt us, for by it the Souldiers are better kept together in their Motion, being not ≈øo apt to flie out, as in the former.

Divi≈øional Wheelings (provided they have ≈øufficient number of men) are of ≈øingular good u≈øe to encounter ≈øeveral Enemies at one and the ≈øame time, which the Front of our Battalia bringing our be≈øt Souldiers for to skirmi≈øh with them. It is likewi≈øe u≈øeful to bring either Arms into Front, Reer, or both the Flanks: for ≈øuppo≈øe the Muskettiers to be upon the Flanks, and fearing a de≈øperate charge of the Hor≈øe to fall upon them by a Divi≈øion of Wheeling, the Pikes are thither brought to receive their on-≈øet; and in the mean ≈øpace, the Muskettiers have time to recruit their Bandiliers again. Much more might be ≈øpoken, but my intent is not to fill my Book with impertinent di≈øcour≈øes, knowing what is already ≈øpoken is ≈øufficient for the intelligible Souldier.

div.head: CHAP. LVI. Intire Wheelings.
div.p:
Command. WHeel your Battail to the
Right.
Left.
Right
Left

Direction. The right or the left-hand-men in the Front are the hinges of the≈øe Motions; the re≈øt have a greater compa≈øs to march then they, to bring their A≈øpects unto the place commanded, following their Leaders.

Command. Wheel your Battail on the ≈øame ground to the
Right.
Left.
Right
Left
about.
Direction. The Left-half-ranks moveth forwards wheeling to the right; and the right Half-ranks contrariwi≈øe faceth to the left ≈øide-wi≈øe falling backward, moving ≈øtill unto the place commanded.

div.head: CHAP. LVII. Divi≈øional Wheelings.
div.p: Command. WHeel the Battail off by Divi≈øion from the Front.
Direction. Turn off to the right and left.
Command. Wheel the Battail off by Divi≈øion from the Reer.
Direction. Face to the Reer, and turn off to the right and left.
Command. Wheel the Battail inward to the Reer.
Direction. Open from the mid≈øt to convenient di≈øtance, and turn off to the right and left.
Command. Wheel the Battail inward to the Front from the Reer.
Direction. Face to the Reer, open from the mid≈øt, and wheel inward to the Front.
Command. Wheel off the Body by Divi≈øion from the right Flank.

Command. Wheel off the Body by Divi≈øion from the left Flank.

Command. Wheel the body inward to the right Flank from the left.

Command. VVheel off your Front and Reer-half-files by Divi≈øion.
Direction. Half-files, face about; & Front & Reer-half-files, turn off by Divi≈øion.
Command. Wheel your Front and Reer-half-files inward to the mid≈øt of Ranks.
Direction. Half-files, face about; and Front and Reer-half-files, open outward to convenient di≈øtance to wheel inward to the mid≈øt of Ranks.
Command. Wheel off your Front and Reer-half-files by Divi≈øion from the mid≈øt of Ranks.
Direction. Front-half-files, face about; and Front and Reer-half-files, wheel off to the right and left by Divi≈øion.
Command. Wheel Front and Reer-half-files inward, both to the Front and Reer from the mid≈øt of Ranks.
Direction. Front-half-files, face about; and Front and Reer-half-files, open from the mid≈øt to convenient di≈øtance, and wheel inward into Front and Reer.
Command. Wheel off your right and left Half-ranks by Divi≈øion.

Command. Wheel your right and left Half-ranks inward to the mid≈øt of Files.
Direction. Face outward, and open to the right and left to convenient di≈øtance to wheel inward to the mid≈øt of Files.

Direction. Face inward, and cau≈øe them to move backward to convenient di≈øtance, to wheel off by Divi≈øion from the mid≈øt of Files.
Command. Wheel your right and left Half-ranks inward to both Flanks from the mid≈øt of Files.

Command. Wheel the outward Angles to the right and left about, to the Center.
Direction. Face to the outward Angles, and clo≈øe Ranks and Files to clo≈øe order; and the Angles on the right, turn off to the right; the Angles on the left, turn off to the left.

Direction. Face to the inward Angles, or to the Center, and wheel about to the right and left inward from the Center.

The≈øe are all the intire and divi≈øional Wheelings that have hitherto been practi≈øed by any, according to my be≈øt ob≈øervation: there are other Wheelings which may properly be term'd Doublings, which I have placed among≈øt the Doublings, where they more properly belong. Now if any ≈øhall demand of me a rea≈øon why I have omitted the Reducements to each particular Command; my an≈øwer thereunto is ea≈øie: for as in the Counter-marches, ≈øo in the≈øe, they may be reduced by three or four words of Command, except a Commander ≈øhall of ≈øet purpo≈øe keep them off from the ≈øame, to make ≈øome experiment. After any wheeling is performed, face them after to the fir≈øt Front, and command them to even their Ranks, and ≈øtraighten their Files, they will be as at fir≈øt; and unto what hand ≈øoever they wheeled, command them to wheel to the contrary hand, and they will be reduced unto the fir≈øt Front; or what part is wheeled off by Divi≈øion, wheel them inward again from that place, and it will ea≈øily reduce them. Thus you ≈øee that it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible for a Leader to be out, unle≈øs he be extreamly ignorant; therefore he need not fear to venter far in the progre≈øs of them, before he ≈øhall reduce them, provided he u≈øe no Doublings: which if he ≈øhall, great care mu≈øt be had that he be not put to a ≈øtand; for the prevention whereof, let him look back unto tho≈øe doublings by wheelings, wherein one doth reduce another, where he may finde ≈øome remedy to help him≈øelf forth again.

div.head: CHAP. LVIII. Of Firings, either for delight or ≈øervice.
div.p:
THe chiefe≈øt thing required of the Muskettiers next their Po≈øtures, by which they are taught how to handle their Arms with delight both marching or skirmi≈øhing, is Firing; which to ≈øpeak the truth, is the full accompli≈øhment of all the re≈øt; for unle≈øs they be really performed, the re≈øt are of no great advantage. For to what end is it for any man to Prime, Lade or Cock, if he Pre≈øent not an≈øwerably? therefore Firings are the execution of all the former; in ≈øo much as my advice ≈øhall be to all Commanders, that they be careful and diligent to have all their Muskettiers often practi≈øed with fal≈øe Firing; whch is, Firing in the Pan only, and falling off, as hereafter followeth, to the end that in
time of need they may not ≈øpend their Powder and Bullets in vain. And that they may likewi≈øe know where to fall off, that others may do the like, and where to place them≈øelves ≈øecure≈øt from danger; yet ≈øo as they may be ≈øtill aiding the one unto the other: I ≈øhall therefore for the good of my Country, and for the benefit of all ≈øuch as are herein concerned, collect forth ≈øome Firings, which ≈øhall be every one differing from the other in one kind or other, either in the execution or reducing, whereby the ingenious Souldier may cull forth ≈øuch as he be≈øt likes to make u≈øe of, what he ≈øhall think to be mo≈øt fit and pertinent to his intended purpo≈øe, be it either for delight or ≈øervice; briefly therefore thus. Firings really con≈øidered, can be performed but five ways, that is to ≈øay, to the Front, Reer, right or left Flank, Oblique or Angular; but there is ≈øo much variety to be expre≈ø≈øed in the performance of each of the≈øe, that it makes them ≈øeem ≈øo many ≈øeveral Firings, as by the following di≈øcour≈øe ≈øhall be fully demon≈øtrated.

div.head: CHAP. LIX. Several Firings to be performed with any number of men.
div.p: THe Front being the head of the Body, and therefore the more honourable part, challengeth the ≈øuperiority, or fir≈øt place; and therefore, without any further circum≈øtance, I come directly to the Firings as they lie in order, as followeth. Draw all the Muskettiers before the Pikes, before you begin your Firings.
Firings to the Front.1 Two Ranks advancing ten paces, falling in the Reer of them≈øelves.
2 By ≈øingle Ranks, advancing three paces, falling in the Reer of them≈øelves.
3 Fire and flank the Pikes.
4 Fire by Files, advancing 10 or 20 paces, fir≈øt ≈øingle, ≈øecondly ranking inward, 1, 2, 3, 4, or more, falling down into their places again.
5 Fire by Ranks filing, and advancing 10 or 20 paces, and moving down, and ranking in the Reer of their own Divi≈øions.
6 Fire by Divi≈øions drawn off 10, or 20, or 30 paces, and returning again.
7 Fire even with the Front, and falling in the Reer of their own Divi≈øions.
8 Fire even with the Half-files, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves.

9 Fire by way of Introduction, thus, the fir≈øt Rank fires and ≈øtands, the la≈øt Rank pa≈ø≈øeth up between the Files, and placing them≈øelves before the File-leaders or fir≈øt Rank, then ≈øtand and give fire, the re≈øt doing the like till the File-leaders come up again into their places, and fire the ≈øecond time.

10 Fire by Introduction after this manner: the fir≈øt Rank gives fire and ≈øtands, the re≈øt moving forward until the next Rank hath placed them≈øelves before the fir≈øt; then ≈øtands and gives fire, the re≈øt moving up and doing the like, until they have all fired twice.
11 Fire even with the Front, falling into the Reer of Pikes.

12 Fire by Extraduction, the fir≈øt Rank pa≈ø≈øing from the Reer upon the out≈øide of the Pikes upon the right, until they have placed them≈øelves in a Rank before the Pikes, the re≈øt ≈øucce≈ø≈øively doing the like, until they have fired all over, and brought them≈øelves as at fir≈øt.

Here the Muskettiers are upon the Flanks again.13 Fire by the outmo≈øt Files, wheeling or ranking outward into the Front, falling off likewi≈øe, being led off by Bringers-up, leading up next the Pikes: this done twice, reduceth.
14 Fire two Ranks together, falling off, or falling down.
15 Fire four Ranks together; two kneeling, and two ≈øtanding upright falling off, or falling down.
16 Fire ≈øix Ranks together, two kneeling, two ≈øtooping, and two ≈øtanding upright.

17 Fire ≈øome Ranks drawn forth to the
right
left
or by Divi≈øion, and in again.

p.hi: Note al≈øo, if you plea≈øe, you may draw forth one Rank to the right, and another to the left, at one and the ≈øame time together.

div.p: 18 Fire by Files drawn forth oblique; then face about, & move into their places. Note al≈øo that ≈øeveral Figures may be made by the≈øe kinds of Firings; as the V, the W, or the Fort-battail, and the like.
19 Fire by Ranks, ranking into the Front, or Files ranking into the Front, and ranking or filing as they were.
20 Fire by Files wheeling outward or inward into the Front, and filing again as they were.
Thus much briefly of Firings to the Front: the Reer challengeth the next place, where ≈øuppo≈øe all the Muskettiers to be in the Reer of the Pikes, the Body marching.

1 Fire to the
right
left
about, falling in the Front of their own Divi≈øions.Firings to the Reer.
2 Fire, and fall off to the right and left, and rank with the fir≈øt Rank of Pikes into the Front.
3 Fire even with the Reer, and fall off before the Front of your own Divi≈øions of Muskettiers.

4 Fire even in the Reer or la≈øt Rank, and fall off to the right and left with a ≈øwift motion, placing your ≈øelves 10, 20, or 30 paces before the Front of Pikes, ≈øtill facing to the Body, and making ready again, and opening to the right and left until they be clear of the Pikes.
5 Fire by Introduction to the Reer twice over until they come down even with the Reer, and flank the Pikes.
6 Fire to the right and left, about to the Reer, Ranks drawn forth, and in again.
7 Fire to the Reer, every Rank drawn forth clear each from other, and falling in again, and flanking the Pikes.
8 Fire to the right and left about, Files ranking downward to the Reer, and filing as they were.
9 Fire to the right and left about, Ranks ranking downward to the Reer, and ranking as they were.
10 Fire lo≈øing ground, falling off to the right and left about, ju≈øt before the Front of Pikes.

11 Now if the Enemy pur≈øue eagerly, and that you cannot make a ≈øafe retreat marching, face all about, and fire upon them by way of Extraduction, or by half-ranks divided, as formerly hath been ≈øhewen.

And thus much likewi≈øe briefly concerning Firings to the Reer; Firings to the Flanks marching. in the next place I ≈øhall ≈øhew ≈øome Firings to the Flanks: for performance whereof, it will be expedient to bring all the Muskettiers upon one of the Flanks; but for order ≈øake, I will begin with the Firings from the right Flank.

1 Fire to the right, and gather up your Files; it is to be performed after this manner, The outmo≈øt File upon the right is to face to the right, and to give fire; and after to face to the Front and ≈øtand, until the next File have fired in like manner; and then the fir≈øt File gathers up unto him upon the right even abre≈øt, and ≈øtanding until the third File have faced to the right, and fired in like manner; and after facing to the Front, the other Files moving up in the like way as before; and following ≈øucce≈ø≈øively this rule until all have given fire, and then to march up and even the Front of Pikes, the Muskettiers will ≈øtand as at fir≈øt, when they were brought upon the right Flank.
2 Fire to the right, File-leaders leading up their Files next to the Pikes.
3 Fire to the right, Bringers-up leading away next the Pikes; which being twice done, reduceth them.
4 Fire to the right, leading up on the contrary Flank, either by the File-leaders or Bringers-up.
5 Fire to the right, and leading up by Bringers-up between the Pikes, and pa≈ø≈øing through to their places again, doing the ≈øame, reduceth them.

6 Fire to the right, and leading up between the Pikes by the Leaders; and pa≈ø≈øing through the Pikes again to the right, they will be as at fir≈øt: the like may be done to the left, or in ≈øome kind to both Flanks, at one and the ≈øame time.
7 Fire to the right by Ranks wheeling; and Ranks to rank as they were to the right, upon their marching, reduceth them.
8. Fire to the right by Ranks inverting or filing, and upon the March the Souldiers ranking reduceth them.
9. Fire to the right Files, filing and gathering up their Files to the left reduceth them.

The≈øe Firings being performed marching, the next ≈øhall be upon a Stand; where note, you mu≈øt ca≈øt all your Muskettiers upon that Flank where you conceive the Enemy will fall on, whether right, left, or both; but for order ≈øake we u≈øually begin with the right; wherefore face to the right, and proceed as followeth.
Firings to the right Flank upon a Stand.1. Fire and fall in the Reer of your ≈øelves.
2. Fire and flank the Pikes.
3. Fire even with the Pikes, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves.
4. Fire even with the Reer, moving forth to the right and left, by Ranks falling in the Reer of them≈øelves.
5. Fire by extraduction by half-ranks drawn forth, and falling Rank after Rank in the Reer of the Pikes; after to reduce them as at fir≈øt, cau≈øe them to double their Front by Divi≈øion.

The≈øe Firings may as well be performed to both Flanks as to one, the Body being faced accordingly, which would make many Firings more; but the≈øe already ≈øet down may be ≈øufficient for any ingenious capacity to work upon for the pre≈øent; ob≈øerving this rule, that in every Firing he ≈øhall make u≈øe of in time of his Exerci≈øe, he may reduce them by another; which will be more plea≈øing to the Souldier, by rea≈øon of the great variety it affords unto them. Now now in the la≈øt place, I know it will be expected, that I ≈øhould ≈øpeak ≈øomething of the u≈øe of Firings: wherefore briefly thus:
Firings to the Front marching or moving, when we either pur≈øue after, or approach to an Enemy.
Firings to the Front, maintaining ground when two Bodies encounter one another.
Firings to the Front, lo≈øing ground, when either we are forced thereunto by nece≈ø≈øity, or that we do it out of policy, to draw the Enemy into a train or ≈ønare.
Firings to the Reer marching, when we are pur≈øued by an Enemy, yet would continue our March until we have gained ≈øome place of importance or advantage.

Firings to the Reer upon a Stand, when we are compelled thereunto by the violent pur≈øuit of an Enemy; or el≈øe when we have gained a place of advantage of ground, or have recovered the Wind or Sun, whereby we are the better able to encounter with them.

Firings to the Flank or Flanks marching, when we are a≈ø≈øaulted by ≈øome Ambu≈øcado ≈øecretly placed to hinder our pa≈ø≈øage; or ≈øuppo≈øing two Armies are marching to one and the ≈øame place, a River being betwixt them.
Firings to Flank or Flanks ≈øtanding, when the Enemy chargeth on with a re≈øolution to cut off or divide part of the Army from the other.

Having thus briefly ≈øet down ≈øeveral Firings to Front, Reer and both Flanks, with their u≈øes, either marching or ≈øtanding: I hold it convenient in the next place to give ≈øome ≈øhort directions in time Battail, both to the Officers and their Souldiers.

Fir≈øt, that the Drummers have a vigilant eye upon their Commanders, who≈øe voices are drown'd by the loud thundring of the Cannon or Muskettiers; as al≈øo by the neighing of Hor≈øes, or the lamentable cries of the maim'd and wounded Souldiers; at which time the Leaders Staff, Half-pike, or what el≈øe he carries in his hand, may be ≈øufficient for to in≈øtruct them to continue their charge, retreat, or el≈øe to charge home.

Secondly, that the Serjeants be careful in time of Battail, that their Souldiers be at their due di≈øtance of order both in Rank and File; and that upon their Firings, whether they be Forlorns either of Files or Ranks drawn forth, or otherwi≈øe by Divi≈øions, they ≈øee them neatly and hand≈øomely perform'd by cocking
their Matches, and pre≈øenting ≈øomething lower then bre≈øt-high, and after Uncocking and returning them, wheeling off either to the right, left, or both, falling in the Reer of them≈øelves, or el≈øewhere as ≈øhall be appointed, in an orderly manner, whereby they may decently come up again to Fire again≈øt the Enemy.

Thirdly, that the Souldiers pre≈øent and give fire upon their Re≈øts, not u≈øing that ≈ølovenly po≈øture of popping their Matches into the Pan, their Muskets being on their left ≈øides; which is not onely hurtful unto them≈øelves, but much endangers their Fellow-≈øouldiers; and by ≈øo doing, they ≈øcarce or ever do any execution again≈øt an Enemy. But here I meet with an objection framed by the Souldiers after this manner: Our Re≈øts are of little or no u≈øe unto us in time of skirmi≈øhing; fit they are, we confe≈øs, in the Military Gardens, but in time of Battail both trouble≈øome and cumber≈øome unto us. To whom I reply, what if they be a little cumber≈øome at fir≈øt, mu≈øt they therefore be rejected and carele≈øly thrown away? nay, rather they ought frequently to practice them≈øelves in the u≈øe thereof; which if they did, they would finde the ≈øame very ≈øerviceable unto them in the time of skirmi≈øhing; wherewith they Fire better, and in a more comely and graceful way, far more ≈øecuring both them≈øelves and Fellow-≈øouldiers from danger; and likewi≈øe upon their March it is both a help and ≈øupport unto them.

Fourthly, their eyes ought likewi≈øe in time of Battail to be fixed ≈øtedfa≈øtly upon their Captain, always conforming to him in Po≈øture when he ≈øhall prepare to charge or retreat; and likewi≈øe they ought to be knowing and well ver≈øt in the ≈øeveral Beats of the Drum; which if well ob≈øerved by all, there would not be ≈øo much confu≈øion in time of Battail among≈øt them, as many times by ≈øad experience hath been found, when di≈øregarding their Officers commands and the bearing of the Drum, they ignorantly and ra≈øhly run on in a di≈øorderly manner; by which means they have cut off their own Officers and Fellow-≈øouldiers, many times, more then they have dangered the Enemy.

Thus you ≈øee what great nece≈ø≈øity there is of in≈øtructing and training up the Souldiers in their Po≈øtures; and how requi≈øite it is to conform them≈øelves to their Officers in time of Battail, performing thereby better execution again≈øt their Enemies; and by their decent and comely array pre≈øerve them≈øelves from eminent dangers and perils.

The Souldiers having now all the ground-work of the exerci≈øing a Body of men laid down before them, in the next place he labours to make experiment thereof; but being no Officer, he cannot attain thereunto without ≈øpecial leave from his Superiours; and therefore (being a File-leader) he craves leave for to exerci≈øe his ≈øingle File both in their Po≈øtures and Motions, contenting him≈øelf for pre≈øent with that ≈ømall number, whereby he is able to run through many plain things of Di≈øtances, Facings, Doublings, Counter-marchings and Wheelings. But being not fully ≈øatisfied, he pre≈øumes upon the former favour had from his Superiours, to go on to make every man in his File a File-leader; fir≈øt by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and after (being not called away by the beat of the Drum, or by his Officers, to lead up his File and to joyn into a Body) according unto Dignity, and after endeavours to reduce them again by proper words of command.

This liberty being granted at convenient times unto a File-leader, much indeers the Souldiers good affections unto their Officers; and is a means whereby many others are brought in to be true lovers of Military Exerci≈øe, as being much taken and well plea≈øed with the ≈øight of the former things. And therefore, I could wi≈øh that they were not hereafter prevented, as formerly I have ob≈øerved by the malice of ≈øome, who have had places of command be≈øtowed upon them, more through favour, or by rea≈øon of their riches, then for any worth or de≈øert found in them: They perhaps hold it a great di≈øpargement unto them to be eclip≈øed; but a judicious and di≈øcreet Captain accounts it a great honour to lead ≈øuch gallant men that are as able and as well knowing as him≈øelf.

Although I have here ≈øet down words of Command to make every man a File-leader, both by Succe≈ø≈øion and Dignity, a Commander is not thereby tyed up, but may, if he plea≈øe, practi≈øe the ≈øame upon a whole Company, altering but a little ≈øome words of Command. As for Example, we cannot ≈øay in a File, Double your Ranks, there being none, until there be ≈øome other Files joyned thereunto: and therefore if we intend a doubling by a ≈øingle File, we command it to rank two to the right or left, which in a Company mu≈øt be expre≈øt, Ranks to the right or left double. Thus you ≈øee with a little alteration every man is brought up into the Front, either by Succe≈ø≈øion or Dignity; whether the Files be even numbers or odd, great bodies or ≈ømall. But here by the way, I mu≈øt crave pardon to ≈øpeak ≈øomething in commendation of the≈øe Doublings, in an≈øwer to them that account them but Toys: to whom I will be ≈øo bold as to tell them, that it is not for want of ignorance they ≈øo ≈ølightly e≈øteem of them; for were they truly knowing in the Art of Drilling, they mu≈øt of force confe≈øs abundance of variety in them, affording much delight to him that ≈øhall command, and great content unto them that are commanded, perceiving them≈øelves to be made File-leaders by the skill and worth of their Leaders. And be≈øides, there may be ju≈øt cau≈øe (at one time or other) many times to alter the Ranks, exchanging the one for the other, bringing thereby their be≈øt de≈øerving Souldiers into the chiefe≈øt places of honour; and ca≈øting others into their rooms at the di≈øcretion of the Commander. Therefore, I could wi≈øh all Leaders what≈øoever to be well skill'd and ver≈øt in the≈øe Doublings; the frequent practice whereof will make them more apt in the Exerci≈øe of more difficult things in the Art Military. To which ingenious ≈øtudy, I leave them; and in the next place proceed to ≈øhew them ≈øeveral Figures of Battail to be performed by ≈øingle Files, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeveral Depths of men.

div.head: CHAP. LXIV. Concerning Figures of Battail to be performed by ≈øingles Files, with ≈øome admonitions to tho≈øe that ≈øhall practice them≈øelves therein.
div.p:
THe great plenty and variety of matter that may be performed in the exerci≈øing of a ≈øingle File, makes me wonder at the ignorance of tho≈øe who are
famed abroad for able knowing Souldiers; who after they have pa≈ø≈øed over the Po≈øtures are at a ≈øtand, as if there were nothing el≈øe to be done with the ≈øame. But did they truely under≈øtand what di≈øhonour and di≈øparagement it is unto them, they would not be ≈øo idle and backward, but ≈øet times a part, often inuring them≈øelves to the practice thereof, going through all the Motions, Di≈øtances, Facings, Doublings, Counter-marches and Wheelings; and may farther, if he plea≈øe, with his ≈øingle File draw forth divers Figures of Battail, declaring unto his Souldiers their ≈øeveral rea≈øons and u≈øes. The exerci≈øing his Company after this manner, affords unto them both content and delight; and it is likewi≈øe very u≈øeful in greater Bodies, when time of need ≈øhall require, as ≈øhall appear in the ≈øequel of this Book.

But here, me thinks, I hear ≈øome ≈øay, Of what u≈øe are your Figures? ≈øeeing for the mo≈øt part in pitcht Battails, or skirmi≈øhes in the field, they commonly fire one again≈øt another in Square, or by Forlorns drawn forth from the Body, and being relieved, return into their places again. To whom, I an≈øwer, that in one re≈øpect it is true, there being ≈øcarce any pitcht Battail in the field fought in the≈øe latter times, but it hath been with even Fronts, who are fir≈øt engaged; whether it be by Divi≈øions drawn off by way of Forlorns, Wings or Battail, they fight with even Fronts or Squadrons, as having every five or ≈øix Files divided a part from each other, having ≈øix foot ground interval betwixt the above≈øaid number of Files for the conveniency of the Ranks, wheeling off after they have fired. As concerning ≈øuch Figures as are framed like the Wedge, Saw, Sheers, or Diamond; I mu≈øt confe≈øs there is little or no u≈øe at all, except it be for delight, or for the practice and experience of ≈øome young Souldier, whereby he may plainly ≈øee the cu≈øtom of the Ancients in ≈øetting forth ≈øuch ancient Figures. But to let this pa≈øs, and to come to the place where we left; I ≈øhall ≈øhew unto the Souldier how needful it is for him to be well skilled in the framing of Figures of Battail, and likewi≈øe to be throughly acquainted with their ≈øeveral u≈øes. Wherefore take this for a general rule, that there was never any pitcht Battail, but there were Re≈øerves appointed out unto all the parts thereof, whereby they might bring off, and at time of need relieve each other; and if ≈øo, certainly they mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity carry along with them ≈øeveral forms and Figures of Battail, according to the di≈øcretion of the Major-general, or the Commanders in chief whom it ≈øhall concern. It will therefore be expedient (≈øince there is a nece≈ø≈øity of Figures of Battail, and for the ≈øetting apart of Divi≈øions for the relieving of each other) for every Commander that will be truely knowing, to have always ≈øome imprinted in his memory; that in time of need, he may not be to ≈øeek, or wanting in them. To which purpo≈øe I have collected ≈øome few, putting them to their view, being formerly practi≈øed by me, for the ≈øatisfaction of tho≈øe loving Gentlemen which have private Meetings in London; but more e≈øpecially for tho≈øe of the Town-ditch, unto whom I am e≈øpecially bound. And therefore without more delay, I ≈øhall lay before them certain Figures of Battail upon all the Depths of Files ≈øet forth in the former Table, leaving them to their own di≈øcretion, to make u≈øe of what ≈øhall be≈øt comply, and ≈øuit to their intended purpo≈øe.

div.head: THE COMPLEAT BODY OF The Art Military. The Second BOOK.
CHAP. I. Concerning the Artillery and the Military Gardens, together with the Private Meetings, in and about the City of LONDON.
div.p: THe great delight in handling of Arms in Military Exerci≈øes, makes the City of London and the Suburbs thereof famous through the whole World, by rea≈øon, as I conceive, of tho≈øe two great Nur≈øeries or Academies of Military Di≈øcipline, the Artillery and Military Garden, from whom, as out of pure Fountains, all other our Private Meetings (as of Townditch, and Cripplegate, &c.) are derived.

The Artillery Gardens de≈øerves the fir≈øt place, in re≈øpect it is the greate≈øt Meeting, from whence, as it were out of a Nur≈øery, have been tran≈øplanted many able knowing Souldiers both at home and in foraign Countries, to the great honour of our Nation.

The Military Garden is famous likewi≈øe for the great improvement of divers worthy per≈øons of quality daily thither re≈øorting, who≈øe excellent skill in Military Exerci≈øes hath rai≈øed many of them to high preferment here at home, and to places of honourable command abroad. The Captains in chief of the≈øe Academies are Major General Skippon, and Major Henry Tyllier, which later was the fir≈øt that ever ≈øhewed in the Military Garden (of which I am a member) the marching of the Souldiers in a Regimental way; who≈øe great pains among≈øt us de≈øerves much honour and high commendation; ≈øhewing unto us ≈øuch variety of matter in a Souldier-like way, as was never before ≈øeen by any member thereof.

Not to eclip≈øe the fore-mentioned Private Meetings in London, but to give them that due which belongs unto them, they likewi≈øe are of great honour and fame for their frequent exerci≈øing of their Souldiers in the handling of their Arms, whether it be of the Pike or Musket, and in≈øtructing them in the knowledge of Drilling, and drawing up of Companies, and Bodies of men, furni≈øhing both Kingdoms with able knowing Souldiers. My hearty wi≈øhes therefore are, that all and every one of them may be propt up, and ≈øupported to all ages, that when need ≈øhall require, we may draw from the≈øe Fountains ≈øuch skilful and experienced Commanders and Officers as may be, as it were, a Bulwark to this our Nation.

Not to dwell any longer upon this di≈øcour≈øe, I come therefore briefly to ≈øet forth ≈øeveral Exerci≈øes (formerly practi≈øed by me among≈øt tho≈øe loving Gentlemen of Town-ditch) according to the u≈øual numbers there appearing, whether they be great or ≈ømall, practi≈øed for the mo≈øt part with 24 or 32 men, and ≈øometimes (although ≈øeldom) with 64 men, unle≈øs it were upon general days, when they were drawn forth into the field; at ≈øuch times, perhaps, there might be an appearance of greater numbers, as 120 and upwards.

My purpo≈øe therefore is to pitch upon, and to make u≈øe of all and every one
of the≈øe numbers, making 12 Exerci≈øes, dividing them by threes, until I have run over them all, conceiving them ≈øufficient for the indu≈øtrious to gather from thence matter enough for his intended Exerci≈øe. And for the more enabling of them, I ≈øhall endeavour (in the≈øe curious times) to walk along in as plain a way as po≈ø≈øibly may be, giving directions unto all Words of Command, for the better performance of the ≈øame; wi≈øhing all my loving fellow-Souldiers to conceive well of my good meaning intended to them: de≈øiring withall to be rightly informed of what part ≈øoever they fall upon, that they proceed lea≈øurely and orderly in the ≈øame; which will not only be an encouragement unto the Author from whom they gather their Exerci≈øes, but will bring much prai≈øes and commendation to them≈øelves. But to leave every one to their own be≈øt thoughts, while≈øt I proceed to practi≈øe what before promi≈øed concerning the ≈øeveral Exerci≈øes following.

div.head: CHAP. II. The fir≈øt Exerci≈øe of four Files ≈øix deep.
div.p: EAch File-leader (as being his duty) having gone over the Po≈øtures, ≈øhewing and in≈øtructing his File with their u≈øes, and neat handling of their Arms, hearing the Drums beat a Call for all to repair and ≈øtand to their Arms, begin to lead up their Files according to Order; the Leader then clo≈øing their Ranks and Files to clo≈øe Order, craving their ≈øilence, may proceed to ≈øhew unto them all their ≈øeveral Di≈øtances and Facings, according unto the former rule ≈øet down, and after he may proceed to Doublings (if he plea≈øeth) as followeth.

div.head: CHAP. III. A Doubling con≈øi≈øting of ≈øixteen in number, every one differing from the other, and not reduced until the la≈øt Word of Command.
div.p: Command. FIles, file to the right intire advancing.
Command. Bringers-up, double your Front to the left.
Command. Half-files, double your Front to the left.
Command. Front-half-files, double your Reer to the right intire.
Command. Right-half-ranks, double your left Flank intire advancing.
Command. Half-files, double your Front to the right intire.
Command. Left-half-ranks, double intire the Depth of your right Flank.
Command. Files, file to the left intire advancing.
Command. Bringers-up, double your Front to the right.
Command. Front-half-files, double your Reer to the right and left outward, following your Leaders.

Direction. Reer-half-files, face about; the File-leaders are to turn off to the right and left, the re≈øt are to follow them until they are marched down into the Reer, and have doubled it to the right and left outward.
Command. Half-files, double your Front inward intire.
Command. The two outmo≈øt Files upon each Flank, double intire the Depth of the inmo≈øt Files.
Direction. The two outmo≈øt Files face about inward, and move ≈øtreight down cleer of the ≈øtanding part; afterwards face inward, march, and clo≈øe your Divi≈øions; to your Leader.
Command. Front-half-files, double your Reer inward intire.
Direction. Reer-half-files, face about, and move outward cleer of the ≈øtanding part; Front-half-files, face about, march down and even the Reer to your Leader.
Command. The two outmo≈øt Files upon each Flank double intire, advancing the four inmo≈øt Files.
Direction. The two outmo≈øt Files move forward cleer of the ≈øtanding part; face inward, march and clo≈øe your Divi≈øions; face to your Leader.
Command. Double your Files inward intire, advancing, every man placing him≈øelf before his Leader.

Direction. The two inmo≈øt Files ≈øtand; the two outmo≈øt Files move forwards,
and double your inmo≈øt Files intire advancing, placing your ≈øelves before your Leaders.
Command. Half-files, double your Front to the right, they are reduced.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Eight ≈øeveral Counter-marches, with their Reducement.
div.p: Command. FIle-leaders, ≈øtand; the re≈øt pa≈øs through to the right, and place your ≈øelves before your Leaders.
Command. The Right-hand-file, ≈øtand; the re≈øt pa≈øs through to the right, and place your ≈øelves on the out≈øide of your right-hand-men.
Command. File-leaders and Bringers-up, ≈øtand; the re≈øt pa≈øs through to the right, and place your ≈øelves before your Leaders and your Bringers-up.
Command. The outmo≈øt File upon each Flank, ≈øtand; the re≈øt pa≈øs through to the right and left, placing your ≈øelves before your out≈øide-men.
Direction. Face outward, and pa≈øs through to the right and left, placing your ≈øelves before the outmo≈øt Files; to your Leader, and clo≈øe your Divi≈øions to open Order.
Command. Bringers-up, ≈øtand; the re≈øt pa≈øs through to the right, and place your ≈øelves behind your Bringers-up.
Direction. The five fir≈øt Ranks are to face about; the next Rank to the Reer is fir≈øt to begin the Motion; the re≈øt are ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to follow, until the Leaders are become the Bringers-up.
Command. The Left-hand-file, ≈øtand; the re≈øt pa≈øs through to the left, and place your ≈øelves on the out ≈øide of your left-hand-men.
Command. File-leaders and Bringers-up, ≈øtand; the re≈øt pa≈øs through to the right, and place your ≈øelves behind your Leaders and Bringers-up.

Direction. The fir≈øt and the two next Ranks from the Reer, face about; the two fir≈øt Ranks from the Front, and the two la≈øt Ranks from the Reer move forwards, placing your ≈øelves behind your Leaders and your Bringers-up; face to to your Leader, and clo≈øe your Divi≈øions.
Command. The outmo≈øt File upon each File face inward; the re≈øt pa≈øs through to the right and left, placing your ≈øelves behind your right and left-hand-men.

div.head: CHAP. V. Ten ≈øeveral Wheelings, with their Reducement.
div.p: Command. WHeel the Front-half-files inward into the mid≈øt, and double your Reer inward intire.

Direction. Half-files, face outward, and march cleer of the ≈øtanding part; after face to the Reer: Front-half-files, open from the mid≈øt to open Order, after Wheeling to the right and left inward into the Reer; to your Leader.
Command. Right and Left-half-ranks, double the depth of the Battail by Wheeling into the Front.
Direction. Right-half-ranks, wheel to the left; and Left-half-ranks, wheel to the right; to your Leader.
Command. Wheel off the Front-half-files, and double the Reer by divi≈øion.
Direction. Half-files, face about; and Front-half-files, wheel off by Divi≈øion, moving down even with the Reer; to your Leader.
Command. Wheel off your right Half-ranks, and double your left Flank to the right intire.
Direction. Face outward, and Right-half-ranks wheel about to the left and move away, and double the left Flank to the right; to your Leader.
Command. Front and Reer-half-files, double the Depth of the Battail by wheeling into the Front and Reer.
Direction. Half-files, face to the Reer; and Front and Reer-half-files wheel to the right and left inward; face to your Leader, and clo≈øe your Divi≈øions.
Command. Wheel off your Left-half-ranks, and double your right Flank by Divi≈øion.
Direction. Face outward, and Left-half-ranks wheel off by Divi≈øion, and move even with the right Flank; to your Leader.
Command. Wheel off your Reer-half-files, and double the Front to the right intire.
Direction. Half-files, face about, and wheel to the left, until you have ranged even with the Front.
Command. Wheel your Battail off by Divi≈øion from the Front.
Direction. Right-half-ranks, wheel about to the right and left; Half-ranks, wheel about to the left, and move down to the Reer; face to your Leader, and clo≈øe into the mid≈øt to order.
Command. Wheel off your Left-half-ranks, and double your right Flank to the left intire.
Direction. Face outward, Left-half-ranks wheel about to the right, and move forward, and double the right Flank to the left intire; to your Leader.
Command. Wheel off your Front-Half-files, and double the Reer to the left intire.
Direction. Half-files, face about; and Front-half-files, wheel about to the right, move down and range even with the Reer; face to your Leader, reduceth them.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Six Figures of Battail, with ≈øeveral Firings thereunto belonging.
div.p: Command. RAnks and Files clo≈øe to order, they will ≈øtand us underneath is ≈øet forth, from which we will draw our Figures after we have fired upon this Platform three or four times.
Command. Double your Files inward intire advancing.

The fir≈øt firing. Let the fir≈øt two Ranks advance forward ten paces, give Fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; after wheeling off to the right and left, placing them≈øelves before the Front of Pikes: the next two Ranks, and ≈øo the re≈øt ≈øucce≈ø≈øively doing the like until they have Fired once over, which reduceth them.
The ≈øecond firing. Let the fir≈øt Rank advance three paces, give Fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; the re≈øt doing the like until all have Fired once over, as before.
The third firing. Let them give Fire on the ground they ≈øtand, and fall off to the right and left, and Flank the Pikes.
The fourth firing. Let them Fire even with the Front, and fall in with the Reer of the Pikes; which being ended, let the Pikes charge on.
Reducement. Muskettiers, double your Front by Divi≈øion.
Command. The fir≈øt two Ranks, ≈øtand; the re≈øt face outward and move cleer of the ≈øtanding part; to your Leader: the two la≈øt Ranks move outward ≈øide-ways two paces.
The fir≈øt firing. Let every Divi≈øion give Fire on the ≈øame ground they ≈øtand, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves.
The ≈øecond firing. Let them advance forwards until they be cleer of the Pikes; give Fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves, after moving down into their places.

Command. Front-divi≈øion, advance forward three paces; the two next Divi≈øions move outward one pace: Pikes in each Divi≈øion face about, and move two paces; to your Leader: Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Reer advance forwards, and range even in Front and Reer with the Middle-divi≈øions of Pikes; the fir≈øt Rank of Pikes in the Front-divi≈øion move three foot cleer of the ≈øtanding part.
The fir≈øt firing. Let them give Fire to the Front, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves.
The ≈øecond firing. Let them give Fire to Front, Reer, and both Flanks altogether.

Direction. Reer-divi≈øions, face outward; the la≈øt Rank of Pikes and Muskettiers of the Front-divi≈øion, face to the Reer; the la≈øt Rank of Muskettiers move down cleer of the Reer, and clo≈øe inward to order; then la≈øt the Pikes port, and after the Muskettiers have Fired, charge on, then retreating into their places again.

Command. The fir≈øt and the la≈øt Rank of Pikes, face about, and move down cleer of the Reer, and clo≈øe Ranks forwards to order; outmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers face about, move down and flank your own divi≈øions of Pikes: The fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes move forward, and range even abre≈øt with your own Divi≈øion of Muskettiers; the Front-divi≈øion of Muskettiers clo≈øing into the mid≈øt to order.
The fir≈øt firing. Let the Front-divi≈øion give Fire and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; after wheeling off to the right and left, move down and Flank the Reer-divi≈øion of Pikes.

The ≈øecond firing. Let the Front-divi≈øion of Muskettiers Fire and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; then face about, and move down upon the in≈øide of the next divi≈øion of Pikes; and after face to their Leader.

The third firing. Let the Muskettiers upon the Flanks move up into the room of the former, and Fire, falling in the Reer of them≈øelves; and after face about, and move down into their places again; the Muskettiers on the in≈øide moving up into their places again.

The fourth firing. Let the Reer-divi≈øion face about; then let them Fire to Front
and Reer, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; let the Pikes charge, and after ordering their Arms, their Reer-divi≈øion facing to their Leader, the Muskettiers thereof may move up into their places again.

Command. The outmo≈øt divi≈øions face outward, and move two paces; face to your Leader, move up until you range even abre≈øt with the ≈øecond divi≈øions next the Front; Reer-divi≈øion move ≈øtreight forward two paces.
The fir≈øt firing. Let them all give Fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves.

The ≈øecond firing. Let the Muskettiers advance forwards until they be cleer of the Front-divi≈øion, and then rank outward and Fire altogether; after filing inward as they were, move down again into their places: the Pikes at the ≈øame time charging, and after order their Arms.
Command. Front-divi≈øion advance forward three paces; the outmo≈øt divi≈øion upon the Flanks move up, and range even with the Front.

The fir≈øt firing.
