Then let the three la≈øt divi≈øions of Muskettiers, and the Reer-divi≈øions of Pikes, face about; and let the two middle-divi≈øions of Muskettiers face outward, and move cleer of the ≈øtanding part; then let the Muskettiers in Front and Reer move forward cleer of the Pikes, and let them fire to Front, Reer, and both Flanks, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; then the Pikes may charge on to Front and Reer, and being retreated back into their places, the Muskettiers in Front and Reer may face about, and move down again into their fir≈øt ground; and the Muskettiers upon the Flanks are to face inward, and to move into their places where formerly they ≈øtood; then face them all to their Leader, and proceed.

Command. Reer-divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the mid≈øt, face about; middle-divi≈øions of Muskettiers move forward three foot before the Front and Reer; Divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the mid≈øt upon the right, face to the left Angles, and move until you ≈øtand even and ≈øtraight in the next range of Muskettiers; the next divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the mid≈øt upon the left, face about; and then likwi≈øe face to the left Angle, and move down into the next range of Muskettiers to them, and to ≈øtand ≈øtreight in the Reer of the Reer-divi≈øion; face all to your Leader, produceth the next.

Upon the former Figure, let the ≈øix la≈øt divi≈øions face about, and let the fir≈øt divi≈øions give fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; then wheel them about to the right, and interchange ground with them that ≈øtand in the Reer, who ju≈øt upon their wheeling about, are to move up cleer of the Pikes, to make them room to fall down through the middle interval into their places, who al≈øo are immediately to give fire, and fall off accordingly. Then let the outmo≈øt divi≈øions give fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; then let the Pikes charge on to Front and Reer; face them after to the Front at ≈øuch time when the Pikes have retreated back into their places again. Now if you will fire them to the Front, the Muskettiers
≈øtand in ≈øuch good order, that you may fire them by divi≈øions, by their ≈øeveral turns as long as you plea≈øe, they relieving each other. After you may fire them to Front, Reer, and both Flanks, the Muskettiers ≈øtanding in fit condition for the ≈øame. But fearing to keep the Souldiers too long in Exerci≈øe, debarring them thereby of their wonted refre≈øhment, I will ha≈øten to the Reducement, and for pre≈øent lodge the Colours, and conclude the eleventh Exerci≈øe.

Reducement. Outmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers face outward and move ≈øix paces; to your Leader. The two fir≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the mid≈øt face to the right, and move clear of the Pikes; then face to the right and left inward, and move, and interchange ground, then ≈øtand, and face to your Leader. The two la≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the mid≈øt, face to the left, and move clear of the Pikes; face all to your Leader. Then let every Divi≈øion clo≈øe forward to Order, and move up even abre≈øt with the Pikes, they are reduced.

div.head: CHAP. XL. The twelfth Exerci≈øe, con≈øi≈øting of 24 Files, ≈øix deep.
div.p: THe place of Exerci≈øe appointed for the Souldiers to meet, they upon a ju≈øt ≈øummons make full appearance, being indeed the very life of any Exerci≈øe, affording much comfort to him that ≈øhall lead them. And therefore ≈øeeing their readine≈øs and forwardne≈øs (as in duty they are concerned) the Leader cannot chu≈øe but forthwith to give order unto his Officers for the compleating up of the Body; who knowing his commands, go nimbly and chearfully to work in drawing forth the Files, and joyning them together, after fetching the Colours, and bringing them to the head of the Company. So that nothing being wanting, the Leader craves their ≈øilence and attention, commanding them to their di≈øtance of Order, both of Rank and File, and after ≈øome few di≈øtances ≈øhewen unto them, he may proceed in the next place to ≈øuch Facings as followeth.

Command.
Face to the right and left outward, and move four paces.
Face to Front and Reer, and move three paces.
Face to the outward Angles in the Front.
Face to the inward Angles in the Front.
Face to the inward Angles of the right Flank.
Face to the inward Angles in the left Flank.
Face to the outward Angles in the Reer.
Face to the inward Angles in the Reer.
Face to the outward Angles both of Front and Reer.
Face to the inward Angles both of Front and Reer.
Face to the mid≈øt of Files.
Face to the mid≈øt of Ranks.
Face to the Centre.
Face to the outward Angles of Front and Reer from the Centre.
Face all about to the right.
Face to Front, Reer, and both Flanks from the Centre.
As you were; To your Leader.

div.head: CHAP. XLI. A Doubling to make every man a File-Leader by dignity.
div.p: Command. HAlf-files double your Front to the left.
Command. Double your Files to the right entire, advancing, every man placing him≈øelf before his Leader.
Command. Front-half-files double your Reer to the left.
Command. Double your Files to the left entire, advancing, every man placing him≈øelf before his Leader.
Command. Bringers-up double your Front to the right.
Command. Files double your depth to the right, every man falling behind his Bringer-up.
Command. Half-files, double your Front to the right.
Command. Double your Files to the left entire, advancing.
Command. Ranks to the right double.
Command. Files to the right double.
Command. Bringers-up double your Front to the left.
Command. Files double your depth to the left, every man falling behind his Bringer-up.
Reducement. Ranks to the left double. Files to the left double.

div.head: CHAP. XLII. Several Wheelings, with their Reducements.
div.p: Command. WHeel off your Reer-half-files, and double your Front by Divi≈øion
Command. Right and left half-ranks double the depth of your Battail by wheeling inward to the Reer. Face to the Reer.
Command. Double the length of your Battail by wheeling inward to Front and Reer. Half-files face about.
Command. Front and Reer half-files double the depth of your Battail by wheeling outward to the right Flank. Half-files face about, and wheel to the left; Front half-files wheel to the right.
Command. Front and Reer half-files double the length of your Battail by wheeling inward to the left Flank; face all to the left.
Command. Front and Reer half-files double the depth of both Flanks by wheeling to the right and left outward. Half-files face about.
Command. Front and Reer half-files double the length of the Battail by wheeling inward to the mid≈øt of Ranks. Face inward.
Command. Front and Reer half-files double the depth of your left Flank by wheeling to the right and left outward. Half-files face about.

Command. Front and Reer half-files double the length of your Battail by wheeling inward to the right flank. Face to the right; and as they then ≈øtand, right half-ranks wheel to the left, and left half-ranks wheel to the right until the right Flank meet together, they are reduced.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII. Plain Figures, and figures of Battail.
div.p: The fir≈øt firing. LEt two Ranks advance forward ten paces and give fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves, and after wheel off to the right and left outward, and move down in the Reer of their own Divi≈øions of Muskettiers; and then the next two Ranks are to move forward, and to give fire, as the former did, and ≈øo con≈øequently all the re≈øt, until all have fired, and reduced back again into their places.
The ≈øecond firing. Let them fire even with the Front, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves, and let the Pikes charge on whil≈øt the Muskettiers make ready again.

The third firing. Let ≈øingle Files be drawn off, and Ranks inward into the Front, and fire, and File again, face about, and move down into their places; then let two Files be drawn off clear, and let the inmo≈øt Files rank inward, the outmo≈øt Files rank outward, and give fire, and File again as they were, and fall into their places.

The fourth firing. Let the four outmo≈øt Files upon each Flank be drawn off until they be clear of the Front; then let them clo≈øe before the Front of Pikes; face then the inmo≈øt Files of Muskettiers to both the Flanks, and let them give fire to the Front and both Flanks on the ground they ≈øtand, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves.

The fifth firing. Let them give fire all together, ≈øix Ranks at once in the Front, and four in the Flanks, ob≈øerving the former Rules in firing ≈øo many Ranks together, as you may find in the place of de≈øcription of firings.

The ≈øixth firing. Let tho≈øe Muskettiers upon the Flanks face to the Reer, and move clear of the Pikes; then clo≈øe to the right and left inward to Order; then let the half-files of Pikes face about, and let the Muskettiers give fire to Front and Reer, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves.

The ≈øeventh firing. Let the Pikes move forth to the right and left outward, until they be clear of the Muskettiers; then let the Muskettiers give fire in an oblique manner, thus; let every two Files open to the right and left outward to ≈øomething more then open Order; then clo≈øe the two fir≈øt Ranks of the four inmo≈øt Files to the Front to Order, and let the other two Ranks clo≈øe likewi≈øe almo≈øt to that di≈øtance; but the two la≈øt Ranks only are to face to their Front, and after in the ≈øame kind clo≈øe the four Ranks inward to the Reer of the four outmo≈øt, in manner and form there, as the other Files were to the Front, and ≈øo let them give fire in each Divi≈øion, an oblique way, two Ranks kneel down, two kneeling, and two ≈øtand upright.

The eighth firing. After the former firing, clo≈øe the four inmo≈øt Files to the right and left outward to Order, and to joyn with the outmo≈øt Files, when their a≈øpects being to the outward Angles of Front and Reer, let the Pikes port, and Muskettiers give fire to the four Angles, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; then let the Pikes charge on whil≈øt the Muskettiers make ready again, and after retreat back into their places again.

The ninth firing. Let them give fire again the fir≈øt rank in each Divi≈øion, and wheel about to the right, and move down into their fir≈øt places where before they were drawn forth, and every rank con≈øequently fall in the reer of them; then let the Pikes clo≈øe into the mid≈øt to Order, and face all to their Leader.

Command. Muskettiers face to the right and left outward, and move twelve paces; then face to the reer, and move likewi≈øe twelve paces; after face to their Leader. Front-half-files of each Divi≈øion move forward three paces; right and left half-ranks of each Divi≈øion move outward two paces; Front-Divi≈øions of Pikes and Muskettiers ≈øtand, reer-divi≈øions of both Arms move to the right and left outward, until you be clear of the Front-divi≈øions; then clo≈øe ranks and files in each Divi≈øion to Order, and face to their Leader, they will ≈øtand in the fir≈øt Figure.

The first firing. Let the Front-divi≈øions of Muskettiers move forward, and range even abre≈øt with the Front of Pikes, give fire, and fall in the reer of them≈øelves; then face about and move down into their own ground again, and face to their Leader; then let the outmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers move in like manner as the former did, and give fire, and fall off in like manner, and down again into their places. Let the Muskettiers in the next place face outward, and move three paces, and after face to the Front; then let the reer-divi≈øions of Muskettiers advance forward until they range even abre≈øt with the Front-divi≈øions; then let
them give fire all together in each Divi≈øion, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves, and after let the outmo≈øt divi≈øions that moved up, move down again into their places; then let the Pikes charge on, and after retreat into their places.

The ≈øecond firing. Let the outmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Front move forward before the Front of Pikes, and the inmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Front, let them likewi≈øe move at the ≈øame time before the Reer-divi≈øions of Pikes; then let the Pikes port, and Muskettiers in each Divi≈øion give fire on the ground they ≈øtand, and after fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; and tho≈øe Muskettiers that formerly moved forth from their places, let the Serjeants wheel them off to the right and left into their fir≈øt ground, and face to their Leader.

Command. Inmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Front, face to the Reer; Divi≈øions of Pikes upon the left in the Front face about to the right; Divi≈øions that are thus faced, move down three foot clear of the Reer of each Arms. Front-divi≈øions both of Pikes and Muskettiers, and tho≈øe that la≈øt moved, face to the left, and move two paces; face all to your Leader; and Muskettiers move forward until your middle Divi≈øions range even abre≈øt with the Reer-divi≈øions of Pikes, and they will ≈øtand as followeth.

Upon this Figure let the Front-divi≈øions give fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves, and then wheel off to the right and left, into the ground of the Reer-divi≈øions, and they at the ≈øame time are to move up into their places, and to give fire, and fall off accordingly into their fir≈øt places. Then let the middle Divi≈øions move forward until they range even with the Front of Pikes, and let them give fire, and fall fir≈øt in the Reer of them≈øelves, and after face about, and move down into their places again, and face to their Leader; then let the Pikes charge on, and after retreat back again into their places. They may fire to the Reer after the ≈øame manner as they did to the Front, they being thither faced; and after they have all fired, face again to their Leader.

Command. Let the four Divi≈øions of Muskettiers upon the right move away, and let the Divi≈øions of Pikes fall in the Reer of them, and the four Divi≈øions of Muskettiers on the left to fall in the Reer of the Pikes; then ≈øtanding ≈øtraight in their Divi≈øions both Rank-wi≈øe and File-wi≈øe, and they will ≈øtand as followeth.

Upon this Figure let the Reer Divi≈øions face about to the right, and let the fir≈øt Divi≈øions give fire to Front and Reer, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; then let them advance forward three paces, and after wheel about to the right, and interchange ground with the Reer-divi≈øions, and they at the ≈øame time are to move up and give fire, and fall off accordingly. Then let the other Divi≈øions move forward until they range even abre≈øt with Front and Reer, give fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves, after face about and move down into their places; then face all to their Leader.

Command. The four fir≈øt divi≈øions ≈øtand, the re≈øt face to the left, and march cleer of the ≈øtanding part; then let the Pikes face to the Front, and march up even abre≈øt with the Muskettiers; Reer-divi≈øions of Muskettiers face to the Front, and move up likewi≈øe; Muskettiers face inward, move all three or four paces until they ≈øtand in form of the ≈øecond Figure; face all to your Leader. Reer-divi≈øion of Pikes face about, and move down three foot clear of the Reer; to your Leader; which produceth the la≈øt Figure.

Upon this Figure let the Reer-divi≈øion of Pikes face about, and Muskettiers face outward; then let Pikes port, and let the fir≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers give fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; then face about, and interchange ground with the Reer-divi≈øions, and face again to Front and Reer, and let tho≈øe that came up into their room give fire in like manner, and fall off and down again into their places. Then let the next Divi≈øions give fire, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves, and let the Pikes charge on; and being retreated back again into their places, command the two middle Divi≈øions of Muskettiers to face to the Reer, and move down and range even with the Reer; then let every Divi≈øion of Muskettiers give fire on the ground they ≈øtand, to both flanks and Reer, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; the Pikes may charge on again, and tho≈øe Muskettiers that moved down into the Reer, may face about and move back again into their places, and face all to the Front.

Reducement. Reer-divi≈øion of Pikes advance forward to the left into the Front, the two inmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers face about, and march clear of the Reer; then face to the right and left outward, and place them≈øelves behind the Reer-divi≈øions of Muskettiers: outmo≈øt divi≈øions of Muskettiers face inward, and move ≈øtraight in the Reer of the Front-divi≈øions, and let the Pikes fall in the Reer of their Front-divi≈øions, and face all to their Leader. Half-files of Muskettiers double your front to the right and left inward, and after move forward, and even the Front, they are reduced.

div.head: THE COMPLEAT BODY OF The Art Military. The Third BOOK.
CHAP. I. Concerning the drawing up of Regiments, with their ≈øeveral Numbers, Fronts, Manner and Ways.
div.p: HE that ≈øhall be de≈øirous to be truly knowing in this point of Military Di≈øcipline, in the drawing up of Regiments, whether they be of le≈ø≈øer or greater Bodies, as in ≈øome 6, others 7, 8, 10, or 12 Companies, they mu≈øt be drawn up into Battalia, either in one, two, or three Squadrons (or grand Divi≈øions) of Pikes flanked with Muskettiers, having always in the Reer a ≈øufficient number of Muskettiers for the guard of the Bagage, Cannon, or to be Convoys for to convey Ammunition and Victual to the re≈øt of their fellows; who are to be drawn forth (by the di≈øcretion of the Major) from each particular Company, according to their ≈øeveral ≈øtrengths, as in greater Companies more Files then in tho≈øe which be le≈ø≈øer, ordering them timely relief, whereby the ≈øeveral duties among≈øt the Souldiers throughout the Regiment by an equal way may take their turns. Now for as much as the true ≈øtating of the Dignities of every particular Officer, in the opinions of many, differ very much, and our former Military Authors have been very ≈øparing in their pains in ≈øetting down their due places of honour; I ≈øhall, for ≈øatisfaction of tho≈øe which de≈øire to be rightly informed, collect out of the many forms practi≈øed abroad and at home, one good way to perfect it.

But here, by the way, I mu≈øt crave pardon from the courteous Reader, by rea≈øon I fore≈øee certain Objections like rubs or blocks lying in my way, to digre≈øs a little from my intended purpo≈øe, to give an≈øwers unto each of them: which are,
Fir≈øt, That I ≈øeem to ≈ølighten the pains of former Authors.
Secondly, That it will be a means to occa≈øion much idlene≈øs in the Souldiers.
Thirdly, That it is too great a knowledge to be laid open to their view.

To the fir≈øt I an≈øwer, That the rea≈øon, as I conceive, why they have been ≈øo ≈øparing of their pains in this kind, was not for want of Abilities or knowledge among≈øt any of them, who≈øe works for the mo≈øt part I highly honour and e≈øteem, but rather believe that they left it forth for the curious ≈øearch of ≈øuch who are called unto Field-Officers places, knowing well, that before they are capable of that preferment, they mu≈øt be good proficients in this part of Military Exerci≈øe.

2. Although many that know but a little, may be puft up with high conceits of them≈øelves, conceiving what the Author hath done, 'twere ea≈øie for any man to perform the ≈øame; yet to them of riper Judgements, the more variety in this kind is pre≈øented to their view, the more painful they are in the curious practi≈øe
thereof, thinking every moment lo≈øt which is not ≈øpent in the ≈øearching after, and informing of their Judgements in this point of Military Di≈øcipline.

3. If it had not been for the worthy pains and labours of our Ance≈øtors publi≈øhed to the view of the world, this our age might have been ignorant both in this, and all other Sciences; for from them we borrowed our fir≈øt light, God putting it in their hearts to publi≈øh their ≈øeveral gifts to after-Generations, which though at this day much refined, yet for our fir≈øt grounds and principles we are beholding unto them. Therefore, give me leave, according as God hath inabled me, not to conceal or keep back any thing which may concern the good and welfare of my Countrey; for, I conceive there is none worthy to receive benefit from tho≈øe that have gone before him, if he conceals that good to ≈øuch as ≈øhall come after him. And if I happen to lie under the hard cen≈øure of ≈øome for my pains, it makes no matter, ≈øo the major part receive benefit thereby; for as I gathered ≈øomewhat of others, ≈øo my de≈øire is, that others may do the like by me.

The opinions of Souldiers in the drawing up of Regiments are very various both in their Forms and Figures, according to the cu≈øtom of their Countreys, commands of their Generals, or Officers in chief, which neverthele≈øs may prove very good and ≈øerviceable when need ≈øhall require. I ≈øhall therefore for the ≈øati≈øfaction of the ingenious Souldier ≈øet before them the be≈øt Collections drawn from them all, ≈øuch as may be mo≈øt u≈øeful for to fight again≈øt the enemy, according to the ≈øituation of the place, the number of men, and aptne≈øs of ground to contain them, which in the next place comes to be handled.

div.head: CHAP. II. The manner of drawing up a Regiment con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix Companies, containing in it a Colonel, a Lieutenant-Colonel, a Major, and three Captains, every one having 108 men in a Company, and the three Field-Officers 144. which makes compleatly up 756 men, whereof two thirds are Muskettiers, and one third of Pikes, the Files being ≈øix deep.
div.p: THe general place of Rendezvous being appointed out unto the Major, it is his care to take a timely view thereof, that there be ground and room ≈øufficient enough for the drawing them up. And having received Orders from his Colonel, Major General, or other ≈øuperiour Officers for the Regiments marching thither, he may appoint the Companies to march either of the≈øe two ways, either by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion or dignity. If by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, fir≈øt the Colonels Company moves away; next the Lieutenant Colonels in the Reer of him; then the Majors, and ≈øo con≈øequently all the re≈øt from the elde≈øt to the younge≈øt, who brings up the Reer of all. If by Dignity, fir≈øt the Colonels Company; and in the Reer of him, the younge≈øt Captain; and after him the elde≈øt; then the Majors; then the ≈øecond Captain; the Lieutenant Colonel bringing up the Reer of all. But it concerns the Major before their marching to give notice to the Lieutenant Colonel and the elde≈øt Captain to countermarch their Ranks of their two particular Companies, as ≈øoon as they come into the place of the general Rendezvous before he ≈øhall draw them up, to pre≈øerve the honour of the right File-leaders, and Bringers up of both Arms. He is likewi≈øe to be there beforehand, attending their marching in, and after the Colonels Company have made Alt, to draw up each particular Company on the left of him, all in one even range, commanding them to clo≈øe Ranks forward to Order, and Files into the mid≈øt unto the ≈øame di≈øtance. He is likewi≈øe to inform him≈øelf of the Captains, Lieutenants, and Serjeants, how many Files of Pikes and Muskettiers they have in each particular Company, and accordingly he is to enter it down in his Paper-Book, and to make u≈øe thereof as followeth.

He is to require one ≈øingle File apiece of Muskettiers to be drawn off from the three ≈ømalle≈øt Companies, and two Files apiece from the greater, which makes nine Files, and contains 54 men, which are to be led away by an able Serjeant into the Reer, for to be a guard to the Bagage, or other occa≈øions. From thence he may proceed, commanding all the Muskettiers to ≈øtand, and the Pikes to advance their Arms, and move forward ten or twelve paces; and then to ≈øtand, and clo≈øe
their Files outward to Order; three of their Colours moving with their Pikes to the right hand; the other three moving away to the left. After he may command Muskettiers to clo≈øe their Files outward to Order, and they will ≈øtand in four Divi≈øions, two of Pikes, and in the Reer of them, two of Muskettiers, as underneath is ≈øet forth; the Captains being all upon the head of the Pikes, with their En≈øigns, and the Lieutenants in the Reer; the Serjeants attending upon the Flanks of each divi≈øion.

This being done, command each divi≈øion of Muskettiers and Pikes to face outward, and to move to ≈øuch convenient di≈øtance, that being faced to the Front, there may be room ≈øufficient upon the ≈øubdividing of each divi≈øion of Muskettiers for their moving up, and flanking each body of Pikes. After which the Major may a≈ø≈øign unto every Captain and Lieutenant his due place of honour, as they ≈øtand all abre≈øt; and that they may al≈øo naturally fall into their proper places upon the march, which ≈øhall be ≈øet forth in the next Figure ≈øtanding in two grand Divi≈øions, the one in the Reer of the other, which may happen ≈øometimes for want of ground; but provided they have ground enough, they ought to ≈øtand in one even range, as in folio 5. The Major, after they are thus drawn up in one even range, will finde three Files of Muskettiers more in the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, and two of the Pikes, then is in the fir≈øt; therefore he mu≈øt take from thence one File of each Company, and add them to nine Files in the Reer, which maketh them twelve, and then he will have ballanced the divi≈øions equal, taking off one File of Pikes, and placing it amon≈øt the elde≈øt Captains Pikes.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Rea≈øons follow for the placing of the Captains, their Colours, and their Lieutenants, after the manner before ≈øet down.
div.p: WHat hath formerly been declared concerning a Rank or File, ≈øix abre≈øt, or ≈øix deep, may be ≈øatisfactory in ≈øome kind unto this point, which takes his rule from hence. For all private Companies, ≈ømaller Bodies, or ≈øingle Files, mu≈øt, or ought to be as neer as they can conformable to greater Bodies, as to Regiments, and con≈øequently they to Brigades. Therefore take notice that this rule ought ever to be ob≈øerved in the drawing of Regiments, that the right Flank, as neer as may be, ought to be ≈øuitable with the left, both in ≈øtrength, number, and dignity; and likewi≈øe to be ≈øo when they are drawn forth upon a long march, the Front equal with the Reer. Now, ≈øuppo≈øe the≈øe two grand divi≈øions ≈øtood even abre≈øt; we will begin to examine the fir≈øt worth, which is the Colonels; and the fourth worth, which is the elde≈øt Captains, and placed upon the right and left of the fir≈øt grand divi≈øion, with the ≈øecond and third worth, who are the Lieutenant-Colonel and Major, drawn up upon the right and left of the ≈øecond grand divi≈øion; and you ≈øhall finde they are every way equivalent in number, worth and dignity, with that of the fir≈øt.

In the next place, there are no more to place, but the fifth and ≈øixth worth, who are the ≈øecond and third Captains: and therefore ≈øince it is the fir≈øt place of honour among the Captains in a Regiment, to lead the fir≈øt Body or Stand of Pikes; it mu≈øt then con≈øequently follow, that the ≈øecond place of honour mu≈øt be to lead the ≈øecond grand divi≈øion of Pikes; and therefore the fifth worth is brought into and placed between the ≈øecond and third, that he may ≈øtand there to lead the ≈øecond Body of Pikes; wherein the Lieutenant-Colonel, the Major, and his own Colours are placed: ≈øo that there remains no more but the ≈øixth worth, or younge≈øt Captain to place, who is to be drawn up between the Colonel and elde≈øt Captain. Now if we ≈øhall further proceed to ballance it more cleerly, con≈øider them by dividing them by two's in their places; as fir≈øt, we will begin with the Colonel, the fir≈øt worth, who hath joyned to him the younge≈øt Captain, which is the ≈øixth worth, and they two make the number (7); then compare the Lieutenant-Colonel, who is the ≈øecond worth, unto the ≈øecond Captain joyn'd with him, which is the fifth worth, and they make alike the ≈øame number; after that compare the Major and elder Captain, who are drawn up into the mid≈øt of the Regiment, who≈øe places carry the third and fourth worth, and their number is ≈øuitable with the re≈øt. And thus much may be ≈øpoken in general: now I ≈øhall come more particularly to give further ≈øatisfaction, both for them, and for all the re≈øt; and therefore I will give rea≈øons for the placing of the Officers of the fir≈øt grand divi≈øion; and cleering that, the ≈øecond will quickly be laid open to the view.

div.head: CHAP. IV. More particular Rea≈øons for the placing of the Captains and Lieutenants of the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion.
div.p:
IN this grand Divi≈øion, there is the Colonel, the elde≈øt Captain, and the younge≈øt drawn up into the mid≈øt, and they having each of them Lieutenants; take notice therefore of the≈øe rea≈øons for their placing thus; That always upon ≈øuch ≈ømall Bodies as the≈øe, the fir≈øt honour is ever placed upon the right, and the ≈øecond upon the left; and that which remains, mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity be drawn up into the mid≈øt; they ≈øtanding all abre≈øt. The≈øe three Companies being ordered into a right and left Flank, and one Stand of Pikes, or Van-guard, Reer-ward, or Main-battail, as they may be term'd, the rea≈øons follow for the thus ≈øtanding of the Officers, whether marching all even abre≈øt, or upon a ≈øtand: it is the Colonels proper place to be on the head or mid≈øt of his grand divi≈øion; which is his chiefe≈øt place of ≈øecurity, and where he ought to fight; for ≈øtanding there, the other may more conveniently repair unto him for their orders, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require. Now the Colonel being a Field-Officer, is not ab≈øolutely tyed to any one place to fight, as the re≈øt are, many occa≈øions calling him from
thence; the elde≈øt Captain therefore is appointed to take charge of the Body of Pikes, whether it be upon a March to lead them, or upon a Stand to fight them, he ought never to for≈øake them, but upon ≈øpecial command from his Colonel, or other Field-Officers. Now the rea≈øon why the fir≈øt Body of Pikes is the mo≈øt honourable≈øt place to lead, is, as I conceive, becau≈øe the Colonels Colours are there flying; and be≈øides, being the more ancienter Arms, far more honour it is to lead them; for mo≈øt commonly the gallante≈øt men of the Infantry de≈øire rather to trail Pikes, then to carry Muskets. Moreover, it hath been a con≈øtant practi≈øe in mo≈øt places, that the elde≈øt Captain ≈øhould have that place to lead on foot, although many times his Colonel being on hor≈øe-back, may be a little before him. Having ≈øpoken of the≈øe two, it remains to ≈øpeak ≈øomething of the younge≈øt Captain, who is appointed either upon the Marching all abre≈øt, or upon a Stand, to take charge of the Reer-ward, or left Flank of the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion to fight them; but upon the long March, it is more honourable for him to fall down in the Reer, and to bring up his own Lieutenant, coming up into his place; for it is greater honour (though many times not believed) to bring up a grand divi≈øion, then to lead a Sub-divi≈øion. In the next place, it may be ≈øuppo≈øed that the Captain-Lieutenants place is too honourable to lead the Van-guard. To which I an≈øwer, That the Colonel him≈øelf is confined thither; for upon the long March he draws off the Van-guard, and leads them him≈øelf, being attended on hor≈øe-back by the Martial and Quarter-ma≈øter of his own Regiment. Now leading away the Muskettiers of his own particular Company, the Captain-Lieutenant being ≈øub≈øervient unto him, marcheth a foot upon the head of the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, and takes charge of them, as a≈ø≈øi≈øting to his Colonel, and fighting them, if he receives no command to the contrary, when they are all drawn up again even abre≈øt, it concerning him e≈øpecially to be there re≈øident in the ab≈øence of his Colonel, for the better regulating of them. The elde≈øt Captains Lieutenant is always placed in the Reer of the Pikes, either upon a Stand, or upon a March, it being very honourable unto him to bring up a grand Divi≈øion of Pikes. The third Captains Lieutenant is ordered to bring up the left Flank, except it be upon the long March, and then he is to exchange places with his own Captain. There is yet one place vacant, which is to bring up the right Flank; and the Captain-Lieutenants Bringer-up many times through courte≈øie is called a Lieutenant, therefore a Major may be ≈øo courteous as to a≈ø≈øign him that place. And here I ≈øhall conclude with the rea≈øons of the places of the Officers of the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion.

div.head: CHAP. V. Rea≈øons for the placing of the Officers of the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion.
div.p: ALthough the Colonel is Commander in chief, yet his di≈øcretion is ≈øuch, as to leave the ordering of places to his Major; and as he takes charge of the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion, ≈øo he leaves the ≈øecond to his Lieutenant-Colonel, who ≈øtands upon the head or mid≈øt of the ≈øame, being drawn up all even abre≈øt; and many times leads the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, as the Colonel doth the fir≈øt, as was the practi≈øe in the Regiments upon their March under the command of the Earl of E≈ø≈øex, General of the Parliaments Forces. To ≈øuch as ≈øhall approve of this way (which may be very good) they ≈øhall not need to Counter-march the Ranks of the Lieutenant-Colonel, as is before expre≈ø≈øed, before the drawing up of the Lieutenant-Colonels Company, but draw them up on the right of that Divi≈øion, and to Counter-march the Ranks of the Majors, and draw his Company up on the left. But I ≈øhall leave that to the liberty of tho≈øe that ≈øhall be≈øt fancie this kinde, and proceed to that which is of more u≈øe.

The ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion ≈øtanding in an even range with the fir≈øt, it will be convenient for the Lieutenant-Colonel to be upon the head thereof. As concerning the Major, he being an Officer at will, hath no certain place a≈ø≈øign'd unto him, by rea≈øon of his moving as occa≈øion ≈øhall require to both Divi≈øions, whereby
he may give orders unto them all, minding the good order of the Regiment throughout every part. But if he will take his place, to march in the propere≈øt place for him, if they march all abre≈øt, will be in the Front, between the Colonel and Lieutenant-Colonel; but in the long march, in the mid≈øt of both grand Divi≈øions, whereby he may have freer acce≈øs unto them both, who≈øe vigilant eye in the well ordering of the Regiment is chiefly concern'd, ob≈øerving all the pa≈ø≈øages, whether there be need of ≈øub-dividing their Divi≈øions; and if at any time they ≈øhall be divided, when there is ground ≈øufficient enough, he mu≈øt give order again for the drawing them all up even abre≈øt, it being far more graceful to the Regiments marching. In the next place, the ≈øecond Captain may claim it as his due, to lead the ≈øecond Body of Pikes, as the elde≈øt Captain challengeth the fir≈øt; and the rea≈øon given for his place, may ≈øuffice for both. The elde≈øt Lieutenant in this grand Divi≈øion, which is the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant, is a≈ø≈øigned unto that place, where he is ≈øet down for to be an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant there unto his Lieutenant-Colonel, for the well regulating of his men which march in the Reer, as the Captain-Lieutenant is to the Colonels men, who march in the Front; and his Lieutenant-Colonel bringing up the whole Regiment, is the ≈øecond place of honour. Some may conceive the Majors Lieutenant hath too great a place of honour in leading the Van of the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion. To which I an≈øwer, If the Lieutenant-Colonel marcheth not there him≈øelf, but ≈øhall bring up the Regiment; certainly it mu≈øt be cleer, that it is the Majors due, for to march there him≈øelf at times convenient; and being ≈øo, there is good rea≈øon in his ab≈øence his Lieutenant ≈øhould lead his men, or in his pre≈øence to be there as a helper unto him, for the well regulating of his men, as the other Lieutenants are to the other Field-Officers, who every one of them according to their ≈øeveral places may have ≈øeveral occa≈øions to call them off; their Lieutenants therefore ought to be at hand, and to march with them in their places, whereby they may receive Orders from them, and know how to act in their ab≈øence concerning their own particular Souldiers. The ≈øecond Captains Lieutenant is ordered to bring up the ≈øecond Body of Pikes; which being a grand Divi≈øion, it falls to him as due there, as the elde≈øt Captains Lieutenant doth in the fir≈øt, it being the greate≈øt place of honour that can be given him in the Reer, next to the Lieutenant-Colonel. Having ≈øpoken thus much concerning every Field-Officer, the Captains and their Lieutenants, where their places are to march, with the rea≈øons for the ≈øame, it will be expected to ≈øupply two places which are vacant in the Reer of the ≈øecond grand divi≈øion. To which I an≈øwer, Upon the long march the Lieutenant-Colonel him≈øelf moves down there, and brings up the Reer of the whole Regiment; and therefore it is left vacant for him. But then you will ≈øay, There wants an Officer to bring up the Reer of that Divi≈øion wherein the Majors Lieutenant is placed. To which I an≈øwer, That there is none remaining to do it, except it be the Majors Lieutenant him≈øelf. For if the Major ≈øhall lead the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, then his Lieutenant may move down to bring up that particular Divi≈øion for to ≈øupply the ≈øame; but in regard the Major (as hath been ≈øhewn before) hath many occa≈øions to call him off, it concerns his Lieutenant to keep his place which was fir≈øt a≈ø≈øigned unto him, to avoid the trouble of moving up again in his Majors ab≈øence. Some are of opinion it would be convenient to place the Lieutenant-Colonels elde≈øt Serjeant there; but in my judgement, it is very unhand≈øome to ≈øee any Halberdeer, either to lead or bring up any Divi≈øion marching in a Regimental way; and rather then I ≈øhould do it, I would let it go un≈øupplyed; but if he ≈øhall be there placed to bring up, his be≈øt way of marching is either with Pallizado, or half-pike, and not with his Halberd.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The ordering of a Regiment to the long March, with the placing of the Officers, and the leading of Carriages.
div.p:
THe Major giving to every Captain his proper place to march in, and what Divi≈øions they are to lead, and what to bring up, in written notes under his hand, commands the Drum-Major to bea ‚Ä¢ a March, and
≈øo con≈øequently all the re≈øt to take it
formation
from him. The Souldiers being warned thereby, begin to ≈øhoulder their Arms, and prepare to move; the Colonel on Horsback being attended on by his Martial and Quarter-ma≈øter, draws off the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, his Captain-Lieutenant being ≈øix foot behinde him; which Divi≈øion is brought up by the Captain-Lieutenants Bringer-up. The elde≈øt Captain follows next, leading the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes, and brought up by his own Lieutenant. The next Divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the third Captains Lieutenant, and the Reer of the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion is brought up by the third Captain. There ought to be full 18 foot of ground betwixt each Divi≈øion; he that brings up a Divi≈øion, ought to be cleer ≈øix foot behinde the ≈øame; and he that leads, to be ≈øix foot before; ≈øo that there will be ≈øix foot proportion of ground betwixt them both, for the better di≈øtingui≈øhing of their Divi≈øions, the Leaders and Bringers-up thereof. And where there is not room ≈øufficient for the marching ≈øo many abre≈øt, as they are now ordered, they mu≈øt ≈øubdivide, being careful to pre≈øerve their Divi≈øions, marching in greater depths, at their due di≈øtance of open order in rank, and order in file. For the Serjeants mu≈øt not pre≈øume upon any ≈øub-dividing to bring them down in the Reer of them that march before, and keep them intire in all their re≈øpective Divi≈øions. And it mu≈øt be their ob≈øervation to attend upon the Flanks, even abre≈øt with tho≈øe Leaders of Files that were taken off; that when there is ground and room enough, they more readier know where to finde them, and to lead them up again as they were at fir≈øt. Care likewi≈øe mu≈øt be had upon any ≈øub-dividing of the Pikes, that there be none of the Colours divided, who are in a Regimental way to march all three together, according to their fir≈øt placing. The≈øe rules and ob≈øervations concern both grand Divi≈øions. Now the fir≈øt being led away, as is before expre≈øt, there ought to be ≈øufficient ground betwixt each grand Divi≈øion for the leading of the Carriages; and in the fir≈øt place there is to be con≈øidered, that to mo≈øt Regiments there is allowed two Waggons, for the Baggage and Ammunition, and two Field-pieces, or great Cannon, be≈øides other Carriages which more concern the Victual for the Souldiers, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require: now concerning the ordering, and ≈øecure≈øt placing of all the≈øe upon the March, will be in the mid≈øt of the Regiment, and to have tho≈øe which are ordred for their Guard, to be Fire-locks, or to have Snap-hances, for the avoiding of the danger which might happen by the Cole of the Match; and being placed where any attempt of the Enemy ≈øhall fall on, either to Front, Reer, or
either Flank, the Cannon may thus be ea≈øily drawn forth to fire upon them; and all the wood of the Carriages, with their Guard, to be ordred in the Reer, whereever the a≈ø≈øault ≈øhould happen, for their better ≈øecurity and ≈øafety. The Major in the next place, if he plea≈øe, may lead the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion; to which purpo≈øe he draws off (with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his own Lieutenant) the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, his Lieutenant being ≈øix foot behinde him, and ≈øo much before the Muskettiers. The next that follows, is the ≈øecond Body of Pikes, which is led by the ≈øecond Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant. The la≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant: and the Reer of the whole Regiment is brought up by the Lieutenant-Colonel. The Serjeants are to march upon the Flanks, attending their own men, that when they are to be reduced into Companies, they may know more readier where to finde them; and according to order they may draw them off to compleat up their Captains Companies. As for the Drums, the care thereof belongs to the Drum-Major to place, and to ea≈øe them timely by reliefs, to beat as many or as few as he ≈øhall think fit; to which purpo≈øe, he orders them to fall in betwixt the ≈øecond and third Rank of Muskettiers and Pikes of each Divi≈øion; but when they are all even abre≈øt, the Drums are placed according as you ≈øee them marked. The Figure for the long-March in the next place followeth.

div.head: CHAP. VII. The fir≈øt Exerci≈øe of a Regiment in the plaine≈øt and ea≈øie≈øt way.
div.p: THe Major finding the commodiou≈øne≈øs of the ground, may draw them up all even abre≈øt again, and proceed to exerci≈øe them in a Regimental way, conferring before-hand with the Captains, Lieutenants, En≈øigns, and Serjeants, what he intends to do. Whether he will exerci≈øe every Maniple, or Divi≈øion (as is u≈øual in a private Company) in all their plain Motions and Firings, which may be very proper, and ea≈øily done, or otherwi≈øe proceed to more variety in every Divi≈øion, to give them commands as one man, either to face, double, or otherwi≈øe according to di≈øcretion. And having fully in≈øtructed them of all his intents and purpo≈øes, he mu≈øt begin to con≈øider of the be≈øt manner for the managing of the ≈øame. To which end, he ≈øhall do well to command the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion to advance forward 12 paces clear of the ≈øecond, and after face them to the Front, and they will ≈øtand in manner as in Folio 147. After he mu≈øt con≈øider how many Files of Muskettiers there are, and whether he can branch them forth into equal Divi≈øions ≈øutable to the Pikes; but finding them to ≈øtand but 18 of a ≈øide, he ≈øhall do well for time of his Exerci≈øe, to draw off eight Files of Muskettiers from the Reer, which were formerly appointed to guard the Ammunition, or Baggage, and add two to every Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, which will make them 20 Files of each ≈øide of the Pikes, and then he may thus proceed.

Command. Files, to their open order, and Ranks to clo≈øe forward to order in each grand Divi≈øion: every five Files of Muskettiers of each Divi≈øion clo≈øe to the right to order: the fir≈øt ≈øix files of Pikes in each grand Divi≈øion clo≈øe to the right to order, the re≈øt of the Pikes clo≈øe every five Files to the right, to the ≈øame di≈øtance; then there will be in each grand Divi≈øion four Divi≈øions of Pikes, and eight of Muskettiers, in manner as ≈øet forth to your view in Folio 147.

Before the Major ≈øhall begin his Exerci≈øe, he ≈øhall do well to appoint unto each Divi≈øion, the Captains and their En≈øigns, (who≈øe Colours in the mean time may be ≈øtuck in the ground, or given to any of the File-leaders of Pikes, to hold during the time of Exerci≈øe) to take charge of them, to order them according unto every word of command, and the Lieutenant and Serjeants to each Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, that after ≈øilence is craved throughout the whole Regiment, the Major by ≈øtretching out his voice in every word of Command, the re≈øt as his Eccho are immediately to give it out along the whole Front, and from thence unto the Reer, and every Officer to lead his men accordingly.

The Major having ≈øtated all things according to the former directions, may if he plea≈øe, either face, double, counter-march, or wheel, to Front, Reer, or both Flanks in every particular Divi≈øion; And may after fire them by way of Divi≈øions
drawn off ten or twenty paces before the Front, firing them 7 or 8 times over, relieving them by other ≈øupplies, marching up into their ground. And may after face the Reer-divi≈øions about, and fire them to Front and Reer on the ≈øame ground they ≈øtand, there being ≈øufficient intervalls for their wheeling off in the Reer of them≈øelves. And after ≈øeveral firings in this kinde, the Pikes may charge on; but before they begin their firings, the Pikes mu≈øt clo≈øe into the mid≈øt to order, and Muskettiers to clo≈øe their Pikes to open order, and every Divi≈øion to pre≈øerve ≈øo much ground betwixt each other for their conveniencie, that after firing they may wheel off.

Now if you will fire, or skirmi≈øh the one with the other, then draw off the Reer, or ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, and move them away, and draw them up in oppo≈øition 100 foot di≈øtance of ground betwixt each Front, and let the Lieutenant-Colonels Company be drawn up upon the right, and the Majors upon the left of that grand Divi≈øion, that it may carry ≈øome an≈øwerablene≈øs with that of the Colonels. The Muskettiers having ≈øix foot interval of ground betwixt each other before they begin to fire, they may continue their firings of this nature, as long as they plea≈øe, and the Pikes may after charge on to ≈øuch convenient di≈øtance, as that they come not within three Pikes length one of another, for avoiding doing hurt the one to the other, the Muskettiers ≈øtill continuing their firing, and falling in the Reer of them≈øelves; and when they come within di≈øtance, not to pre≈øent above knee-height, for the above-named rea≈øons. Now the Souldiers being almo≈øt tired, and all their Powder ≈øpent, and retreating from each other, that ≈øide which falls out to be ≈øtronge≈øt, (as being the Colonels grand Divi≈øion or party) may beat a parley, to invite the weaker to come in to mercy, offering them all fair Quarter, provided they timely and pre≈øently receive it, and that they will cheerfully and willingly go along with them, and never any more revolt, but be on their ≈øide, to fight with them upon all ju≈øt occa≈øions, as ≈øhall be required. After which, the Lieutenant-Colonel yeilding, they may wheel about, and march into the ≈øame ground from whence they were fir≈øt drawn forth, and be reduced to the ≈øame order and condition as they were before they began to skirmi≈øh. And thus much ≈øhall ≈øuffice concerning the ordinary plain way of exerci≈øing of Regiments: but tho≈øe that ≈øhall de≈øire a little more curio≈øity, they may ob≈øerve ≈øuch Exerci≈øes as in the next place ≈øhall be ≈øet forth unto them.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. A ≈øecond way of exerci≈øing Regiments of the ≈øame number of men.
div.p: THe fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion being in the Front, and clear of the ≈øecond 12 paces, every five Files being 18 foot of ground a part from each other, and at their di≈øtance of order, both in Rank and File, in their own particular divi≈øions, as was mention'd in Folio 146. comes in this place to be ≈øet forth to their view. And having pa≈øt over ≈øome of the di≈øtances to bring them to this Station, in ≈øtanding in 24 Maniples, or Divi≈øions, the next thing that I ≈øhall ≈øhew for Exerci≈øe, ≈øhall be four ≈øeveral Figures of Battail, branched from thence, by proper words of Command, with their reducement.

Command. Divi≈øions of Muskettiers face outward; Pikes and Muskettiers march all twelve paces and ≈øtand; to your Leader. The two middle Divi≈øions of Pikes and Muskettiers in the Reer next the Flanks, face about; outmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Pikes and Muskettiers in Front and Reer, face outward; march all four paces, and ≈øtand. Again, let the outmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Pikes and Muskettiers face about to the right, then march all three paces; then ≈øtand, and face to their Leader, it produceth the fir≈øt Figure.
Each of the former Divi≈øions containing five Files apiece, excepting the outmo≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes upon the right in Front and Reer, and they contain ≈øix Files in each of them.
Command. Divi≈øions of Muskettiers face outward; Pikes face about to the right; march all, until the Pikes range even with the Reer; then face to their Leader, occa≈øioneth the next.

Command. The four la≈øt Divi≈øions of each Arms in the mid≈øt, face about; the ≈øix outmo≈øt Divi≈øions of each Arms face outward; the two middle Divi≈øions of Pikes in the Front face about: march all four paces, and ≈øtand; then face the ≈øix outmo≈øt divi≈øions about to the right, and the four middle Divi≈øions of Pikes about to the left; then march all four paces, and face to their Leader.
Command. The two next Divi≈øions of Pikes in the mid≈øt from the Reer, face about; middle Divi≈øions of Pikes move forward ≈øix foot before the Front and Reer; to your Leader.

Reducement. The twelve la≈øt Divi≈øions face about; then ≈øet every Divi≈øion march forward, until they range even abre≈øt with the Front and Reer, and face to their Leader; then let the Reer-divi≈øions move forward within eighteen foot of the Front-divi≈øions, and they will be in two grand Divi≈øions, the one in the Reer of the other, as at fir≈øt when they began their facings.

Having pa≈øt over part of the Di≈øtances and Facings, the next which in order falls to be handled is Doublings; and having by command gained eighteen foot di≈øtance betwixt every five Files, if in their former motions they ≈øhould chance to lo≈øe it, you may then proceed to Doublings by way of Divi≈øions, as ≈øhall be in the next place ≈øet down.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Doublings belonging to a Regiment.
div.p: Command. DIvi≈øions, double to the right File-wi≈øe.

Direction. Every even Divi≈øion from the Front face to the right, and march down clear until you ≈øtand ≈øtraight with the next Interval; then face to the left, and move in, and double tho≈øe Divi≈øions on the right File-wi≈øe; to your Leader.
Command. Divi≈øions double to the right Rankwi≈øe.
Direction. Every even Divi≈øion from the Front face to the right, and march forward ≈øix paces; then face to the Front, and move forward, and double your Divi≈øions to the right.
Command. Divi≈øions double the Length of the Battail to the right and left outward.
Direction. The 12 la≈øt Divi≈øions face outward, and march clear of the ≈øtanding part; face to your Leader; move up all even abre≈øt, and double according to command.
Command. The 12 inmo≈øt Divi≈øions double the ≈øix outmo≈øt to the right and left outward, advancing.

Direction. The 12 middle Divi≈øions advance forward until you be ≈øix foot clear of the ≈øtanding part; then face outward, and march until you ≈øtand ≈øtraight before the ≈øix outmo≈øt; face to your Leader: and after face inward, and move forward, until they ≈øtand again unto eighteen foot di≈øtance from each other; to your Leader.
Command. Divi≈øions, double the Depth of the Battail to the right.

Direction. Every even Divi≈øion from the right, face about to the right, and move down eighteen foot clear of the Reer; face to the left, and move until you ≈øtand ≈øtraight with tho≈øe Divi≈øions on the right which you are to double; to your Leader.
Command. The 12 la≈øt Divi≈øions in the Reer, double the Front to the right.
Direction. The 12 la≈øt Divi≈øions face to the right, and move ≈øix paces; then face to the left; march forward, and double the Front to the right, and they will be reduced.

div.head: CHAP. X. Four ≈øeveral Wheelings, with their Reducement.
div.p: Command. DIvi≈øions wheel about to the right, and move down into the Reer.

Direction. Front-divi≈øions wheel about to the right, and move down into the Reer; the re≈øt march up into the ≈øame ground, wheeling to the right hand, and following ≈øucce≈ø≈øively; after face to your Leader.
Command. Divi≈øions wheel about to the right to the left Flank.

Direction. Face to the right, and the outmo≈øt Divi≈øions wheel about to the right, and march away unto the place of the left Flank, the re≈øt moving up into the ≈øame ground, wheeling about to the right, and following accordingly; to your Leader.
Command. Divi≈øions wheel about to the right from the Reer into the Front.

Direction. Face to the Reer, and let the fir≈øt Divi≈øions wheel about to the right, and move up into the Front, the re≈øt marching forward into their ground, wheeling off, and following in like manner.
Command. Divi≈øions wheel about to the right, to the right Flank.

Direction. Face all to the left, and let the outmo≈øt Divi≈øions wheel about to the right, and move forward to the right Flank, the re≈øt marching up into their ground, following after in the ≈øame kind, reduceth them.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Countermarches not fit to be u≈øed in the Exerci≈øing of Regiments.
div.p:
IT might be expected after Doublings, that I ≈øhould ≈øhew ≈øome kinds of Countermarches among≈øt the Military Motions, in the exerci≈øe of a Regiment; but being of very little u≈øe or practi≈øe among≈øt Commanders in the≈øe times, e≈øpecially in ≈øuch great Bodies; and for my own part, I fancy them not, therefore have pa≈ø≈øed them over, and pitcht upon ≈øuch wheelings, which by ≈øome are accounted Countermarches. Who≈øe judgements my de≈øire is better to inform by the≈øe ≈øeveral rea≈øons following, wherein, and in what kind they differ from them. As thus: by the≈øe wheelings, they keep their di≈øtance in Rank and File unto Order, and wheeling entire unto any hand down to the Reer, cannot be performed but by gaining in the Motion before the Front, and unto all places as they move, ≈øo much ground as is the Length of their particular Divi≈øions; and in the execution thereof, they ≈øtill pre≈øerve the honour of the right and left-hand-file-leaders, and all others as are concerned in their particular Divi≈øions, unto any accidental Front which they ≈øhall be brought unto. Now concerning Countermarches, they are to be performed either by ≈øingle Files, Ranks, Half-files, or Half-ranks, and at their di≈øtance of Open Order, their words of Command having relation to all the≈øe particulars. Their Countermarching of Files to the Reer gaineth no ground before the Front in the Motion, but only the room of one particular File upon the right; it pre≈øerveth not the honour of the right and left-hand-file-leader at one time by any one word of Command
formation
unto any of their Motions to ≈øuch accidental Fronts they ≈øhall make, but ever lo≈øeth it to ≈øome, and giveth it to others. And therefore it may appear cleerly unto any ingenious capacity, that the former Wheelings cannot be accounted, or given in their Motions in that kinde to the Souldiers for Counter-marches, but by ≈øuch terms as in their place are ≈øet down. In the next place, I ≈øhall ≈øpeak ≈øomething of the great benefit or u≈øe that may be made of the≈øe ≈øorts of Wheelings: as fir≈øt, a Commander may u≈øe them in the Motions of Doublings to Front, Reer, right-flank, or left, or double either the length or depth of the Battail unto all needful places, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require; which I ≈øhall forbear to ≈øet down, but leave them to the di≈øcretion of the ingenious Souldiers practi≈øe, when time and opportunity ≈øhall ≈øerve him to make u≈øe of them. In the next place, they are very nece≈ø≈øary to draw off any part, and to bring them unto ≈øuch needful places for Service, as are in eminent danger. Therefore pa≈ø≈øing over for pre≈øent what might be more ≈øpoken of in this kinde, I come in the next place to ≈øhew one Figure of Battail to fire upon; and then conclude my Exerci≈øe upon this Regiment, and go on unto the re≈øt.

Command. Pikes, clo≈øe Files to the right to Order; then let them in the Reer double their Front to the left intire: Muskettiers, advance forward until your Front-divi≈øions exceed ≈øix foot the Front of Pikes; the two inmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Front, move forward 20 paces, and clo≈øe inward to open Order; the two inmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Reer, face about, and move down ≈øix paces, and clo≈øe inward to open Order; to your Leader: Muskettiers upon the Flanks, clo≈øe to the Body of Pikes to open Order: Middle-divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Reer by each Flank, face about; Middle-divi≈øions of Muskettiers by each Flank, move forward ≈øix foot cleer of the ≈øtanding part; face to your Leader, and it will ≈øet forth the Figure, as it ≈øtands in Folio 151.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Several Firings to be performed upon the former Figure, and how to be managed by the ≈øeveral Officers.
div.p: THe Regiment being drawn up into the former Figure, they may proceed to Firings upon it; fir≈øt let the Forlorns fire five or ≈øix times over, being commanded by the elde≈øt Captains Lieutenant, who is to be a≈ø≈øi≈øted by a couple of able Serjeants; after let him wheel them off to the right and left, and bring them down in the Reer of the Pikes. Then let the ≈øecond Captains Lieutenant, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted by two Serjeants, lead up the re≈øerves by the out≈øide of the Pikes, at ≈øuch time when the Forlorns begin to come off, for the better ≈øecuring of them from danger upon their retreat; then let them move forward to their ground, and give fire in like manner, falling in the Reer of them≈øelves, and after wheel them off to the right and left, and bring them down in the Reer of tho≈øe Muskettiers that are behind the Pikes. Then let the Front and Reer-divi≈øions of Muskettiers next the Flanks advance forward 12 paces; the Muskettiers upon the right to be led away by the Captain-Lieutenant, and tho≈øe upon the left by the third Captain, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted by four Serjeants apiece; let them fire the fir≈øt Divi≈øions ≈øome ≈øix or eight times over, falling in the Reer of them≈øelves; then wheel them off to the right and left into the ground of tho≈øe Divi≈øions that follow them; and facing again to their Front; then let the Reer-divi≈øions advance forward into their places, and give fire in like manner to the former: which being ended, let tho≈øe four divi≈øions be led down into their fir≈øt places. Then let the next eight Divi≈øions by the Pikes advance forward, until they be cleer of the ≈øtanding part; tho≈øe four Divi≈øions upon the right, are to be led away by the Majors Lieutenant, and the Captain-Lieutenants Bringer-up; and tho≈øe four Divi≈øions upon the left, by the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant, and the third Captains Lieutenant, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by 12 Serjeants; then let them fire ≈øome half a ≈øcore times, the Front-divi≈øions falling in the Reer of them≈øelves; after wheeling off to the right and left into the ground of their Reer-divi≈øions, they then moving up into their places, may fire after the ≈øame manner; and having ended, they may be led down all again into their fir≈øt places.

Then Command the fir≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers to face about to the right, and let them and the two la≈øt Divi≈øions move forward, and range even abre≈øt with tho≈øe that ≈øtand before them, and after face all to the Front; then let the Muskettiers face outward, and move 12 paces, and after face again to the Front; then move up tho≈øe divi≈øions that were the Forlorn-hope, to the right and left into the Front, unto their fir≈øt places; and tho≈øe that were the Re≈øerves up even abre≈øt with the Reer, from whence they were taken, after let them fire in, and even Front altogether, ≈øome half a ≈øcore times over, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; then let the Colonels elde≈øt and ≈øecond Captains move forward the Pikes, and charge on if they plea≈øe, the Colours falling in the ≈øecond Rank, being furled up; and after let all order their Arms, and reduce them into Companies again.

Reducement. Left-half-ranks of Pikes, face about, and move down until you range even with the Reer-divi≈øions of Muskettiers; face to your Leader: Right-half-ranks of Pikes, advance forward, and range even abre≈øt with the Front-divi≈øions of Muskettiers; Files, clo≈øe to the left to Order of each grand Divi≈øion; then they will ≈øtand in two grand Divi≈øions as at fir≈øt, the one in the Reer of the other: then draw up the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, provided there be room upon the left of the fir≈øt. Then let a Serjeant of each particular Company draw off tho≈øe thirteen Files, which before were taken off to ballance the Divi≈øions into equal number, and were appointed for the guard of the Ammunition, or Baggage, and bring them to joyn with their own Arms, where their Captains Companies ≈øtands. Which being done, let every Captain draw off his own men, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted by his Lieutenants and Serjeants, and compleating them up into a Body as at fir≈øt; his Pikes to be flanked with Muskettiers, they may after march away in ≈øingle Companies after ≈øuch manner, unto their ≈øeveral Quarters, as ≈øhall be appointed to them by the Major. And here I ≈øhall conclude concerning a Regiment of ≈øix Companies.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. The manner of drawing up a Regiment, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeven Companies, conteining in the four Captains, twelve Files of Muskettiers, and ≈øix of Pikes, in each of their particular Companies, and in the three Field-Officers, ≈øixteen Files apiece of Muskettiers, and eight of Pikes, which amounts to the number of 864 men.
div.p:
IT hath been my ob≈øervation in the City of London, and the Suburbs thereof, there being eighteen Regiments, nine of the Trained Bands, and nine of the Auxiliaries, that their Regiments in ≈øome have but ≈øix Companies; others, and that for the mo≈øt part ≈øeven; and again in ≈øome, and but a few to have eight Companies. I ≈øhall therefore for the better ≈øatisfaction of ≈øuch as remain unskill'd herein, go through them all, partly to ≈øhew the practi≈øe of this our City in their ≈øeveral drawings up, with the rea≈øons to confirm the ≈øame. And having pa≈ø≈øed over as much as is convenient, to ≈øatisfie any ingenious Souldier concerning the drawing up of ≈øix Companies in a Regimental-way, with the confirmation and rea≈øons of every particular Officer, as he there ≈øtands, it may in many things give full light to this that follows of ≈øeven Companies. Yet neverthele≈øs, for more fuller ≈øatisfaction herein, I ≈øhall ≈øhew the true manner hereof, that I may not be wanting to any Souldiers benefit that he ≈øhall receive thereby. Where note, for better Order herein, that I have pitcht upon a particular number of men, although it may many times fall out ≈øo, that the Captains Companies, and the Field-Officers cannot be ≈øo full as I have here ≈øet down. Or again, it may chance to fall out (as in our Trained Bands of London) that they be a great deal fuller, as ≈øometimes they are; for I have led a particular Company my ≈øelf upon a general day, being drawn into the Filed con≈øi≈øting of above 300 men. Yet neverthele≈øs, whether the Companies be great or ≈ømall, ob≈øerve this general Rule; make two grand Divi≈øions, and ballance their number equal in both Arms, and make no more Sub-divi≈øions then what you have Captains to lead, and Lieutenants to bring up; and let the Serjeants march by the Flanks, and
not pre≈øume either to lead, or bring up any divi≈øions, being conceived by mo≈øt to be very improper. And again, if you fight the Regiment, let your Muskettiers as neer as you can be equal alike in their Sub-divi≈øions, as they may mo≈øt conveniently fall out, whether four, five, or ≈øix abre≈øt, it makes no great matter, always leaving in time of fight, between ≈øuch numbers of Files, ≈øix foot of ground interval, for to wheel off their Ranks after they have fired.

Now, ≈øuppo≈øe the whole Regiment were marching to their general place of Randezvous; the Major being there beforehand, attending the Companies coming in, he Orders to the Colonels Company the mo≈øt convenient place for their drawing up; and next to him, the fourth Captains Company upon the left; and next to him, the third Captain; and after him, the elde≈øt or fir≈øt Captain, which makes the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion. In the next place, he orders the Lieutenant-Colonels Company to be on the left of the whole Regiment, ≈øtanding in even Front with the Colonel; upon the right of him, the ≈øecond Captain is placed, and after him the Majors own Company, which make up the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion.

Having thus far proceeded, let the Major command the Pikes and Colours to advance forward ten paces, before the Front of Muskettiers; then let him clo≈øe the Pikes of the fir≈øt four Companies to the right to Order, and the Pikes of the la≈øt to the left to Order, and the like of the Muskettiers in the Reer to tho≈øe hands, to the ≈øame di≈øtance; then they will ≈øtand in four Divi≈øions; two of Pikes in the Front, and two of Muskettiers in the Reer. In the next place, let him count how many Files of Pikes there are in each Divi≈øion, and he will finde in the Colonels Divi≈øions 26 Files, and in the Lieutenant-Colonels but twenty two. To make the≈øe even, he mu≈øt take off one File apiece from the younge≈øt Captains, and bring them into the mid≈øt of the Lieutenant-Colonels Divi≈øion; and then he will make them equal, there being in each grand Divi≈øion 24 Files of Pikes. The Pikes being made thus equal, let him move down into the Reer, and examine the Muskettiers; where upon the right he will finde 52 Files, and upon the left but 44; to make the≈øe even in number, he mu≈øt take off one File apiece from the four Companies of the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion, and lead them away up into the mid≈øt of the ≈øecond; and then there will be in each grand Divi≈øion of Muskettiers 48 Files apiece. In the next place, let him face them to the right and left outward, and move them to ≈øuch convenient di≈øtance, as he may after divide his Muskettiers into four Divi≈øions to move up, and flank the Pikes.

This being performed, he ought appoint unto every Captain and Lieutenant his place where to lead, and where to bring up, and what men upon all occa≈øions they are to fight. To which purpo≈øe, there being in the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion four Captains, there mu≈øt be four places to lead, and four to bring up; and therefore having their four Colours upon the long March, that Body of Pikes may be divided into two Divi≈øions, and to march with two Colours in the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes, which are to be led by the elde≈øt Captain, and brought up by the Captain-Lieutenants Bringer-up. The ≈øecond Divi≈øion of Pikes is to be led by the fourth Captain, and to be brought up by the elde≈øt Captain-Lieutenant. The Reer-guard of Muskettiers in this grand Divi≈øion, is to be led by the third Captain, and to be brought up by his Lieutenant; who upon the long March, his Captain if he plea≈øeth, may exchange places, being more honour to him to be there to bring up, then to lead that Divi≈øion, as hath been formerly expre≈øt. As concerning the Captain-Lieutenant, his place is to be fixed according as in the Figure to lead the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, and to be brought up by the fourth Captains Lieutenant: but at ≈øuch time when they are drawn up all abre≈øt, they are to take their places as at fir≈øt fixed, both in their leading and bringing-up, as ≈øhall be ≈øet forth in the following Figure, with all their ≈øeveral places appointed thereunto. As concerning all the re≈øt, they are placed in manner as was ≈øhewed in my di≈øcour≈øe of a Regiment con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix Companies.

But here it may be objected, that in the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion I have placed the Colonel, elde≈øt Captain, third and fourth, and by ca≈øting up their number of dignity, we finde it to amount unto 18; and in the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion,
the Lieutenant-Colonel, Major and ≈øecond Captain, who≈øe number amounts but to ten. Here we finde (≈øay they) a great deal of difference and alteration, your intentions principally tending to make them equal in dignity; for certainly, where the greater number is, there is the le≈ø≈øer dignity; and therefore a wrong unto that part where ever it ≈øo falls out.

To which I an≈øwer, Where there is no ju≈øt exceptions to be made to the contrary, the former Rule ought ever to be pre≈øerved in the keeping an equal ballance of the number of dignity; but herein it doth not: For the Colonel ought always to have placed in his Divi≈øion the elde≈øt Captain, who is to lead his Colours, and the fir≈øt Body of Pikes, which is the fir≈øt place of honour among the Captains: And in the ≈øecond place, the Majors Company is always drawn up upon the outmo≈øt part, on the right of the Lieutenant-Colonels grand Divi≈øion, to carry an equal proportion of number, they being the ≈øecond and third worth unto that of the fir≈øt or fourth, as is in the Colonels. In the next place, the ≈øecond Captains turn comes to be regarded, who by the ≈øame Rule, as the elde≈øt Captain layes claim to carry the fir≈øt honour, by leading the fir≈øt Body of Pikes, and the Colonels Colours; ≈øo the ≈øecond Captain cannot expect any other, but to be placed to lead the ≈øecond Body of Pikes, & the Lieutenant-Colonels Colours. Now there being an odd Captain, he mu≈øt be either placed upon the right or left; he is therefore thought in di≈øcretion to be rather placed with the Colonel in his Divi≈øion, that his Colours may there flie, marching four together, being far more honourable and graceful then that of three, as in the Lieutenant-Colonels; and therefore where there is an honour in that kinde which cannot be divided, it is very fit and requi≈øite to place and fix it with him that is the Commander in chief. As for number of men, both Divi≈øions are equal alike; and therefore, I conceive, what hath been ≈øpoken may take off all objections of this nature.

And now according to my promi≈øe, I ≈øhall ≈øet forth the manner of the ≈øtanding of ≈øeven Companies in a Regimental way, with all the ≈øeveral places of honour appointed forth unto them, either marching, or ≈øtanding all even abre≈øt: If they be upon the long march, they are to ob≈øerve that manner ≈øet down in ≈øix Companies, onely to minde that alteration before expre≈ø≈øed: the Figure of their drawing up, and the Officers ≈øtated in their proper places, follows in Folio 156.
From which Figure I ≈øhall draw up another, placing the Souldiers in Battalia, which may be u≈øeful for them to fight-upon.

Command. Pikes in both Divi≈øions, face inward, inmo≈øt Divi≈øions of Muskettiers face outward, march, and interchange ground with other; face to your Leader. The four inmo≈øt Files of Muskettiers next the Pikes,Let them be at open Order in their Ranks and Files, and the two grand Divi≈øions ≈øtanding in one even Front together. face about, and march ≈øix foot cleer from the Pikes, and ≈øtand; then clo≈øe their Files to the right and left to Order, in their own particular divi≈øions; then face inward, and march all together, until they ≈øtand ≈øix foot cleer of each other; face to your Leader. The next five Files of Muskettiers in each ≈øide of Pikes, advance 18 foot before the Front; then clo≈øe their Files into the mid≈øt to Order, and Ranks forward to Order; Pikes, clo≈øe your Ranks forward to Order, and Files into the mid≈øt to Order: every five Files of Muskettiers clo≈øe inward to Order, and Ranks forward to Order; then face to the Pikes, and march forward, being betwixt every five Files of Muskettiers ≈øix foot of ground di≈øtance each from other, and the ≈øame di≈øtance from the Body, of Pikes; face all to your Leader. The 12 outmo≈øt Files of Pikes and Muskettiers, advance forward ≈øix foot cleer of the ≈øtanding part; then move forward the three outmo≈øt divi≈øions of Muskettiers 12 paces; then face them inward, and move them until they ≈øtand ≈øtreight before the five remaining divi≈øions; face all to your Leader. The middle-divi≈øion of Muskettiers of tho≈øe three taken off before from each Flank, move forward ≈øix foot cleer of the ≈øtanding part; the three middlemo≈øt divi≈øions of the five remaining upon each Flank, move up until you ≈øtand ≈øix foot ≈øhort of the divi≈øions which are before you; the two outmo≈øt divi≈øions of the la≈øt three that moved, face outward, and march ≈øix foot cleer of the former divi≈øions between them: The two remaining divi≈øions by the out≈øide
of Pikes move inward, until you ≈øtand ≈øtreight in the Reer with the two Front-divi≈øions, facing all to their Leader, they will ≈øtand as is ≈øet forth unto your view in Folio 156.

Notwith≈øtanding the former directions of drawing forth the Figure, make this alteration; wheel off the fir≈øt two divi≈øions of Muskettiers before the Pikes, and place them ≈øix foot behind the Reer of tho≈øe upon the Flanks, and before you reduce them, carry them into their fir≈øt places.

In this Figure you have Forlorns, aptly ≈øtanding to the Wings and main Body of Pikes, with Re≈øerves to them all, ≈øo that I ≈øhall not need to trouble my ≈øelf for to de≈øcribe what firings might be here performed upon the ≈øame, they lying ≈øo apparent to the view; the divi≈øions being cleer each of other, any ingenious Commander may fire them according unto his own be≈øt di≈øcretion, continuing the ≈øame as long as he ≈øhall think fitting; and therefore pa≈ø≈øing it by, and leaving it to their own liberty, I come in the next place to reduce them again into private Companies.

Reducement. Pikes of the main Body, advance forward, and range even abre≈øt with the Pikes before you; the two la≈øt divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Reer move up, and Flank the Pikes; the two divi≈øions of Muskettiers before the Front, face about, and move down upon the right and left of the other two divi≈øions of Muskettiers; to your Leader. The two la≈øt divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Reer of the Flanks, advance forward to the right and left, and range even abre≈øt on the out≈øide of tho≈øe three divi≈øions that ≈øtands before you: Single divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Front of each Wing, face about, and move down even abre≈øt with the Reer of the next divi≈øions. The eight divi≈øions of Muskettiers upon each Wing, face about; the five fir≈øt Divi≈øions move down, and range even abre≈øt with the Reer; the three la≈øt move to the right, and left outward, until you be cleer of the re≈øt; face to the Reer, and move down in like manner, and Rank even with the re≈øt; after face all to the Front, and they will all ≈øtand in one even Front. Next command the Pikes to face outward, and the five inmo≈øt divi≈øions of Muskettiers in each Flank, face inward; then march and interchange ground each with other, and face to their Leader; they will ≈øtand again in two grand Divi≈øions all even abre≈øt in the Front. In the next place, let tho≈øe ≈øix Files be taken off by the Serjeants of their own Companies from the two grand Divi≈øi≈øions, and be brought into their fir≈øt places. After the Major may give order to every Captain to draw off his men, and put them into Companies again, which is ea≈øily done; after the Regiment may be ordered to march home in ≈øingle Companies, either by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion or dignity, which he plea≈øeth. And here I ≈øhall conclude concerning a Regiment of ≈øeveral Companies.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. The manner of drawing up and placing the Officers of a Regiment con≈øi≈øting of eight Companies, having in it a Colonel, a Lieutenant-Colonel, a Major, and five Captains: their number of men in each Company, being equal with the former Regiment, they amount unto 972 men.
div.p:
IT concerns a Major (provided he have room enough) to draw up every Company even abre≈øt, and to give unto every Captain his due place of honour; after which, he may proceed to order them in a regimental way. Wherefore, briefly thus; ob≈øerve the manner of the Dignity of every Captain, how they ought to be placed, fir≈øt the Colonels Company being drawn up in its convenient place; next to him upon the left ≈øtands the third Captain; and next to him the fourth; and the next that follows is the elde≈øt: the≈øe four Captains being drawn up after this manner, makes the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion; and therefore I ≈øhall endeavour to give Rea≈øons for to confirm this, before I ≈øhall proceed upon the ≈øecond, as being the right half-ranks, which ought to carry an equal proportion of Worth, Honour, and Dignity with that of the la≈øt. Where, fir≈øt, take notice, that the Colonel being the mo≈øt worthie≈øt man, is placed upon the right, and is the fir≈øt place of Honour; and the outmo≈øt upon the left is the elde≈øt Captain, which is the fourth Worth, there being the Colonel, Lieutenant-Colonel, and Major above him: now con≈øider that the fir≈øt and fourth Worth makes the number five; betwixt the≈øe two is drawn up the third and fourth Captains, which are the ≈øixth and ≈øeventh Worth, who≈øe number carries 13; add them to that number above, and it makes 18. In the next place, ≈øince it is the judgement of mo≈øt Souldiers, that there ≈øhould be an equal proportion of Skill, Valour, and Worth, the Reer-half-files an≈øwerable to them of the Front: ≈øo likewi≈øe the ≈øame rule is to be ob≈øerved between the right and left half-ranks; That whether we con≈øider the Front-divi≈øions, or Reer, right or left half-ranks, they may be ≈øo ballanced in every kind of re≈øpect, with true proportion; ≈øo neer as the knowledge of the Souldiers, and number of men will give leave. To which purpo≈øe, I will proceed to draw up the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, and compare it to the fir≈øt; The Lieutenant-Colonels Company being drawn up upon the left of the whole Regiment; upon his right, is the ≈øecond Captain drawn up; and next to him the fifth Captain; after, the Major upon the right of the Lieutenant-Colonels Divi≈øion. Now, if we con≈øider, the Lieutenant-Colonel he is the ≈øecond man of Honour, and therefore ought to be upon the outmo≈øt part of the Front on the left, when the Companies are marching all even abre≈øt; but upon the Long-march he is to fall down into the Reer; the outmo≈øt upon the right of his Divi≈øion is the Majors Company placed, and he is the third man of Honour. Now the third Worth and ≈øecond will carry equal ballance of number with that of the fir≈øt and fourth: and ≈øo have I ≈øet forth the four fir≈øt places of Honour, which, I ≈øuppo≈øe, no knowing Souldier can deny.
