Betwixt the ≈øecond and third Worth is drawn up the ≈øecond Captain and fifth; the ≈øecond Captain is the fifth Worth, and the fifth Captain is the eighth, which makes the number 13, and will carry an equal weight of number with tho≈øe in the mid≈øt of the fir≈øt and fourth Worth. Now having ≈øtated the ≈øeveral Worths of the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, being compared together, makes a like number of 18 unto that of the fir≈øt Divi≈øion. And to take off all Objections that might be made concerning the ≈øecond Captain and fifth, why they ≈øhould not rather be placed in the fir≈øt Divi≈øion, then in the ≈øecond, becau≈øe it hath been held by the opinion of ≈øome, it ≈øhould be ≈øo, but never any ≈øub≈øtantial rea≈øon to be given for the ≈øame: Therefore, unto this I ≈øhall ≈øay, that they ought to be there where I have placed them, in re≈øpect of what I have formerly ≈øaid, that as it is the fir≈øt place of Honour among≈øt the Captains to lead the fir≈øt Body of Pikes, where the Colonels Colours does flie, and to make them of the ≈øecond Divi≈øion equal in number with the fir≈øt; the younge≈øt Captain, which is the eighth Worth, is brought in, and joyned to the ≈øecond Captain, who is the fifth, and therefore a File or a Rank ought to be ≈øet forth in Dignity after this manner, in re≈øpect
2585 4761
18 18
there is no truer ≈øtating the Dignity of a ≈øingle File or Rank, then that which ≈øhall conform to greater Bodies, as that of Regiments. And thus much briefly ≈øhall ≈øuffice to be ≈øpoken concerning the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, for the placing the ≈øecond and fifth Captains betwixt the Lieutenant-Colonel and the Majors, in re≈øpect the ≈øecond Captain ≈øtands very aptly there to receive his proper place, and the younge≈øt Captain is brought in to ballance their Dignities unto that of the fir≈øt.

In the next place, I ≈øhall ≈øhew how they ought to be drawn up in a Regimental way: being all even abre≈øt as before, command Muskettiers to face about, and to march down 12 foot clear of the Reer, then face to the Front, after clo≈øe Files outward to Order of each Arms, then ≈øubdivide each Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, and move them up to flank each Body of Pikes. And having accounted and ca≈øt up the number of Files of each Arms in each grand Divi≈øion, you will finde the Colonels Divi≈øion to have in it 26 Files of Pikes, and 52 Files of Muskettiers; next the Lieutenant-Colonels Divi≈øion being examined, you will finde that to have in it 28 Files of Pikes, and 56 Files of Muskettiers. Now to make the≈øe equal in number, there mu≈øt be taken forth one File of Pikes, and two of Muskettiers from the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, and place one a piece in the mid≈øt of the fir≈øt Divi≈øion, in every one of their particular Divi≈øions, and they will contain equal alike in each grand Divi≈øion 27 Files of Pikes, and 54 Files of Muskettiers. In the next place, the Major may a≈ø≈øign unto every Captain and Lieutenant where his place ≈øhall be to lead, and where to bring up; the Colonel being upon the head of his Divi≈øion, and the Lieutenant-Colonel upon the head of the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, the Major in the Front betwixt them both, or where el≈øe he plea≈øeth, being an Officer always to act through the whole Regiment. And in the fir≈øt place he appoints the Captain-Lieutenant to be on the head of the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, and to be brought up with the fourth Captains Lieutenant; next he orders the elde≈øt Captain to be on the head of the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes, and to be brought up by the Captain-Lieutenants Bringer-up; and the fourth Captain to be on the head of the ≈øecond divi≈øion of Pikes, and to be brought up by the elde≈øt Captains Lieutenant; and the ≈øecond divi≈øion of Mu≈økettiers he appoints unto the third Captain, and to be brought up by his own Lieutenant; and upon the Long-march, let him and his Captain change places until ≈øuch time they ≈øhall draw up again. After he orders his own Lieutenant to be on the head of the third divi≈øion of Muskettiers; and the third divi≈øion of Pikes he appoints to the fifth Captain, and to be brought up by his own Lieutenant; the fourth Divi≈øion of Pikes is ordered to be the ≈øecond Captains place, and brought up by his own Lieutenant; the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant is appointed to the fourth and la≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers, the Lieutenant-Colonel upon the Long-march bringing up the whole Regiment. It might be ≈øuppo≈øed the Captain-Lieutenant, Lieutenant-Colonels and Majors Lieutenants have too great places of Honour: but to an≈øwer them all, their Captains being Field-Officers, and upon ≈øeveral occa≈øions moving off, their Lieutenants do officiate there in their rooms, and are but as a≈ø≈øi≈øtants unto them; for likewi≈øe upon ≈øeveral occa≈øions they come to tho≈øe places them≈øelves to lead, marching there before their Lieutenants. As concerning the placing of all the re≈øt of the other Officers, they lie clearly, for as much as formerly hath been ≈øpoken in their proper places, without (as I conceive) the exceptions of any.

Secondly, u ‚Ä¢ on the Long-march the Colonel draws off the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, and leads them, marching ≈øome 12 foot before his Captain-Lieutenant; and that divi≈øion is brought up by the fourth Captains Lieutenant, the Colours marching two and two upon every divi≈øion, whereof the fir≈øt is drawn off and led by the fir≈øt Captain, and brought up by the Captain-Lieutenants Bringer-up; the next divi≈øion of Pikes falling in the Reer of the fir≈øt, and led by the fourth Captain, and brought upo the fir≈øt Captains Lieutenant; the ≈øecond divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the: ‚Ä¢ ird Captains Lieutenant, and brought up by
his own Captain; the fourth or fir≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion is led by the Major, when he plea≈øeth, ≈øome 12 foot before his own Lieutenant; and the third Divi≈øion of Pikes is led by the fifth Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant; the fourth and la≈øt divi≈øion of Pikes is led by the ≈øecond Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant; the fourth and la≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant, the Reer of the whole Regiment being brought up by the Lieutenant-Colonel. Thus every Divi≈øion is to march by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, the one in the Reer of another, keeping eighteen foot di≈øtance betwixt every Divi≈øion, until they ≈øhall have room to march all even abre≈øt, and then with very little alteration with the third Captain, changing places, with his own Lieutenant, they are all to take their places again, as at fir≈øt.

Having now ≈øet forth the true Dignity of every Captains and Lieutenants place, what men they ≈øhall take charge on to fight, where to lead, and where to bring up; I ≈øhall ≈øpare the Figure in re≈øpect I ≈øhall ≈øhew (with very little alteration) the manner of drawing up and marching of divers Regiments that were under the command of the late Earl of E≈ø≈øex.

The fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion in re≈øpect of every Officer and place, is to be ordered as the former; only in the ≈øecond, there will be this ≈ømall alteration, the Lieutenant-Colonels Company and the Majors are to enterchange places, the re≈øt are to remain as they were, only with this alteration following; the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant is to lead the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, until ≈øuch time that his Lieutenant Colonel ≈øhall come unto that place; and then he is to bring up that Divi≈øion being near at hand, that if his Lieutenant-Colonel ≈øhould upon ≈øome ju≈øt occa≈øions be called off, he may immediatly move up, and lead there in his ab≈øence. For upon the Long-march, as the Colonel leads the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion, ≈øo it is conceived by ≈øome, (they marching in two grand Divi≈øions ≈øome twenty paces di≈øtance from each other in manner of two regimental Marchings) that the Lieutenant-Colonel ought to lead the ≈øecond. Next, let the Fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes be led by the ≈øecond Captain, and to be brought up by the fifth Captains Lieutenant; and the ≈øecond Divi≈øion of Pikes to be led by the fifth Captain, and brought up by the ≈øecond Captains Lieutenant; the la≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers to be led by the Majors Lieutenant, and the Reer of the ≈øecond grant Divi≈øion being left for the Major to bring up, at ≈øuch time as with conveniency he may be ≈øpared. Therefore, to march thus, it being a very good way, and with very little alteration to be made, I was unwilling to pa≈øs it by, leaving it to the di≈øcretion of every ingenious Souldier, to make u≈øe of which way he be≈øt plea≈øeth, or likes of, while≈øt I in the next place ≈øhall ≈øet forth the Figure, which follows in pag. 161; affording more variety in the ≈øame.

div.head: CHAP. XV. How to make the Figure of a Ring, with its u≈øe and ≈øervice.
div.p: But, methinks, I hear ≈øome ≈øay, Of what u≈øe or ≈øervice upon any occa≈øion may this Ring be unto the Souldier? To whom I an≈øwer, that it is one of the mo≈øt ≈øerviceable Figures that can be made, to ≈øecure the Souldier from danger again≈øt the furious charge of Hor≈øe in Campania; the accompli≈øhing, or making of it up, being ea≈øily and ≈øuddenly performed, the Muskettiers having Pallizadoes, may advance three or four paces, and ≈øtick them down in ≈øuch manner, as they may keep the Hor≈øe from breaking in among them. And after, if they ≈øhould be charged round, they may give fire over them again≈øt their enemies, and fall in the Reer of them≈øelves; yet neverthele≈øs, if the Hor≈øe ≈øhould be undaunted, and attempt to come on again, they may re≈øi≈øt them with a more de≈øperate charge after this manner, bringing all hands to fight, and to pour out their ≈øhot, or to fire altogether after this kind. Command fir≈øt the Pikes to move forward, until they be three foot behind the Muskettiers, then let every File rank to the right, which will make them to ≈øtand but one abre≈øt in one ≈øingle Ring behind the Muskettiers. Now that all hands may be brought to fight together, command the fir≈øt Rank of Mu≈økettiers to kneel down, the ≈øecond ≈øtoop, and the third ≈øtand upright; then let all clo≈øe forward to clo≈øe Order, and let the Pikes, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require, charge betwixt the Muskettiers, who may fire altogether, and the Pikes may charge on while≈øt the Muskettiers make ready again. The Pallizadoes formerly ≈øtuck, keeping off the Hor≈øe from breaking in upon them, they may fire after this manner, as often as they plea≈øe. And ≈øo much may ≈øuffice to be ≈øpoken concerning the ≈øervice and u≈øe that may be made of it in time of fight; and now in the next place I come to reduce them into Companies again as at fir≈øt.

Let the Pikes that ranked to the right, file three to the left as they were, and let the Bringers-up that doubled face about to the right, and march forth into their places. Then let the Major come to that place where he clo≈øed the Ring, and brake it off, wheeling them all along about to the left, until he hath brought them to ≈øtand in one even Front as at fir≈øt; the ≈øame in like manner to be performed of the Pikes, and to ≈øtand in the Reer of the Muskettiers. Next, let the Mu≈økettiers and Pikes face outward, and move to ≈øuch convenient di≈øtance, that after the Muskettiers may be ≈øubdivided again, and the Pikes move up, and double their Front inward entire in each grand Divi≈øion. Which being brought into that form, each Captain may draw off his men, being ≈øo commanded by the Major, and compleat up his Company again, and be after di≈øpo≈øed of to farther duty, or to march home to their Quarters according to command. And here I ≈øhall conclude this Regiment of eight Companies.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. The manner of drawing up a Regiment con≈øi≈øting of ten Companies, having in it ≈øeven Captains, and three Field-Officers, being in each particular Company the former numbers, which in all amounts unto 1198 men.
div.p: THe Major having ground ≈øufficient for the drawing up the Regiment, after the Colonels Company hath made Alt, next to him upon the left he draws up the younge≈øt Captain, which is the tenth; and the next to him the third Captain, which is the ≈øixth; after that the fourth Captain, which is the ≈øeventh; then the fir≈øt Captain, which is the fourth: then the Majors, which is the third; next to him the fifth Captain, which is the eighth; and after that the ≈øecond Captain, which is the fifth; then the ≈øixth Captain, which is the ninth. All the≈øe being drawn up upon the left of the Colonels Company, the clo≈øier of all upon the left, is the Lieutenant-Colonels Company, who≈øe figure carries the number 2. Place now all the≈øe numbers of Dignity according to the former Figures, and they will ≈øtand as followeth in a Rank.

In the next place compare the Dignity of the right Half-ranks with the left, and they are ballanced as neer as can be po≈ø≈øible to be equal, there being one odd, which of nece≈ø≈øity mu≈øt be ca≈øt upon the right Half-ranks, for the rea≈øons formerly expre≈øt, in placing the ≈øecond Captain into the Lieutenant-Colonels Divi≈øion. Then according to the former rule, draw forth the Pikes, and ingro≈øs them into two Bodies, and the like of the Muskettiers; after ≈øub-divide the Muskettiers, and make them four divi≈øions, and move them up to flank the Pikes, and then they will be in two compleat grand Divi≈øions. In the next place, let the Major order forth unto the Captains and Lieutenants their ≈øeveral places to lead and to bring up, after this manner. There being two grand Divi≈øions, having in them five Captains, and five Lieutenants, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to appoint our five ≈øeveral Charges in the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion to lead, and five to bring up, after this manner. As fir≈øt, divide the Van-guard into two Divi≈øions, the fir≈øt to be led by the Captain-Lieutenant, and brought up by his Bringer-up: the ≈øecond Divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the Van to be led by the third Captains Lieutenant, and to be brought up by the fourth Captains Lieutenant. The fir≈øt divi≈øion of Pikes is to have the three fir≈øt Colours to fly upon the head of them, and to be led by the elde≈øt Captain, and brought up by the ≈øeventh Captains Lieutenant: the next divi≈øion of Pikes to be led by the fourth Captain, having his own and the elde≈øt Captains Colours flying upon the head of them, and to be brought up by the ≈øeventh, or younge≈øt Captain in the Regiment: the Reer-guard of Muskettiers of the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion to be led by the third Captain, and brought up by the elde≈øt Captains Lieutenant, who upon the Long-march the≈øe two are to inter-change places if the third Captain de≈øire it, and having ≈øuch permi≈ø≈øion from the Major, being more honour to bring up, then to lead, as was ≈øaid before in the former Regiments.

Next follows the placing of the Officers in the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion: let the Van-guard of Muskettiers there be led by the Majors Lieutenant, or by him≈øelf when he plea≈øeth, and be brought up by the fifth Captains Lieutenant: next let the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes be led by the fifth Captain; having two Colours flying in the head of them, the Majors, and his own, and to be brought up by the ≈øixth Captains Lieutenant: let the next Divi≈øion of Pikes be led by the ≈øecond Captain, having three Colours flying on the head of them, the Lieutenant-Colonels, his own, and the ≈øixth Captains, and let that be brought up by the ≈øecond Captains Lieutenant: let the la≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers be led by the ≈øixth Captain, and brought up by the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant; the Lieutenant-Colonel upon the Long-march bringing up the Reer of the Regiment, ≈øome 12 foot behind his own Lieutenant.

I ≈øhall in the next place ≈øhew the Rea≈øons for the thus placing of the Officers, where fir≈øt I ≈øhall endeavour to clear the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion, which will occa≈øion the ≈øecond to be more ea≈øily re≈øolved. Where briefly thus, as concerning the Colonel, elde≈øt Captain, third Captain, and Captain-Lieutenant, I ≈øhall pa≈øs them over, having formerly ≈øpoken ≈øufficient to ≈øatisfie any Souldier therein. It follows therefore to ≈øpeak of the fourth Captains place, which is the next man of Honour after the former, and therefore is placed to lead the ≈øecond Divi≈øion of Pikes, which is more honour to him to lead there, then to lead a ≈øub-divi≈øion of Muskettiers. In the Van-guard next to him in Honour in this Divi≈øion, is the ≈øeventh Captain, who is appointed to bring up the fir≈øt grand Body of Pikes, which likewi≈øe is more Honour unto him, then to lead or bring up any ≈øub-divi≈øion of Muskettiers; as before expre≈ø≈øed. Having thus re≈øolved of all the Captains, and Captain-Lieutenants place, next follows the rea≈øons of the Lieutenants places; where fir≈øt take notice that the elde≈øt Captains Lieutenant is appointed to bring up the Reer-guard, which next the Pikes is the greate≈øt place of honor in the reer, and a very honorable place unto him; or if he alters places with the third Captain upon the Long-march, yet neverthele≈øs he hath the chiefe≈øt place of honour after the Capt. Lieut. among≈øt all the Lieutenants unto tho≈øe places he is ordered unto. The third Captains Lieutenant is a≈ø≈øigned to the next place, who leads the ≈øecond Divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the Van-guard, which is more honour to him then to bring up any ≈øuch Divi≈øion; after follows him the fourth Captains Lieutenant, who brings up the Reer of the Van-guard, which is more honour to him, of the places remaining, to be there, then to bring up either the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, or the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes. La≈øtly, the ≈øeventh Captains Lieutenant is placed to bring up the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes, which being the more honourable Arms, it adds more honour to him to be there to bring up, then the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, which being the la≈øt place of honour, it is given to the Captain-Lieutenants Bringer-up to be there. And thus much ≈øhall ≈øuffice for the rea≈øons of the places of the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion.

Now for placing of the Officers of the ≈øecond grand Divi≈øion, I ≈øhall not need to ≈øpeak any thing concerning the Lieutenant-Colonels Major, Second Captain, and the Majors Lieutenants place, in regard in the former Regiments I have endeavoured to give the Souldier ≈øatisfaction therein. Therefore next to tho≈øe in this grand Divi≈øion follows to be ≈øpoken is the fifth Captain, who is the next man of honour, and therefore hath his due place appointed out to him to lead the fir≈øt divi≈øion of Pikes, where the Majors and his own Colours flie, which is more honour to him to lead there the Van of the Pikes, then the Reer-guard of Muskettiers. Next to him is the ≈øixth Captain, which next the Pikes hath his due place of honour remaining to him to lead the Reer-guard. Having thus re≈øolved the Captains places, I ≈øhall in the next endeavour to ≈øhew the Lieutenants, where fir≈øt it falls to the Lieut. Colonels Lieutenant to be placed fir≈øt, who is ordered to bring up the Reer, to be an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant unto his Lieut. Colonel, who is a Field-Officer, and may have many occa≈øions to fall off, and therefore he requires his Lieutenant to be pre≈øent with his men there, as the Colonels doth his in the Front. And as much may be ≈øaid of the Majors Lieutenant, but pa≈ø≈øing him by, I come next to the ≈øecond Captains Lieutenant, who is appointed to bring up the Reer of the ≈øecond Body of Pikes, which is the greate≈øt place of honour that is in the Reer next to the Lieu. Colonels Lieutenant. After him follows the fifth Captains Lieutenant, who is placed to bring up the Reer of the Van-guard of this divi≈øion, which is more honor then to bring up the Van of the Pikes, who≈øe turn being the la≈øt place of honor, fals to him that is the younge≈øt Lieutenant, which is the ≈øixth Captains Lieutenant.:

And thus as briefly as I could I have run over all the rea≈øons for the placing of the Officers in the Regiment drawn up after this manner, that I might not be wanting unto the de≈øire of any ≈øuch who are willing to be informed therein, being always ready to employ my ≈øelf in as plain a way as I can for the benefit of all true loving Souldiers, who are concerned herein. And therefore, for their better ≈øatisfaction, let them ca≈øt their eye upon the Figure, as it is demon≈øtrated between Folio 161 and 162, where they ≈øhall ≈øee every man placed according to my former Di≈øcour≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. The manner both of the drawing up, and the order of the Long-march of Colonel Rainsborough his Regiment, bringing up the Reer of the Foot of the Army under the Command of the Lord General Fairfax, at their fir≈øt marching through the City of London, on the ≈øeventh of Augu≈øt, 1647.
div.p: THe fir≈øt order of drawing up the Regiment at their fir≈øt place of Randevous, before they marched or joyn'd with the Army, was thus: The Colonels Company being upon the out-mo≈øt part of the right of the Regiment; next to his left by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion was drawn up the ≈øecond, ≈øixth, fifth, and fir≈øt Captain, which make up his Divi≈øion, or the right Half-ranks in their fir≈øt drawing up to be compleat, and may in their Figure of Dignity ≈øtanding in a rank be demon≈øtrated as followeth, 4:8:9:5:1: This number of Worth being ca≈øt up, amounteth to 27. And thus much for the Colonels Divi≈øion.

Now for the left Half-ranks, or Lieutenant-Colonels Divi≈øion, (as many times it is ≈øo ordred and appointed) his own Company being drawn up upon the outmo≈øt part on the left of the Regiment; and next to his right after each other is drawn up the third, ≈øeventh, fourth, and Majors Company; who≈øe Figure of Dignity ≈øtanding Rank-wi≈øe, may be thus de≈øcribed, 2:6:10:7:3: and their number of Dignity in all amounteth to 28. Where you may perceive a rule that the Di≈øcretion of the Major walketh by, in the drawing up of the Regiment, to ballance with as neer proportion as he can the Number, Worth, and Dignity of his right Half-ranks, or right Flank, ≈øutable with that of the left. For it would be unrea≈øonable that all the be≈øt men ≈øhould be on the right, and that the left of the Regiment who are to oppo≈øe the Enemies right ≈øhould have the weake≈øt or meane≈øt men of Worth: therefore without all que≈øtion, that Body of men that ≈øhall be drawn up ≈øo as to make all parts of equal Worth, and Strength, as the right Flank with the left, the Front with the Reer, ≈øo that where-ever the Enemy ≈øhall fall on to charge any one of the≈øe parts, being all made equal in Strength, and Worth, it mu≈øt needs prevent all murmuring complaints, and carry be≈øt approbation to all knowing Commanders. And thus much briefly may be ≈øpoken in the commendation of the ordring of his Regiment thus far.

The Captains now ≈øtanding by their own Colours, on the head of the Pikes, and their Companies being drawn up all, and ≈øtanding in an even Front, the Major next commands the Muskettiers to ≈øtand, the Pikes and Colours to troop forth ≈øome ten or twelve paces cleer of the Muskettiers, and then they likewi≈øe to ≈øtand, and after to clo≈øe their Files to the mid≈øt to order.

Next he commands the Muskettiers in their Files to clo≈øe outward to order, commanding them afterward to move up, and flank the Pikes, after which he orders the Body into thirteen remarkable Divi≈øions, four Divi≈øions of Muskettiers upon each ≈øide of the Pikes, and the Pikes into five divi≈øions, having their Colours fly by two and two, and to be led by the En≈øign-bearers that do belong to each of them, excepting the fir≈øt and middle divi≈øions, for they have Leaders in chief, as the fir≈øt and fifth Captain, and the third Captain, to bring up the Reer of the whole Body of Pikes. For more fuller illu≈øtration of the leading and bringing up of each divi≈øion in the Regiment upon their Long-march, ob≈øerve the≈øe following directions.

1 The Regiment being upon their march, the fir≈øt divi≈øion upon the right is led by the Colonel, his Captain-Lieutenant marching in the Reer of him ≈øeveral paces, and that particular divi≈øion is brought up by the Captains-Lieutenants Bringer-up.
2 The ≈øecond divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the ≈øecond Captain-Lieutenant, and brought up by the fir≈øt, or elde≈øt Captains-Lieutenant.
3 The third divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the ≈øixth Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant.
4 The fourth divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the fifth Captains Lieutenant, and brought up by the fourth Captain.
5 The fir≈øt divi≈øion of Pikes is led by the elde≈øt Captain, having the Colonels, and ≈øecond Captains Colours flying in the head of them.

This Regiment being thus drawn up, they ≈øtand in the length of their Front or Battalia, 150 abre≈øt, and ≈øix in their depth, having two thirds of Muskettiers, and one of Pikes, their number amounting in all to 900 men; each particular Company con≈øi≈øting of fifteen Files, and containing in each of them 90 men a piece; but the Field-Officers Companies are many times larger.
6 The ≈øecond divi≈øion of Pikes is led by the fifth and ≈øixth Captains En≈øigns, having their own Colours flying upon the head of the ≈øame.
7 The third Divi≈øion of Pikes is led by the fifth Captain, having the Majors and elde≈øt Captains Colours flying upon the head of the ≈øame.
8 The fourth divi≈øion of Pikes is led by the fourth and ≈øeventh Captains En≈øigns, having their own Colours flying upon the head of the ≈øame.

9 The fifth and la≈øt Divi≈øion of Pikes is led by the Lieutenant-Colonels, and third Captains En≈øigns, having likewi≈øe their own Colours flying upon the head of the ≈øame; and the Reer of the Pikes is brought up by the third Captain.
10 The fir≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers on the left Flank is led by the ≈øecond Captain, and brought up by the fourth Captains Lieutenant.
11 The ≈øecond upon the left is led by the third Captains Lieutenant, and brought up by the Majors Lieutenant.
12 The third divi≈øion is led by the ≈øeventh Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant.
13 The fourth or la≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant, and the Reer of the Regiment is brought up by the Lieutenant-Colonel.

Notwith≈øtanding I have thus laid down the manner of the Divi≈øions, with the placing of the Officers, there are al≈øo from all the≈øe divi≈øions both of the Pikes and Muskettiers, ≈øub-divi≈øions drawn off upon the Long-march betwixt every fifth or ≈øixth File, as they can equally divide them with even proportions to march. And for the leading of ≈øuch divi≈øions, there are Serjeants ca≈øt in that properly belong unto them which do lead and bring them up; ≈øo that upon this accompt they make in their Long-regimental-march ≈øome thirty divi≈øions, by rea≈øon, as I conceive, upon any Alt, or convenient place of drawing them all up even abre≈øt, the Serjeants as well as the ≈øuperiour-Officers may be helpful to bring up the File-leaders again as at the fir≈øt into their proper places. And thus far I have endeavoured for the ≈øatisfaction of all ingenious Souldiers to ≈øet forth the manner of Colonel Rainsboroughs Regiment of their drawing up, di≈øpo≈øing of Colours, and placing of Officers, as was the Ob≈øervation of my ever-honor'd Friend, and mo≈øt exqui≈øite knowing Souldier Thomas Walker, one of the Captains of the ≈øame Regiment, and a true lover of the Military-art, who frienly communicated to me the practi≈øe of their Regiment. Which although it differs from the drawing up of all others in our Army (as I am inform'd, they varying in one kinde or other by their ≈øeveral ways) I que≈øtion not, but this may be as good as any of the re≈øt, which I leave to the judgment of the curious ≈øearchers into this Art, whil≈øt I proceed to ≈øhew the Figures following.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. A third way of drawing up a Regiment of Ten Companies, after the manner u≈øed amongst the Swedes.
div.p: THe Companies meeting altogether, whether it be in the Alarum place, otherwi≈øe at their general Randezvous, where they have ground and room ≈øufficient enough for their drawing up: The Major appointing forth unto the Lieutenant-Colonels Company a place mo≈øt convenient to ≈øtand, he draws all the re≈øt of the Companies upon the left of him after this manner. The ≈øeventh and the ≈øecond Captain, then the Colonel, after him the ≈øixth, fourth, and fir≈øt Captain, then the Major, after him the fifth and third Captain, who clo≈øes up the left of the whole Regiment; the figures of their Dignity ≈øtanding after this manner.

Here you may perceive they follow a rule to Ballance their number of Dignity as neer as they can, carrying their odd number on the left Half-rank, and not upon the right; for the≈øe rea≈øons, as, I conceive, following. Their Regiments being ≈øo full of men, they draw them up for the mo≈øt part into three Squadrons,
or grand divi≈øions, giving unto the Lieutenant-Colonel the right Wing; the Major, the left; and the Colonel, the Main-battail. The Colonels grand Divi≈øion con≈øi≈øts of the four middle Companies, where you are to take notice, being drawn off ≈øome ten paces cleer from the re≈øt they ≈øtand after this manner by way of Figure, 4:7:9:1. The Lieutenant-Colonels Divi≈øion after this manner, 5:10:2. and the Majors after this kinde, 6:8:3. Wherein I do ob≈øerve in each grand Divi≈øion this Rule, that by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion and degrees they put the be≈øt Souldiers upon the right, and the ≈øecond according to cour≈øe upon the left, and the re≈øt between them. As fir≈øt, the Colonel being the chiefe≈øt man of honour, is placed upon the right of his Squadron; next to his left is the ≈øixth and fourth Captain, and the clo≈øing up of his grand Divi≈øion is placed the fir≈øt or elde≈øt Captain. The Lieutenant-Colonel being the ≈øecond man of honour, is likewi≈øe placed upon the right of his Squadron; and next to his left, the ≈øeventh Captain, his grand Divi≈øion being clo≈øed up by the ≈øecond Captain. In the next place, the Major, he being the third man of honour, is placed upon the right of his Squadron; and upon hisleft, the fifth Captain; and his grand Divi≈øion is clo≈øed up upon the left by the third Captain. So that you may ob≈øerve in the clo≈øing up of every Divi≈øion, that as every Field-Officer is upon the right of their Squadrons, ≈øo they take by degrees upon the outmo≈øt of their left to clo≈øe their Divi≈øions, the Captains according to their degrees by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion. As fir≈øt, and more cleerly, the Colonel takes the elde≈øt Captain to him on his left, who will aptly fall in to lead his Body of Pikes and Colours; the Lieutenant-Colonel takes the ≈øecond Captain for to lead his Stand of Pikes and Colours; the third Captain being placed upon the left of the outmo≈øt part of the Majors Squadron, to lead likewi≈øe his Colours and Body of Pikes. And further, if you ob≈øerve the number of worth and dignity, that the right Wing hath with the left, you will finde them to be equally ballanced, and to be ≈øeventeen alike in number. Now in re≈øpect there cannot be an equal Divi≈øion of the Colours by threes, there is very good rea≈øon that the odd ≈øhould be placed in the Colonels Squadron, who is Commander in chief, and to whom it properly belongs unto.

In the next place, I ≈øhall ≈øhew you how to draw them forth in a Regimental-way; the four middle Companies being advanced forward ten paces cleer form the three outmo≈øt Companies, may ≈øtand; then draw forth the Pikes of each Squadron, until they be ten foot cleer of their Muskettiers; then clo≈øe Pikes into the mid≈øt to Order in their Files in each Divi≈øion, and they will be in three Bodies; after clo≈øe the Muskettiers into the mid≈øt to Order, then ≈øub-divide them in as equal a way as you can; and let them move up upon the right and left, and flank each Body of Pikes. Then let the Major examine the Files in the Colonels Divi≈øion, how many they exceed in number the other two, and he will finde twelve Files of Muskettiers, and ≈øix Files of Pikes, more then in the re≈øt. Now to make them equal alike in each Squadron, let him take off from each particular Company of the Colonels Squadron, one File of Pikes, and place two of tho≈øe four in the mid≈øt of the Lieutenant-Colonels Squadron, and the remaining two in the mid≈øt of his own Squadron; which being done, each body of Pikes will have in it 22 Files. After let him take off from each Company two Files of Muskettiers, which will be eight Files, & let him place two Files in the mid≈øt of each Flank of Muskettiers, both in the Divi≈øions of the Lieutenant-Colonels and his own; and then there will be in each particular Divi≈øion of Muskettiers 21 Files. This being likewi≈øe a very good way to draw up a Regiment of ≈øo great a number of men, I was unwilling to pa≈øs it by, but to pre≈øent it unto the view of all loving Souldiers, which will more fuller appear in the Figure following (Folio 167) in which Figure I ≈øhall ≈øhew the ≈øeveral places of the Captains, and their Lieutenants, where they are to lead, and where to bring up.

div.head: CHAP. IX. The way of drawing up a Regiment con≈øi≈øting of twelve Companies, the nine Captains having eighteen Files in each Company, and the three Field-Officers every one of them twenty four Files; whereof, there are two thirds of Muskettiers, and one of Pikes, in each particular Company, amounting in all to 1404 men.
div.p: THe Major having convenient place, he fir≈øt orders where the Colonels Company is to ≈øtand, and after draws all the re≈øt of the Companies upon the left of him, after this manner: The ninth, the fourth, the third, the ≈øixth, and the fir≈øt Captains; then the Major, next the ≈øeventh, the fifth, the ≈øecond, and the eighth Captains, and the outmo≈øt of all upon the left, the Lieutenant-Colonels Company, in manner of the dignity of a Rank, as they thus ≈øtand.

The dignity of places cannot be better ≈øtated, then in this of twelve Companies; as fir≈øt, the Right-half-ranks is equal with the left in number of dignity. Again, divide them into three parts, and their number of dignity falls out to carry along with it an equal number of twenty ≈øix all even alike. Con≈øider likewi≈øe, the ≈øtating of every Captain in the Regiment, and they are qualified equal throughout, the be≈øt and the younge≈øt Souldiers joyned together, as by examining them how they ≈øtand by two's, their number of worth and dignity throughout carries thirteen all equal alike. In the next place, draw forth all the Pikes, and ingro≈øs them into two Bodies; then divide the Muskettiers into
four parts, and move them up, and Flank tho≈øe Stands of Pikes, and they will be in two grand Divi≈øions; then, place the Officers after this manner; beginning fir≈øt with the Colonels divi≈øion, make two Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in his Van, let the fir≈øt be led by the Captain Lieutenant, and be brought up by his Bringer-up; let the next Divi≈øion of Muskettiers be led by the fourth Captains Lieutenant, and brought up by the third Captains Lieutenant; let the Pikes be divided into three Divi≈øions, the Colours flying two and two upon the head of them‚ñ™ let the fir≈øt Divi≈øion be led by the elde≈øt Captain, and brought up by the ninth Captains Lieutenant; let the next Divi≈øion be led by the ≈øixth Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant; let the la≈øt Divi≈øion be led by the fourth Captain, and the whole Body of Pikes be brought up by the ninth Captain. Then let the Reer-guard of the Colonels Divi≈øion be led by ≈øuch ob≈øervations as is ≈øet forth in other Regiments, by the third Captain, and brought up by the fir≈øt Captains Lieutenant.

Having placed the Officers in the fir≈øt grand Divi≈øion, he may proceed unto the next; let the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers be led by the Majors-Lieutenant, and brought up by the fifth Captains Lieutenant. Let the Pikes be divided into three parts, the Colours likewi≈øe flying, two and two upon the head of them; then let the fir≈øt Divi≈øion be led by the fifth Captain, and brought up by the eighth Captains Lieutenant; next let the ≈øecond Divi≈øion be led by the eighth Captain, and brought up by the ≈øeventh Captains Lieutenant. La≈øtly, let the third Divi≈øion be led by the ≈øecond Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant; let the la≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers be led by the ≈øeventh Captain, and brought up by the Lieutenant-Colonels Lieutenant: The Colonel is to be on the head of his Divi≈øion, and the Lieutenant-Colonel upon the head of his, and the Major between them both in the Front. The Officers before they are thus placed, are to have their grand Divi≈øions of both Arms equally ballanced for number of worth, ob≈øerving ≈øtill the former Rules in the execution of the ≈øame. It might be here expected I ≈øhould ≈øhew rea≈øons for the thus placing of the Officers, after this manner: but to ≈øatisfie ≈øuch, if they plea≈øe but to ob≈øerve and take notice of the rea≈øons given in the former Regiments, which will give ≈øatisfaction unto this, carrying with it the ≈øame order and way. And likewi≈øe it might be expected, that I ≈øhould here ≈øet forth a Figure for the thus drawing them up as before expre≈øt, and placing of the ≈øeveral Officers. But ≈øince this Regiment falls out to be ≈øo full in number, I ≈øhall ≈øet it forth after the manner of drawing up a Brigade, according to the Swedi≈øh practi≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XX. The manner of drawing up a Regiment according to the Swedi≈øh Brigade.
div.p: AFter that the Major hath plac'd the Lieutenant-Colonels Company in ≈øuch a convenient place, that he may draw all the re≈øt up on the left of him, he thus proceeds in bringing up the Companies; he fir≈øt places to him the eighth Captain, then the fifth, after that the ≈øecond, then the Colonels Company, next to him the ninth Captain, then the ≈øixth Captain, and fir≈øt Captain; after the Majors, then the ≈øeventh Captain, after the fourth Captain; then upon the outmo≈øt part of the le≈øt, is placed the third Captain, in manner and form as they thus ≈øtand.

Having thus far proceeded, he may command the four outmo≈øt Companies upon each Flank, to advance forward ≈øome ten paces cleer from the four middle Companies; then let them ≈øtand, and after let him draw forward the Pikes cleer from the Muskettiers, and clo≈øe their Files outward to Order; then let the
Muskettiers be divided into four parts, their Files being clo≈øed to Order, let them move forward, and flank tho≈øe two Bodies of Pikes. After in the ≈øame manner move forward the Pikes in the four middle Companies, until they be cleer of the Muskettiers, and clo≈øe their Files into the mid≈øt to Order, and divide their Muskettiers into two parts, and let them move forward, and flank the Body of Pikes; and then they will ≈øtand in their Squadrons or grand Divi≈øions, their dignities ≈øtanding after this manner in the Colonels divi≈øion, thus, 4:9:12:1. In the Lieutenant-Colonels divi≈øion, thus, 5:8:11:2. and in the the Majors, thus, 6:7:10:3. So that you may perceive this to be a very good way among≈øt the re≈øt, each particular Squadron bearing the number of 26, and having unto every one of them their Dignities and worths equally divided, and ≈øtated alike. In the next place, the Major ought to inquire of the number of men they carry in each divi≈øion of both Arms; where as fir≈øt, he ≈øhall finde in the Colonels Squadron, to have in it 26 Files of Pikes, and 52 Files of Muskettiers; and examining all the re≈øt, they will fall out to the ≈øame proportion of number. So that in each Divi≈øion there contains, whether they be Pikes, or Muskettiers, to have in every particular thereof 78 Files. In the next place, he ≈øhall do well to appoint forth unto them their ≈øeveral places to lead and bring up; and fir≈øt, of the Colonels grand Divi≈øion, he being on the head thereof, the Captain-Lieutenant leading the fir≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers in his Squadron, being brought up by his Bringer-up; the fir≈øt two Colours, and his half Body of Pikes to be led by the elde≈øt Captain, and brought up by the ninth Captains Lieutenant; the next two Colours, and half Body of Pikes to be led by the ninth Captain, and brought up by the elde≈øt Captains Lieutenant; the la≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers in his Squadron, to be led by the ≈øixth Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant. The fir≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the Lieutenant-colonels Squadron, is led by his own Lieutenant, and brought up by the eighth Captains Lieutenant; his fir≈øt two Colours, and half Body of Pikes is led by the ≈øeventh Captain; and the next two Colours, and half Body of Pikes, is led by the eigthth Captain, and brought up by the ≈øecond Captains Lieutenant; his la≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the fifth Captain, and brought up by his own Lieutenant; him≈øelf ≈øtanding as the Colonel doth upon the head of his Squadron. The fir≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers in the Majors Squadron (him≈øelf being upon the head) is led by his own Lieutenant, and brought up by the ≈øeventh Captains Lieutenant; his fir≈øt two Colours, and half Body of Pikes is led by the third Captain; and the next two Colours, and half Body of Pikes, is led by the ≈øeventh Captain, and brought up by the third Captains Lieutenant; his la≈øt divi≈øion of Muskettiers is led by the fourth Captain, and brought up by his Lieutenant; as in the next place, in the Figure ≈øet forth in Folio 170, more fully appeareth.

They ≈øtanding according to the former directions in three Bodies of Pikes flanked with the Muskettiers, before they come to the Figure ≈øet forth, you mu≈øt command in each grand divi≈øion the ≈øix inmo≈øt Files of Muskettiers next the Pikes to face about, and to march ≈øix paces cleer of the Reer, and then clo≈øe inward to Order. Afterward open every four Files outward to open Order, of tho≈øe 12 Files, and let the middle-divi≈øion there face about, and move down ≈øix foot cleer of the Reer; and after face to their Leader. Then there will remain 20 Files of Muskettiers upon the Flanks of each Body of Pikes; after move forward the eight middle Files of particular divi≈øion of Muskettiers, ≈øome ten foot before the Front. Then command the left-half-ranks, or the four Files of Muskettiers upon the left of tho≈øe divi≈øions drawn forth, to face about, and to move down ten foot cleer of the Reer, and after face to the Front. Then let the 12 remaining Files of Muskettiers clo≈øe to the Pikes to open Order; and let every four Files of tho≈øe remaining 12 upon the Flanks, open outward ≈øix foot of ground betwixt each four Files, and move the Front and Reer-divi≈øions of Muskettiers ju≈øt again≈øt the mid≈øt of tho≈øe three divi≈øions of Muskettiers that are the Flankers to the Pikes, and they will ≈øtand in the Figure as it is placed in Folio 170.

They ≈øtanding now in a perfect Order of a Brigade, the number of men in this Regiment allowing it in a full manner, according to the ≈ømall Brigades of the Swedes; I ≈øhall not need to point out of what ≈øervice this Figure, or drawing up may be, in re≈øpect there is no ingenious Souldier, but may cleerly perceive they ≈øtand in a very good Order to fight again≈øt an Enemy; their Commanders being appointed forth to manage it accordingly. Therefore I ≈øhall leave it to the practi≈øe of ≈øuch who in time of need ≈øhall have occa≈øion to make u≈øe of it; and in the next place ≈øhew the manner of reducing them again into Companies.

Fir≈øt move forward tho≈øe 12 Files of Muskettiers in the Reer of each body of Pikes, ≈øix to the right, and ≈øix to the left, next to the out≈øide of their own body of Pikes: After command the Reer-divi≈øions of Muskettiers to advance forward upon the left of tho≈øe Divi≈øions of Muskettiers in the Front; then face them about, and move them down into the mid≈øt of tho≈øe Muskettiers that were the Flankers. After let every Captain draw off his Pikes and Muskettiers, and ingro≈øs them into particular Companies, and they will then be ready to march away to their ≈øeveral Quarters. And here I ≈øhall conclude concerning a Regiment of twelve Companies.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. The manner of drawing up a Brigade or Tertia, being a third part of an Army, according to the practi≈øe of the Netherlands, under the command of the Prince of Orange.
div.p: BEfore I ≈øhall begin to draw up this Tertia, Army, or Brigade; I ≈øhall ≈øet down the ob≈øervation of Col. Hen. Hexam, in his Book treating of the Office of the three Serjeant-Majors of the Tertia, otherwi≈øe called the three Field-Corporals. His words are the≈øe:

p.hi: The States Army by order of his Highne≈øs, is divided upon a March into three Brigades or Tertia's; and a Serjeant-Major of a Tertia, being one of the great Captains of the Field, receives his Order immediate from the Lord-General, or the Lord Martial, but mo≈øt commonly of the Serjeant-Major-General of the Army, how he ≈øhall form and order his Brigade or Tertia; and how many Regiments of Hor≈øe and Foot are to march under it, and with what Ordnance and Baggage. He a≈ø≈øigns and ≈øhews him the place where they are to draw out into Battalia, and receives Orders from the Serjeant-Major-General, whether they are to march in the Van-guard, the Battail, or the Reer: So that in marching in every one of the≈øe, he ≈øhall attend upon his Brigade and ≈øeveral Divi≈øions; and in the ab≈øence of the Serjeant-Major-General, ≈øee that the order of marching and embattailing be duly kept and ob≈øerved. And every one of the≈øe three Serjeants-Majors of Brigades, are to be at the command of the Colonel, General, or be that leads or commands that Brigade or Tertia; and is to be ≈øent to the Lord-General, Lord-Martial, or Serjeant-Major-General upon any occa≈øion belonging to the ≈øervice.

The≈øe three Majors of the Tertia's are to be lodged as neer the Serjeant-Major-General, as conveniently may be; and tho≈øe three which attend upon the Van-guard, the Battail or Reer, which the Serjeant-Major ≈øhall make choice of ground for the placing of Guards, and a≈ø≈øign them to the Serjeant-Majors of every Regiment. They are to go the Round, and to vi≈øit the Guard commonly every night, and at ≈øuch an hour as the Serjeant-Major ≈øhall appoint them either by day or night.

If any of the≈øe three Serjeant-Majors of the Field ≈øhall finde any want of Powder, Ammunition or Victuals, either in the Van-guard, Battail or Reer, as well upon the march, as when the Troops are quartered, or during fight, he is pre≈øently to adverti≈øe the Serjeant-Major-General of the Field with the ≈øaid wants. And then by his direction ≈øhall go with an Officer of every Regiment of that Tertia, to the General, or Lieutenant of the Ordnance, or to the Commi≈ø≈øary General of the Ammunition, or Victuals.

A Serjeant-Major of a Tertia, to conclude, having received his Orders from the Lord-General, the Martial, or Serjeant-Major-general, gives them to the Serjeant-Majors of every particular Regiment. But becau≈øe the Word and Orders are to be ≈øent to Quarters far di≈øtant one from another, the Serjeant-Major of every Regiment cannot
come conveniently to the Serjeant-Major-General. Therefore the Majors of every Brigade are to attend every morning and evening upon the Serjeant-Major-General, to receive their Orders, and to carry the Word to the ≈øeveral Quarters, whither the Serjeant-Majors of Regiments comes to him, and from him receives the Word and Orders.

div.p: The drawing up of Brigades in the next place comes to be handled after the way of the Hollanders; therefore, fir≈øt take notice, that Brigades are not tyed to a ≈øet number of Companies or Regiments, but are ordered according to the ≈øeveral ≈øtrengths of an Army. As ≈øometimes they con≈øi≈øt of 12 Companies, ≈øome of two Regiments, others of three, or four, having in them not alike number of Companies or men, which ought accordingly unto the ≈øeveral Divi≈øions of a Brigade to be ballanced alike, both in number of men, dignity, and worth, as is in particular Regiments fully ≈øet forth. And in re≈øpect that ≈øeveral Divi≈øions make a Brigade, and that according to the di≈øpo≈øition of an Army, all the Officers and Souldiers are divided into three parts, called Brigades or Tertia's, each of them having a ≈øeveral name; to wit, the Van-guard, Battail and Reer-guard. Now that Tertia which is to march fir≈øt, is called the Van-guard; that which marcheth next in the middle, the Battail; and that which comes up la≈øt, the Reer. Every one of the≈øe upon march, as was formerly expre≈ø≈øed in the Swedi≈øh Brigade, take their turns interchangeably; for the ≈øecond day of the March, the Battail becomes the Van-guard; and the Reer, the ≈øecond day the Battail; and the third day, the Tertia, that had fir≈øt the Reer, is become the Van-guard. So likewi≈øe, there ought to be in every particular Brigade or Tertia, a Van-guard, Battail and Reer-guard, to each of them; which with more conveniencie may be orderly brought to fight by him that ≈øhall be Commander in chief, for the relieving each other, according as occa≈øion ≈øhall require.

In the next place, for a Brigade, I ≈øhall point forth four Regiments, having in them eight Companies a piece, after the manner of a Regiment of eight formerly ≈øet down, which amounts to 3888 men, which number may ≈øerve for a third part of an Army of foot, and make up a very compleat and ≈øufficient Brigade. And I ≈øhall order in this Brigade to have in it four Divi≈øions; that is to ≈øay, a Van-guard, Battail and Reer-guard, repre≈øented in the three fir≈øt Regiments; but the fourth ≈øhall be a re≈øerve, ≈øtanding in the Reer of the Main-battail or Brigade, whereby upon all occa≈øions of the other retreating, or being driven backward, that Regiment may move up to relieve each part thereof that ≈øhall be di≈øtre≈ø≈øed. But upon the Long-march of this Brigade, the two middle Regiments according to their order of dignity, are to make the Battail, which in the Figure were made the Van-guard, and Reer-guard; and that which formerly was the Van-guard, is become the Battail; and the Reer-guard, the Re≈øerve; but where they have ground ≈øufficient, it will be better to march in that form of Battalia, ≈øet down according to the Figure, Folio 176.

This Brigade con≈øi≈øting of four Regiments, mu≈øt be drawn up according to the dignity of their Captains; but with this alteration of Arms, for the former Regiments con≈øi≈øting of two Divi≈øions, this hath but one, after this manner:

div.head: CHAP. XXII. How to draw up an Army of twelve Regiments of Foot, and three of Hor≈øe, the Foot amounting unto 11664 men, and the Hor≈øe unto 3000; in all 14664 men.
div.p:
THe drawing up or an Army mo≈øt properly belongs to the Serjeant-Major-General, who≈øe place and charge is of an high degree, his commands being
full of action, and therefore ought to be a wi≈øe, grave, and able per≈øon, and an experienced Souldier, in re≈øpect he hath the ordering and di≈øpo≈øing of the Divi≈øions and Battalions, according to that form which the General ≈øhall command him. And upon all occa≈øions he mu≈øt be active, and ≈øtirring up and down to ≈øpie out all advantages which might offend an Enemy; and wi≈øely to fore≈øee all di≈øadvantages that may bring the Troops into any di≈øorder or confu≈øion. He hath ab≈øolute command over the three Serjeant-Majors of the Brigades, otherwi≈øe called the three Grand Corporals of the Field, who are to be his a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, and his mouth, as he is the mouth of the Lord General, or Martial of the Field; and therefore mu≈øt have a vigilant eye over all things, ≈øeeing that the Generals command delivered to him be ≈øtrictly kept and ob≈øerved; and withall acquainting and informing the three Serjeant-Majors of the Brigades of the Generals plea≈øure, that they may forthwith put the ≈øame into execution.

Now the Method (that I ≈øhall ob≈øerve) ≈øhall be according to the form of the former Brigade; wherefore in the fir≈øt place, the Serjeant-Major ≈øhall do well to appoint out unto the elde≈øt Serjeant-Major of the Brigades, how to draw up that Brigade which ≈øhall be the Battail, wherein the Lord Generals Regiment, and the Colonels is to be upon the right and left of that Brigade, and betwixt them the elde≈øt Colonel, and ninth Colonel, according to this rule of Dignity in the Figure ≈øet forth, 4:9:12:1. In the next place, let the next Serjeant-Major of the Brigades in ≈øeniority draw up that which ≈øhall be the Van-guard, and place the ≈øecond Colonels Regiment upon the right, and the fifth upon the left, and between them the eleventh and eighth Colonels, after this manner of this Figure, 5:8:11:2. Let the la≈øt Serjeant-Major draw up that Brigade which ≈øhall be in the Reer, and let him draw them up after this manner; the third Colonels Regiment upon the right; and upon the left the ≈øixth Colonels; and between them the tenth and ≈øeventh Colonels Regiment after this manner, 6:7:10:3: This charge being given by the Serjeant-Major-General unto the three Serjeant-Majors of the three Tertias or Brigades, how each particular Regiment ≈øhall be drawn up, being every one ≈øingle, and compared alike each to other, being rightly ≈øtated according to the rule of Dignity, avoiding thereby confu≈øion and di≈øorder. In the next place, for the better expedition in drawing up the Army, every Serjeant-Major of each Brigade draws the former Regiments a≈ø≈øigned unto them, unto ≈øuch place as ≈øhall be appointed forth unto them by the Serjeant-Major-General, being helped and a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Field-Officers of the ≈øame Regiments, the Serjeant-Major-General being an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant unto them all, ≈øeeing thereby all the Commands of the General rightly ob≈øerved and fulfilled.

figure.head: AN ARMY OF FOOT, OR THREE SINGLE BRIGADS CONSISTING OF 11664 MEN, DRAWN VP AND EMBATTELLED; TOGETHER WITH THE PLACING OF THE CANNON
figure.p: Let the≈øe three Sheets be pa≈øted together at length, one after another, ≈øo that they may appear as one ≈øingle Leafe, and let them be placed between Page‚ñ™ 174 and 175.

div.p: After this, the General of the Ordnance, his duty and care mu≈øt be in the day of Battail, to ≈øee that the Ordnance be well placed; for at ≈øuch time his wi≈ødom is mo≈øt di≈øcern'd, keeping (with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his Lieutenant) the Train of Artillery together in good order. He mu≈øt have a vigilant eye upon all accidents that may fall but, and make choi≈øe of ≈øuch ground for their planting, as the General of the Army and he ≈øhall think mo≈øt fit and convenient. He mu≈øt be careful that all things be in a readine≈øs, putting the Ma≈øter, Gunners, Gentlemen of the Ordnance, and Commanders in minde of their duty, that they do their be≈øt endeavours, and acquit them≈øelves like men. It is likewi≈øe partly his charge to ≈øee that the whole Army be well provided with Ammunition, becau≈øe the Ammunition marcheth under his Train. He mu≈øt al≈øo be neer the General of the Army upon all occa≈øions, to receive his Directions and Commands, and to know from him after what manner he will make his Battail, that he may plant his Ordnance accordingly, finding out Hills and Heights to play over his own men. And when the Enemy ≈øhall pre≈øent him≈øelf, and come up to charge, he mu≈øt draw, and plant his Ordnance as neer their Hor≈øe as po≈ø≈øible may be, to hinder them from breaking in upon the Divi≈øions of Foot, taking along with him Saylours, and Pioneers, to help to draw up the Ordnance, and ≈øufficient Guards to defend them.

As concerning the planting of the Ordnance, when the Battalia is drawn up, they may be di≈øpo≈øed of ≈øeveral ways; as ≈øometimes they are placed upon the head of the Battalia; others again between them, by two and two; and others threes, upon the Flanks and Wings of the Muskettiers. Some are of opinion, that they ought to be planted upon the Flank, and in the Reer of the Battalia, by leaving a free place for Arms which may give no offence to their own men. But as concerning this la≈øt way, it might be an≈øwered, it can no way be expedient; for if an Enemy ≈øhould perceive that the Frout is left bare without Ordnance, it will give them cau≈øe to come up with more courage to fall on upon the Charge. Therefore, the be≈øt way among≈øt the ancient experienc'd Souldiers, is, that the Artillery be divided, ≈øome here, ≈øome there, both before the Front, between the Battalions, and upon the Flanks, and to be placed ≈øome 50 or an 100 paces one from another; and then there will be no danger when the Enemy ≈øhall come up to ≈øhock to encounter you, or to offend our own men: E≈øpecially, when they are fa≈øtned to them by drawing Ropes and Iron Rings, that upon an in≈øtant they may be removed, and turn'd for the advantage of our own Troops, giving fire as fa≈øt as they can charge and di≈øcharge again≈øt the Enemies Troops, it being a matter of great moment for the obtaining of a Victory, and gaining the day from the Enemy.

But that many times the Ordnance cannot be planted in ≈øuch convenient places as could be wi≈øhed for, in re≈øpect an Army may be driven into ≈øuch places, as the Ordnance mu≈øt be planted according to the be≈øt ground it will afford, by rea≈øon of Woods, Hills, or Mari≈øh-grounds; and ≈øuch like di≈øadvantageous places, may be oftentimes met withal; for which no certain Rule may be given, but that the General by his wi≈ødom and di≈øcretion may make choice of the be≈øt advantages, which might annoy an Enemy mo≈øt, and give the lea≈øt offence to his own men, either by dazling them by the Sun, or by rai≈øing of the du≈øt, ob≈øerving the winde which drives the Smoak both of the Ordnance and Small-≈øhot full upon them. To conclude, it is conceived the be≈øt way for every Captain of the Ordnance, and Ma≈øter-Gunner, to u≈øe ≈øome light Field-peeces and ≈ømall Drakes, which upon any occa≈øion may be removed from one place to another, being with ea≈øe planted upon ≈øuch places of advantage, as may mo≈øt annoy the Enemy.

In the next place, 3000 Hor≈øe may be a good proportion for 10000 or 12000
foot, which ought to be equally divided in their Troops, and placed upon the Flanks of the foot in ≈øuch good order, as the Troops may come with conveniencie to fight, for the relieving of each other. But in ca≈øe you ≈øhall perceive the Enemies Hor≈øe, as ≈øometimes through nece≈ø≈øity of ground, or by other political ends, may be interlaced and placed between the Intervals and Divi≈øions of their foot; it will be needful then that we ≈øhould ob≈øerve the ≈øame form, and likewi≈øe have Hor≈øe to come forth, and encounter with their Hor≈øe, le≈øt they ≈øhould break in upon our Divi≈øions of Foot; which by this means and good order, may be timely prevented. Next follows the Figure of the Army, as before de≈øcribed, and ordered to be drawn up, Folio 176.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. The ≈øeveral duties belonging to the Foot in a Regiment, as followeth by degrees from a private Souldier unto a Colonel of the ≈øame: and fir≈øt, of a Private Souldier.
div.p: A Private Souldier ought to be very active, not ≈ølothful and idle, informing him≈øelf of his duty, learning from his Corporal, or other Officers, the true u≈øe and well handling of his Arms, always keeping them neat, clean, and well fixed. Upon the beat of the Drum, he is to repair to his Colours, Squadron; or Company; upon the march, he mu≈øt ob≈øerve his Leader, and his right and lefthand-men, that he may march ≈øtreight in file, and even in rank; in time of Exerci≈øe he mu≈øt be ≈øilent in the Body, well minding the words of Command and Directions, which are given forth by the Leader. He ought likewi≈øe to be well vers'd in all the ordinary words of Command; and to mind the place wherein he ≈øtands, that he may the more readier move, and not be to ≈øeek at ≈øuch time when he ≈øhall be commanded, whether it be to face, double, counter-march, or wheel. He mu≈øt inform him≈øelf of all the ≈øeveral beats of the Drum; as fir≈øt, or a Call; ≈øecond, a Troop; third, a March; fourth, a Preparative; fifth, a Battle or Charge; ≈øixth, a Retreat, and al≈øo of the Revalley and the Tattoo.

By the fir≈øt, he is ≈øummoned to hear pre≈øent Proclamation, or el≈øe commanded to repair to his Colours; upon the beat of the ≈øecond, he is to advance his Arms, and to clo≈øe in Rank and File, to the di≈øtance of Order, and to Troop along unto ≈øuch places and ≈øervices, as he ≈øhall be commanded unto; upon the hearing of the third, he is pre≈øently to ≈øhoulder his Arms, and to take his di≈øtance of ≈øix foot in Rank, and three foot in File; upon the fourth, he is to clo≈øe both in Rank and File, unto the fighting di≈øtance, which is called Order, and to prepare him≈øelf for skirmi≈øh; upon the beat of the next, he is undauntedly to move forward, boldly ≈øtepping in good Order, into the place of his fellow-Souldier that ≈øhall happen to fall down dead before him; upon the beat of the la≈øt, he mu≈øt orderly fall back, either for relief or advantage of ground, or other political ends whereby he may draw the Enemy into a ≈ønare. The fir≈øt of the remaining two, gives warning in the morning for ≈øome of the Sentinels to fall off, or to be taken in; the latter is u≈øed in the night to give notice unto the Souldiers, or others, for their repairing to their ≈øeveral Guards, Watches, and Lodgings. To conclude, a private Souldier ought to avoid all Quarrelling, Mutinies, Swearing, Cur≈øing or Lying, and to be content with his wages; and likewi≈øe to be a good Husband in the well managing of his means, keeping him≈øelf neat and hand≈øome in his apparel; avoiding drunkenne≈øs, and all manner of gaming; truely to ≈øerve and fear God, and to be obedient unto all the commands of his ≈øuperiours, cheerfully going on upon all Duties, and to be loving, kind, and courteous unto all his fellow-Souldiers.

div.head: The duty of a Sentinel.
div.p:
A Sentinel mu≈øt be very vigilant, carefully ca≈øting his eyes about him, and harkning whether he hear the noi≈øe or approach of any drawing neer him; which if he perceive, he is pre≈øently to command them to ≈øtand, pre≈øenting his Musket or Pike to their bre≈øt, after calling his Corporal for to take the Word, unle≈øs
he ≈øhould be commanded to come in ≈øilently. He is not to come off until he be relieved by the Corporal or Lan≈øpa≈ø≈øadoe.

His proper Po≈øture, being a Muskettier, is to have his Musket re≈øted, and loaded with Powder and Bullet, his Match cockt, and his Pan guarded; being a Pike-man, if he ≈øtand Sentinel in the night, he mu≈øt have his Pike cheek'd; if in the day, his Pike ordered: Or it may be a very proper Po≈øture for a Pike-man to ≈øtand Sentinel with his Pike in his left-hand, holding it a little below the cheeks thereof, and with his Sword drawn, being held in his right-hand, which I leave to judge, or to be made u≈øe of according to di≈øcretion, and as occa≈øion ≈øhall require.

div.head: Of a Gentleman of a Company.
div.p: A Gentleman of a Company ought to have ≈øuch worth in him as may make him capable to be a File-leader, or Captain of his File; and he more e≈øpecialy above the re≈øt ought to be well skill'd in all the Po≈øtures of ≈øuch Arms he wears; and at convenient times in≈øtructing and teaching his File in the neat and graceful handling of their Arms. He ought to be of an undaunted courage and gallant re≈øolution, for the better Example and imitation of the re≈øt; who≈øe worth and valour many times indears them ≈øo much into the favour of their Commanders, that they rai≈øe them up to greater places of preferment. In the Low-Countries a Gentleman of a Company hath his full pay, having nothing kept back for after-reckonings, as common private Souldiers have. At his fir≈øt entrance he ≈øometimes ≈øtands Sentinel, to inform him≈øelf of the Duties thereof; but mo≈øt commonly he is placed to be a Sentinel perdu in time of imminent danger, either in the Field, or upon approaches. He is to lie perdu with his Sword and Pi≈øtol, not removing from his place till he be relieved; nor is he to retreat for one man, but in ca≈øe of more, then he is to fall back to the ≈øecond; and di≈øcovering an Enemy, he is to come off betimes, and ≈øilently to give the Alarum, whereby the Corps du Guard or Company may be provided for their own defence. A Gentleman of a Company doth many times go the Round with the Captain of the Watch, or his Fellow-Gentlemen, who are likewi≈øe Rounders, either in the Field, or in Garri≈øon; and do give the Corporals of the Guards the Word, charging the Sentinels to look well about them. To conclude, he ought truely to love, re≈øpect, and obey his Captain, and to ≈øtick clo≈øe unto him, vindicating him upon ju≈øt occa≈øions, when he ≈øhall be wronged and injured by any Mutinies of the common Souldiers, or others.

div.head: Of a Barber-Chyrurgion.
div.p: IN every Company there ought to be a Barber-Chyrurgion for the trimming of the Souldiers, who ought likewi≈øe to have ≈øome skill in Chyrurgery; that when the Souldiers are upon the Watches and Guards, where imminent danger may be, he may be then at hand, to be ready in the ab≈øence of the Chyrurgion of the Regiment to bind up, and dre≈øs the hurt and wounded men. He is free from duties belonging to the Company; and in ≈øome places, is allowed to be an Officer in the Li≈øt of their Armies, which I conceive it ought ≈øo to be, in re≈øpect they allow but of one Chyrurgion to a Regiment; and if it ≈øhould happen many to be wounded, as oftentimes in field-fights there are, one man is not able ≈øcarce in three days to bind up the wounds, and dre≈øs the ≈øores of them that are maimed. And therefore it concerns every Captain to be provided, and to have in the ab≈øence of the Chyrurgion, a Barber-Chyrurgion attending on his Company.

div.head: Of a Clerk of a Company.
div.p:
HIs carriage ought to be very ju≈øt and hone≈øt; his chiefe≈øt duty is to keep the Mu≈øter-Roll, and to have it ready upon all occa≈øions for the entring of his men upon the Mu≈øter-Roll, and Pay-bill. He is many times intru≈øted to receive the Service-mony of the Company, and pays ≈øuch monies unto the Souldiers as ≈øhall be ordered him from his Captain to pay. He mu≈øt inquire out in their
Quarters where they lie, and duly for to pay them, and every pay-day to deliver up a true bill, giving an account unto his Captain of all ≈øuch moneys he hath either received or paid forth.

div.head: Of a Drum-Major.
div.p: THere ought to be in every Regiment a Drum-Major, being skilful in his Profe≈ø≈øion, in≈øtructing the others in the true beating of a March, with all other points of VVar. A Drum-Major mu≈øt likewi≈øe be well skill'd in ≈øeveral Languages and Tongues, and to be wi≈øe and courteous when he ≈øhall be imploy'd or ≈øent to an Enemy: He is in a di≈øcreet manner upon the marching of a Regiment to order part of the Drums where they ≈øhall beat, ≈øeeing them truely and duly relieved by the others for the better performance of their ≈øervice. For upon the march, if all the Captains Drums ≈øhould beat together, it would quickly tire them out; therefore for their ea≈øe, it is his place and duty to order them according to di≈øcretion to take their turns to beat, and to be relieved by each other. He is, moreover, to take into his charge ≈øuch Drums as ≈øhall be brought in from the Enemies by their Drummers, when they come to ran≈øom their pri≈øoners; and upon their return to deliver them again unto them. He ought to be lodged neer the Serjeant-Major, in re≈øpect he is to give in≈øtructions to the re≈øt of the Drummers, and may upon fail of their Duties give them correction.

div.head: Of the Drummers to a private Company.
div.p: EVery Captain ought to have two good Drummers, that knows-how to beat all the ≈øeveral points of War before mentioned. It is likewi≈øe expedient that he ≈øhould be a good Lingui≈øt, in re≈øpect ≈øometimes he may be ≈øent unto an Enemy for the ran≈øoming of Pri≈øoners: His duty is, coming to the Camp or Garri≈øon of an Enemy, having his Generals Pa≈øs in his Hat, to beat a Call, till he is fetcht in; and becau≈øe he ≈øhall not di≈øcover the weakne≈øs of Guards, Works or Trenches, he is led blind-fold, and ≈øo carried to the Commander, and place where his Pri≈øoners are: VVith whom (after he hath ran≈øomed them) he is to return to his own Quarters, giving an account of ≈øuch things he hath ≈øeen or heard, which may prove advantageous to his own party, or of any other thing he had opportunity by their neglect to take notice of.

div.head: Of a Gentleman of Arms.
div.p: HIs Duty is to ≈øee that the Souldiers keep their Arms neat and clean, and that they be well fixed; and if any thing be ami≈øs or broken, he is to have them carried to the Armourers to be repaired. And if any Souldier ≈øhall be ≈øick, dead, or have leave to return to his own Country, he is to bring his Arms to his own Lodging, there pre≈øerving and keeping them clean, until he ≈øhall have occa≈øion to deliver them to ≈øome other newly entertained. He is likewi≈øe to mark and figure the Arms of the Company, and to pre≈øerve and keep a Li≈øt what number of figure each Souldier ≈øhould bear upon his Arms. He is likewi≈øe to keep the Powder, Bullet and March, and to deliver it forth upon occa≈øions to the Corporals, or Lan≈øpa≈ø≈øadoe.

div.head: Of a Lan≈øpa≈ø≈øadoe.
div.p: HIs Duty is concerned in the ab≈øence of his Corporal to officiate in all things belonging unto his place, and is at all times to be an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant unto him, for his ea≈øe and help-mate upon all occa≈øions, for the better managing of his place; and many times they are Rounders and Sentinel Perdues in time of great nece≈ø≈øity.

div.head: The duty of a Corporal.
div.p:
THe Corporals of a Company are not tyed to a ≈øet number, but to be ordered according to the ≈øeveral ≈øtrengths and divi≈øions of the ≈øame, for each to take
his charge and care of every Squadron thereof. And unto each of them there is a Lan≈øpa≈ø≈øadoe for an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant: for their Rule of Dignity, I conceive, it makes not much more matter then to make them the right-hand File-leader in every particular divi≈øion; but if any will be ≈øo curious to order them according to that, let them apply them≈øelves unto the former Rules for directions to the ≈øame. The Corporals duty in his Squadron is to teach and in≈øtruct them in the u≈øe of the Pike and Musket, and to have a Roll and Li≈øt of his men in his Divi≈øion or Squadron. And when a Souldiers name is cro≈ø≈øed out, he is to give notice unto his Serjeant; and when a new one ≈øhall ≈øupply his place, his care mu≈øt be to in≈øtruct and enable him in the Po≈øtures of ≈øuch Arms as he ≈øhall bear. Being with his Squadron upon his Guard, he is to provide them with Wood, Coal, Candle and light. Having an Out-guard, his care mu≈øt be to ≈øtrengthen it, his little Corps du Guard and Sentinels mu≈øt be forth according to the avenews or comings on of the Enemy, whereby he prevents their cutting off or ≈øurpri≈øal; the negligence whereof proves both dangerous to them≈øelves, and the whole Army. Wherefore it behoves him to be very careful and vigilant to vi≈øit them, after giving them an e≈øpecial charge to be both faithful and careful in the great tru≈øt repo≈øed in them. He mu≈øt likewi≈øe pre≈øerve and keep the Word con≈øtant in his memory; when the Captain of the Watch goes the fir≈øt Round, he ≈øhall with his Sword drawn again≈øt his bre≈øt give it him, and receive ≈øuch Orders from him as he ≈øhall command him; but afterwards when the Round ≈øhall come again, he ≈øhall cau≈øe the Rounders or Gentlemen (with his Sword drawn) to give the Word to him before they pa≈øs. He ought never to go alone, being called forth by the Sentinel, but to have a Guard of three or four Muskettiers along with him, ≈øelected out of his Corps du Guard. He mu≈øt advi≈øe his Sentinels how to demean them≈øelves upon the di≈øcovery of an Enemy, either to give an Alarum, or el≈øe to give notice without making a noi≈øe. And if upon his Guard he ≈øhall either ob≈øerve, or be adverti≈øed by his Sentinels of the approach of the Enemy, then he is to have his men in readine≈øs with Bullets in their Muskets, and their Matches lighted; him≈øelf ≈øecretly coming in, giving intelligence unto his Captain, or other Superiour Officer, whereby they may all be in a readine≈øs before the Alarum be given. He is likewi≈øe to di≈øtribute Victual, Powder, Bullet and Match, unto his Squadron, and to take notice of the be≈øt experienced men, and accordingly to imploy them upon action upon the Watches. He mu≈øt cau≈øe re≈øpect to be given to the Corps du Guard; and ≈øilence to be kept, whether it be about the Walls or Gates, that ≈øo the noi≈øe may not hinder the hearing of the adverti≈øement from the Sentinels. He is likewi≈øe to have an eye to their lives and manners, and to take care of the Baggage and Money of ≈øuch as are hurt or ≈øick, and to be in his own carriage ≈øober, wi≈øe and di≈øcreet, for the avoiding ill example unto others.

div.head: Of the Martial of a Regiment.
div.p: HE ought to take into his cu≈øtody all per≈øons committed unto his charge by the chief Officers of the Regiment; and if they be called to ju≈øtice, he is to bring them to the Martial-General, who are to be carried from thence to the Council of War. It is al≈øo his care to ≈øee that all Women, Boyes, Servants, Bread, and Aquavita-≈øellers, belonging to the Regiment, do march in the Reer, and not before, or upon the Flanks. He is likewi≈øe to ≈øet ≈øuch prizes upon Beer and Victuals, as the Lord-Martial, or Serjeant-Major-General ≈øhall appoint; which Order he ≈øhall receive from the Provo≈øt-Martial of the Army, and to ≈øee it duly executed within the Circuit of the Regiment: And that the Sutlers do not ≈øell their Beer and Victuals above the ≈øet rate, le≈øt they grate upon the Souldiers. After the Captain of the Watch hath gone the fir≈øt Round, he is to ≈øee that the Sutlers keep no tipling or di≈øorder in the night, but make them put out their Candle-light and Fires. During the time of Divine Service, he is to go the Round, for fear any di≈øorders ≈øhould be committed in the Quarters.

div.head: Of a Quarter-Ma≈øter.
div.p: IF the Regiment be marching with the Army, (and not alone) he is then every evening to attend upon the Quarter-Ma≈øter-General, to receive his directions, and to take the place, ground, and hou≈øes, appointed by him, for the Quarter and Lodging of the Regiment; who pre≈øently is to acquaint and adverti≈øe his Colonel of the ≈øame, and after to follow his charge. Fir≈øt, he appointeth or prepareth the Colonels Lodging, and other Officers of the Field, in the Center or mid≈øt of all the Quarters; and neer them him≈øelf, and all the other Officers of the Staff. After, according to the ≈øeniority of the Captains, and their marchings, to di≈øtribute forth their Quarters as may be de≈øigned. Having thus far acted through the help of the Con≈øtables and Head-boroughs of tho≈øe places where the Regiment is to Quarter; and having drawn forth their Billets in a good and orderly way, he is before the Regiments entring the Quarters, to deliver the ≈øame to the Colonel, or other Field-Officers of that Regiment; and they to deliver it to the re≈øt of the Captains, to direct them to their Lodgings, with the particular Souldiers of their Company. And during the time that he is about the vi≈øiting the di≈øtribution of the Lodgings, all the Troops are to keep watch round about the place, and to ≈øend out to di≈øcover: he mu≈øt al≈øo be informed of the Lodgings of the whole Army, to know whom to give, or whom to receive Supplies in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity.

If the Quarter be in the open field, the Quarter-Ma≈øter-General ≈øhall appoint to each Quarter-Ma≈øter the place and ground which he ≈øhall take, which he is to di≈øtribute to the Serjeants of every Company of the Regiment, who are to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in taking the depth, length and breadth of their Quarters, with the di≈øtances of the Alarum-place between the head of the Quarters and the Trench, and the true di≈øtance of the Streets betwixt the in-getting of each Captains particular Company.

When an Army or Regiment ≈øhall ≈øit down before a Town, or forraging place, to be≈øiege it, they are imployed ≈øometimes to be Forragers to fetch in provi≈øion for the Army, or particular Regiments. Which when they ≈øhall be required, they ought to have ≈øufficient Convoys and Guards, both of Infantry and Cavalry to ≈øecure them; who are to be commanded by able Officers; and the Provo≈øt-Martial, or one of his A≈ø≈øi≈øtants is to go along with them, to puni≈øh ≈øuch as are exorbitant, or do ≈øtraggle. It will be expedient to the Regiment, that the Quater-Ma≈øter upon the Service may be imployed twice in a week, to bring in a fre≈øh Victual to the Souldiers; but not to go twice to one place, le≈øt they be di≈øcovered by an Enemy, and be way-laid by their Forces, who may ≈øometimes prove ≈øtronger then them≈øelves, to prevent, or to cut them off by the way, laying of them ≈øecretly in ≈øome Ambu≈øhments: Which being truely con≈øidered of, care may be taken accordingly of Supplies in other remote places, free from the danger of the Enemy. To conclude, a Quarter-Ma≈øter ought to carry him≈øelf hone≈øtly and carefully in his place, and to be well skill'd in the Art of Mathematicks, that he may the better give Directions for fortifying and mea≈øuring of ground, quartering of his whole Regiment, and in hutting of the particular Souldiers.

div.head: The duty of a Serjeant.
div.p:
HE that is a Serjeant to a Company, ought to be well skill'd in the Po≈øtures and all Military Motions, whereby in the fir≈øt place he may endeavour to correct the errours of ≈øuch who handle not the Arms in a hand≈øome, or a ≈øerviceable way. And ≈øecondly, that he may be helpful to his Captain, or other Superiour Officer. In time of his Exerci≈øe, his duty is to draw forth the Files according to ≈øuch depths as ≈øhall be appointed unto him by his Captain, or other Superiour Officer, and to order them in the drawing up, and joyning together the Souldiers unto ≈øuch places of honour as they ≈øhall direct him unto. In a ≈øingle Company he leadeth oftentimes a Divi≈øion, but ought not always there to march, in re≈øpect he is concerned to ≈øee that the Souldiers march even in their Ranks at their di≈øtance of Order in File, and open Order in Rank. To which
purpo≈øe, he ought many times to be upon the Flanks, and perceiving any Souldier out of order, he may ca≈øt in his Halbert between their Ranks, to cau≈øe him to march even abre≈øt with his right and left-hand-men. He is likewi≈øe either in Field or Garri≈øon to lead his Squadron to their Guard, and to carry to pri≈øon ≈øuch Offendours as his Captain or other Superiour Officer ≈øhall commit to the Provo≈øt-Martial. He is to ≈øee that the Muskettiers in time of skirmi≈øhing pre≈øent all even abre≈øt, with their Matches all cockt, giving fire all together in good Order; and to direct them how to fall off, and rally again in the Reer of their own Divi≈øions. His duty likewi≈øe is to fetch Ammunition, Powder, Match, and all other Materials for the Company. He is, moreover, every particular evening to attend at the place of Parade, or at the Majors Lodging, to fetch the Word, and carry it to his Captain, Lieutenant, En≈øign, and Corporals; and likewi≈øe as ≈øoon as he is come unto his Guard, he mu≈øt direct the Corporals where to ≈øet out the Perdues and Sentinels, and how to order his Watch. He mu≈øt likewi≈øe make Rounds; and if he finde a Sentinel a≈øleep in the Field, he is to commit him to the hand of Ju≈øtice. And thus much concerning the duty of a Serjeant.

div.head: Of an En≈øign.
div.p: AN En≈øign being a Commi≈ø≈øion-Officer, in the ab≈øence of his Captain and Lieutenant, is Commander in chief of the Company, and ought to march upon the head of the ≈øame, leading them with a Half-pike.
