His Captain and Lieutenant being pre≈øent, and upon a Stand, his Colours ought to re≈øt upon his ≈øide, being held by his right or left-hand, and unfurled; upon the March, his Colours ought to be ≈øhouldered, taking up the corner-end of them in his right-hand, and to let them be half flying; the Pikes and Muskets all conforming unto the ≈øame Po≈øture. Marching through a City, for the more grace, his Colours may be wholly flying, being advanced and held up by his right-hand, or re≈øting upon his right ≈øide. He ought to be a proper man, grave, valiant and di≈øcreet, and to be well skill'd in the Po≈øtures of the Pike; in re≈øpect he leads them, and they expect from him to be taught the Po≈øtures thereof. He ought to be well skill'd in all the lofty Figures of the di≈øplaying of the Colours above the head, and to make u≈øe of them according to di≈øcretion and command; which is not onely a healthfull exerci≈øe to his body, but al≈øo mo≈øt becoming to him, or any other Gentleman or Commander what≈øoever, that ≈øhall ≈øometimes make u≈øe of the ≈øame; although condemned through ≈øloth and ignorance by others, who will not take the pains to learn it. An En≈øign upon a Troop, lodging he Colours, or in time of skirmi≈øhing, may fold them up, and retreat into the ≈øecond Rank for the ≈øecuring of his Colours, which he ought to ≈øtick by, and not to ≈øtir from them at ≈øuch a time, although he hazardeth his la≈øt drop of blood, or makes them his winding-≈øheet. When the General ≈øhall pa≈øs by, or any ≈øuch man of worth, he ought a little to vail his Colours, inclining the head, or narrow end thereof, a little downward; but not to bow his knee, or uncover his head. He may ≈øometimes for his ea≈øe or recreation upon the March, reque≈øt ≈øome Gentleman of knowing tru≈øt of the Pikes to carry his Colours for him, until ≈øuch time as he ≈øhall come again for to take them. In the ab≈øence of his Lieutenant, when his Captain ≈øhall exerci≈øe the Company, he may ≈øtick his Colours in the ground, or deliver them to ≈øome Gentleman of the Pikes, and fall down him≈øelf in the Reer with a Half-pike or Cane, there to be an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant to his Captain in ≈øupplying the Lieutenants place, except his Captain ≈øhould command him to the contrary. He ought to have a Guard along with him, as well to the lodging of his Colours, as to any other place. He ought to perform all courteous offices for the Souldiers unto his Captain, which will gain him both love and reputation among≈øt them, they thereby better re≈øpecting him, and more couragiou≈øly following of him.

div.head: Of a Lieutenant.
div.p:
HE that is a Lieutenant to a Company, ought to be a good and able Souldier, and well to under≈øtand the Duty of a Captain; in re≈øpect that in his ab≈øence he is as Captain and Commander in chief over them. He is likewi≈øe to receive
all Orders, Charges, and Commi≈ø≈øions from his Captain, a≈ø≈øuming no authority unto him≈øelf; but in the ab≈øence of his Captain he is to ≈øee all ≈øuch Orders he hath received duly executed, for the better ea≈øe unto him. He is likewi≈øe at ≈øuch times frequently to exerci≈øe the Company in all their Military Motions, Skirmi≈øhings, and Fal≈øe-firings in the pan. He is to hold the Serjeants and Corporals ≈øtrictly to their duty, cau≈øing them to provide all things nece≈ø≈øary for the Company, and to be a≈ø≈øi≈øtants unto him where he ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe. He is to teach and in≈øtruct the Souldiers in the u≈øe of their Arms, and ≈øometime for their ea≈øe, he may command every File-leader to draw forth his File, and to ≈øhew them their po≈øtures. By which means he ≈øhall do ≈øuch good ≈øervice to his Captain, that when he ≈øhall exerci≈øe them him≈øelf, he may find them more apter and readier to fulfil his Commands; at which time the Lieutenant ought to be in the Reer, and to ≈øee all things there truly executed according to the Captains commands. He is in time of danger and great importance to advi≈øe with his Captain about the welfare of the Company; for knowing his Captains intentions and purpo≈øes beforehand, he may be the better provided to with≈øtand the furious on≈øet of the Enemy. He ought to have the En≈øign, and all other Officers of the Company as near him as may be, there being often-times urgent bu≈øine≈øs to make u≈øe of them as occa≈øion ≈øhall require. He mu≈øt neither ca≈øhiere nor puni≈øh any man in the pre≈øence of his Captain, but ought to make him acquainted therewith, that he may puni≈øh the offender by committing him either to pri≈øon, or cau≈øe him to give recompence to the party wronged. To conclude, he ought to know how far his power doth extend, either in the pre≈øence or ab≈øence of his Captain, always demeaning him≈øelf ≈øo, that he may gain the love of his whole Company, by acting tho≈øe things among≈øt them as may be ju≈øt and hone≈øt.

div.head: Of a Captain.
div.p:
HE that is a Captain of a Company, ought in re≈øpect he leadeth the ≈øame, and is Chief, to appoint unto the Officers their ≈øeveral places, what Divi≈øions they ≈øhall lead, and where they ≈øhall march, and according to the number of Files to make his Divi≈øions an≈øwerable thereto, by dividing his Muskettiers as near as he can, the one half upon the right of the Pikes, and the other upon the left: for they being the Flankers, ought equally to be ballanced; but if there be an odd File, it ought to be contrived, and carried to the right. In the Van, Battail, or Reer, he mu≈øt according to the number of his men, order his Officers places, and draw them off accordingly in as equal a way as they will afford. He is, as well as his own, to know all the ≈øeveral duties of his Officers, and to be a good Po≈øtureman him≈øelf, that when he ≈øees any of his Souldiers handling their Arms in an undecent and ≈ølovenly manner, he may the better reprove them for the ≈øame. And although many Captains regardeth them not, but leaveth them to be in≈øtructed by the inferiour Officers; yet it is a great deal of honour to him, when his Souldiers ≈øhall be taught by him≈øelf, they more cheerfully and confidently marching along with him, when as they perceive that he is throughly knowing in all things belonging to his charge. He ≈øhall do well to exerci≈øe his Company ≈øometimes him≈øelf, teaching them how to fight upon all occa≈øions, whether it be to Front, Reer, or Flanks, or upon ≈øurpri≈øe of an Ambu≈øcado, or any other di≈øadvantage which may befall them, informing them how to fall off and rally again in good order. And at ≈øuch times he mu≈øt couragiou≈øly and wi≈øely behave him≈øelf, and incourage his Souldiers of hopes of Victory, ca≈øting off all appearances of fear or danger what≈øoever, cheerfully animating his Souldiers to fall on, taking care, and making much of them, and not to for≈øake them until ≈øuch time they may be relieved by others. He is to have a fatherly care of his Souldiers, timely providing for the maimed, wounded, and ≈øick, ≈øuch helps and remedies as their pre≈øent conditions requires. He mu≈øt likewi≈øe ≈øee that there be no want of Victual, Arms, or Ammunition. He ought not to be covetous, nor keep back his Souldiers pay, but to ≈øee them duly paid, vi≈øiting and relieving them according to their ≈øeveral wants
and nece≈ø≈øities. His care mu≈øt be to execute Ju≈øtice, appea≈øe quarrels, puni≈øh offenders; by doing whereof, he will maintain the honour and dignity of his place. He ought to carry a very even hand over his Souldiers, and to be very courteous and kind unto them; yet with that re≈øtriction of familiarity, that he come not under contempt. And again, he mu≈øt not be too rigid and har≈øh, caning or beating them without ju≈øt cau≈øe, le≈øt he incurre their hatred, who ≈øecretly, or in time of Battail will ≈øeek to be revenged of him, endeavouring to kill him, before their enemy; therefore he ought to be wi≈øe and di≈øcreet in his commands and carriage towards them. His place of marching with his Company, is ≈øome ≈øix foot before the fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers; but if his Company be drawn up, he is either upon a Stand, or upon the March, to be on the head of the Pikes, ≈øix foot before the En≈øign. In time of Battail, although he leads his men up fir≈øt again≈øt the Enemy, yet he is not always tied to be in the Front, having often ju≈øt occa≈øion to remove down into the Reer, Mid≈øt, or Flanks, carefully ca≈øting his eye upon all parts of the Body, thereby preventing the lea≈øt error or neglect of his Souldiers, directing them what to do, keeping them in good order as long as occa≈øion ≈øhall require. Moreover, he ought to be very religious, temperate, and di≈øcreet, faithful in his tru≈øt, valiant in the field again≈øt the face of his enemy, and being be≈øieged in either Town or Fort, (for to pre≈øerve his honour) never give his con≈øent for the yielding it up, until it be pa≈øt hope, that there is no po≈ø≈øibility to hold it out any longer.

div.head: Of a Serjeant-Major.
div.p:
HIs duty is every morning and evening, or upon any other occa≈øion, to attend upon the General, Martial of the Field, or Serjeant-Major-General of the Army, to receive his Orders how, or in what manner the Regiment ≈øhall march, whether in a ≈øingle Battalion, or el≈øe in two, to be joined with others. After which he gives order accordingly unto the Captains how to draw up their Companies and orders them accordingly. At which time of embattelling or marching, he ought to be as near the mid≈øt of the Regiment as he can, for the better regulating of the ≈øame. He is to place all the Officers according to their Dignity where they are to lead, and where to bring up, and which men they ≈øhall take charge of to fight, cau≈øing the Drum-Major (after they are all drawn up) and the other Drummers to beat a March, and to move all at one in≈øtant, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require. He ought to make all the Divi≈øions as near equally alike as po≈ø≈øible he can. He mu≈øt likewi≈øe be well ver≈øt in the ≈øeveral drawing up of Regiments, with their various forms of Battail, that according to the condition of the place, ground, number of men, and Orders received from the Major-General, or Majors of the Brigades, he may not ≈øhew him≈øelf a Novice, or one that is to ≈øeek: nor ought he to go dully or ≈ølothfully upon his charge or place, but to be very ready, quick, and nimbly performing with much ea≈øe and readine≈øs his Battalions and grand Divi≈øions. In their drawings up he may be permitted to have Pen, Ink, and Paper for to take an accompt of the ≈øeveral ≈øtrengths of the Captains Companies, and to order his men accordingly, and ought to give unto all the Officers of the Regiment notes in writing of their ≈øeveral charges and places. In time of fight, or otherwi≈øe marching with the Regiment, he is to be on hor≈øe-back, in regard he is the eyes, hands, and feet thereof: in time of Battail he is to ≈øee every Officer to perform his charge, and Souldier his duty, forcing and compelling them forward, if in ca≈øe they turn their backs. He is al≈øo to di≈øtribute to the Captains and other Officers ≈øuch Orders as he ≈øhall receive from his Colonel or other Superior Officer. In marching with the Regiment, not alone, but with the Army, he mu≈øt know from the General, Martial, or Major-General, whether the Regiment be to march in the Van-guard, Battail, or Reer. He ought to have ≈øome knowledge or information of the Country, whether it be long or ≈øtreight, thereby judging how to order his marching ≈øo, as he may not be di≈øturbed by the enemies Hor≈øe, or Artillery. Being troubled with Baggage, if there be any difficult pa≈ø≈øage, he ought to be there pre≈øent to prevent ≈øuch di≈øorders as may happen; giving directions for their placing and marching, as they may not be any hinderance to
the Regiment, putting them in order again before the Regiment ≈øhall enter into their Quarters; at which time he may give licen≈øe to the Captains and their En≈øigns to take their lodgings, excepting only tho≈øe who are appointed for Guardians, who mu≈øt enter the Corps du guard, and place their Sentinels until ≈øuch time as they ≈øhall be relieved by others.

Now if a Regiment be to be quartered or lodged either in the Field, or under ≈øhelter; if in the Field, he mu≈øt cau≈øe it to be barracado'd, or intrenched by the Waggons, or other defences of the Field; after which he is to place his Corps du guard round about the Quarters, and the Sentinels at ≈øo near a di≈øtance, that they may hear one the other ≈øpeak, being about 80, or 100 paces off from the Corps du guard, being placed double, a Pike and a Musket; and five paces from them, other ≈øingle Sentinels are to be placed, which are called Perdues. And in ca≈øe of Alarm, the Sentinel Perdue ≈øhall retreat to the double Sentinel; and in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, all together, having given fire, are to retreat to the Corps du guard. He mu≈øt likewi≈øe at divers hours of the night vi≈øit the Corps du guard, and if an Alarm be given in the Field, he is to betake him≈øelf to the Alarm-place of the Regiment, and there to form his Battalion, and to ≈øend men to double the Guards on that part where the Alarm was given, and to give notice thereof to his Colonel, or other Superior Officer, if they be pre≈øent, of what pa≈ø≈øeth. The En≈øigns ought not to retreat, unle≈øs their Colonel or he give leave: no Order at any time ought to be altered, but by him, in re≈øpect he giveth none but ≈øuch as he receiveth from the Colonel. It is his duty to ≈øpeak for Ammunition, as Powder, Bullets, Match; and for Victuals, if there ≈øhall be any want in the Regiment, which provi≈øions ought to be delivered unto him, and he to ≈øee it equally di≈øtributed unto the Companies according unto the proportion given out. And likewi≈øe he is to give Order what proportion or number of workmen, or commanded men, ≈øhall be drawn forth to work.

If under ≈øhelter, then he is to view the place, both within and without, appointing the places for the Corps du guards and Sentinels, and the way of the Rounders, that it be free. It will be expedient for him to chu≈øe the Alarm-place, whither the Companies upon the Alarum given are to repair, being the Rendezvous for the whole Regiment; being careful to place ≈øufficient Guards, both upon the Walls, and about the Gates, for their more ≈øecurity. Which being ended, he may give leave to the Captains to go to their Lodgings, and ≈øeveral Quarters, there to remain until they ≈øhall be called upon Duties; for the due performance whereof, he is to cau≈øe them to ca≈øt Lots, whereby they may know what part of the Walls may fall to their turn. He is to command the Captains to enter the Guards about ten or eleven a clock in the morning; he is likewi≈øe to open and ≈øhut the Gates, at the ri≈øing or ≈øetting of the Sun, and to place the Watches upon the Walls pre≈øently upon the ≈øhutting of the Gates, and to relieve them upon the opening thereof.

And as he doth receive his directions for marching, imbattelling, viewing of ground, and placing of Guards, from the Serjeant-Major-General, or Serjeant-Major of that Brigade: ≈øo he is to deliver them over to the Captains and Officers of that Regiment, and to call upon them to whom it appertains, to ≈øee them duly executed. In the pre≈øence of his Colonel, and Lieutenant-Colonel, he is to be an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant unto them, in ≈øeeing all orders and directions duly performed; and in their ab≈øence, he hath the ≈øame authority and command as they. He ought after he hath received the Word and Orders from the Serjeant-Major-General, or Serjeant-Major of the Brigade, he pre≈øently delivers them to his Colonel and Lieutenant-Colonel; and afterwards to the Serjeants of every Company, drawn in a Ring, according to the Seniority of their Captains, which are to come, and attend upon him for the ≈øame. In the ab≈øence of his Superiour Officers, he giveth the Word him≈øelf; every night he is to vi≈øit all the Guards of the Regiment, commanding them duly to keep the turns of their Watches and Marches, ≈øeeing that one Captains Company perform not more duty than another, to the end, that both the honour and labour may be equally divided among
≈øo he may exerci≈øe the whole Regiment, being thereunto required by his Colonel, or Lieut. Colonel, in all their Di≈øtances, Facings, Doublings, Wheelings, and Fal≈øe firings; or in their ab≈øence, of him≈øelf he hath full power ≈øo to do. To conclude, he ought to be well grounded in all Military Affairs, and to be both wi≈øe and valiant.

div.head: Of a Lieutenant-Colonel.
div.p: HE that is a Lieutenant-Colonel to a Regiment, hath a very honourable place, having power and command over all the Regiment in the ab≈øence of his Colonel, and may al≈øo at ≈øuch time exerci≈øe the Regiment in all the Military Motions, and is to lead the Regiment upon the head thereof: but when his Colonel is pre≈øent, he bringeth up the Reer, if they march in one Divi≈øion; but if in two, in ≈øome places he leadeth the ≈øecond, as his Colonel doth the fir≈øt; or if in three, as formerly is ≈øhewen, he commands the Van-guard, the Colonel the Battail, and the Major the Reer-guard. His place is not of ≈øo great pains and toyl as the Majors is; therefore he ought in the drawing up of the Regiment to be helpful and a≈ø≈øi≈øting unto him in that particular, and in all others where he ≈øhall think fit. To conclude, the greate≈øt affairs of the Regiment being carried forth by the Major, there is the le≈øs remaining to be ≈øpoken concerning him, but that he ≈øee all things duly ob≈øerved throughout the Regiment, according unto ≈øuch orders received from tho≈øe which are above him.

div.head: Of a Colonel.
div.p: IT concerneth every Colonel to take care that his Companies be full and compleat (if it may be) that they be well provided of Arms, and to take cognizance what Exerci≈øes are continually performed by them, communicating Orders, and commanding all Officers of his Regiment what is to be performed by each Company re≈øpectively, when≈øoever they ≈øhall happen to be upon their March.

In the Head of his Regiment is his mo≈øt honourable and proper place, and there he ought to be mo≈øt frequent. He is to be ≈øub≈øervient to the Lord General, Lord Martial, and Serjeant-Major-General of the Field, to whom he is to pay like re≈øpect and ob≈øervance as he him≈øelf expecteth, (and that ju≈øtly) from all inferiors to him. For from tho≈øe his ≈øuperior Officers, by him are received in charge all ≈øuch Orders as refer to the place of Alarms, Marchings, Imbattellings, Guards, or Convoys. Furthermore, it is requi≈øite that every Colonel ≈øhould acquaint him≈øelf at lea≈øt once every week, how and in what manner the Souldiers of his Regiment have deported them≈øelves in their ≈øeveral Quarters, by a due and ≈øtrict examination of the qualities of all ≈øuch offences as have occurred, and been committed by the ≈øeveral and Di≈øtinct Souldiers under his command, hereby preparing every ≈øeveral mi≈ødemeanor for a readier hearing before a Council of War, or Court-Martial; and this is ea≈øily effected by convening the Captains, or other Officers under them, at ≈øuch convenient times as may ≈øuit with his occa≈øions; every Colonel being bound to make his appearance at each Council of War, as A≈ø≈øi≈øtant to the Lord Martial, and Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Council, for the hearing and determining of all ≈øuch propo≈øitions and matters in que≈øtion relating to the Army.

In all matters of Advice and Coun≈øel, but more e≈øpecially when any Stratagem, Siege, or intended Battail is in agitation to be put in action, the Colonel ever as one of the primary Field-Officers is ≈øummoned to con≈øult with the General, and with all freedom to deliver his opinion in all things that ≈øhall be there di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, for the be≈øt advantage (as he ≈øhall conceive) for the de≈øigns in hand, how weighty and important ≈øoever, and to be ready to go upon any ≈øuch ≈øervice as ≈øhall be ca≈øt into his charge to be executed by the major part of the ≈øaid Council, and to expre≈øs his obedience to his General, although it be a ≈øervice that corre≈øpond not with his own opinion at the fir≈øt, but being cleared by the larger number to be more conducing to the good of the De≈øign, couragiou≈øly to undertake it, and faithfully to perform it.

In the quartering of his own Regiment, which is always ordered for Quarter in two grand Divi≈øions, regard is to be had that his own Lodgings be ever taken up in the mo≈øt equal place between his grand Divi≈øions, that ≈øo he may with more facility and celerity di≈øpen≈øe and import his commands to either Party.
What commands ≈øoever ≈øhall de≈øcend unto him in charge from his ≈øuperior Officers, as relating to the Guards, di≈øpo≈øing of Marchings, appointing Imbattellings, ordering of Quarters, &c. he is carefully to ≈øee executed. He mu≈øt do ju≈øtice unto all without partiality, ≈øo far as he exceed not his proper Authority, & at all times to be diligent in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of Mutinies, even in their fir≈øt growth, by a di≈øcreet puni≈øhment of the principal offenders, for prevention of further mi≈øchief and inconvenience.

div.head: Of Guides.
div.p: MAps, with the right u≈øe and knowledge of them, are great helps towards the finding out of the be≈øt and mo≈øt convenient ways. Skilful and expert Inhabitants of the Countrey, are mo≈øt proper to be elected for Guides; and it is nece≈ø≈øary, for their better encouragement, and the Armies ≈øudden and nece≈ø≈øary u≈øe of them, to have them li≈øted in Souldiers pay. For the finding out of the fitte≈øt and able≈øt per≈øons for this employment, it is mo≈øt e≈øpecially the duty of the Waggon-Ma≈øters, who are to ≈øee and enquire certainly, that they be men known and practi≈øed in all po≈ø≈øible By-paths, Cro≈øs-ways, &c. That they be able to give an accompt of the di≈øtance of places, of the evenne≈øs and ≈øtraightne≈øs of them, whether they be plain or crooked, hilly or ≈øtony, and difficult for pa≈ø≈øage; what Rivers, Hedges, Ditches and Bridges lye in the way, and which way (if there ≈øhall be ≈øeveral ways) is the ≈øafe≈øt and ≈øhorte≈øt, which the nearer or farther to or from the Enemies Quarters, which more probable for their approaches, as likewi≈øe for Quarter; what Forrage, what Water is to be had, and how convenient the way is for Baggage. If it ≈øhall happen that the≈øe Guides may be cho≈øen partly out of the Souldiers, and partly from the Country-men, and ≈øo any ≈øcrumple, jar, or difference happen in opinion, ≈øuch Officers and others as are be≈øt skill'd in tho≈øe parts and places, are either to reconcile the difference, or from the mo≈øt probable intelligence, to conclude upon the mo≈øt convenient pa≈ø≈øages. In re≈øpect of the danger and great hazards, if not utter ruine, that the Guides ≈øometimes do, and often may draw the Souldiers into by treachery and fal≈øe play, they are many times cau≈øed to ride haltered about the neck, to put them in mind of capital puni≈øhment, if they ≈øhall mi≈ølead the party they guide; but in ca≈øe they di≈øcharge their tru≈øt faithfully and ably, they ought to be as well rewarded for their encouragement, as otherwi≈øe to be puni≈øhed for the terrour of others.

div.head: Of Scouts.
div.p: AN active Enemy is always watchful, and diligent to apprehend every opportunity that may make for his advantage, and therefore it concerns every Commander by way of Counter-mine, as it were, to be careful that he rightly and fully inform him≈øelf of their ways and cour≈øes, for prevention of his own danger, in ca≈øe of ≈øudden a≈ø≈øaults, and the better infe≈øting of his enemy. And to this end, he mu≈øt make choice of ≈øuch as are approved for their valour and fidelity, di≈øcretion and vigilancy, not probable to be corrupted with gain, or daunted through fear. The≈øe men are not only to take direct, plain, or high ways, but al≈øo by private and un≈øu≈øpected pa≈ø≈øages, and ≈øcouring as they ≈øcout all places what≈øoever that are acce≈ø≈øible; and when they have made diligent ob≈øervation in all places, to inform of nothing but what they can give the ocular proof of, le≈øt by their errour and mi≈øtake, the whole Army po≈ø≈øibly may be led into an irreparable ruine; and who≈øoever is the Conduct or Officer of the≈øe Scouts (for one, and an able one they mu≈øt have always with them) mu≈øt be exceeding careful of his reputation, that he inform of nothing more then what he can ju≈øtifie from his own eyes or ears; and if he inform further, to inform them al≈øo, that that information is but from report, that it may be con≈øidered of accordingly, and his repute pre≈øerved intire.

div.head: Of Spies.
div.p:
OF all men, the≈øe are at all times nece≈ø≈øary for an Army, and in all Armies of all men they will de≈øerve to be mo≈øt certainly & liberally rewarded, to the intent that they may at all times cheerfully and faithfully undertake any imployment of the greate≈øt tru≈øt, hazard, or danger. And he that will make choice of able and tru≈øty men in this kind, mu≈øt after diligent ob≈øervation, and weighing of their di≈øpo≈øitions
and courage, ≈øelect them out of his own Souldiers, who under pretence of ≈øome di≈øcontent for want of pay, &c. may thereby with le≈øs ≈øu≈øpition receive entertainment from the enemy, and (if it be po≈ø≈øible) to be li≈øted with the Hor≈øe, whereby they may gain the fairer opportunities in Field or Garri≈øon, to give certain intelligence of all De≈øigns and Occurrences in the enemies Quarters.

Before their departure from you, let them take their ≈øeveral in≈øtructions (for the more you have, the better, if they be de≈øign'd for ≈øeveral places, and unknown unto each other) both for times & places of conveyance, which places mu≈øt be ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved, & duly ≈øearched for ≈øuch informations, as your Spies ≈øhall convey thither; and thither let your an≈øwers & advices be reconveyed for their further in≈øtruction.

Sometimes there may ari≈øe matters of ≈øuch importance and con≈øequence, that it will not only be convenient to certifie by Letter, but mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to make appearance in per≈øon, and there to con≈øult and advi≈øe together, if perhaps the enemy ≈øhall be re≈øolved to fall upon ≈øome of the oppo≈øite Quarters ≈øuddainly, &c.

For Cur≈øary Spies, and pre≈øent Intelligence, the people of meane≈øt rank and quality are the fitte≈øt In≈øtruments; as common Pea≈øants, Pedlars, Sellers of Strongwaters, or Tobacco, and the like, who may pa≈øs un≈øu≈øpected, and with more ≈øecurity effect your purpo≈øe.

There are yet another ≈øort of Spies of another nature, who are denominated double, who being cho≈øen to this Office upon great experience of their tru≈øt and con≈øtancy, may in ≈øome ca≈øes be allowed to inform the enemy aright, in ≈øome ≈øuch affairs of yours, as may not be prejudicial to you, but to in≈øinuate and win belief upon the contrary party; and hereupon let them ≈øecure them≈øelves into the private ≈øervice of ≈øome of their Prime Officers, whence they ≈øhall (as being better acquainted) more ea≈øily di≈øcover, and more certainly inform of the enemies proceedings and intentions.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Of Military Watches.
div.p: HOw nece≈ø≈øary the≈øe Watches are in all Armies, is evident to all men; the grand and chiefe≈øt care whereof, for order and direction, re≈øteth in the Serjeant-Major, who i≈ø≈øueth out ≈øuch precepts therein to the Captains or Companies, as he him≈øelf before received from his ≈øuperior Officer; & according to the ≈øaid precepts received, whether it be in Garri≈øon or Field, the work and duty required is to be performed either by Squadrons or ful Companies, having re≈øpect unto the ≈øtrength or weakne≈øs of the place to be guarded, and in ≈øuch places as are mo≈øt likely for the Enemy to make his approaches in, and that there they be careful to fortifie the Guard above other places of le≈øs concernment; which mu≈øt be ob≈øerved by the Major, in ≈øurveying the Guards, and Guard-places, in his walking of the grand Round, and ≈øo, according as his di≈øcretion ≈øhall ≈øee fit, to take from the ≈øtronger places of Guard ≈øuch Souldiers as may ≈øupply the defects of the weaker.

The appointment of particular Guards unto particular Captains, is in the power of the Major; or otherwi≈øe, he commandeth the Serjeant of each Company to attend him at his Quarters at any hour of the day, as he ≈øhall think fit, where every one that is to do duty upon the Guard that night, taketh his lot in order, (which lots are ≈øhuffled together in an Hat) which directeth him upon what Guard to attend that night. This being done, all the Serjeants that have their direction for the duty of the Guard, are to make a Ring, or Circle, according to their degrees in Seniority. To the Senior of all which Company of Serjeants, the Major giveth the Word privately in his ear, who after the ≈øame manner pa≈ø≈øeth it to the next, and ≈øo from man to man unto the younge≈øt, who whi≈øpers it in the ear of his Major, who ≈øends it back again in the former manner for ≈øecurities ≈øake, until it come to the ≈øenior Serjeant again, who then leaves it in the ear of his Major, which preventeth all mi≈øtakes for each particular Company.
The Guards being thus ≈øet in order, the Officers relieved ought to inform the Officers of the Relievers; of all the ≈øeveral duties of their ≈øeveral Guards, &c.

Every Commander in Chief of that particular Squadron which he is appointed unto, leadeth up his own Squadron from the Parade to their appointed Guard, to which when they approach, the Officer in Chief delivers the Word to the Corporal, or his Lan≈øpa≈ø≈øadoe, and they to their Superior Officers.

The manner of relieving is by planting a guard of Pikes next to the Relievers, and adjoyning to them in the Reer a guard of Muskettiers, through whom the Relievers are to pa≈øs, and the Relieved to march back to their Quarters. After all things thus ≈øet in order, the Captain of the Guard in per≈øon by ≈øtrict injunction commandeth every man to his duty, from which no man either. Officer or other is to depart without an e≈øpecial licen≈øe, and in all Alarms to ≈øtand clo≈øe and quietly to their Arms, expecting further in≈øtruction and command what they are to do. And all this time, and con≈øtantly, a Sentinel is appointed to guard the entrance into the Main-Guard.

Every Officer and Souldier in a Regiment is worthy of Honor, Pay, and Encouragement, according to his Merit and Seniority; and to this end there ought to be a perfect Li≈øt of the names and number of all particular Souldiers and Officers in every Squadron; which Li≈øt or Catalogue is to remain in the hands of the ≈øeveral Corporals or Lan≈øpa≈ø≈øadoes; which Corporals are diligently to ≈øee what defects there are of all ≈øeveral nece≈ø≈øaries in their Corps du guard, and to be careful that they be continually ≈øupplied; which he mu≈øt do by information to his Major, and (in ca≈øe of his ab≈øence or neglect) to his Captain, who may inform the Governor, that all wants of Fire, Ammunition, or Lights be made good, and compleated.

The Corporals according to order and precept given to them, are to di≈øpo≈øe of the ≈øeveral Sentinels, as well Pikes as Muskettiers, and to have an e≈øpecial care that they keep their Muskets prim'd and laden, and their Match cockt and lighted, with their Pan guarded; which mu≈øt be ob≈øerved by their often vi≈øiting the ≈øeveral Sentinels, to ≈øee that all things be in due order, and with ≈øilence, to the end that the Sentinels may always be heard, as often as occa≈øion is offered.

The Office of every Sentinel after he is placed upon his duty, and in his due po≈øture (according as is above declared) is to enquire of every pa≈ø≈øenger, or other that ≈øhall but ≈øtir, Who goes there? yea, though it be the Captain him≈øelf: and how≈øoever the remote≈øt Sentinel from the Corps du guard, is to permit him with his Retinue to pa≈øs; yet he is bound to have an eye upon them, till he approach the neare≈øt Sentinel to the Corps, who upon the like demand, is an≈øwered, The Captain of the Watch; which latter Sentinel commands him to ≈øtand, and therefore with a loud voice calls forth his Corporal, the Sentinel not ≈øtirring from his place or po≈øture, until the Corporal with his Sword drawn ≈øhall approach with a Guard of Muskettiers, who are to be all arm'd, and appointed, as the Sentinels, ready to pre≈øent; whereupon the Corporal with one only Muskettier advancing, and perceiving him to be the Captain of the Watch indeed, is to give him the Word in his ear, having re≈øpectively ca≈øt down the point of his Sword: afterward receiving further in≈øtructions from him, he conducts him to his furthe≈øt Sentinel. But if it ≈øhall appear that he be not the Captain, or the Corporal knowing him not ju≈øtly to be ≈øo, by a ju≈øt ≈øu≈øpition, he may then detain him (although he ≈øhal give him the Word) and then he ≈øhall further demand the Word of ≈øome other attending him, from whom having received it, he may more ≈øafely permit them to pa≈øs; but of all others what≈øoever that ≈øhall attempt a pa≈ø≈øage, he is to receive the Word from them, and not deliver it to them.

The Captain him≈øelf having done the duty in per≈øon of pa≈ø≈øing the fir≈øt Round, upon his return, he is to ≈øend forth others upon the like duty, ≈øuch as he ≈øhall out of his di≈øcretion chu≈øe from his Main-guard, and may mo≈øt confide in, to whom he is to impart the Word at their ≈øetting forth upon the duty, and not before, with ≈øtrict admonitions, and full in≈øtructions what they are to do, and what way to take.

Now if he ≈øhall be ≈øupplyed with men enough upon his own Guard, he may at the ≈øame time command out ≈øeveral Rounders to be taken ≈øeveral wayes; who are diligently to ob≈øerve their directions given them, and to be very vigilant in the ob≈øervation of all things in their pa≈ø≈øage, both by the eye and the ear, and to admoni≈øh the Sentinels (in ca≈øe of neglect) that all things be more carefully lookt unto in their duty. And of the≈øe Rounders likewi≈øe (as before) the foremo≈øt Sentinel demands, Who goes there? When being an≈øwered ≈øatisfactorily, as by the name of the Round, or Friends, the permits them pa≈ø≈øage to the neere≈øt Sentinel,
who having ≈øtopt them there, takes a further accompt, what, and who they are: Which is done by calling forth his Corporal, who placing the point of his Sword at one of their bre≈øts, takes the Word privatly, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øes them by conduct to the furthe≈øt Sentinel. But if there ≈øhall happen a mi≈øtake in the Word, the Corporal is either to ≈øecure them with him≈øelf, or by Guard to transfer them to the Main-guard.

Such as ≈øhall walk the Round, are to take a ≈øtrict accompt of all they meet, what, and who they are; and in ca≈øe of deficiency of an≈øwering ju≈øtly on the one ≈øide, or ≈øu≈øpition of the other, they are to ≈øecure and guard them to the Captain of the Watch.

Now ≈øetting a≈øide tho≈øe Queries which ≈øome do make between Rounders and Counter-Rounders, if they meet, who ≈øhall give or take the Word; the be≈øt and ≈øafe≈øt cour≈øe is for them all, that before the Word be either given or taken, they go together to the neere≈øt Corps du Guard, and there to give the Word; after which they are to pa≈øs upon their duty again; and ≈øo having fini≈øhed the Round, and returning to the Captain of the Watch, he taketh accompt of them of the things that they have done and ob≈øerved in their duty and cour≈øe upon the Round; and thus the Captain ≈øtill ≈øupplies the Rounds ≈øucce≈ø≈øively by ≈øuch others as he ≈øhall take by ≈øeniority, and di≈øpo≈øe off for the like ≈øervice.

Furthermore, that all di≈øorders, irregularities, and ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhall cau≈øe the ≈øame in a Town or Garri≈øon, may be found out and rectified, and that all dangerous accidents by fire or otherwi≈øe may be prevented; the Captain of the Watch commandeth out a Guard of Firelocks or Muskettiers, to view the Streets, and all ≈øu≈øpitious and irregular per≈øons as they take, they are to bring to the Main-Guard of this Guard, which is always conducted by a Serjeant, and is called the Patrouille: and if they happen to be Muskettiers, and not Firelocks; then they are to be every one provided of ≈øuch an in≈øtrument as may cover the lighted Matches, and keep them from di≈øcovery. From the≈øe al≈øo, as from the Rounders, the Captain of the Watch takes full accompt of all their pa≈ø≈øages and ob≈øervations on their duty.

When at any time any ≈øudden approach ≈øhall be made, or any Enemy di≈øcovered, the Sentinel (who is to be firm & con≈øtant to his Place and Po≈øture, till he ≈øhall be relieved) forthwith by firing gives the Alarm, and immediately ≈øeconds it by crying with a loud voice, Arm, Arm. When the Alarm is thus given, the other two Divi≈øions immediately led by their Officers, are orderly to march up to the Captain of the Main-Guard, to the intent that all Guards of the Garri≈øon may with expedition be made good; and it is nece≈ø≈øary that the≈øe in≈øtructions be given them indeed by the Serjeant-Major, when he ≈øhall give the Word to the Minor-Serjeants, who mu≈øt likewi≈øe inform their chief Officers of it, and from them the Souldiers are to be charged and acquainted therewith, that ≈øo upon all occa≈øions they may not be ignorant of this part of their duty, but ready to perform it.

The duty of a Sentinel, is to ≈øtand in the Place and Po≈øture, a full hour, and no more; at which time the Corporal, or (in ca≈øe of his ab≈øence) his Lan≈øpa≈ø≈øadoe is to relieve him, and not onely him, but all the Sentinels that are out upon duty, relieving the farthe≈øt Sentinel fir≈øt (who falls in the Reer of the re≈øt) and ≈øo all the others backward in the like Order, and then conducts the relieved Sentinels back to the Guard again.
At an early hour of the morning appointed for beating up the Revally, the two Sentinels next unto the Guard are to retreat into it.

At the time appointed in the morning for opening of the Gates, the Serjeant-Major attended with a ≈øufficient Guard, repairs to the Governour, or place el≈øewhere alotted, and there receives the Keys; which being done, he is to unlock fir≈øt that Gate which is mo≈øt remote from danger of the Enemy, and the re≈øt in order an≈øwerable: but if it happen to be in place and time of imminent danger, the Major commandeth forth a party of Souldiers conducted by an able Officer to go fir≈øt, and make diligent ≈øearch for di≈øcovering of Ambu≈øcadoes, which may happen to be in any clo≈øe ≈øu≈øpected places, as Lanes, By-ways, Hedges, ruinous
Cottages, Churches, Pits, or Hollow-trees, Woods, Gardens, and all ≈øuch-like inclo≈øures; at which time he openeth not the Main-ports, but only the Wickets. And except upon command to the contrary, which is not u≈øual, both the Guards and the Watches at the Gates are to be kept night and day, and all per≈øons upon them to continue upon their duty until they ≈øhall be relieved by order.

Upon the di≈øcharging of the Watch, to the end that every Officer and Souldier may have notice to make ≈øpeedy repair to their ≈øeveral Guards, each ≈øeveral Drum fir≈øt beats a Troop, and afterwards a March in the Main-guard. Hereupon, it is to be ≈øuppo≈øed the Relievers are advanced toward the Main-Guard, where the relieved are to be drawn off, and to make a ≈øtand, expecting till the Relievers ≈øhall come up; which being done, the relieved then are to troop homeward; and after that they have attended and ≈øeen their Colours lodged, they are to disband, and not before.

And now, further to ≈øatisfie the expectation of the Lovers of the Art Military, it ≈øhall not ≈øeem un≈øea≈øonable here to declare ≈øomewhat concerning the manner of Field-Watches, or Vigils de Campe, denoted unto us by the Expert and Ancients, under the≈øe three Notions. The fir≈øt are Ca≈øtra temporanea, aleager ad placitum, pitcht onely for the pre≈øent, and may perhaps alter and change it's Station in a day, or an hour, according to the plea≈øure and judgement of the General, and Commanders in chief. Secondly, there are Ca≈øtra, a ≈øelect or con≈øtant Camp, ≈øo called, becau≈øe of their intentions of continuance in the be≈øieging of a Ca≈øtle, or Town, &c. until they ≈øhall have taken the ≈øame, or by ≈øome other nece≈ø≈øity, or further advantage, forced to rai≈øe their Seige. The third and la≈øt, called Ca≈øtra, Such a Camp as is pitcht before or neer ≈øome Rivers ≈øide, to oppo≈øe and fru≈øtrate the Incur≈øions of the Enemy, who otherwi≈øe might this way break in for the infe≈øting or taking of a Country. Now concerning ≈øuch Watches or Guards, which ≈øhall relate unto ≈øeveral Camps, both in regard of the ≈øeveral and mo≈øt convenient places for ≈øecuring the Camps by Sentinels and Perdues, they are to be primarily appointed and ordered according to the di≈øcretion & command of the Ma≈øters of the Field, whether Generals, or Majors of Brigades; & afterwards the Serjeant-Majors & Captains of Regiments, according to their commands and relieved order, are to de≈øign them for the afore≈øaid place.

To enlarge the ≈øeveral Arguments and Di≈øputes that might further ari≈øe in-point of Field-duties relating thereunto, would be too tedious, and to little purpo≈øe, in regard that who≈øoever ≈øhall but diligently ob≈øerve what hath before been ≈øet down concerning the duty of Watches in Garri≈øon and Fortre≈ø≈øes, may ≈øufficiently be able to apprehend and perform all manner of Duties that ≈øhall concern this Field-≈øervice, provided that he be careful to adhere to the directions of the Field-Officers in all points, and diligent to ob≈øerve the manner of managing of all things according to their in≈øtructions. And therefore to avoid prolixity and fruitle≈øs di≈øputes, I refer the Reader to what hath been above related.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. The ordering of a private Company unto a Funeral-occa≈øion.
div.p: WHen any Commander or Souldier of worth ≈øhall be decea≈øed, a private Captain that would ≈øhew re≈øpect and honour by marching along with his Company attending the Corps to the place of burial, mu≈øt order his Souldiers after this manner.

They being ≈øummon'd by beat of the Drum, to meet at their u≈øual place of Rendezvous, they may be drawn up according to the u≈øual manner, having a Van-guard, Battail and Reer-guard: being thus ordered, and each of the Souldiers having either in his Hat a black Feather or Ribbin; the Captain may draw them off, and order them to their Long-march; moving them away in an orderly manner unto the place of him that is decea≈øed, and there make Alt. After which he may command the Muskettiers in the Van to open to the right and left outward to ≈øuch convenient di≈øtance as the Pikes may move up between them, and take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their fir≈øt ground; and tho≈øe Muskettiers may face about, and move down cleer of the Pikes, and after clo≈øe their Files inward to Order, and face to their Leader.

Now being in two Divi≈øions, let them ≈øo continue with their Arms ordered,
until ≈øuch time as they ≈øhall perceive the Corps to be brought forth into the Street; then the Captain may face them all about, and move them ≈øome three Pikes length before the Corps; after which he may command his Muskettiers to perform their Funeral-Po≈øture, which is to have their Muskets under their left Arm, with the But-end upward, their Re≈øts likewi≈øe on that ≈øide trailing. After which the Pikes are to face again to their fir≈øt Front, and to lay the narrow end of their Pikes down upon the ground; after facing about to the left, and bringing up the But-end of their Pikes on their right ≈øide, conforming them≈øelves with the Muskettiers in their Funeral-Po≈øtures. In the next place, the En≈øign ≈øtrips his Colours off from the Staff, and ties them about his right Wa≈øt; putting a black Ribbon towards the very end of his Staff, he after faceth to the Body of Pikes, ≈øtanding in the Reer of them, and trailing his Staff in the ≈øame Po≈øture. Next followeth the Captain, having in his hand a Half-pike or Leading-≈øtaff, conforming him≈øelf likewi≈øe to his Funeral-Po≈øture. Thus being all ready to march, and rightly faced toward that place where the Corps are to be interred, are after this manner following to lead and to bring up.

The fir≈øt Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, which was the Reer-guard, is led by the Lieutenant; the next Divi≈øion of Muskettiers, that was formerly the Van-guard, is led by the ≈øecond Serjeant; the Body of Pikes, is led by the elde≈øt Serjeant, he trailing a Half-pike upon the head of them; the En≈øign bringing it up, and the Captain twelve foot ≈øhort of him bringing up the Reer of the whole Company. And after him the Mini≈øters marching ju≈øt before the Coffin; & in the Reer, & next unto it, the neere≈øt kindred, and after them tho≈øe that are invited to the Funeral.

Having thus ≈øtated the manner and order of the Military Part, with all others belonging thereunto, for any ordinary Funeral-occa≈øion; I ≈øhall in the next place proceed to ≈øhew their Order upon the March, and how each Arms ought to be di≈øpo≈øed before the Corps enter into the Church, with the re≈øt of the Train.

All per≈øons being ordered as before expre≈ø≈øed, the Drums being covered with Black-bays, and placed betwixt the ≈øecond and third Ranks in each Divi≈øion; and all being ready to move, the Drums may begin to beat their Funeral-March, and the Lieutenant leading them away, with the But-end of his Patti≈øon upward and comported; the re≈øt following, and marching in a lea≈øurable and ≈ølow way along together, until they come within a hundred foot of the Church-door, or place where the Corps are to be interred, there making Alt. After which, let the Muskettiers in their Ranks File to the right and left, not advancing ground; and face in oppo≈øition, making a Guard for the re≈øt to pa≈øs through, and re≈øting their Muskets, or putting the But-end thereof to the ground, with the Barrel towards them (which is a conformity to the Pikes being ordered.) In the mean time, let the Pikes advance their Arms, and immediately after move forward betwixt the Guard of Muskettiers, and let their Ranks afterward file to the right and left, making al≈øo a Guard, their Pikes being ordered, and they as the re≈øt, facing in oppo≈øition. Then let the Captain, who brings up the Reer of all his whole Body, move forward with the re≈øt to the Church-door; then falling off in re≈øpect of ordering his Company, the re≈øt of the Train Marching into the Church.

After which the Captain may cau≈øe them all to face to the Church, or to their Leader; he ≈øtanding then before the Church-door, commanding them to Rank again as they were. After every Leader may draw off his File, and ≈øet their Arms apart in each File by them≈øelves, and go in to hear part of the Sermon, if there ≈øhould be any ≈øuch order before-hand from their Captain, placing Sentinels to look to their Arms. And when Sermon is almo≈øt done, they ought to go forth of the Church, and draw forth the Files by ≈øome little warning of Drums, to be in readine≈øs to an≈øwer ≈øuch directions as they ≈øhall receive from their Captain; who may, if he have conveniency of room, draw all his Muskettiers into a Ring, and the Pikes in like manner on the out≈øide of them; and as ≈øoon as the Souldiers have notice (being all ready and pre≈øented) that the Body is laid down in the grave, they may upon warning of the Drum, give one volley of ≈øhot all together, and after make ready again, performing the ≈øame twice over more. After which, the En≈øign may put his Colours upon his Staff, and furl them up; then the Pikes may be drawn up again into one Body, and the Muskettiers into another; and
falling in the Reer of the Pikes, they may troop away. And a little before the place of lodging the Colours, they may make Alt, and the Muskettiers may ≈øleeve up by the out≈øide of the Pikes from the Reer, filing to the right and left, making a Guard for the Colours and Pikes to march through them; and being cleer, and the Colours lodged, they may face about again to the right, and give another volley of ≈øhot: but if there ≈øhould be ≈øuch a ≈øtreight of ground, that the Muskettiers cannot be drawn into a Ring; then they mu≈øt be otherwi≈øe di≈øpo≈øed of, by making them into two Ranks, the one on the one ≈øide of the Street, and the other on the other ≈øide, facing them either in oppo≈øition, or in an oblique manner: if in oppo≈øition, they mu≈øt pre≈øent very low, and give fire three times all together as before, with one volley after another; if oblique, the one Rank is to be faced towards the upper end of the Street, and the other towards the lower end, and ≈øo may fire with le≈øs danger to each other; the Pikes to be filed away to the right and left, behind the Muskettiers before they were thus faced. And again, where they have not length of ground to contrive the Muskettiers into two ≈øingle Ranks, they may fire all together as they ≈øtand at Order, mounting up the Muzzles of their Muskets into the Air, without offending each other. Therefore according to the conveniency of the ground, it mu≈øt be the di≈øcretion of every Commander to order his men accordingly to perform his three volleys of ≈øhot in the mo≈øt gracefulle≈øt way; which being ended, they may all return to their Quarters. And thus much may ≈øuffice for ≈øatisfaction to any Commander in ordering his ≈øingle Company to any Funeral-occa≈øion, marching along of it ≈øelf.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. The ordering of a Regiment to a Funeral-occa≈øion.
div.p: WHen Companies are to march in a Regimental-way, care mu≈øt be had that the Regiment be fir≈øt drawn up according to this Rule. The Pikes to be in one Body, and the Muskettiers equally divided to flank that Body; after which let the Major make his Divi≈øions, appointing the places of every Captain and Lieutenant, where they ≈øhall lead, and where they ≈øhall bring up. After that they may move away towards the place or lodging of him that is to be interred, and there make Alt, opening the Van-guard or Muskettiers, and facing them to the Reer; then let the Body of Pikes and them interchange ground, that the Pikes may march next the Hear≈øe, in manner as before expre≈øt of a private Company, who≈øe ≈ømaller Bodies take Rule from the greater. Then let the Lieutenant-Colonel lead the Regiment, and the Colonel bring it up; and ≈øo in like manner in every Divi≈øion, the Bringers-up are to lead, and the Leaders to bring up. All Officers and their Arms being thus rever≈øt, the Front becomes the Reer, and the Reer the Front, they mu≈øt move ≈ølowly away‚ñ™ and before the Corps pa≈øs into the Church, there mu≈øt be ground re≈øerv'd, that after the Muskettiers have fir≈øt made a Guard, the Pikes may move through them, and may al≈øo in like manner file in their Ranks as the Muskettiers did, joyning to them, and making a Guard in like manner of each Arms. After which the whole Train may pa≈øs through in an orderly manner into the Church; the Souldiers in the mean time attending without until Sermon be pa≈ø≈øed over. And being all in a readine≈øs, they may give three ≈øeveral Peals, or Volleys of ≈øhot, according to ≈øuch warnings as ≈øhall be given them. After which the Souldiers being ranked again as they were, if they have conveniency of ground, the Major may cau≈øe the Captains to draw off their Companies, and troop home to their ≈øeveral Quarters, according to their be≈øt conveniency. But if they have not room, it will be mo≈øt propere≈øt for the Major to command the Muskettiers to ≈øtand, and fir≈øt to rank the Pikes again as they were. Then let the Drums beat a Troop upon the head of the Pikes in the Reer of the Colours; and let the En≈øigns and Pikes fir≈øt troop away, through the Guard of the Muskettiers; who being cleer of them, and being led by the Colonel and other Officers there appointed, the Muskettiers may al≈øo rank again in like manner, and fall in the Reer of the Pikes, following them until they come unto a convenient place or ground for the Captains drawing off their Companies, as they ≈øhall receive order from the Colonel, Lieutenant-Colonel or Major. And here I will conclude my Di≈øcour≈øe concerning the Exerci≈øing of the Infantry in all their Military Motions and Exerci≈øes.

div.head: An Adverti≈øement to the Souldiery of the Nation.
div.p:
WHereas this Book in the ≈øeveral Tracts thereof, with much variety doth ≈øet forth at large, as to their ≈øeveral kinds and changes, all your Military Motions and Po≈øtures, which may not only ≈øerve to give light to the unexperienced, and lead them by the hand into the Military Gardens of Honour, and other * Place this Sheet betwixt Bb and Cc *
places, where they are trained up, until by degrees they arrive unto perfection; but may delight and confirm the mo≈øt able and mo≈øt knowing Souldiers, whil≈øt here they read over tho≈øe ≈øeveral forms, in which heretofore they ≈øtood, when in ≈øo many Battails, with ≈øuch admirable ≈øucce≈øs they have both oppo≈øed and overcome their Enemies. And whereas even from hence may be extracted many excellent Directions and Rudiments of War, which may incourage and fully inable all active and gallant Spirits in this City of London to perform ≈øuch Commands, and to follow tho≈øe Conducts to which they ≈øhall be di≈øciplined by tho≈øe exqui≈øite and mo≈øt expert Souldiers, who ≈øhall train them up, either in the new Artillery, or any other ground of ≈øuch Honorable Imployment, and hereby be ≈øo fitted and furni≈øhed with all directions, that the performance of them ≈øhall render them mo≈øt acceptable: yet I cannot but confe≈øs, that through the u≈øual variety of this mo≈øt Noble Profe≈ø≈øion, proceeding from the great plenty which the≈øe times afford thereof (the exerci≈øe of Arms being every where ≈øo frequently ≈øhown) that the mo≈øt plain and ordinary Rules, though far more u≈øeful, are not ≈øo well relli≈øhed, many men looking more in ≈øuch your publick Trainings after novelty and delight, then ≈øolidity; which was purpo≈øely contrived by the Authors of it only for variety, and for drawing of one another to the love of Arms, and not for any prejudice to the Fundamentals of War, on which the Ruine or the Safety of the Kingdom and Commonwealth of the World depends. If peradventure it be alleadged, that he who can perform things of difficulty, will be more apt to carry on things of more facility: It may be ≈øpeedily an≈øwered, that the plain Rudiments and Principles of War, being of greate≈øt u≈øe and importance, and practi≈øed in all Armies, both in this and other Nations, they are by no means to be neglected or omitted, but to be pre≈øerved and e≈øteemed in that high manner which they do de≈øerve; for the ability in the performance of them, will no doubt more readily prefer a man, and render him more capable of any imployment, then the practice of any u≈øele≈øs or impertinent things in War. Add unto this, that the more ea≈øie and plain a man is in his command, the more readily it is received by the Souldiers, and more promptly obeyed; for new coined, and Se≈øquipedalian words of Command do ≈øo puzzle and torment the apprehen≈øions with directions and expo≈øitions to have them under≈øtood, that not only they oftentimes tran≈øcend the reach of tho≈øe that are to give them; but they do much amaze and confound the capacities of tho≈øe who are to be led and ordered by them. I do the rather make mention of this in this place, that a di≈øcreet care be taken, that no man make him≈øelf ridiculous in his undertakings or Commands; but that he may be able to give an ab≈øolute account of any Branch, which in the whole Body of the Art Military ≈øhall be propounded to him, to give ≈øatisfaction therein to any judicious Souldier, as concerning the u≈øe, purpo≈øe, and property of it; for otherwi≈øe it would ≈øignifie nothing at all. But when a man being required thereunto can render a ≈øufficient rea≈øon for what he doth, or ≈øhall voluntarily give it him≈øelf, as to this or that management of any ≈øervice in War, it will very much both content him, and inform them who ≈øhall be under his Command, and give them a ju≈øt encouragement to proceed in it: but if he ≈øhould fail in this point of Knowledge and Judgment, there is but little benefit to be expected from his Conduct; for it were far better that a man did but a little in a Souldierly way, which is proper, and carrying good approbation to men of under≈øtanding, then to ≈øpin forth a long thred with new expre≈ø≈øions and inventions, that are of no u≈øe or profit, but tend rather unto laughter, and to the lo≈øs of time, and the offence of many, and to the bringing of a generall contempt upon the Art.

And although there be many Rules which may be ≈øufficient forms to direct, and to teach to be expert in War, and doubtle≈øs are of great concernment to them who have both the. Theorick and the Practick part; yet neverthele≈øs there is no rule, but at ≈øome time or other doth admit of ≈øome exception, there being e≈øpepially ≈øo many cro≈øs events in War, that no Commander can po≈øitively tie him≈øelf up to any Rule; for occa≈øions do vary ≈øo in ≈øeveral places, that the chiefe≈øt Rule a man can walk by, is his Eye, and his Intelligence, wherein accordingly he
mu≈øt accommodate him≈øelf to encounter his Enemies. And although a Commander ≈øhould be qualified with much Knowledge, Courage and Faithfulne≈øs, the only accompli≈øhments of a true Souldier; yet they are to be attended with diligence; for in all his undertakings and performances, delays being always dangerous, it is u≈øually ≈øaid, That which is ≈øoonest done, and well done, is be≈øt done. But above all, he is to have an eye to order, which is the very life of an Army. And in acting again≈øt an Enemy, great care is to be taken not to puzzle the Souldiers, by confounding their under≈øtandings, which may occa≈øion their utter overthrow. And this makes me to reflect on what hath been mentioned heretofore. Let every Commander that truly delights in Military exerci≈øes, ≈øtudy to be exact in all plain things, and practice the Souldiers much in the exerci≈øe thereof; for this is the only u≈øe, and is altogether practi≈øed and ob≈øerved in the Field. If a man will be curious in new fancies, there are ≈øtratagems enough to be found out, in which he may exerci≈øe him≈øelf with much variety, to delight the curious, and find much matter in them to be highly valued, and e≈øteemed. But this is to be carried on in a plain way, the ≈øtudy whereof would ask ≈øome time; and it is not ea≈øily obtained by ordinary capacities, which ≈øhould content them≈øelves to learn of ≈øuch who are of higher abilities. And on this account the Art would be more highly prized, and not only bring more Honour to the Profe≈ø≈øors thereof, but even the Learners them≈øelves would become more capable of good preferment abroad, and our Military Gardens and Meetings would much more flouri≈øh, and be beheld with more delight and ≈øatisfaction, not only by the Souldiers them≈øelves, but all other Spectators what≈øoever.

I do not de≈øire to be mi≈ø-under≈øtood by this Di≈øcour≈øe, that herein I ≈øhould go about to ≈øtartle any ingenious Souldier, or di≈ø≈øwade him from any thing that ≈øhall be new to his Invention, which is proper: I ≈øhall rather incourage him, and be glad to under≈øtand of him what Rea≈øon he can give for every thing he doth, and of what u≈øe it may be unto the Publick, and then it will admit of no controulment. But vacant ≈øea≈øons may be u≈øed for variety and delight, in making experiments of wit, fancy, and ingenuity; provided they do not dwell too much upon them. But the ≈øub≈øtantial and ≈øolid things of War are above all things to be preci≈øely regarded, without which an Army, though of the mo≈øt valiant men, will be expo≈øed to the greate≈øt dangers, and fall into a mo≈øt certain Ruine.

I ≈øhould here humbly offer my Advice to the mo≈øt eminent Meetings in the Artillery and Military Gardens, in the latter of which I was heretofore a Member, and ≈øtill am a true Lover, and honourer both of that, and all other places like unto it: My advice is, that on their days of publick Meeting, they would have chiefly before their eyes the main Grounds and Principles in the Art of War, which (through permi≈ø≈øion) I am per≈øwaded, would cau≈øe greater appearances, and make their Ground to flouri≈øh more then ever; to the Honour of our Nation, and the increa≈øe of experienced and able Commanders, if ever this Commonwealth ≈øhould ≈øtand in further need of them. And becau≈øe the Ambition of ≈øome doth ≈øtrive to aim at higher things in their thoughts then what is practi≈øed abroad, I have thought good to ≈øet down the plain way of exerci≈øing a Company, as u≈øually it is practi≈øed in the Army, our Companies con≈øi≈øting of one hundred men, two parts being Muskettiers, and a third Pikes, the depth of our Files being always ≈øix deep in the Armies of England, Scotland, and Ireland: the Company being drawn up abre≈øt, the Exerci≈øe is as followeth, they ≈øtanding in their clo≈øe≈øt Order in Ranks and Files.

Fir≈øt, The Muskettiers being on both flanks, fir≈øt firing, let the fir≈øt Rank ≈øtand and fire, every Rank pa≈ø≈øing through before his Leader, after ≈øtanding and fire, till all have fired over twice, or four times, the Pikes moving ≈ølowly in the mean time; they will upon a ≈øtand be reduced as at fir≈øt.

Secondly, Bring all the Muskettiers before the Pikes, then let them fire in the Front, falling off, and flank the Pikes upon the Right. Fire upon the right flank, the body marching, and the Muskettiers to pa≈øs on the left flank: after the Pikes may charge to the right, the body moving again. Let the Muskettiers fire on the left flank, and fall in the Reer of the Pikes, who may after charge their Pikes on the left. The body marching, the Muskettiers may fire in the Reer, and fall off to the Right and Left, and flank the Pikes as at the fir≈øt; the body facing about, the Pikes may charge to the Reer. We u≈øually fire in the Front ≈øometimes two ranks ≈øtanding, the re≈øt pa≈ø≈øing by turns; then ≈øtanding after they have gained the ground before their Leaders, do fire, till all have fired twice: other times three Ranks fire together; the fir≈øt kneels down, the ≈øecond ≈øtoops, the third ≈øtands upright; then falling down, the three la≈øt Ranks pa≈øs through, and do the like. This being done twice, reduces them all as at fir≈øt, the Pikes moving ≈ølowly; this being the u≈øual way of exerci≈øing our Companies in the Army.
