div.head: THE PUBLISHER To the READER.
div.p: HAving now an opportunity of reprinting the preceding Treati≈øe of Military Di≈øcipline, written by Lieutenant-Colonel Richard Elton, containing the Di≈øcipline and Exerci≈øe of Foot-companies, Regiments, Brigades, &c. I thought it not convenient to let the Infantry March into the Field of the [World] any more, without the Cavalry, nor they without their Train of Artillery: I have therefore endeavoured to make good the words of the Title, namely [The Compleat Body of the Art Military] by adding the following Treati≈øes: wherefore, to the Infantry here is added Cavalry, and In≈øtructions for them, both in Po≈øture and Motion; and for both, here is provided Quarters; and for the ≈øecuring of the Quarters, we have ≈øurrounded them with Intrenchments, Redoubts, Bulwarks, Hanworks, &c. and for the defending and maintaining of the≈øe Works, we have brought hither our Great Artillery.
The additional Treati≈øes in brief are the≈øe:
1. The Names, Offices, Duties and Qualifications of all Officers belonging to an Army, from the General to the Private Souldier.
2. The manner of Enrolling, Arming and Exerci≈øing of the Cavalry, both in Po≈øtures and Motions.

3. The manner of the Marching of an Army, both Hor≈øe and
Foot, with its Train of Artillery, Bag and Baggage, and all other nece≈ø≈øaries thereunto belonging.

4. The order of De≈øigning, Mea≈øuring and laying out the Quarters for the Encamping of an Army, either of Hor≈øe or Foot, or both; together with the Artillery, and all requi≈øites; with Orders for Watching, and other Orders to be ob≈øerved in the Quarters.

5. The manner of Fortifying and ≈øecuring of the≈øe Quarters, by Intrenchments, &c. and how to Erect a Fort of any number of ≈øides from four to ten, with their ≈øeveral Ramparts, Bulwarks, Parapets, and all other the appurtenances thereunto relating.

6. There is added ≈øome part of the Gunners Art, namely, ≈øo much thereof as is nece≈ø≈øary for a Souldier in general to know, and in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, to put in practice; with the making and u≈øe of the two mo≈øt material and ≈øerviceable Fireworks, namely, the Petard and Granado.

Other things I could have added, but I (with the advice and probation of my Military acquaintance) deemed the≈øe ≈øufficient: and as the Book is Entituled, The Compleat Body of the Art Military; ≈øo I am per≈øwaded that he that can attain to perfection in what is here delivered, may be accounted a Compleat Souldier: And that all Practitioners in the Art Military may attain to be ≈øuch, is the hearty wi≈øh of

div.head: A SUPPLEMENT TO THE COMPLEAT BODY OF The Art Military.
How the Officers of an Army in general ought to be qualified.
div.p: IN every Souldier (e≈øpecially a Commander) the≈øe e≈ø≈øential qualities are required, viz. Knowledge, Experience, Valour and Dexterity; of which, how many are there that take upon them the profe≈ø≈øion of a Souldier, that hardly know what any of the Words mean; but think their patrimony a ≈øufficient Commi≈ø≈øion for them, to take a Command upon them, they wanting Knowledge how to manage the men under their Command; Experience in the Art Military being a ≈øtranger to them. But certainly, if ≈øuch men did but ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øider how various and changeable the ≈øtate of a Souldier is, that in a moment he may loo≈øe that honour and reputation he hath been many years obtaining, and ≈øeen the ignominie and di≈øgrace which ≈øome have come unto by their mi≈øcarriages, they would doubtle≈øs be very cautious, and not run headlong into an imployment of ≈øuch importance.

But he that hath had experience by being under command for a time, and arrived to the degree of a Captain gradually, as from a Corporal to a Quarterma≈øter, thence to a Cornet, and ≈øo to a Lieutenant; he is then well prepared for a Captains charge: for having pa≈ø≈øed the≈øe inferior Offices, depre≈ø≈øeth tho≈øe vehement pa≈ø≈øions which by nature otherwi≈øe are apt to ari≈øe in young men, which in a Commander are dangerous: Be≈øides, his accu≈øtoming him≈øelf to the former employments, maketh him Valorous; ≈øo that if he be ≈øuddenly a≈ø≈øailed, he can recollect him≈øelf without a≈øtoni≈øhment; and to the forementioned Qualifications adde this, his accu≈øtoming him≈øelf to hard≈øhip, as to Watch, Travel, Labour, endure Hunger and cold, &c.

His chief end mu≈øt be Honour; to attain which, he mu≈øt be vigilant, and let no opportunity ≈ølip to attempt any brave exploit or ≈øtratagem. And for that end he will be always ob≈øerving his Enemy, and contriving how to circumvent him in his de≈øigns; knowing that in War no material matter can be effected without vigilancie and danger. But let him not always tru≈øt to his own judgement, but advi≈øe with his Officers al≈øo; and upon any ≈øuch enterprize let him take to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance ≈øuch of his Souldiers as he ≈øees de≈øerve well, and quit him≈øelf at ≈øuch a time of the debauched part of his Souldiery. He mu≈øt always a≈øpire to higher degrees
of Honour. Let him hate Covetou≈øne≈øs: for nothing more will continue his Souldiers good affections towards him then Liberality. Gaming let him dete≈øt; and in≈øtead of gorgeous Apparel, let him delight in good Arms and Hor≈øes. Let L ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ry and Drunkenne≈øs be enemies to him, which his Souldiers perceiving, will be the more vigilant to rec ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m in them≈øelves by his Example.
But above all, let him ≈øee before his eyes the fear of God, deporting him≈øelf internally and externally blamele≈øs. Thus by good Example of the Commander, the commanded will be reformed.
Having given you an account how every Commander in general ought to be qualified, I will now ≈øhew you the Office, Duty, and Qualification of every Commander in particular. And

div.head: I. Of the General of the Hor≈øe.
div.p: THe General of the Hor≈øe was wont to ≈øupply the place of Lieutenant-General of the Army, and in the ab≈øence of the Lord General to command the whole Army. It is true, that the Lord Mar≈øhal, fora≈ømuch as he giveth the Orders (according to the opinions of ≈øome) u≈øed to have the ≈øuperiority of Command; whence it is, that the Lord General ab≈øenting him≈øelf from the Army, u≈øed to take along with him either the General of Hor≈øe, or the Lord Mar≈øhal, to avoid competition between them.

He mu≈øt be a man of Experience and Valour, having in charge the nerves of the principal Forces, and upon whom the ≈øucce≈øs of many de≈øigns and actions depend, they being u≈øually executed by the Cavalry, where the charging of the Enemy orderly u≈øually giveth Victory; and the di≈øorderly charging, di≈øturbs oft-times the whole Army. Witne≈øs that Battle at Gembloers de≈øcribed by Meteren, where the Infantry were overthrown by their own Hor≈øe. He is to take particular notice not only of the Officers, but the private Souldiers al≈øo, rewarding them when vigilant, and upon ≈øome ≈øignal act advancing them to higher preferment, and puni≈øhing Delinquents and ≈øuch as are deficient in their endeavours: by which means the good will love, and the bad fear him. He is to ≈øee the Cavalry be furni≈øhed with all nece≈ø≈øaries, and be always in good equipage. A Troop being to march, he is to ≈øee that they be provided with Naggs, for the pre≈øervation of the Souldiers Hor≈øes; for with them they mu≈øt go to forrage after their March, and pre≈øently enter into Guard or Quarter without re≈øt, to refre≈øh their Hor≈øes. The Captains are not to ab≈øent them≈øelves from their Companies, nor to place of di≈øplace Officers without his leave and approbation. He hath his particular Officers a part; and in that which concerneth the Cavalry, neither Lord Mar≈øhal nor General him≈øelf di≈øpo≈øe of any thing without his advice. When he pa≈ø≈øeth through the Quarters either of the Cavalry or Infantry, his Trumpets are to ≈øound; but not where the Lord General is pre≈øent, or where he lodgeth. When he commandeth in the Army (in ab≈øence of the Lord General) upon occa≈øion of fight, his place is in the Battle, that he may the better give Order to all. U≈øually he hath a Company to lodge with him, to ≈øerve him as his Guard, and ≈øix or more of his Company attending on him. He ≈øhould not re≈øolve upon any enterprize, unle≈øs he con≈øider of all that might happen, and propound to him≈øelf greater difficulties in the action then in reality there be, and ≈øo prepare remedies ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing the ≈øaid difficulties, it being a ≈øingular benefit to be able to fore≈øee (with good judgement) tho≈øe things which might ≈øucceed in the uncertain and variable accidents of War. As Sertorius ≈øaith, A good Commander ≈øhould rather look behind him then before him.

div.head: II. Of the Lieutenant-General of Hor≈øe.
div.p:
THe Charge of the Lieutenant-General of the Hor≈øe is of great importance, and mu≈øt therefore be ≈øupplied by a Souldier of known Experience and Valour: careful and vigilant he mu≈øt be; he marcheth and lodgeth for the mo≈øt
part with the Cavalry: he ought to be well ver≈øed in the ways of the Country, that he may either meet or avoid his Enemy as occa≈øion ≈øhall required. He mu≈øt be always bu≈øied about his Enemies motion, con≈øidering with him≈øelf from what place they may ≈øhew them≈øelves, with what number, whether Infantry or Cavalry; in what time they may probably come upon him, and where to place him≈øelf to advantage to prevent them.

He mu≈øt be circum≈øpect and wary in the choice of the place appointed for Quarters, in preparing good Guards, cau≈øing the High-ways to be cleared, and by-ones di≈øcovered, placing men on tho≈øe places where he ≈øuppo≈øes the Enemy may make head; ≈øending forth Scouts continually, and placing Sentinels, omitting no diligence to ≈øecure the Quarter where the Cavalry findeth it ≈øelf to be expo≈øed to mo≈øt danger, e≈øpecially if they be lodged without Infantry. He mu≈øt be ≈øure to have Spies in and about his Enemies Quarters. He mu≈øt look that the Captains wrong not their Souldiers, but that he ≈øee them well armed, and kept in good Order, and that they and his Officers ob≈øerve good Orders and Di≈øcipline. As he ought to be ≈øevere in puni≈øhing, ≈øo he mu≈øt be ready and willing to hear his Souldiers ju≈øt complaints, and relieve them. He mu≈øt not ≈øuffer any extortion to be u≈øed by him≈øelf or others, by which the Country is ruined, and the Souldiery hated: for too great liberty of the Souldiers produceth bad effects.

He ought to be knowing in the command of the Infantry; for upon occa≈øion of ≈øending a good part of the Cavalry to ≈øeveral places, he hath the charge not only of the Hor≈øe, but of the Foot al≈øo: And in the ab≈øence of the General, the Orders from the Lord General or Lord Mar≈øhal come to him, and to him are all reports made of the occurrences of the Cavalry and Army. He may ≈øu≈øpend a Captain of his command, upon ju≈øt cau≈øe; but cannot re≈øtore him again without order from the General, who mu≈øt fir≈øt give notice thereof to the Lord General. When he pa≈ø≈øeth the Quarters of Cavalry, the Trumpets ≈øound; but not in the pre≈øence of the General, or in his Quarters. When the General of Hor≈øe commands the whole Army, and therefore takes his place in the Battle, the Lieutenant-General placeth him≈øelf in the Van-guard of the Cavalry, where otherwi≈øe the General u≈øeth to be.

div.head: III. Of the Commi≈ø≈øary-General,
div.p: HE ought to be a good and experienced Souldier; for that in the ab≈øence of the Lieutenant-General he is to have the command. He mu≈øt reconcile Differences which at any time ari≈øe among the Souldiers, as having mo≈øt to do with the Souldiery. He is to keep Li≈øts of the Guards, Convoys and other ≈øervices, and is to di≈øtribute the Orders. Every evening he is to go and receive the Orders and the Word, and having given it to the General and Lieutenant-General, he is to give it to the Quarterma≈øter-General, for him farther to di≈øtribute. He is upon all occa≈øions of ≈øingular u≈øe, and entru≈øted with the Execution of the Orders. In appointing the places or lodgings in ≈øeveral Exploits, he mu≈øt be free from partiality; and ≈øuch as at one time have cau≈øe of di≈øcontent, he mu≈øt make them amends the next; that ≈øo he may ≈øee it was of nece≈ø≈øity, not of partiality. His place being of great importance, ought therefore to be ≈øupplied by one knowing and experienced.

div.head: IV. Of the Quarterma≈øter-General.
div.p:
THe Office of the Quarterma≈øter-General is to a appoint the Lodgings or Quarterings; wherefore he mu≈øt be well acquainted with the Countrey, with the Towns and Villages about it, not only by Maps (which in ≈øome mea≈øure will inform him) but by his own experience, that he may the better know where to place the Corps-du-gards and Sentinels, and vi≈øit them by day and night, and order what ways to ≈øecure them: and is to keep a Li≈øt of all the Guards, Convoys, Cavalcadoes (or exploits by Hor≈øe.) He mu≈øt ≈øhew the Allarm-place to the particular
Quarter-ma≈øters when they receive the Word of him in the Evening. He mu≈øt be very cautious in giving in his reports true; and if any Order for ha≈øte be delivered him by mouth, he mu≈øt not tru≈øt it to others, but mu≈øt him≈øelf deliver it.

div.head: V. Of the Captain.
div.p: A Captain ought to be a man Sober, Continent, and mode≈øt in his Apparel, aiming rather at good Arms and Hor≈øes, then gorgeous Apparel; to ≈øee his Souldiers punctual in their re≈øpective Duties, and often calling them to exerci≈øe. Let him be generous, and not given to Gaming, le≈øt the Souldiers pay by that means be dimini≈øhed, which will overthrow his credit. He is diligently to ob≈øerve the Orders he receives; and to be punctually ready with his Troop where appointed, him≈øelf being fir≈øt on Horsback, ≈øeeing his Troop compleat and full before he march. He ought to know every Souldier in his Troop by name, that upon any Exploit he may draw forth ≈øuch as he di≈øcerns mo≈øt fit for the bu≈øine≈øs he hath in agitation. The Captains taking notice of a Souldier does very much animate and encourage him. He mu≈øt cheri≈øh his well-de≈øerving Souldiers, and ca≈øhier the idle and debauched. Let him always have 2 or 3 of his Souldiers well skilled in the Countrey, for they may ≈øerve him as Guides, for that tho≈øe of the adjacent Towns or Villages are not always to be had, nor is it at all times ≈øafe to intru≈øt them: to the≈øe Souldiers he is to contribute ≈øomething extraordinary be≈øides their pay.

Out of his Troop he is to chu≈øe his Lieutenant, Cornet, &c. impartially by their merit, and not for favour or affection; by which he ≈øhall be beloved of his Souldiers, and not be forced to alter his choice by the Generals Order.
In the ab≈øence of the Captain, the Lieutenant commands the Troop.

div.head: VI. Of the Lieutenant.
div.p: THe Lieutenant of a Troop ought to be an experienced Souldier, having attained thereunto by the experience he attained in being a Corporal and Cornet, from which by de≈øert he attained to be a Lieutenant. In the Captains ab≈øence he commands the Troop. He mu≈øt be diligent to ≈øee the Souldiers do their duties, and ≈øee that their Hor≈øes and Arms be in good ca≈øe. He is to bring up the Reer of the Troop, and ≈øee the Souldiers keep Rank, File, and Di≈øtance orderly after the Captain and Cornet, and to permit none to depart from the Body or Troop. In fight he is to be ≈øtill in the Reer with his Sword drawn, encouraging the Souldiers, and cutting, if not killing ≈øuch as ≈øhall pre≈øume to flinch. He is to keep a Li≈øt of the names and ≈øirnames of the Souldiers in his Troop, and know the ≈øufficiency of each Souldier, that he may make u≈øe of them accordingly.

The Troop being to go to Guard, when neer, the Lieutenant is to go before to the Lieutenant that is to be relieved, and take notice of the Corps-du-guard, and receive information from him, when and where the Sentinels are to be placed, what ways to clear, and all other things nece≈ø≈øary; and he mu≈øt vi≈øit the Sentinels often both by night and day, he fir≈øt him≈øelf having placed them. If the Troop be lodged in a Village, the Billets mu≈øt be ≈øigned by the Quarterma≈øter of the Troop, and di≈øtributed to the Souldiers before the Cornets lodging, where the Alto is made to attend the ≈øaid Billets; ≈øo that in ca≈øe of an Allarm, the Souldiers may know whither to repair. If they ≈øtay longer then a day in one place, the Lieutenant is to vi≈øit the hou≈øes to ≈øee that the Souldiers keep good orders; and being to go away, to bid them be careful to put out their Fires. If they go to be lodged in a Town or Fort, and there to keep Garri≈øon, the Lieutenant is to accommodate their Lodgings according to their degrees and de≈øerts; and where≈øoever they lodge longer then a day, he mu≈øt write the name of the Souldiers upon the ≈øaid Billets, that if the Souldier commit any Mi≈ødemeanor, he may be the readier di≈øcovered and puni≈øhed.

When the Troop is to March, and the Trumpets ≈øound to Hor≈øe, he mu≈øt be fir≈øt mounted, and ≈øee the Souldiers do the ≈øame with all ≈øpeed; and finding any lingering, either out of idlene≈øs, or an intent to Plunder, ≈øeverely to cha≈øti≈øe them. He ought to have knowledge of the ways: And if the Troop be charged by the Enemy, him≈øelf with ≈øome of the mo≈øt experienced Souldiers, and be≈øt mounted in the Troop, are to ≈øtay behind.

div.head: VII. Of the Cornet.
div.p: IN the ab≈øence of the Captain and Lieutenant, the Cornet is to command the Troops, but in the Captains pre≈øence upon a March, his place is in the Front before the fir≈øt Rank, but behind the Captain: in his charging of an Enemy, he is to charge with the Captain, and endeavour to break his Standard upon the Enemy; and being broken, and falling to the ground, he is not to regard taking it up again, his honour lying much in the breaking of his Standard in cha≈øe either of Hor≈øe or Foot: But if the Enemy ≈øhould take the Cornets Standard unbroken, it were to him a great di≈øgrace. And this is contrary to the practice of an En≈øign in the Infantry, the pre≈øerving of who≈øe Colours is ever e≈øteemed his greate≈øt glory; as is evident in the Example of one Jaques Martaeus, who, when mo≈øt of his Souldiers had for≈øaken him, he fought ≈øo long as he could; and finding him≈øelf over-powred, wound him≈øelf up in his Colours and dyed.

The Cornet of Cuira≈ø≈øiers in march hath his place at the head of the Troop, and pre≈øenteth him≈øelf in the Alarm-place; but in fight, in the mid≈øt of the Troop, having two third parts of the Souldiers behind him. [And this is the place of his marching in the≈øe times, which does mo≈øt agree with the manner of marching of the Infantry, where the En≈øign marches before the divi≈øion of Pikes.] The Souldiers in the Front-divi≈øion of the Troop, mu≈øt be tho≈øe be≈øt armed, and the mo≈øt couragious. He mu≈øt keep a Li≈øt of the Troop, and ≈øend ≈øo many to the Guard, as the Captain or Lieutenant ≈øhall appoint. Once every day, he is at the Lord-Generals pa≈ø≈øing by the Troop to do obey≈øance to him, by inclining his body and Cornet towards the ground.

div.head: VIII. Of the particular Quarter-Ma≈øters.
div.p: THe Quarter-Ma≈øters duty is, (when all the Troops are lodged together) to accompany the Quarter-Ma≈øter-General in his laying out of the general Quarters; but if they are to be lodged in ≈øeveral places, ≈øome of the particular Quarter-ma≈øters accompany the Lieutenant-General, others the Commi≈ø≈øary-General; and if a Captain command the Quarters, then the particular Quarter-Ma≈øter maketh the Quarter. There is much tru≈øt repo≈øed in him, as the di≈øtributing of the Word and the Billets; and therefore ought to be hone≈øt and true to his charge. When he goes with the Quarter-Ma≈øter-General to make the Quarters or Lodgings, he mu≈øt be very diligent, taking with him two or three of his Souldiers, which are to return to their Troop, as guides to conduct the re≈øt to their Quarters.

div.head: IX. Of the Corporals.
div.p: THe Corporal is to a≈ø≈øi≈øt his Lieutenant in placing the Sentinels; the Harquebu≈øiers are to di≈øcover and ≈øcoure the ways, and to officiate as forerunners or Scouts, under the charge of one of their Corporals, who mu≈øt be an experienced per≈øon in re≈øpect of the ways. If any place of importance be to be guarded, a Corporal with his Squadron is ≈øent thither; he mu≈øt be capable of good literature, for that he mu≈øt keep a particular Li≈øt of his Squadron.

div.head: X. Of the Trumpeters.
div.p: A Trumpeter ought to be a politick, di≈øcreet and cunning per≈øon; for that the delivery of Emba≈ø≈øies to and from the Enemy, are by him performed. In going upon any ≈øuch, he ought to have a vigilant eye upon their Works, Sentinels, and other things that lye in his pa≈ø≈øage, and privately conceal them till his return. And in his di≈øcour≈øe with his adver≈øary, very cautious and catching, or circumventing him, by trapping him in his parley: Be≈øides this, he mu≈øt ≈øound all the ≈øounds of the Trumpet; as the Bontezelle, that is, Set on the Saddle; the Cheval, which is, Mount on Hor≈øe-back; the Standard, that is, Repair to your Colours. One Trumpet mu≈øt always lodge with the Cornet, (for which the Captain mu≈øt give allowance) and he mu≈øt always have his Trumpet about him upon a ≈øudden Alarm.

div.head: XI. Of the Auditor.
div.p: THe Auditor ought to be a man of great integrity, and under≈øtanding in the Law: In the ab≈øence of the Auditor-General, he heareth and judgeth the cau≈øes of the Cavalry, and maketh report thereof to his General, or in his ab≈øence, to the Lieutenant-General; without who≈øe order he cannot execute any of his ≈øentences. He is to keep neer the per≈øon of the General or Lieutenant-General, who are to ≈øee him re≈øpected. He is to take notice of the prizes of Victuals brought to the Quarters of Hor≈øe, that they be ≈øold at rea≈øonable rates; and to ≈øee that the Victuals ≈øuffer no extortion by the Provo≈øt-Mar≈øhal, or his Officers.

In the States Army, and at this time with us, the Hor≈øe and Foot have but one Auditor-General, who pa≈ø≈øeth no ≈øentence him≈øelf; but it is done by a Council of War, in which every Captain hath a Vote.

div.head: XII. Of the Provo≈øt-Mar≈øhal.
div.p: THe Provo≈øt-Mar≈øhal ought to be an hone≈øt man; for that he is to look to the Weights and Mea≈øures, and to protect the Victuallers and Sutlers from the in≈øolencies of the Souldiers. Him≈øelf, or one of his men, mu≈øt always be in the Market-place, and is to inform him≈øelf at what rates the Sutlers buy their Victual, that the Commi≈ø≈øary and Auditor may rate them accordingly. He mu≈øt ≈øee the Orders publi≈øhed in the Hor≈øe-quarter ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved, and he mu≈øt cleer tho≈øe Quarters of vagrants and idle fellows. He mu≈øt always carry his Truncheon in his hand; and having the ≈øame, it is death for any Souldier to lay hands on him. If he be to take a pri≈øoner, he is not to enter the Quarter without leave of the Chief, who is to cau≈øe the Delinquent to be delivered up to him; but if the Delinquent offer to make e≈øcape, he may then enter the Quarter by his own Authority. In marching, he is to cleer the Ways, and to prevent the ≈øtragling Souldiers of Pillaging.

div.head: CONCERNING The Enrolling, Arming, and Exerci≈øing OF THE CAVALRY.
div.p: ALl things mu≈øt be pre≈øuppo≈øed in a Souldier to be enrolled into the the Cavalry, which are common to him with the Infantry; as ≈øoundne≈øs of Body, vigour of Members, of fitting Age, between 20 and 40. a Re≈øolution to addict him≈øelf to that Profe≈ø≈øion, and a De≈øire to learn it; a vertuous emulation of Advancement by Merit, due Obedience to his Superiours, and a ≈øtrict ob≈øervation of Military Di≈øcipline; above all, the fear of God, which will direct him to follow Virtue, and abhor Vices: with the≈øe general Qualifications he ought to be endowed; and as to the Profe≈ø≈øion he hath now undertaken, the≈øe particular Faculties are nece≈ø≈øary. He ought to be active, nimble, and to know well what belongs to a Hor≈øe; he mu≈øt be curious and careful to keep his Hor≈øe and Arms in good order. He mu≈øt wear a Scarf of his Princes or Generals Colours, and not put it off though he go out of his Quarter, whether alone or in Company, by which means (be≈øides the Ornament) they will (by the thoughts of who≈øe Badge it is) forbear many unfitting Words and Actions, they being ≈øubject by that to be di≈øcovered.

div.head: I. Of the Arming of the Cuira≈ø≈øier.
div.p: THe Cuira≈ø≈øier is to be armed in this manner. His Hor≈øe being about 15 hand high, ≈øtrong, ≈øwift, and well managed. His Arms, a clo≈øe Ca≈øque, or Head-piece, Gorget, Bre≈øt, Pi≈øtol and Caliver-proof, the Back, Poldrons, Vanbraces, two Gauntlets, Ta≈ø≈øers, Cui≈ø≈øets, Culets, or Guard de vain, all fitting to his Body. A good Sword, very ≈øtiffe and ≈øharp pointed, with Girdle and Hangers ≈øo fa≈øtned upon his Cuira≈øs, as he may readily draw it; a Buff-Coat with long skirts, to wear between his Armour and his Cloaths.

He mu≈øt have two Ca≈øes with good Fire-lock-Pi≈øtols hanging at his Saddle, the Barrel being 18 Inches long, and the bore fitting for Bullets of 20 or 24 in the pound to rowl in. He is to have a Boy and a ≈øpare Nag to carry his ≈øpare Arms and Oat-≈øack, and to get him Forrage. His Saddle and Bit mu≈øt be ≈øtrong, made after the be≈øt manner: he mu≈øt wear his Scarf, and mu≈øt have his Bridle made with a Chain, to prevent cutting.

div.head: II. Of managing of the Hor≈øe and Arms.
div.p:
COncerning the Hor≈øe (≈øuppo≈øing him to be of ≈øufficient ≈øtature and ≈øtrength, nimble of joynts, and ≈øure of foot) he mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity be made fit for ≈øervice,
≈øo that you may have him to be ready at command, to pace, trot, gallop, to run in full carreer; al≈øo to advance, ≈øtop, retire, and turn readily to either hand, and all with alacrity and obedience. Now to bring him to this ready turning, he is to be ridden the Ring, and Figure of 8. fir≈øt in a large, then in a narrower compa≈øs. Fir≈øt upon his pace, then upon the trot, and ≈øo to the gallop and carreer. He may be taught the≈øe things by u≈øing the Hand, Leg, and Voyce: for the Hand (ob≈øerving not to move the Arm, only the Wri≈øt) if you would have him to face to the Left, a little motion of the little Finger on that Rein, and a touch of the left Leg (without u≈øing the Spur) doth it. If to face or turn to the Left about, then a little harder. If you would have him to Trot, move both your Legs a little forward; for the gallop, more forward; and for the carreer, to yerk them mo≈øt forward, and to move the Body a little forward al≈øo with it. After every motion performed, it were good to keep him ≈øome ≈ømall time in that motion: As when you bid him ≈øtand, to ≈øtand a while, &c. Al≈øo it were not ami≈øs (after every thing well performed) to give him ≈øome Bread or Gra≈øs for a reward. For the Voyce, you may u≈øe the Words, Advance, Hold, Run, or the like: but becau≈øe the Voyce cannot always be heard, it were therefore be≈øt to u≈øe him mo≈øt to the motion of the Hand and Leg. It is al≈øo very nece≈ø≈øary, that you teach him to go ≈øide-ways; this he may be brought unto by laying his Provender ≈øomwhat far from him in the Manger, and keeping him from turning his head towards it. You mu≈øt u≈øe him to the ≈ømell of Gun-powder, the ≈øight of Fire and Armor, the hearing of Shots, Drums, and Trumpets; all by degrees, and with di≈øcretion. When he is at his Oats, you may fire a little Gun-powder at a good di≈øtance from him, and ≈øo neerer by degrees: Afterwards a Pi≈øtol at a di≈øtance, and ≈øo neerer by degrees; and in like manner may a Drum or Trumpet be u≈øed. He may ≈øometimes be dre≈ø≈øed in Armor, and eat his Oats upon a Drum-head. It will be u≈øeful ≈øometimes to cau≈øe two Muskettiers, at convenient di≈øtance from you, to fire at each other, and thereupon to ride up clo≈øe to him. Al≈øo to ride him upon a compleat Armor upon a ≈øtake, and overthrow it, and trample upon it; by which means he will grow bold, not fearing to attempt any Object. You may u≈øe him to mountanous and uneven Ways, and teach him to Leap, Swim, &c.

div.head: Of Exerci≈øing the Cuira≈ø≈øier.
div.p: BEfore I ≈øpeak of the particular Po≈øtures belonging to the exerci≈øing of the Cuira≈ø≈øier, I will begin with this nece≈ø≈øary preparative to Po≈øture, viz.
Command. 1. To Hor≈øe.

Direction. Both Reins hanging in a loo≈øe po≈øture, over the Hor≈øe-neck, and upon the Pummel of the Saddle, the Hor≈øman is fir≈øt to take the end of the Reins, above the Button, in his right Hand, and with the Thumb and two fir≈øt Fingers of that Hand, to draw them to an even length. Then putting the little finger of his left Hand between both Reins, under the Button, with the other three fingers of the ≈øame Hand, on the farther Rein, and the Thumb on the nether ≈øide of the Button, to gra≈øp both Reins, that ≈øo (before he endeavour to mount) he may have his Hor≈øe-head in ballance and at command; then gra≈øping the Pummel of the Saddle with his left hand, and ≈øtanding with his full body clo≈øe to the Hor≈øe-≈øide, and ju≈øt between the Bol≈øter and Cantle of the Saddle (always on the nere ≈øide of the Hor≈øe) with the help of his right Hand, he ≈øhall put the left Foot into the left Stirrup, and with his right Hand taking fa≈øt hold on the highe≈øt part of the Cantle behind, he ≈øhall (by the help of both Hands) gently (but ≈øtrongly, and in an upright po≈øture, without inclining his body to either hand) rai≈øe him≈øelf until he may ≈øtand perpendicular upon his left Foot, and
then ca≈øting over his right-leg, place him≈øelf in the Saddle. He being now mounted, his Po≈øtures are as follow:
Command. 2. ∆≤ncap your Pi≈øtols.
Direction. Turn down the Caps of your Pi≈øtol-ca≈øes (or Hol≈øters) with your right-hand.
Command. 3. Draw your Pi≈øtol.
Direction. Draw your Pi≈øtol out of the Ca≈øe with your right-hand, (always the left Pi≈øtol fir≈øt) mounting the Muzzle of it.
Command. 4. Order your Pi≈øtol.
Direction. Sink your Pi≈øtol into your Bridle-hand, and remove your right-hand towards the Muzzle, and re≈øt the But-end upon the right Thigh.
Command. 5. Span your Pi≈øtol.
Direction. Sink your Pi≈øtol into your bridle-hand, and take your Spanner in your right-hand, and put it upon the Axle-tree, winding it about till it ≈øtick, and return your Spanner to its place.
Command. 6. Prime your Pi≈øtol.

Direction. Holding your Pi≈øtol in your bridle-hand, (as when you Span'd it) take your Priming-box in your right-hand, pre≈ø≈øing the Spring with your fore-finger to open the Box, put Powder into the Pan.
Command. 7. Shut your Pan.
Direction. Pre≈øs in the Pan-pin with your Thumb, and ≈øhut it.
Command. 8. Ca≈øt about your Pi≈øtol.
Direction. With your bridle-hand ca≈øt about your Pi≈øtol, and hold it on your left ≈øide with the Muzzle upwards.
Command. 9. Gage your Fla≈øque.
Direction. Take your Fla≈øque in your right-hand, and with your fore-finger pull back the Spring; then turn the mouth of the Fla≈øque downwards, and let go the Spring.
Command. 10. Lade your Pi≈øtol.
Direction. Pre≈øs down the Spring which openeth the Fla≈øque with your fore-finger, and bringing, the mouth thereof to the Muzzle of the Pi≈øtol, turn the Powder into the Barrel.
Command. 11. Draw your Rammer.
Direction. Draw your Rammer with your right-hand turned, and hold it with the head downwards.
Command. 12. Lade with Bullet, and ram home.

Direction. Hold the Rammer-head in your right-hand, and take the Bullet out of your mouth with your thumb and fore-finger, and put it into the Muzzle of your Pi≈øtol, and your Rammer after it, and ≈øo ram home.
Command. 13. Return your Rammer.
Direction. Draw forth your Rammer with your right-hand, and return it to its place.
Command. 14. Pull down your Cock.
Direction. Bring your Pi≈øtol towards your right≈øide with your bridle-hand; and re≈øting the But-end upon your thigh, with your right-hand pull down the Cock.
Command. 15. Recover your Pi≈øtol.
Direction. Take your Pi≈øtol into your right-hand, and mount the Muzzle.
Command. 16. Pre≈øent and give Fire.

Direction. Your Pi≈øtol being in your right-hand, with your fore-finger upon the Tricker, incline the Muzzle thereof towards your Mark (with a fixed eye, and by degrees) on the right ≈øide of your Hor≈øe-head, turning your right-hand, ≈øo that the Pi≈øtols Lock may be upwards; having obtained your Mark, draw the Tricker and give Fire.
Command. 17. Return your Pi≈øtol.
Direction. Return your Pi≈øtol, and with your right-hand put it into your Ca≈øe.

p.hi: Concerning the Snap-hans Pi≈øtol, tho≈øe Po≈øtures wherein it differeth from the Fire-lock Pi≈øtol, are the≈øe.

div.p: Command. 18. Bend your Cock.
Direction. Hold your Pi≈øtol in your Bridle-hand, and with your right hand bend your Cock.
Command. 19. Guard your Cock.
Direction. Pull down the Back-lock with your right hand, it will ≈øecure the Cock from going off.
Command. 20. Order your Hammer.
Direction. Draw down the Hammer upon the Pan, with your right hand.
Command. 21. Free your Cock.
Direction. Thru≈øt back the Back-lock with your right thumb, thereby to give the Cock liberty.

For the more ea≈øie and ≈øpeeding lading of the Pi≈øtol, for the gaining of time, and avoiding the carrying of either Flask or Touch-box, there is an invention of a Spanner or Key, which contains ≈øix Charges of Powder at the lea≈øt, and priming-Powder ≈øufficient for tho≈øe Charges, and for the Cartouches wherewith the Pi≈øtol-ca≈øes be furni≈øhed; which the Cuira≈ø≈øier will find to be of very good u≈øe.

The Cartouches are made of white Paper, cut into convenient breadth and length, and rowled upon the Rammer or other ≈ømall round ≈øtick; the edge being pa≈ø≈øed down, and the Rammer drawn out, one end of the Paper is to be doubled in, to keep the Powder from falling out: the≈øe Cartouches are to be made ≈øo big, as to fill neerly the bore of the Pi≈øtol, and of length to contain as much Powder as the Pi≈øtol requires for a Charge. When the Powder is in, tie it with thred, and then put in the Bullet al≈øo, tying that al≈øo; the≈øe the Souldier may make at ≈øpare hours, and have them always by him. When he u≈øes his Cartouches, he mu≈øt bite off the Paper at the head of it, and ≈øo put it into the Barrel of the Pi≈øtol with the Bullet upwards, and then ram it home: the≈øe being beforehand prepared, it will much expedite the work of lading his Pi≈øtol.

The Cuira≈ø≈øier being well mounted, and throughly exerci≈øed in his Po≈øtures, the next thing he ≈øhould apply him≈øelf unto is, to be a good Marksman; to attain which, he mu≈øt be frequently ≈øhooting at Marks on Horsback, having ≈øuch ≈øet upon a Tree, ≈øome higher and ≈øome lower.

The Cuira≈ø≈øier being armed Pi≈øtol-proof, he mu≈øt not give fire but at a very neer di≈øtance, being careful to make his Bullet do execution: the principal place of advantage to aim at is, the lower part of the belly of his Enemy, his arm-pits, or his neck. Some are of opinion, that it is not fitting for a Cuira≈ø≈øier to give fire, till he have his Pi≈øtol under his Adver≈øaries Armor, or again≈øt ≈øome unarmed place; and if he mi≈øs of an opportunity of hitting the man, he may aim at the head or bre≈øt of his Hor≈øe. He is commonly to give the charge upon a Trot, and ≈øeldome galloppeth, but upon a pur≈øuit. Having ≈øpent both his Pi≈øtols, and having no opportunity to load again, he mu≈øt then betake him≈øelf to the la≈øt refuge, his Sword, placing the Pummel of it upon his right thigh, and with his
right hand to direct the point thereof by his eye, rai≈øing it higher or lower as oc≈øion ≈øerveth, aiming at his Enemies Neck, Arm-pits, Eye, or about the Pummel of the Saddle at his Belly, &c. but being pa≈øt his Enemy, he is to make a back-blow at him, aiming to cut the buckle of his Poldron, thereby di≈øarming one of his Arms, &c.

div.head: Of Exerci≈øing the Harquebu≈øier and Carbine.
div.p: NOtwith≈øtanding there be ≈øome difference between the Harquebu≈øier and Carbine in their Hor≈øe, their Arming, and their Piece; yet in regard the Harquebus differeth nothing from the Carbine in length, only in the Bore, the manner of u≈øing them is one and the ≈øame.

In Marching he is to carry his Carbine hanging at his Belt by his right ≈øide, or el≈øe to order it upon his right thigh. In Fight he is to ≈øtrive to gain the left ≈øide of his Enemy (contrary to the Cura≈ø≈øier) becau≈øe that in pre≈øenting he is to re≈øt his Carbine on his bridle-hand, placing the butt-end on the right ≈øide of his Brea≈øt neer his Shoulder. He mu≈øt exerci≈øe him≈øelf, that he may u≈øe his Carbine with exactne≈øs and dexterity, and be exqui≈øite in ≈øhooting at Marks.

For the manner of handling the Harquebus or Carbine, the directions before delivered may ≈øerve for ≈øufficient In≈øtruction; but fora≈ømuch (as now adays) our Carbines are made with Snaphans, and ≈øomewhat differ from the former, I will ≈øet down the order of handling of it in the ≈øeveral words of Command.

div.head: Of Exerci≈øing the Dragoon.
div.p: THe Dragoon is of ≈øpecial u≈øe and ≈øervice to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Cavalry as Infantry; for there be many con≈øiderable Exploits which cannot be effected by the Cavalry alone.

The Muskettier mu≈øt therefore exerci≈øe him≈øelf to give fire on Horsback. When they come to guard a Pa≈ø≈øage, or do other the like ≈øervice, they are to alight, and to demean them≈øelves as Infantry; and being alighted to do their ≈øervice, every of them is to ca≈øt his Bridle over the neck of his Sides-mans Hor≈øe, in the ≈øame order as they marched, keeping them ≈øo together, by ≈øome purpo≈øely appointed to attend them.

div.head: Of Exerci≈øing the Cavalry in their Motions.
div.p: THe Hor≈øman being ≈øufficiently in≈øtructed in the managing of his Hor≈øe, and in the u≈øe of his particular Arms; it is time now that he be taught how to demean him≈øelf being joyned in a Body.

The Hor≈øe being to be exerci≈øed, is to be drawn up into a Body, not by Ranks (as in the Infantry) but by Files, and tho≈øe of 5 deep, according to mo≈øt Authors; or of 6 deep, according to others, that of 5 being a number not divi≈øible by 2, ≈øo that in doubling of Ranks, or Half-files, or the like, there will always remain an odd Rank. Others would have them (e≈øpecially the Harquebu≈øiers) to be 8 in File, making the Troop to con≈øi≈øt of 64 Men, being drawn up into a ≈øquare Body. Being thus put into Battalia, the fir≈øt thing they are to be in≈øtructed in, is Di≈øtance; and herein there is a di≈øagreement among Authors; Some making Clo≈øe order to be 2 paces; Open order 4 paces, and ≈øo forward to a triple, quadruple Di≈øtance proportionable. Others make but two kinds of Di≈øtances; Clo≈øe order, which is 3 foot; and Open order, which is 6 foot. And here a difference is to be ob≈øerved between the manner of taking the Di≈øtance of the Cavalry, and that of the Infantry; for in the Foot, the Di≈øtance is taken from the Center, or middle of the Souldiers Body, which here cannot be under≈øtood but only of the ≈øpace of Ground between Hor≈øe and Hor≈øe. But the be≈øt and late≈øt Authors are of opinion, that the Cavalry being to be exerci≈øed in their Motions, ≈øhould be at their Di≈øtance of 6 foot or Open order, ≈øtanding right in their Ranks and Files.
The Motions which belong to the Exerci≈øing of the Cavalry are principally four, viz.

list.item: 1. Facings.
2. Doublings.
3. Countermarches.
4. Wheelings.

div.p: And here note, that in the exerci≈øing of the Cavalry we u≈øe to this day the ≈øame words that the Graecians and Romans did of old: for a File the Romans called Ver≈øus and Decura; a Rank, Jugum; a File-leader, Ducanus; (becau≈øe their Decurae or File con≈øi≈øted of 10) Bringer-up they termed Tergi-ducor; a Leader (being every odd man in a File) Phra≈øtes; a Follower (which is every even number) Sub≈øtes; a Side-man, A≈øtes.

Their Di≈øtances al≈øo were the ≈øame with ours; their two Cubits (every Cubit being a Foot and a half of our Mea≈øure) agrees with our three Foot; their four Cubits, our ≈øix Foot: and ≈øo increa≈øing upon occa≈øion.
They ordered their Hor≈øe-troops at ≈øix Foot Di≈øtance between File and File in March, and three Foot in fight.
In all the motions, we al≈øo retain the ≈øame words of Command which they u≈øed.

Facing, they called Declinatio: to the
Right,
Left,
Ha≈øtam.
Scutum.
Facing about, Immutatio.

Doubling by
Ranks,
Files
Duplicandi duo genera, per
juga.
ver≈øus.
Their Countermarches the ≈øame which we u≈øe:

Wheelings, the ≈øame with us, Conver≈øio ad
Ha≈øtam.
Scutum.
Rever≈øio e≈øt conver≈øionis re≈øtitutio. Inflexio, Wheeling about.
The u≈øe of Facings is to make the Troop perfect to be ≈øuddenly prepared for a Charge, on either Flank or in the Reer.
Doubling of Ranks, or doubling by Half-files, or by Bringers up, is u≈øed upon occa≈øion of ≈øtrengthning of the Front.
Doubling of Files, or doubling by Half-ranks, ≈øerveth to ≈øtrengthen the Flanks.

Countermarches ≈øerve either to reduce the File-leaders into the place of Bringers-up, and ≈øo have the be≈øt men ready to receive the charge of the Enemy in the Reer; or to bring one Flank into the place of the other, or Front and Reer, or either Flank, into the middle of the Body.
The u≈øe of Wheelings is to bring the Front to be ready to receive the Charge of the Enemy, on either Flank or Reer.

For the better information and ≈øatisfaction, and for the ea≈øie apprehending of what hath been ≈øaid, tho≈øe ≈øeveral Motions are here following repre≈øented in Figures, by a Troop of Harquebu≈øiers of 64 men; and in every Figure, the file-leaders are repre≈øented by this kind of A. the Bringers up by this kind of a. and the re≈øt of the Body by this kind of a.
The form of the fir≈øt ≈øtanding.
To face them to the Right, is done by commanding,
Direction. This is done by turning (all at one and the ≈øame time) to the right hand.
The Front is where the right Flank was.
To reduce them to their fir≈øt form, the word is,
Command. As you were.
Direction. It is performed by turning to the left hand.
From thence to face them to the left, the Word is,
Command. To the right hand.
Direction. It is performed by turning to the left.
From hence they are to be reduced, by ≈øaying,
Command. As you were.
Direction. It is performed by turning to the right.
Now to face them to the Reer, though it be proper fir≈øt to do it by the right hand, yet for the more ready way, I would ≈øay,
Command. To the left hand.
Direction. It is done by turning towards the left hand, until their faces front to that place which was before the Reer.
To reduce them to their fir≈øt form (as that mu≈øt be ob≈øerved) the word is,
Command. To the right hand about as you were.
Command. To the left hand about.
Command. Ranks to the right double.
The u≈øe hereof hath been ≈øhewed before; but to perform it, this is the
Direction. Every other Rank, that is, every even Rank, is to pa≈øs into the odd upon the right hand of his Leader, the ≈øecond Rank into the fir≈øt, and ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈øively.
To reduce them, the Word is
Command. Ranks as you were.
Direction. It is be≈øt done by cau≈øing tho≈øe Ranks which doubled to ≈øtand, and tho≈øe that ≈øtood to advance.
Command. Ranks to the left double.

Direction. The difference of this Motion from the former is nothing, but that here they which double do it to the left hand of their Leaders, which before they did to their right hands, as the Figure maketh it plain.
This done, they mu≈øt be reduced by commanding,
Command. Ranks as you were.
Command. Files to the Right Double.

Direction. Let the ≈øecond File pa≈øs into the Fir≈øt (every man behinde his ≈øide-man) accounting from the right hand, the fourth into the third, and ≈øo the re≈øt; which mu≈øt be done through the whole Company at one in≈øtant.
But becau≈øe the fir≈øt Rank of the Troop is as the edge, and the Files are for the mo≈øt part appointed but five deep, there ≈øeemeth no great nece≈ø≈øity of doubling Files.
To reduce them, the Word is,
Command. Files to the left as you were.
Command. Files to the left double.

Direction. The Difference between this and the former Motion, is the difference of hands only. And by this means, tho≈øe Files which ≈øtood before, mu≈øt move now; and they which moved before, now ≈øtand; as appears by the Figure. They are reduced by commanding,
Command. Files as you were, or, Ranks to the Right double.
Command. Half Files to the Right hand, double the Front.
Direction. Middle Men, double the fir≈øt Rank on the right hand; the other three Ranks, double the threee following Ranks.
To reduce them, the Word is,
Command. Half files, as you were.
But it is better to cau≈øe them that doubled to ≈øtand, and the fir≈øt Divi≈øion to advance.
Command. Half-Files to the Left hand, double the Front.
Direction. This Motion differs from the former, in the hand only.

There is al≈øo doubling of Ranks by the Half Files entire to the right or left, or both by Divi≈øion; but becau≈øe the Files (e≈øpecially of Guira≈ø≈øiers) are ≈øeldome above five deep, the doubling of Ranks, Half-files, &c. is little u≈øed.
The reducing of them is ≈øhewed in the former Motion.
Command. Bringers-up, to the right hand double the Front.
Direction. The la≈øt Rank mu≈øt pa≈øs into the fir≈øt, and ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈øively every one by the right hand of his Leader, as in the figure.
It is of goood u≈øe, but trouble≈øome for the Hor≈øe to perform (e≈øpecially in the reducing) ≈øo it may be u≈øed or omitted as ≈øhall be thought fit.
To reduce them,
Command. Bringers-up, as you were.
Command. Files to the Left hand Countermarch.
Though it were fit to begin with the right hand, yet for the convenient turning of the Hor≈øe to the left, I think it not ami≈øs to prefer the left.

Direction. The Figure ≈øufficiently repre≈øents the manner of the Motion, which repre≈øents the Choraean manner; there be al≈øo Countermarches after the Macedonian and Lacedemonian ways, which for brevity are here omitted.
Command. Files clo≈øe to the right and left, to your clo≈øe Order.
Direction. Being about to wheel the Troop, they mu≈øt be clo≈øed, fir≈øt the Files, and then the Ranks.
And being to open them again, the Ranks are fir≈øt to be opened, and then the Files.
All the Files clo≈øe to the right and left towards the middle of the Body.
Command. Ranks clo≈øe forward to your clo≈øe Order.
Direction. All the Ranks move forward, ≈øaving the fir≈øt, which ≈øtand.
The ≈øecond Rank having their di≈øtance, ≈øtand; and ≈øo all the re≈øt.

The Hor≈øe being to wheel, it mu≈øt be conceived, that it cannot be performed by them in ≈øo exact a manner, nor in ≈øo ≈øtrait a room as the Foot, therefore the Commander is to ride a rea≈øonable compa≈øs, that ≈øo the Hor≈øe may do it with convenience.
Command. To the left hand Wheel.

Certain Authors, as Melzo and Ba≈øta, would have the Hor≈øe in all their Wheelings, to do it by the left (which is the readier way, unle≈øs the ground or other hinderace will not permit it:) the Wheeling to the Right, is here omitted, which ≈øhould in order go fir≈øt.
Direction. All the Body mu≈øt move to the left upon the left File-leader, who is the Center or Hinge upon which the whole Body turneth.
To reduce them,
Command. Wheel as you were.
There is al≈øo Wheeling to the Right or Left about, Wheeling Wings into the Front, &c.
To reduce them into their fir≈øt Order,
Direction. Fir≈øt the Ranks are to be opened, then the Files, which bringeth them to their fir≈øt form.
In opening of Ranks, the only way is, to do it by opening forward.

The≈øe and ≈øuch like Motions are directed and commanded by the Voice of the Commander; but becau≈øe the Voice cannot at all times be heard (e≈øpecially in gro≈øs bodies) by rea≈øon of the cla≈øhing of Armor, trampling and neighing of Hor≈øes, tumultuous ≈øounds, and noi≈øe of the Multitude (and that e≈øpecially in fight) Antiquity hath invented helps, making three kinds of Military Signs or Directions:
1. Vocal, which is by the Commanders Voice pronounced by the inferior Officers, to the Ear.
2. Semivocal, by Drum, Trumpet, or other Warlike in≈øtrument, to the Ear.
3. Mute, By Signs to the Eye; as by the En≈øign, Standard, &c.

The Cavalry therefore mu≈øt be taught di≈øtinctly to know the Sounds of the Trumpet, as when to clap on their Saddles, when to mount, when to repair to
their Cornet, when to Troop away, when to give a Charge, when to retreat, when to attend the Watch, and the like. All which being the louder Voice of the Commander, they mu≈øt perfectly ob≈øerve and obey.

Notwith≈øtanding I have here propounded a Troop of 64 Hor≈øe to be exerci≈øed in their Motions, and tho≈øe of eight in File, yet the general opinion is, that a Troop ought not to be deeper then five in File, though the Troop do con≈øi≈øt of 100 Hor≈øe.

Every Troop mu≈øt be furni≈øhed with
A Captain.
A Lieutenant.
A Cornet.
A Quarterma≈øter.
Three Corporals.
Two Trumpetters.
A Clerk.
A Sadler.
A Ghyrurgeon.
A Farrier.

When the Troop is to March, they are to be divided into three equal parts, according to the number of Corporals; which parts are called Squadrons, and di≈øtingui≈øhed by the≈øe Names, The Captains, Lieutenants, and Cornets Squadron. The fir≈øt Squadron is to be led by the Captain, the ≈øecond by the Cornet, the third by the elde≈øt Corporal: the Lieutenant and Quarterma≈øter are to march in the Reer.

div.head: The manner how a Troop of 60 Hor≈øe, be≈øides Officers, ≈øhould March into the Field to be Exerci≈øed, as it is in u≈øe at this day.
div.p: Let this ≈øuffice for their particular Marching and Drawing up into Battalia: as for their Marching in gro≈øs, we ≈øhall next come to ≈øpeak of that.

div.head: Concerning The MARCHING of an ARMY Both HORSE & FOOT, With the Train of Artillery, Baggage, &c. Exemplified in an Army of 22000 Foot, and 5000 Hor≈øe. With the manner how the Prince of Orange Marched to be≈øiege Groll.
The Marching of an Army.
div.p: I Come now to let you ≈øee an Army of 22000. Foot, and 5000 Hor≈øe, with thirty pieces of Ordnance, to wit, eight Half cannon, ≈øix Quarter-cannon, and ≈øixteen Field-pieces, march in a Country where they may be charged either in Front or Reer; then ≈øhall I give you ≈øome rules for pa≈ø≈øing of Straits and Rivers: And la≈øtly, I will ≈øhew you the form and Order that the Prince of Orange ob≈øerved in ≈øome of his Marches.

You are to ob≈øerve, that the Army is to be divided into Van-guard, Battail and Reer; and becau≈øe the Van is the mo≈øt honourable place, they change every day, ≈øo that he that hath the Van this day, hath the Reer to morrow; and he that had the Battle, marcheth in the Van; ≈øo likewi≈øe he that had the Reer the fir≈øt day, marcheth in the Van the third day: and this Order doth the Regiment in every Tertia al≈øo follow.

Being thus divided, they are all upon Order given by the General to ≈øtand ranged in Battalia, either in their ≈øeveral Quarters, or in ≈øome place of Arms appointed for the whole Army; and ≈øtanding ≈øo in readine≈øs, Command being given to March,

There ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øet forwards 500 Hor≈øe, in one or more Troops, as occa≈øion ≈øhall require, to di≈øcover and cleer all the Pa≈ø≈øage that the Army is to march by; they ≈øhall advance an Engli≈øh Mile or more, according to the Quality of the Country, before the Army, and ≈øend a Corporal out of every Troop, which be≈øt knows the Country, with fifteen or ≈øixteen Hor≈øe, to ≈øearch and ≈øcoure all ≈øu≈øpected ways; tho≈øe Corporals ≈øhall al≈øo advance as much before their Troops, as their Troops are before the Army, or thereabouts, according as the Country
is opened or covered, and always keep three or four Hor≈øe a Mu≈øquet ≈øhot before them, to prevent any ≈øudden ≈øurpri≈øe; and if they di≈øcover any Enemies, they are pre≈øently to ≈øend a Hor≈øe-man to adverti≈øe their Troops, and they likewi≈øe to give notice to the Army.

They mu≈øt al≈øo diligently inform them≈øelves, as neer as po≈ø≈øibly they can with the ≈øtrength of the Enemy, and ≈øtill ≈øend Me≈ø≈øengers with adverti≈øement; by whom they ≈øhall al≈øo receive Order, how they ≈øhall retire or di≈øpo≈øe of them≈øelves.

After them ≈øhall follow 1000 with Fire-locks and Half-pikes, divided into ≈øeveral Troops, as well to ≈øuccour the ≈øaid Hor≈øe, as to guard the Ordnance of the Van-guard that follow; and they ≈øhall al≈øo ≈øend fifty men on either Flank, with ≈øufficient Officers to di≈øcover and keep off ≈ømall parties.
Then ≈øhall march two Companies of Pioniers, to even the way for the Artillery; and with them one Waggon with Materials, and an other with Victuals.
Next eight Field-pieces all ready charged, and attended by two Gentlemen, four Gunners, two Waggons loaden with Powder, two with Bullets, and one Conductor.
Then three Quarter-cannon likewi≈øe charged, and attended by one Gentleman, two Gunners, one Waggon loaden with Powder, one with Bullets, and one Conductor.

After them four Half-cannon upon their Carrages, attended by two Gentlemen, four Canoniers, four Waggons loaden with Powder, four with Bullets, one with a Bucks head, and other In≈øtruments nece≈ø≈øary to mount and di≈ømount the Pieces, and two Conductors.
Next ≈øhall follow 2000 Hor≈øe, marching in a good di≈øtance by Regiments or Troops, and in good Order.
After them the Van-guard of Foot con≈øi≈øting of 7000, and marching orderly by Regiments, at their appointed di≈øtances.

There ≈øhall follow them half the Ammunition and Victuals for the Army; then the Generals and Chief Officers Waggon; and la≈øtly, the particular Waggons belonging to the Van-guard, and half of that which belongs to the battail, marching, and taking place in the ≈øame Order, as do the Regiments they belong unto in their ≈øeveral Bodies.
Then ≈øhall march the Battail, con≈øi≈øting likewi≈øe of 7000 Foot, followed with the re≈øt of the Ammunition, Vivers and baggage of the Battail; and al≈øo with that which belongs to the Reer.
After them ≈øhall march in well ordered Divi≈øions, the Reer of the Foot con≈øi≈øting of 6000 Foot, and next 2000 Hor≈øe, as afore≈øaid.

Then (in the ≈øame order as is mentioned in the Van-guard) ≈øhall march four Half-cannons, three Quarter-cannon, and eight Field-pieces accompli≈øhed with their appurtenances, as Powder, Bullets, nece≈ø≈øary In≈øtruments, and ≈øufficient per≈øons to manage and attend them.
Next them 1000 Fire-locks to guard the Ordnance, and ≈øuccour the Forlorn-hope of the Reer, as is afore≈øaid.
La≈øtly, (to clo≈øe up the Army) ≈øhall march 500 Hor≈øe, ob≈øerving the ≈øame Order as is pre≈øcribed them in the Van-guard.

Many there are that di≈ølike the placing the baggage among the Troops, e≈øpecially when the Army is to pa≈øs any narrow way or ≈øtraits, becau≈øe the Waggons take up ≈øo much ground, and ≈øeparate the Troops ≈øo far, that upon occa≈øion they will not be able to ≈øuccour each other; and it is certain, that an Army thus divided may ea≈øily be affronted: But there is no General ≈øo ill adverti≈øed, being to pa≈øs a ≈øtrait, that hath not intelligence where his Enemy attends for him, whether it be in Front or Reer: And if his Enemy waits for him a head, he can let his baggage come in the Reer, next after the Reer of the Foot. If he follow him, he may place his baggage before the Van-guard of the Foot, ever taking care to appoint a ≈øufficient guard to attend it: and in an open Country,
where the Troops may march in Battalia, the Waggons may well march between the Troops, placing them≈øelves likewi≈øe in Ranks, and making a Front as large as the Body they follow; ≈øo ≈øhall they take up but little ground, and be no trouble at all: and there they are out of danger, which otherwi≈øe they will be ≈øubject to, if an Enemy be neer, and ≈øtrong in Hor≈øe.

After them two Companies of Pioniers, with two Waggons loaden with Victuals, and one with Quarter-poles.
Next the Enginiers and Quarter-ma≈øters a Hor≈øe-back.

Then followed the Guards, and after them three Field-pieces of ≈øix pound Bullet, and ≈øix Chambred-pieces of twelve pound Bullet, with all things belonging to them, upon ninteen Waggons; five for the Field-pieces, and fourteen for the Chambred-pieces.

Next came the Van-guard of Foot, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øix Regiments, and followed by three Waggons loaden with 3000 pound of Powder, one with 1000 pound of Match, and one with 1000 pound of Mu≈øquet-bullets, and upon them ≈øixty or ≈øeventy empty bags to deal out the Powder.
Then followed a Lieutenant with fifty men taken out of the Van-guard to guard the Waggons.

Next marched the Battail of Foot, con≈øi≈øting of four Regiments, and after them (as before) three Waggons with 3000 pound of Powder, and one with 1000 pound of Match, and one with 1000 pound of Mu≈øquet-bullets, with empty bags, as afore≈øaid.
After them followed the Reer-guard of the Foot.
Then the Waggons belonging to his Highne≈øs, the States, and all the Officers of the Army, as al≈øo of the Foot-voluntiers.
Next the Ammunition, Materials, and other nece≈ø≈øaries belonging to the Army, upon 485 Waggons, under the Command of Commi≈ø≈øary Martien, followed by four Troops of Hor≈øe.
Then the Ammunition and nece≈ø≈øaries belonging to the Artillery, under Commi≈ø≈øary Bockbout.
After followed the re≈øt of the Artillery, to wit, twelve Half-cannon, ≈øix Chambred-pieces of twenty four pound Bullet, twenty four Drakes of ≈øix pound Bullet, and twenty four of three pound.
Next came the Officers and Train belonging to the Artillery.
After them, one Company of Pioniers with fifty Fire-locks, and one Waggon loaden with Victuals; then the Commi≈ø≈øary of the Vivers with 100 Waggons, loaden with bread and provi≈øion.
After him eight Troops of Hor≈øe, followed with one Waggon, loaden with 1000 pound of Powder, and one with 1000 pound of Match, as al≈øo empty Bags to deal the Powder.
Then a Lieutenant with a Guard, as is afore≈øaid.
And la≈øt of all, ≈øix Troops of Hor≈øe.
Note, that his Highne≈øs in place of this Lieutenant and his Guard, doth u≈øually appoint a Regiment of Foot to come in the Reer to guard the Waggons.

div.head: How to pa≈øs a ≈øtrait.
div.p: WHen you come to any Pa≈ø≈øage or Strait, Let your Van-Guard make a Halt, until the re≈øt of the Army be come up and drawn in order of Battle, and then divide the Troops, and fit them to the bredth of the place you are to pa≈øs through, and let every Troop when it is pa≈ø≈øed, put it ≈øelf into the ≈øame order it was in before it came to the Strait, and advance ≈øo far forwards, as that the Troops that follow may have room likewi≈øe to draw in order, and then ≈øtand until all the Army be come thorow. If the pa≈ø≈øage be Woody where no di≈øcovery can be made, ≈øend not above twenty or thirty Hor≈øe before, for di≈øcovery of the Pa≈ø≈øage in Front, but let the re≈øt of the Hor≈øe of the Van-guard march between the Van-guard and Battle of Foot, until they be pa≈øt the Strait.

div.head: The manner of pa≈ø≈øing a River.
div.p: IF you be to pa≈øs a River, and that the Enemy be not at the Pa≈ø≈øage, but on his way to hinder you; Fir≈øt, draw your Army in Battalia, and plant ≈øome pieces of Artillery in places mo≈øt advantageous, to ≈øuccour your Troops in their pa≈ø≈øage; and if you find that he is ≈øtronger then you in Foot, let your Hor≈øe pa≈øs fir≈øt over, and chu≈øe a fit place to ≈øtand neer the way that the Enemy is to come, and let them ≈øend ≈øome light-Hor≈øe before to di≈øcover: then let your Van-guard of Foot with ≈øome Field pieces follow, and find a place to ≈øtand in Battalia; after it let the Battle march, and place it ≈øelf on the left hand of the Van-guard, then the Reer-guard, which ≈øhall likewi≈øe take the left hand of the Battle, each with their Field-pieces belonging to them.
The Troops being pa≈øt, the re≈øt of the Ordnance with their Train ≈øhall follow, then the baggage of the great Officers; and la≈øtly, the baggage of the Troops in the order of March.

But if your Enemies chief ≈øtrength con≈øi≈øt in Hor≈øe, then ≈øhall you ≈øend no more Hor≈øe over then ≈øhall be fit for di≈øcovery; but let the Van-guard of the Foot pa≈øs fir≈øt, and after it the Hor≈øe belonging to the Van-guard, which ≈øhall place them≈øelves in Battalia on the right hand of the Foot; then ≈øhall follow the Battle, which mu≈øt ≈øtand on the left hand of the Van-guard; after it the Hor≈øe of the Battle, which ≈øhall cover the Flank of the Battle, until the Foot of the Reer-guard be come up, and then they ≈øhall edge to the left hand, and leave room for the Reer to come in between them and the Battle, and ≈øtand on the left Wing, which is their due place; then ≈øhall follow the Hor≈øe of the Reer, which mu≈øt be divided indifferently between the two Wings; and la≈øt of all ≈øhall march the Artillery, Ammunition and baggage in the order afore≈øaid.

If you be to pa≈øs a River, and have an Enemy at your back, when you have made your Bridge, ≈øend over eight or ten Pieces, and place them in places mo≈øt convenient to annoy your Enemy, if he offer to come to trouble you, and then ca≈øt up a Horn-work, or fair half Moon upon the ≈øide you are on, and place therein five or ≈øix Field-pieces; then let the re≈øt of your Ordnance be drawn over, and planted likewi≈øe on the other ≈øide in places mo≈øt commodious for the advantage afore≈øaid. After them ≈øhall follow your Ammunition and baggage; then the Hor≈øe; and la≈øtly, the Foot in good order, bringing with them the Pieces left in the Works, which ≈øhall pa≈øs ≈øafely under the Command of the Ordnance planted on the other ≈øide, and break up the bridge after them.

Having thus far proceeded, I ≈øhould in the next place let you ≈øee a Li≈øt of the Ammunitions, Materials, and other Warlike provi≈øions, which the Prince of Orange takes with him in Shipping when he goes to the Field; as al≈øo what he
takes out of it to be carried upon Waggons, when he marcheth by Land, with the Waggons thereto nece≈ø≈øary. But ≈øince I have fir≈øt ≈øpoken of the marching of an Army with eight half-Cannon, ≈øix quarter-Cannon, and ≈øixteen Field-pieces, I will ≈øet down what Ammunition and other things are needful to march with them, allowing every half-Cannon to ≈øhoot an 150 ≈øhot, every quarter-Cannon 100, and every Field-piece 80.

div.head: The ART of De≈øigning, Mea≈øuring and Laying out Of the QUARTERS, For the ENCAMPING Of an ARMY In the FIELD. VVith ORDERS to be given out in ≈øuch a QUARTER. Al≈øo ORDERS for WATCHING, And other General Ob≈øervations.
div.byline: By Capt. THOMAS R∆≤DD, Enginier to K. CHARLES the First.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p:
HAving given you an account of the ≈øeveral Officers belonging to an Army, with their re≈øpective Offices, Duties, and Qualifications, with which they ought to be endowed: As al≈øo how, and in what manner the Cavalry is to be Enrolled, Armed, and Exerci≈øed both in his Po≈øtures and Motions, and how a Troop or Company, and a
whole Army both Hor≈øe and Foot, with Train of Artillery and other nece≈ø≈øaries is to March: I think it now time to bring you to a Quarter, and therein I ≈øhall declare,
I. What Rules are to be ob≈øerved in the choi≈øe of the Ground to Quarter in.
II. How the Quarter-ma≈øter-General is to de≈øign the Quarters, the Ground being cho≈øen.
III. The Geometrical or In≈øtrumental manner of laying out the Quarters in the Field.
IV. How the building of the Huts is to be managed, and by whom.
V. The manner of ≈øecuring the Quarters by Intrenchments, Redoubts, Horn-works, and other Fortifications.
The manner of Quartering in the general being thus largely di≈øcour≈øed of, I proceed next to the particular Quartering of the Souldiery: Giving you
VI. Examples of Quartering a Regiment, both after the Old and New way. With the Rea≈øons which moved the Prince of Orange to alter the old Form.
VII. I have di≈øcovered the manner of Quartering the Hor≈øe, giving you an Example of Quartering four Cornets, by which Pre≈øident a whole Regiment or Regiments may be quartered in the like manner.
VIII. You have the manner of Quartering of a Foot-Army: and

IX. An Example of Quartering of a whole Army both Hor≈øe and Foot: and for an Example have added a Scheme of the Form in which the Prince of Orange Quartered his Army both Hor≈øe and Foot, Artillery, Waggons, &c.

And to bring up the Reer, for the farther ≈øatisfaction of the Reader, I have added divers Orders for Watching, and other General Orders to be ob≈øerved in the Quarters, with what el≈øe is nece≈ø≈øary for the Encamping of an Army, either in part or in whole.

div.head: What Rules are to be ob≈øerved in the choice of the Ground to Quarter in.
div.p: IN chu≈øing your Ground for your Quarters, let it as neer as you can be upon high Ground, le≈øt your Enemy being higher, may have an advantage of you by that means.

2. Let it be neer no Woods nor Groves, where your Enemy may lie in ambu≈øh, and ≈øally out upon you, and vex you; yet let it not be very far from neither Wood nor Water, they being two as nece≈ø≈øary things as can be. But let the Ground be champion, the better to di≈øcern your Enemy at a di≈øtance; and if po≈ø≈øible, neer ≈øome River, for the relief of Men and Cattle, and for the cheaper conveying of nece≈ø≈øaries for the u≈øe of the Souldiery.
3. See that the Ground you quarter upon be not at any time ≈øubject to overflow with Water, nor that any Water be let in upon you by Slu≈øes or otherwi≈øe.
4. That no boggy, moori≈øh, or unwhol≈øome Grounds be neer your Quarters, which may be a means to bring Di≈øea≈øes and Sickne≈øs among the Souldiers.
5. That Forrage, Wood, and Straw be neer you, or may be ea≈øily conveyed to you.
6. That the Quarters be not too neer your Enemy, for fear of their Cannon; nor very far di≈øtant, but that timely relief may be given to the approachers.

7. That the Ground be of a competent largene≈øs to contain the number of Companies, Hor≈øe, Foot, Artillery, and other nece≈ø≈øaries thereunto belonging, with allowance of fit dimen≈øions for every particular.

But it will rarely fall out that any place you can chu≈øe will have all the≈øe conveniencies, wherefore gain as many of them as you can, and for the re≈øt you mu≈øt by indu≈øtry ≈øupply. Wherefore (above all) let the Fortifications and Intrenchments about your Quarters be well made and guarded, le≈øt by the neglecting of them you be ≈øurprized, and your Enemy hinder your relief.

div.head: How the Quarter-ma≈øter is to de≈øign his Quarters when the Ground is cho≈øen.
div.p: THis work is not to be done of a ≈øudden, but the Quarter-ma≈øter knowing the place where the Quarters are to be, let him go to his Chamber, and there con≈øult with his Li≈øt which he is to quarter; namely, how many Regiments of Hor≈øe, how many of Foot, what Waggons, what Artillery, and what≈øoever el≈øe, as Sutlers, &c. he is to quarter; al≈øo how many Companies there is in each Regiment, and how many men in each Company.

He having collected and gathered them all together in a Note, let him take ≈øome pieces of fine pa≈øt-board, and cut them into pieces 300 foot (by ≈øome ≈ømall Scale) deep, and ≈øo broad as to contain the number of men of ≈øuch a Regiment, either Hor≈øe or Foot, he is to quarter; allowing true di≈øtance, of Ground both for Hut, Pa≈ø≈øage, Stable, &c. and at that length let him cut off his pa≈øt-board ≈øquare, and write upon that pa≈øt-board the Colonels name, and number of men; and thus mu≈øt he do for every Regiment both of Hor≈øe and Foot.

In like manner for the Generals Quarters and his Retinue, for the Provo≈øt, Quarter-ma≈øter, Mini≈øter, Chirurgion, and all others that require ≈øingle Quarters; and likewi≈øe for the Waggons and Sutlers. All the≈øe mu≈øt he lay one according as he finds their Numbers greater or le≈ø≈øer in his Li≈øt, and cut his pa≈øt-boards accordingly, writing upon them as before.

His pa≈øt-boards being thus prepared, let him upon a Table, or rather upon a
≈øheet of Imperial or Royal paper, draw divers occult parallel lines at 50 foot di≈øtance for Streets, and ≈øpaces of 300 foot for his ≈øeveral Regiments.

By help of the≈øe parallel Lines he may lay his pa≈øt-boards upon this paper, and move them this way and that way, till he have brought them into a Square, or Parallelogram, or as regular a form as they will permit.

He having thus di≈øpo≈øed them to the be≈øt advantage in his judgment, he may draw a Scheme or Plat thereof upon fair Paper or Parchment, writing the name of every Colonel and his number of men upon his particular Quarter, with the Generals Quarters, Market, Streets, Lanes, &c. making thereof a perfect Map; and adding a Scale thereto, he may mea≈øure the di≈øtance of any part thereof at plea≈øure. This being done, he may repair to his General, and ≈øhew him his de≈øign; which if he approve of, he may proceed to the laying out of the Quarters in the Field.

div.head: How the Quarters are to be laid out in the Field.
div.p: THe paper-de≈øign being approved on, the Quarter-ma≈øter-General repairs to the Field, the ≈øeveral Quarter-ma≈øters of every Regiment accompanying him, each of them having four ≈øtaves of nine or ten foot high, painted of the Colour of their Regiment, with a Standard or Banner at the top thereof.

Then the Quarter-ma≈øter-General coming to the Field with a Surveying In≈øtrument, pitcheth it down at one of the angular points of his Quarter, and taking his ≈øights, ≈øetteth off a right Angle from the point where his In≈øtrument ≈øtandeth, and mea≈øureth from thence with a Chain, the whole length of his Quarter; and at the end of that mea≈øure, he ≈øetteth up a Standard of the Colour o ‚Ä¢ that Regiment that is to be quartered in that angle of the General Quarters. Likewi≈øe from his In≈øtrument at right angles, he mea≈øureth out the bredth of his Quarters; and at the end of that mea≈øure he cau≈øeth another Standard to be erected, of the Colour of that Regiment that is to be there quartered:
and going to his In≈øtrument, he cau≈øeth another Standard to be erected there, of the Colour of the Regiment that is there to be quartered.

Then removing his In≈øtrument from this fir≈øt place, let him carry it to any of the other Standards, and there place it; laying his Index and ≈øights upon the Diameter thereof, and turning it about till he ≈øee his Standard that was ≈øet up where his In≈øtrument la≈øt ≈øtood; then fixing it there, turn the Index to a Right-angle, and looking through the ≈øights, mea≈øure out the length or bredth of your Quarters that way, and at the end of that mea≈øure ≈øet up a fourth Standard, of the colour of the Regiment there to be quartered.

figure.head: The Quarters laid out in the Field.

div.p: Let the Ground made choice of for the Quarters be Q; then the Quarter-ma≈øter coming into the Field, makes choice of the Point A for one of the Angles of his Quarters; and there erecting of his In≈øtrument, the Index lying upon the Diameter thereof, he directs his ≈øight to B; and becau≈øe the length of his Quarters are to be 3000 foot, he cau≈øeth ≈øo much to be mea≈øured out from A to B; and at the point B cau≈øeth a Standard to be rected of the Colours of that Regiment which is to be quartered in that Angle. Then going to his In≈øtrument, let him turn the Index about to a right Angle from the line A B, and looking through the ≈øights towards C, let him cau≈øe 1700 foot (the breadth of his Quarters) to be laid out upon the ground from A to D, and at D, let them cau≈øe another Standard to be erected, of the Colours of the Regiment that is there to be quartered.

This done, let him remove his In≈øtrument from A to D, and at the place where his In≈øtrument ≈øtood, let there be erected another Standard. The In≈øtrument being placed at D, and the Index laid upon the Diameter thereof, let him turn the In≈øtrument about, till through the ≈øights he ≈øee the Standard at A, and then fixing it there, turn the Index about till it be removed a right Angle (or 90 deg.) from the Diameter; then looking through the ≈øights, cau≈øe 3000 foot to mea≈øured from D to C. La≈øtly, remove your In≈øtrument to C, and laying the Index on the Diameter thereof, turn it about, till through the ≈øights you ≈øee the Standard at D, and fixing the In≈øtrument there, remove the Index to a right Angle from the Diameter; and then looking through the ≈øights (if you have
performed the former work truly) you ≈øhall exactly look upon the Standard which was fir≈øt erected at B, and the di≈øtance between B and C being mea≈øured, ≈øhall be found to be exactly 1700 foot.

Thus are the four grand Angles of the Quarters found in the Field. Then beginning with any of the Regiments that are to be quartered in any of the Angles, as with that at B, look in your Draught, and ≈øee how many foot in length is allotted for it, which is 676; then mea≈øure that out from A to O, and ≈øet up a Standard there; then ≈øee how many foot broad that Quarter is, viz. 300, and mea≈øure that out from B to K, and there al≈øo ≈øet up a Standard. Then the length 676, and the bredth 300, being mea≈øured both ways from K to S, and from O to S, then erecting a Standard al≈øo; the≈øe two la≈øt Standards at O and K, will finde the place where the fourth Standard at S is to be erected. So is the ground laid out for one of the Angular Regiments; the like mu≈øt be done for the other three, and al≈øo for all the re≈øt.

A≈ø≈øoon as any Quarter for a Regiment is laid out by the Quarter-ma≈øter-General, the particular Quarter-ma≈øter of that Regiment begins to ≈øubdivide his Quarter according to the number of his men, putting down a ≈øtick at each end of every row of Huts and Streets end.

Then the Serjeants of every Company pre≈øently fall a dividing the Souldiers Huts, and ≈øet up four ≈øticks at the corner of each Hut: then the two Souldiers that lodge together build their Huts; and ≈øo the re≈øt.

In the Souldiers building of their Huts, the Serjants are to ≈øee that they build them regularly, and not incroach one upon another, but as their Ground is allotted them. And to this the Superior Officers al≈øo are to have an eye.

What is hitherto delivered, I ≈øuppo≈øe, is plain enough to be under≈øtood without a farther addition either of Words or Schemes; the Figures and Directions here delivered being ≈øufficient (in my judgment) to give full ≈øatisfaction to the Reader.

div.head: Concerning the ≈øecuring of the Quarters by Entrenchment, Redoubts, &c.
div.p: THe Quarter-ma≈øter-General having done his part, and the particular Quarter-ma≈øters theirs; the Enginier next is to act his part: who drawing Parallel lines to the out-≈øide of the General Quarters at 206 foot di≈øtance, 200 foot being for the Alarm-place, and the ≈øix foot for the Parapet.

At this 206 foot di≈øtance, the Pioniers dig a Trench or Furrow of about half a foot broad, and ≈øo much deep. Without or in this Furrow is the beginning of a Ditch ≈øix foot broad, to be digged round about the Quarters, which is to be done by the Foot-Souldiers, it being for their ≈øecurity.

Then the Enginier is to con≈øider how many foot of Ditch there is about the whole Quarters, and with that number goes to the Quarter-ma≈øter-General, and enquires of him the number of the Infantry; and by the≈øe two they compute how much of the Ditch each Regiment mu≈øt dig: thus,
If the number of ditching be 7500 foot, and the number of the Infantry is 8560.
Now ≈øuppo≈øe one Regiment contain 1320 Souldiers, how much of that Ditch mu≈øt that Regiment dig?
Multiply 1320 by 7500, and it produceth 99100. which being divided by 8560 giveth 1157 and about three quarters, and ≈øo many yards mu≈øt that Regiment dig which hath 1320 men in it.

div.p: THe rea≈øons that moved the Prince of Orange to remove the Captains from the Front, and place them as they are lodged in this la≈øt Quarter in the Reer, I take to be three; Fir≈øt, becau≈øe the Souldiers upon any ≈øudden occa≈øion, could not readily draw out into the Alarm-place, by rea≈øon of the narrow Streets between the Captains Huts. Secondly, becau≈øe the Colours and Arms lay hid by the Captains Huts, which now ≈øtand open in the eye of the Alarm-place, and make a hand≈øome ≈øhew, being likewi≈øe readier for the Souldier to draw out in an in≈øtant. La≈øtly to prevent the many in≈øolencies and di≈øorders committed among the Sutlers, which he pre≈øumed the Souldiers dur≈øt not do, not the Sutlers ≈øuffer, the Captains being lodged ≈øo neer them.

You may ob≈øerve, that in this lu≈øt form of Quartering, there are 20 foot of the 200 allowed the Souldiers in depth taken off, and added to the ≈øtreet between the Captains and the Sutlers; for the ≈øtreet being in the former Quarter but 20 foot broad, was found to be too narrow for the Waggons, and Carriages to pa≈øs to and fro, which did continually go and come through it with Provi≈øions for the Army.

And whereas in the allowance of 200 foot in depth for the Souldiers, there were but two allotted to lodge or hut together, it happened ≈øometimes that they came to quarter in places where there was ≈ømall ≈øtore of Provi≈øion to but, withal ≈øo that the Souldiers could neither fit the ground allotted to them, nor make any uniform or hand≈øome huts; therefore it was thought fit to take from them the ≈øaid 20 foot, and to allow them but 180.

Note, that the Officers mu≈øt ≈øee the Souldiers build formally, and that they make their Beds a foot and half or two foot from the ground, to prevent ≈øickne≈øs, which they will be ≈øubject to fall into by lying upon the ground.

Note, that when the Regiment is quartered in one Divi≈øion, the Colonels Company quarters on the right hand, the Lieutenant-Colonels on the left, the Sergeant-Majors next the Colonel, the elde≈øt Captain next him, and ≈øo all the re≈øt of the Captains by ≈øeniority in order from the right hand.

But if the Regiment be quartered in two Divi≈øions, then the Lieutenant-Colonels Company quarters on the right hand of the ≈øecond Divi≈øion, & the Sergeant-Majors in his place, on the left hand of the fir≈øt, the elde≈øt Captain next the Colonel, the ≈øecond on the left hand of the ≈øecond Divi≈øion, the third next the elde≈øt, the fourth next the Lieutenant-Colonel, the fifth next the third, the ≈øixth next the fourth in the ≈øecond Divi≈øion, and ≈øo all the re≈øt of the Captains according to this Order: Ob≈øerving (if it may be) that the younge≈øt Captain be always placed next to him that clo≈øeth the left flank of the ≈øecond Divi≈øion.

div.head: Quartering of Hor≈øe.
div.p: THe Hor≈øe (unle≈øs pre≈ø≈øed by an Enemy) are always or mo≈øt commonly quartered in Hou≈øes, both for the commodity of Forrage, and that their Hor≈øes may ≈øtand under covert; which otherwi≈øe, by ≈øtanding three or four nights in rain and cold, would be in danger to be ≈øpoiled and made un≈øerviceable.

So careful (≈øaith Melzo) was the Duke of Alva of his Hor≈øe, that he not only quartered them in Hou≈øes, but made Courts of Guard upon the Avenues and places where they watched, to ≈øhelter them from the weather. But ≈øeeing they may be ≈øometimes forced to make Huts, I will ≈øhew you their manner of Quartering, which is the ≈øame as the Foot, but that they have more ground allowed them, e≈øpecially in bredth: for their main ≈øtreets are twenty foot broad, and the men have ten foot allowed them; whereas the Foot have but eight foot for either Hut: their Hor≈øes are allowed ten foot in bredth, and four in depth: ≈øo the ground allowed for 100 Hor≈øe, is 300 foot in depth, and 70 in bredth.
