div.p: A Good Commanders Judgment is to be di≈øcerned by his well chu≈øing of ground to quarter on; for he mu≈øt not only chu≈øe a place advantageous to re≈øi≈øt an Enemy, but where there is plenty of Forrage, Water and other Nece≈ø≈øaries, and where the Air is whol≈øome; and how nece≈ø≈øary it is to intrench a Quarter, and what ea≈øe and ≈øafety it brings to an Army, dayly experience tells us; and whereas by lying open you are ≈øubject to be affronted, and forced to fight by an Enemy, it is in your choice being Intrenched, whether you fight or not, which is no ≈ømall advantage; be≈øides, your Watches will fall nothing ≈øo often, nor your Guards ≈øo trouble≈øome.

The Romans were the fir≈øt that found out the right u≈øe of the Spade; and the benefit of Intrenching; and it is from Cae≈øar that our late great Generals have learned the way to Beleaguer and ≈øingle Towns with Works and Trenches, though the u≈øe of Powder have made them alter the form and manner of working; and how advantageous it its to make ≈øuch Works, the taking (not to ≈øpeak of Alexis and other places by the Prince of Orange) but of Groll, Bolduke, Ma≈øtricht, and Breda within the≈øe few years, in the view, as I may ≈øay, of an Enemies Army, are ≈øufficient te≈øtimonies: and as divers Armies have in vain attempted the relief of Towns thus beleaguered, ≈øo have ≈øome out of negligence, and want of care in making their Lines of circumvallation, been forced to quit their de≈øign, and ri≈øe with di≈øhonour.

div.head: Orders to be given out in a Quarter.
div.p: 1 NO man without leave of his Officer ≈øhall go further then Cannon-≈øhot out of the Quarter, or lie in the night out of the Quarter, upon pain of the Strappado; and if he have done any man hurt, he ≈øhall be hanged without mercy.
2. No man ≈øhall do hurt to ≈øuch as are under Neutrality or Safe-guard, upon pain of bodily puni≈øhment.
3. No man ≈øhall fight within the Quarter, draw his Sword, or make any uproar in the night, upon the like pain.
4. No man ≈øhall mole≈øt any Sutler, or ≈øuch as bring Provi≈øion into the Leaguer, ≈øpoil or take any of their Goods from them within or without the Leaguer, upon the like pain.

5. No man ≈øhall ≈øell any Booty or Goods in the Leaguer without ≈øound of Drum, and by con≈øent of the Fi≈øcal, and knowledge of the Mar≈øhal-General, upon forfeit of the Goods, the one half to the poor, the other to the Mar≈øhal.
6. No man ≈øhall buy any Goods without ≈øound of Drum, as al≈øo notice to be given to the Mar≈øhal, upon forfeit of the Goods, and ≈øix Gilders in money.

7. No Sutler, Saylor, or any other per≈øon, ≈øhall buy any Iron, Metal, or any other thing belonging to Bells, Arms, Bullets, Powder, or any thing belonging to Ammunition, or any other forbidden Wares, or take any ≈øuch thing to pawn, upon forfeit of the ≈øame, and al≈øo to be openly whipped.
8. No man ≈øhall make any Arre≈øt, or go to Law upon any old Action or Debt made before or without the Leaguer

9. All Pri≈øoners, as well of our own men, as of the Enemy, whether de≈øerving bodily puni≈øhment, or otherwi≈øe, are to be delivered to the Mar≈øhal-General, with true notice of their offences and accu≈øations.
10. All Mar≈øhals of Regiments, Admiralty, Artillery, Guards, or others, ≈øhall ≈øtand under the Mar≈øhal-General.
11 No man ≈øhall ≈øet any price upon Victuals, or any Leaguer-provi≈øion within the Leaguer, without the con≈øent of the Mar≈øhal-General, upon pain of being ≈øeverely puni≈øhed.
12. No man ≈øhall abu≈øe the Mar≈øhal-General or his ≈øervants by word or deed, or offer them any violence, upon pain to be hanged without mercy.
13. No man ≈øhall Suttle in the Leaguer before he hath given up his name to the General of the Victuals and Provi≈øion, and al≈øo to the Mar≈øhal, upon pain of ≈øix guilders.
14 All Sutlers that come into the Leaguer ≈øhall give notice to the General of the Victuals, or to his Commi≈ø≈øary, of their Wares; and mu≈øt not Suttle without his Commi≈ø≈øion upon the like pain.
15. No Sutler ≈øhall ≈øet up his Cabbin in any other place then where is appointed by the Mar≈øhal, upon the like pain.

16. No Sutler ≈øhall buy any Provi≈øion within the Leaguer, until it be brought to the place appointed for Market, and there prized and taxed, upon forfeiture of half the goods ≈øo bought or ≈øold, to the u≈øe of the Poor and Mar≈øhal afore≈øaid.

17. No Sutler ≈øhall u≈øe any Weights or Mea≈øures, but ≈øuch as are ordained them by the Mar≈øhal-General, upon pain of ≈øix guilders; and tho≈øe that are found to u≈øe fal≈øe Weights or Mea≈øures, ≈øhall forfeit their goods, the one half to the poor in general, the other to the poor of the Regiment, and al≈øo to be ≈øeverely puni≈øhed.
18. No Sutler ≈øhall tap Beer or Wine in the morning before the Sun ri≈øe, or at night after the Warning-Piece goes off, upon pain of forfeiting for every offence three guilders.
19. No man ≈øhall kill any meat within the Leaguer, but ≈øhall carry all garbage, and filth thereof without the Leaguer, and there bury it, upon pain of forfeiting of ≈øix guilders for every default.

20. No man ≈øhall do his ea≈øment within the Quarter, but in the place appointed, (which mu≈øt be 100 foot without the Intrenchment, and be marked out by the Mar≈øhals of every Regiment) upon forfeiture of his upper garment.

div.head: Orders for Watching.
div.p: A Company having the Watch at an Avenue or Trench, the Souldiers ≈øhall place their Pikes in Battalia a little di≈øtance from the Parapet, and their Muskets in order upon the Parapet.
No Captain, Officer, or Souldier what≈øoever, ≈øhall ab≈øent him≈øelf being in health from his Watch.
No Souldier ≈øhall be ≈øuffered to hire his duty, or to put one of his fellows to ≈øtand ≈øentinel for him: if he do, he is to be puni≈øhed without favour.
Every Sentinel ≈øhall ≈øtand full armed, and not ≈øtir from his ≈øtation until his Corporal relieve him, upon the like pain.
The Corporals ≈øhall in≈øtruct the Sentinels how they mu≈øt behave them≈øelves, and be careful to ≈øet them out at ≈øuch a di≈øtance, as they may ≈øee each other.

A Sergeant-Major, or ≈øome better qualified Officer, ≈øhall every night go the Round, and ≈øee the Watches be well ordered, and the Sentinels duly ≈øet out; and if he find any defect or fault in the Guards, he ≈øhall acquaint the Sergeant-Major-General with it, that it may be amended.
When the Round comes, an Officer accompanied with ≈øome Muskettiers ≈øhall readily give the Word, and not hold the Round long up.
The Corporal in taking the Word ≈øhall do the ≈øame.

Note, That ≈øome are of Opinion, that the Corporal in the Field ought to give the Word to no man, but take it from all that pa≈øs, to prevent the inconvenience that may happen by giving it to an Enemy, which coming ≈øecretly, may pretend to have the Round: and I have known that the Prince of Orange hath ordained that the grand Round ≈øhould give the Word to the Officer that had the Watch.

One of the chief Officers of the Company or Troop ≈øhall continually keep waking and ≈øtirring, to keep the men by their Arms; and there mu≈øt be never le≈øs then the third part of the Company or Troop afoot, to be ready upon all occa≈øions.
The Officers mu≈øt have a care and ≈øee that the Sentinels be well and orderly placed, and mu≈øt go them≈øelves, and often ≈øend to vi≈øit them.
The Officers mu≈øt be careful to keep all their men upon the Guard, and to puni≈øh ≈øuch as go off without leave.

div.head: Imbatteling.
div.p: OUr modern Warrs ≈øeldome bring Controver≈øies to the trial of Battle, for men now make War rather like Foxes then Lyons; yet Germany hath of late given us ≈øome Examples; and nece≈ø≈øary it is to know in what order an Army may be≈øt receive, or charge an Enemy. To give you therefore ≈øome ≈øatisfaction therein, I will let you ≈øee divers forms of Imbatteling Foot and Hor≈øe apart and together, as they have been ordered by the Princes of Orange and others, whereby you may learn how to range Troops when occa≈øion doth require. But I beleeve it will not be impertinent fir≈øt to give you ≈øome ob≈øervations con≈øiderable before, and when you come to fight; as al≈øo to ≈øpeak a little of a Cha≈øe and Retreat.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: IF you be upon Defence, venture not your Game at a ca≈øt; your Enemy can loo≈øe but his Army, you may loo≈øe your Countrey: have a care that you be not forced to fight: hinder him of Provi≈øion, by cutting off his Convoys, or burning all before him, that he may gather none in the Countrey; u≈øe ≈øome means to call him home by diver≈øion, or wait upon him in places of advantage, as Straits and narrow Pa≈ø≈øages, when he mu≈øt march in ≈ømall Divi≈øions, and draw his Troops into ≈øuch a length that they cannot ea≈øily ≈øuccour each other; then finding opportunity, attach him re≈øolutely; ≈øo ≈øhall you be ≈øure, if he be not a vigilant and expert Captain to do him an affront. Many Examples there are in Hi≈øtory, of men that peri≈øhed by pre≈ø≈øing an invading Enemy to fight: the Battails of Cre≈ø≈øy, Poitiers, and others, are fair warnings to per≈øwade men not to pre≈øume, or wilfully to hazard all in one day. Had the Cardinal Infanta fought with the Prince of Orange and the French when they were in little Brabant, without doubt he had lo≈øt his Country. In a word, if you fight, you ≈øet your fortune upon the Dice; if you husband your bu≈øine≈øs warily, the ≈øtorm will over.

If you be an undertaker, the ≈øooner you bring your Cau≈øe to trial, the better you are like to ≈øpeed; delays are dangerous: for change of Air, Diet, and other inconveniencies, may breed ≈øickne≈øs and divers ill humors in your Army: and if your Enemy will not fight, but make a Fabian or lingring War, he may put you to your ≈øhifts; therfore fir≈øt acquaint your ≈øelf with the ≈øtrength and quality of your Enemies forces, with the ≈øtate of his Country, with his own di≈øpo≈øition, and the di≈øpo≈øition of tho≈øe that are neere≈øt about him; and before you declare your ≈øelf gain ≈øome of his great men (if it be po≈ø≈øible) to take your part: maintain good Spies in his Court.

Foreca≈øt all that can further or hinder your de≈øign, before you undertake it; and let your Cau≈øe be ju≈øt, left you draw the vengeance of God and jealou≈øie of other Princes upon you. In your preparation, let your fir≈øt care be of the belly: want of Victuals hath been the lo≈øs of many a brave de≈øign, and the ruine of great Armies. Let your men be well trained, and ≈øuch as have been u≈øed to exerci≈øe and labour (if you can) let them be all of your own Subjects: provide plenty of materials and other nece≈ø≈øaries for your de≈øign, and u≈øe the means to begin your War with ≈øome notable lo≈øs to your Enemy; ≈øo ≈øhall you terrify him, and di≈øcourage his Allyes and friends from giving him a≈ø≈øi≈øtance.

When you come to fight, chu≈øe ground (as neer as you can) to fight upon proper for the number and quality of your men: if you be ≈øtrong in Hor≈øe, chu≈øe champion; if your ≈øtrength be on foot, and that you want Hor≈øe, chu≈øe uneven, bu≈øhy, or inclo≈øed ground, and place ≈øome Muskettiers in the di≈øtances between tho≈øe Troops you have, which may advance, and give fire upon the Enemies Hor≈øe: if they offer to charge, cover one of your Flanks if you can with ≈øome River, Mora≈øs, or Wood. Make your Front ≈øo large, that your Enemy may not be able with his Wings to charge you in Flank. Let your Battalions be ≈ømall, as of five or ≈øix hundred at the mo≈øt, which may nimbly move, charge, retire, or ≈øuccour each other at their plea≈øures; for great Bodies are unweildy, and being forced to move, cannot keep their order unle≈øs the ground be very even; for upon uneven ground, they will either fall foul, or be forced to open; and if an Enemy can then make u≈øe of his advantage, and charge, they are ea≈øily broken, and being broken are irrecoverable; whereas ≈ømall Troops, although they break, may under the favour and ≈øuccour of their ≈øeconds, put them≈øelves again in order, and be able to do good ≈øervice. U≈øe means to draw your Enemy off the ground he hath cho≈øen to ≈øtand upon; it may to your advange, perhaps bring ≈øome di≈øorder in his Troops. Be ≈øure to have ≈øtore of Seconds, and always keep ≈øome Troops in re≈øerve: rather give, then attend the charge; it will encourage your own men, and di≈øhearten the Enemy. Charge on that hand you think your ≈øelf the ≈øtronge≈øt. Let the di≈øtances between the Battalions, as al≈øo between the Ter ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a's of your Army, be carefully kept; and get the advantage of Sun and Wind if you can.

div.head: Of a Cha≈øe.
div.p: IF your Enemy turn his back and fly, let the third part of your Van-guard, Battail, and Reer, as al≈øo a third part of both the Wings of Hor≈øe, be appointed for the Cha≈øe; and let one third part of them ≈øo appointed cha≈øe the Enemy disbanded; the re≈øt following in their order to ≈øuccour the disbanded Troops, if the Enemy ≈øhould turn head and make re≈øi≈øtance: and let the other two thirds of the Army lei≈øurely advance in good order to countenance the Troops in Cha≈øe if occa≈øion ≈øhould require. When you would have the Cha≈øers retire, let the Drums and Trumpets of tho≈øe Cha≈øers that keep their order, ≈øound the Retreat, that the disbanded Cha≈øers may know where to find their Troops: and if it be night, let the Drums and Trumpets of the re≈øt of the Army likewi≈øe ≈øound. And let there be fires made in divers places in the Army, whereby all the Cha≈øers may the better find the way to their Quarter.

div.head: Of a Retreat.
div.p:
TO make a good Retreat, is one of the Ma≈øter-pieces of a General; nor is it di≈øhonorable for him to take the advantage of any time that he finds u≈øeful for the ≈øafety of his Army, and good of the Cau≈øe; although ≈øome young Souldiers (more hardy then wi≈øe) think it a di≈øparagement to retire in the night: but he that will not retire in the night, when rea≈øon and the benefit of his party doth require, may ≈øtay and be beaten in the day. Many Examples there are in Hi≈øtories, of Armies that have been lo≈øt by ≈øuch gallantry, and their party thereby ruined. There is no experienced General ≈øo indi≈øcreet or ill advi≈øed, as to follow a retiring Enemy with his Gro≈øs in the night, e≈øpecially if he find him retire in good order; for ≈øo he may be drawn into Ambu≈øcadoes, or his enemy may wait for him in places of advantage, and do him an affront, and what knows he when he finds the Retreat made orderly, but his Enemy ≈øeeks to draw him out purpo≈øely to intrap him? by this means the party retiring may before day get into a place of ≈øafety; whereas if he retire by day, his Enemy may ≈øafely follow him with his whole Army, and pa≈øs upon all advantages, whereof he ≈øhall find plenty in a well-ordered Army, if he know how to make u≈øe of them, and take his opportunity. I
therefore conclude, that to retire by night, without ≈øound of Drum, with matches covered, or to u≈øe any other ≈øecret way to avoid an Enemy when occa≈øion doth require, is not di≈øhonorable, but the duty of a good Captain.

div.head: The Order that the Prince of Orange retired in from Gelders.
div.p: FIr≈øt, He po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed a high piece of Ground that lay half-way between Gelders and Rhineberk, to which Town he was re≈øolved to March; and lodged there 2000 men well intrenched, with ≈øome pieces of Ordnance: then he made ready three ways for the Tertia's of the Army to march in Front: before the Troops began to march; he ≈øent away the Baggage and great Ordnance, with ≈øome part of the Ammunition. An hour before day, or thereabouts, he gave Order that the Army ≈øhould march, and the three Tertia's drew out of the Quarter, without ≈øound of Drum, and marched in even Front, about 200 paces di≈øtant from each other, until they came an Engli≈øh mile or more from the Quarter; and then Command was given that the Drums ≈øhould beat. In the Reer of each Tertia came ten or twelve Field-pieces, with Ammunition and all other nece≈ø≈øaries belonging to them. On either Flank marched ≈øixteen Troops of Hor≈øe; and after the Foot, at a large di≈øtance came the re≈øt of the Hor≈øe. In this Order did he march from thence to Rhineberk without the ≈øight of an Enemy, although the Cardinal Infanta were lodged within an Engli≈øh mile or little more of his Quarter.

Two Principal Propo≈øitions Geometrical, u≈øeful in Fortification.
div.p: ALthough all the fundamental Problems and Propo≈øitions in plain Geometry are nece≈ø≈øary and u≈øeful for an Enginier, e≈øpecially to rai≈øe and let fall Perpendiculars, draw Parallels, divide Lines into equal parts, and other proportional parts required to make Angles of any quantity, and al≈øo to divide them; the≈øe are ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary; for without mo≈øt of them, few others can be re≈øolved: wherefore ≈øuppo≈øing him to be ≈øo much a Geometrician, I will proceed to the≈øe two, nece≈ø≈øary in this Art.

div.head: Prop. I. A Circle being giuen, to find the ≈øide of any Polygon that may be in≈øcribed within the ≈øame Circle, the number of Sides not exceeding ten.
div.p: Let the given Circle be A F C G. Fir≈øt, through the Center thereof at E, draw the Diameter A E C, dividing the whole Circle into two equal parts.

Secondly, Take in your Compa≈ø≈øes half the Diameter A E, or E C, and ≈øetting one foot in A, with the other foot make the marks B and D, and draw the line E D, which ≈øhall be the ≈øide of a Triangle, or Polygon of three ≈øides, which will be in≈øcribed in that Circle.
Thirdly, Draw the Line F G through the Centre, cutting the Diameter A G at right Angles. Then draw the line A F, which ≈øhall be the ≈øide of a Square or Polygon of four ≈øides.

Fourthly, Set one foot of your Compa≈ø≈øes in H, and extend the other to F, drawing the Arch-line F I; then draw the right line F I, and it ≈øhall be the ≈øide of a Pentagon, or Polygon of five ≈øides, that will be in≈øcribed within the given Circle.
Fifthly, Half the Diameter, as E A, E F, E C, or E G, are either of them the ≈øide of an Hexagon, or Polygon of ≈øix ≈øides.
Sixthly, Half the line B D, viz. H B, or H D is the ≈øide of an Heptagon, or Polygon of ≈øeven ≈øides.

Seventhly, Divide the Line A F into two equal parts in M, and draw the Line E M K, cutting the Peripherie of the Circle in K. So ≈øhall the Line A K be the ≈øide of an Octagon, or Polygon of eight ≈øides.

Eightly, Divide that part of the peripherie of the Circle D A B into three equal parts, one third part will reach from D to L; then draw the Line D L, and it ≈øhall be the ≈øide of a Nonagon, or Polygon of nine ≈øides.
Ninthly, The Line E I is the ≈øide of a Decagon, or Polygon of ten ≈øides, which will be in≈øcribed in this Circle.

div.p: BEing provided of a Scale of equal parts for the ≈øetting of your Lines, and likewi≈øe of a Line of Chords for the ≈øetting of the Angles; both which Scales may be upon one and the ≈øame Ruler:

Fir≈øt, Take from your Scale of equal parts 484, which you ≈øhall find under V in the line of Semi-diameters; and with the length de≈øcribe the Circle A F B E; then take from the ≈øame Scale 569, which is under V in the Line of the interior Polygon, and this will reach in the Circle from B to B, and will divide it into five equal parts; according to the number of Sides of the Fort.

Secondly, Set off from the Point B, B I, equal to 104, which ≈øhall be the Gorge and Neck: from the point I erect two Penpendiculars I G H, and I H to the line B B, making I H 87 parts of the Scale, which is in the line under V, belonging to the fir≈øt Wing.

But it may ≈øo fall out ≈øometimes, that you cannot readily find the Centre of your Figure, by rea≈øon ≈øome Hou≈øe or other ob≈øtacle may ≈øtand in the way, ≈øo that you will be troubled to draw the Line A G, upon which your Capital line is taken, nor perhaps know what Angle it makes with the Polygon interior continued; though in truth that Angle is always equal to half your Angle of Circumference: you may make u≈øe of your Table, and find the quantity of the Angle contained between the Wing continued and the Face, namely, the Angle G H F in the Figure, which in this Example will be found to be 70 degrees 30 minutes. div.head: Concerning the farther ≈øtrengthning of your Fort by Half-Moons, Horn-works, Redoubts, &c.
div.p: YOur Fort thus fini≈øhed, you may farther ≈øtrengthen it with Half-Moons, Ravelines, Horn-works, Redoubts, and ≈øuch like, according as the place ≈øhall require, and the number of Souldiers you have for defence will permit.

div.head: I. Of the Half-Moon.
div.p: A Half-Moon hath either relation to the Curtain or Ba≈øtion, and in the ≈øecond Figure are marked with ‚òΩ: that which hath relation to the Curtain, is properly called a Raveline; and that at the point of the Ba≈øtion, a Half-Moon.

div.head: How to delineate a Raveline.
div.p: Divide the Curtain into two equal parts by the perpendicular n o: from p, the middle of your Wing, draw p o, p o; and from o, their inter≈øection, ≈øet off o q, equal to the Wing of your Ba≈øtion H I, or thereabouts; but this is left to the di≈øcretion of the Enginier, as al≈øo at what di≈øtance they ≈øhall be made from the Curtain or Ba≈øtion. But he mu≈øt not make the Angle of the Raveline too acute, but ≈øo to proportion the di≈øtance, that the Angle may be neer or equal to the Angle of the Ba≈øtion.

The Half-Moon is alike with the Raveline, but that it hath relation to the Ba≈øtion, and is drawn after the ≈øame manner; all which is plain in the ≈øecond Figure, where the Half-Moons are marked with ‚òΩ.

div.head: II. Of the Horn-work.
div.p: The Horn-work is mo≈øt conveniently defended from the face of your Ba≈øtion; which if you intend to do, make H F equal, or neer equal to G L your line of defence, and draw F F, which ≈øhall be equal to I I your Curtain; and let M L the Curtain of your Horn-work be about one third part of I I, but ≈øomewhat more, viz. 130 ≈øuch parts as your Curtain is 360 or more; if you plea≈øe to 150; and from n, the middle of F F, ≈øet off n o, n o, equal to 65 of your Scale, and draw o m, o l, right Angles at o. Then ≈øet off the Angles F K S, each of them 65 deg. as you would have the Angle of your Horn-work contain. Draw the Lines F S, and F S, and bi≈øect the Angles S F F, which ≈øhall cut off F K equal to M L, the Curtain of your Horn-work, of which k m, k l ≈øhall be the Wings.

div.head: Of Irregular Fortifications.
div.p: TOuching Irregular Fortifications, I can give no new Precept; only in the general, it is be≈øt, if po≈ø≈øible, to reduce them to regular Forms: but if the place will not permit it, take fir≈øt the Plot of the place, and ob≈øerve what Angles are made between every two ≈øides thereof.

Then look in the Table, in the cell of the Angles of Polygons, and ≈øee what Polygon the ob≈øerved Angle comes neere≈øt to, and make that Ba≈øtion according to the mea≈øures belonging to that Polygon, and ≈øo of the re≈øt; ≈øo ≈øhall you have unequal Ba≈øtions, but alike defen≈øible. Wherein likewi≈øe it is be noted, that if the
two ≈øides of your interior Polygon be of unequal length, the Ba≈øtion is be≈øt framed according to the mea≈øures taken upon the ≈øhorter ≈øide.
Example. Let it be required to draw Ba≈øtions to the ≈øide of an inordinate Pentagon, who≈øe Angles are, as they are marked in the third Figure.

Fir≈øt, I ob≈øerve 134, the Angle comprehended between two of the ≈øides, comes neere≈øt to the Angle of an Octagon in the Cell of the Angles of Polygons; I conclude therefore, that Ba≈øtion is to be drawn according to the mea≈øures belonging to an Octagon, taking the mea≈øures from the ≈øhorte≈øt ≈øide A B.

Now becau≈øe the mea≈øures of the Polygon interior belong to an Octagon, is 614, you mu≈øt make a Scale, of which 614 parts ≈øhall be equal to A B; then ≈øet off the Neck or Gorge A E, B E, 127 ≈øuch parts, as A B is 614; then mea≈øure 106 for the Wing. La≈øtly, becau≈øe the Center of the Figure is not known, by which the mea≈øure of the Capital line ≈øhould be taken, I take the Angle between the Wing prolonged and the Face, and take off 240 ≈øuch parts as the Curtain is 360, and ≈øo fini≈øh the Ba≈øtion belonging to the Angle 134

The next Angle 113, which is neere≈øt to a Hexagon, therefore that Ba≈øtion mu≈øt be framed from the ≈øhorter ≈øide, according to the mea≈øures of a Hexagon; and ≈øo mu≈øt all the Angles be fortified by tho≈øe mea≈øures which come neere≈øt to the Angle comprehended between the ≈øides thereof.

But in all Irregular Fortifications, much is attributed to the judgment of the Enginier, either to increa≈øe or dimini≈øh the Angles as he finds mo≈øt convenient, but in ≈øuch manner as the line of defence may ≈øcoure the face of the Ba≈øtion, and that one part thereof may defend, and be defended by the other.

It now remains to treat of the manner of making of Ditches about Forts, of the quantity of earth required to make a Fort, with Walls of any determined breadth and height; as al≈øo what inclinations they ought to have, both on the in≈øide and the out≈øide; within, of that ≈øloapne≈øs, that the Souldiers may (without much difficulty) go up and down; but without, ≈øloaping ≈øo little, that they may not be ≈øcaled by the Enemy; yet ≈øo much, that the foundation may be ≈øtrong. But this I ≈øhall omit for the pre≈øent, my de≈øign not being to write here all nece≈ø≈øary to be known in this Art, but only ≈øo much as might enable the Ingenious Souldier to be able to fortifie any place in the ab≈øence or want of an Enginier.

div.head: Some Principles of the GUNNERS-ART: Containing ≈øo much thereof as is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary for a compleat Souldier to be acquainted with, and (in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity) to put in practice.
div.p: HE that will be a compleat Cannonier, mu≈øt have knowledge and skill in the Sciences Mathematical, e≈øpecially in Arithmetick, and ≈øome part of Geometry; he mu≈øt be able to Multiply, Divide, and work the Golden Rule both Direct and Retrograde, either in whole Numbers or Fractions, or both. He mu≈øt be ready at the Extracting of the Square and Cube Roots, two of the chief hinges upon which many Que≈øtions in Gunnery do depend. His skill in Geometry mu≈øt be ≈øo much, as to take all manner of Heights, Depths, and Di≈øtances, either acce≈ø≈øible or inacce≈ø≈øible, with many other the like Qualifications.

But it was not intended to make an ab≈øolute or entire Treati≈øe of this My≈øterious Art of Gunnery in this place, but to give the curious (and he that de≈øires to be an accompli≈øhed) Souldier, ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction therein, that in the ab≈øence of the Cannoneer or Gunner, either by ≈øickne≈øs, lamene≈øs, or by being taken away by death, the expert Souldier may take upon him the Command of his Artillery, to his own Commendations, and for the Honour of the General under who≈øe Command ≈øuch Souldier is.

In order whereunto, I have laid down ≈øuch Rules and Directions, that the Souldier may ≈øafely and commendably attempt
the management of any Piece of great Artillery again≈øt his Enemy.

Fifthly, How to Di≈øport his Piece.

Eightly, To ≈øhoot at his Enemies Quarters in the Night-≈øea≈øon, and al≈øo as they pa≈øs by in the Day. With other Warlike Stratagems.

And la≈øtly, I have declared the making and u≈øe of the two De≈øtroying and Invincible Engines of Fire, the Granado and Petard. The peru≈øal and practice whereof I leave unto the ingenious Souldier: Bidding him heartily

div.p: WHereas in the following Di≈øcour≈øe, there is continual mention made of the ≈øeveral parts of a Piece, which cannot well be defined nor rendred ea≈øie without the Figure thereof repre≈øented in Plano; in order whereunto, I have drawn the Figure following, repre≈øenting the Ichnography of a Piece; and to the ≈øeveral parts thereof I have ≈øet ≈øeveral letters of the Alphabet directing to the ≈øame, by which at one view all will be vi≈øible.

div.head: What proportion the ≈øeveral parts of the Carriage ought to bear to the Gun it is to carry, as al≈øo of the Rammer, Ladle, Lanade, or Spunge, &c.
div.p: EVery Carriage ought to be in length once and an half the length of the Concave Cylinder of the Piece. The Planks at the fore-end of the Carriage ought to be in depth four Diameters of the Bore of the Piece. At the middle of the Planks, three Diameters and an half; and at the end next the ground, two and an half. And they ought to be in thickne≈øs one Diameter.

For the Traver≈øes (or bars of Wood) that joyn the≈øe Planks together, the foremo≈øt mu≈øt be three Diameters and an half in length, and mu≈øt enter one half of a Diameter in length into either of the Cheeks or Planks. That in the middle
mu≈øt be four Diameters in length, and enter into the Cheeks as the former. And that at the foot or lower end of the Carriage mu≈øt be in length five times the Diameter, and entred into the Planks as the former.

The Wheels mu≈øt be in height one half of the length of the Piece; the Circles mu≈øt be equal both in breadth and thickne≈øs to one Diameter of the Bore; the Spokes or Arms three times the Diameter. The Cube three Diameters in thickne≈øs, and three and an half in length. The Bore of the Cube mu≈øt be one Diameter, and the length of the Axle-tree eight Diameters and two third parts more.
The Wheels for the Saker and Minnion mu≈øt be in height the half length of the Piece and 1¬Ω part more. And the Faulcon and Faulconet half the length and ‚Öô part more.

div.head: Of the Ladle.
div.p: It is by ≈øome taken for a general rule, that the Circumference of a Bullet being divided into five equal parts, that three of tho≈øe parts mu≈øt be the breadth of the Ladle.
The bottom of every Ladle mu≈øt be one Diameter and ‚Öì long, and of ≈øuch a thickne≈øs as may with ea≈øe enter into the Bore of the Piece.

div.head: Of the Rammer.
div.p: The Rammer of every Piece mu≈øt be made of hard Wood, once and an half the Diameter long; and ≈øo thick, as it may with ea≈øe enter into the mouth of the Piece. It mu≈øt be bound at the lower end with a plate of Bra≈øs, ≈øet on with bra≈øs or Copper-nails to ≈øtrengthen it.

div.head: Of the Lanade or Spunge.
div.p: The bottome of the Lanade mu≈øt be one Diameter and ‚Öî parts in length, and ‚Öî parts of a Diameter in thickne≈øs, covered with Lambs or Sheeps-skin the Wool≈øide outwards, and made fa≈øt to the bottom with ≈ømall bra≈øs Nayls.
The Staff both for the Lanade and Rammer mu≈øt be one foot longer then the Cylinder of the Piece.

To every Piece there mu≈øt be Coyns of ≈øeveral ≈øizes, ≈øome great, ≈øome ≈ømall; and al≈øo Leavers proportionable to the Piece: the Coyns to keep the Piece at any elevation it ≈øhall be ≈øet to, and the Leavers to move the Piece and Carriage upon the Platform.

div.head: Cautions.
div.p: Before you attempt to charge your Piece, ≈øee that the Ground or Platform be level, that the Wheels of your Carriage be of equal height, that the Trunnions of your Gun lie right in the Carriage; If they be not, cau≈øe them to be amended, or expect to make no perfect ≈øhot.

div.head: How to Load any piece of Ordnance both ≈øurely and fafely.
div.p:
BEfore you load your Piece, take care to clean≈øe the Touch-hole, and ≈øweep the Piece clean within with a dry Lanade or Spunge; then (ob≈øerving the Winde) ≈øet your Powder-barrel to weather your Piece, and your Lin≈øtock on the contrary. Then filling your Ladle, give it a gentle knock on the foot, that the loo≈øe Corns may ≈øhake off into the barrel; then put your Ladle into your Piece, and being come to the bottome of the bore, draw it back two fingers breadth, and turn it over; then take it out, and with your Rammer (you
≈øtanding on the right ≈øide of your Piece) ham the Powder clo≈øe into the Chamber of the Piece, another (in the mean time) holding the Finger or Thumb upon the Touch-hole, that the Powder may not fly out that way: If the Touch-hole be full, it is a ≈øure ≈øigh that the Powder is well rammed; and if your Piece be to be charged at twice, you mu≈øt do this after each Ladle-ful.

Then take a wi≈øp of Hey or Straw, and chru≈øt it hard into the mouth of the Piece after the Powder, that no loo≈øe Corns may remain in the empty part of the Cylinder, and ram that ha ‚Ä¢ d home upon the Powder.
Then again, take a dry Lanade, and clean≈øe the Cylinder of the Piece, that ‚Ä¢ oothing be left in the hollow Cylinder, to hinder the Bullets way.
This done, make your Bullet very clean, that neither Earth nor Sand hang upon it, and put it gently into your Piece, and after it a wad of Hey or Straw ea≈øily rammed.

And here note, that in doing this you mu≈øt not ≈øtand right before the mouth of your Piece, but on one ≈øide, for fear of mi≈øchances; and having charged your Piece, you mu≈øt lay your Ladle, Lanade, Scowrer and Rammer on the right ≈øide of your Piece, the Ladle and Lanade their heads towards the mouth, and the Rammer and Scowrer towards the Breech of the Piece.

Your Piece being thus charged, direct her to the intended Mark, and then Prime her; in the doing of which, Fir≈øt, with your Priming-iron enter the Touch-hole, and let your Powder come from the Touch-hole to the Ba≈øe-ring, for there you may fire ≈øafely; for if you fire at the Touch-hole, your Lin≈øtock may be forced out of your hand: therefore ≈øome u≈øe to prime their Gun two or three inches forward off the Touch-hole; for if that be large, the more care mu≈øt be had in firing.

In firing of any Piece, take your Lin≈øtock in your right hand, and coming to the ≈øide of your Piece, ≈øet forward one Leg, keep your Body upright, and your Arm extended at full length; the cole of your Match being cleared, give fire to the Powder, ≈øo ≈øhall you perform your work both ≈øafely and gracefully.

div.head: Another way of Loading a Piece of Artillery.
div.p: There is another way u≈øed to load Guns, which is by Cartredges; the≈øe Cartredges are made, either of Canvas or Paper, rowled upon a Former or Rowler, turned ≈øomething le≈øs then the hollow Cylinder of your Piece; the≈øe being ≈øewed or pa≈øted, and having bottoms put to them, are filled at ≈øpare times (in Garri≈øons or other places) with a due charge of powder belonging to the Piece for which they were made, and are ready when≈øoever occa≈øion ≈øhall require: one of the≈øe being put into the mouth of the Piece, together with the Bullet, and well wadded and rammed, with your priming-iron at the Touch-hole, make a hole through the Cartridge, and then having primed it, you may give fire as before.

div.head: How to Di≈øpart any Piece of Ordnance.
div.p: THere are ≈øeveral ways to di≈øpart a piece of Ordnance; I will mention one or two in lieu of all the re≈øt. ‚Äî Now, to Di≈øpart a piece, is, To bring the Metal of the Muzzle-ring, equal to that of the Ba≈øe-ring; or, it is, To find the difference of the Metal at the Muzzle and the Ba≈øe-rings. To effect which, either of the≈øe wayes will declare.

Fir≈øt, Take a ≈ømall ≈øtreight Stick or Wyer, and put it downright into the Touch-hole of your piece, and even with the top of the Metal of the ba≈øe-ring; this Stick taken out of the Touch-hole, apply to the bottom of the Metal, at the bo ‚Ä¢ e of the piece; and that part of the Stick or Wyer which ≈øtands above the Metal of the Muzzle-ring, is the true Di≈øpart for that piece.

Secondly, Or take with a ≈ømall ≈øilk or thred the Circumference of the Metal
at the ba≈øe-ring; and al≈øo with another ≈øilk the Circumference of the Metal at the muzzle-ring divide either of the≈øe lengths into 22 equal parts, and from each of them cut off ≈øeven parts; half the difference that is between the length of the≈øe two ≈øtrings, is the true Di≈øpart. This way is in it ≈øelf exact enough; but I prefer the former far before it, both for ea≈øe and exactne≈øs, if carefully handled.

div.head: How to level your Piece to ≈øhoot at any Mark within Point-Blank.
div.p: YOur Piece lying upon his Carriage well fixed, the Ground or Platform clean and even, and your Gun clean≈øed, loaded and wadded, as is before directed, and having di≈øparted the ≈øame as was la≈øt taught;

Place the di≈øpart upon the top or upper part of the muzzle-ring of your piece perpendicular or upright, fixing it there with wax or the like: then going to the breech of your Gun, cau≈øe one of your Matro≈ø≈øes with a leaver to turn the piece towards the mark: then the carriage there ≈øtanding, cau≈øe him to rai≈øe the piece or depre≈øs it, till with your eye (at about 2 or 3 foot di≈øtance from the breech of your piece) you can ≈øee the very top or highe≈øt part of the Metal of the ba≈øe-ring, the very top of your di≈øpart, and the mark you are to ≈øhoot at, all three in a right line; which when you have found, cau≈øe the piece to be kept there by, putting a Coyn under it; and when it is coyned, look again, and ≈øee if all be as you before left it; if it be not, cau≈øe it to be altered: but if it be you may, prime and give fire.

div.head: The fir≈øt Shot being defective, how to amend it in the ≈øecond.
div.p: A Shot is ≈øaid to be defective, when it is either over, under, or wide of the mark aimed at: to remedy this, you mu≈øt ob≈øerve the≈øe few Directions following:

Fir≈øt, If your Shot be right to your Mark, but yet over, it is a ≈øign your Di≈øpart is too ≈øhort, which you may remedy by placing a di≈øpart upon the muzzle-ring of ≈øuch a length, that looking by the ba≈øe-ring and the mark the ≈øhot la≈øt made, you may ≈øee the top of the di≈øpart: with this new di≈øpart level your piece to the mark, prime and give fire, and doubtle≈øs your ≈øhot will prove good.

Secondly, If your Shot be ju≈øt under the mark, then look how much the di≈øpart is over the Mark of the Shot la≈øt made, and cut it ≈øo much ≈øhorter, that looking at the breech of the Piece, you ≈øee the mark of the la≈øt Shot, and the top of the di≈øpart in one right line; then by this di≈øpart level your Gun to the Mark, and give fire.

Thirdly, But if your fir≈øt Shot had been level with, but yet to the right hand of the Mark; to remedy this, ≈øtand at the breech of the piece, looking over the di≈øpart at the mark the la≈øt Shot made, and upon that part of the ba≈øe-ring, which you then look over, ≈øet up a pin with a little wax; ≈øo this pin will be in a right line with the di≈øpart and Mark of the Shot: then level the piece again, by help of this pin and the di≈øpart, to your a≈ø≈øigned Mark, and without Que≈øtion you will make an effectual ≈øhot.
Fourthly, But if your ≈øhot be both wide, and too high, or too low, then both the former rules mu≈øt be applied to regulate it, which rea≈øon will be≈øt direct how to perform.

And here note, that the≈øe defective Shots la≈øt ≈øpoken of, are not, or may not be in the fault of the Gunner; for let him di≈øpart and level his Gun never ≈øo well,
he may make a bad Shot; for, 1. The Wind may alter the Range of the bullet. 2. The irregularity or inequality of the thickne≈øs of the Metal of the piece may much impede. 3. The uneven lying of the piece in the Carriage; and many other rea≈øons not here to be enumerated.

div.head: To make a good Shot in a dark Night at a Mark that hath been ≈øhewn you in the Day-time.
div.p: MOunt, level, and di≈øpart your piece at the a≈ø≈øigned Mark in the day-time, according as hath been before directed; the piece thus remaining, from the bottom of the muzzle-ring, let fall a Line with a plummet at the end thereof having a point; and where the point toucheth the platform, there make a Mark, and take al≈øo the length of that ≈øtring, or run a pin through the ≈øtring in that place; do the like by letting fall the ≈øame line and plummet from the breech of the piece, and make a Mark upon the platform as before, and the length of the ≈øtring. Then (though your Gun be moved out of its place, yet) you may in the darke≈øt night (by help of a dark Lanthorn) bring your piece to the former po≈øition; which being primed and fired, will doubtle≈øs come neer, if not hit the Mark.

div.head: How you may ≈øhoot at your Enemies Lights in his Quarters in a dark Night.
div.p: BRing your piece upon your platform to lie right again≈øt your Enemies Lights; then take two pieces of lighted match, one ≈øo much longer then the other, as is the true di≈øpart of the piece you are to ≈øhoot with; place the longe≈øt of them upon the muzzle-ring of your piece, and the ≈øhorter upon the ba≈øe-ring thereof, and there fix them upright with wax; then elevate or depre≈øs your Gun, till at a di≈øtance with your Eye, you e≈øpy both your Matches and the Enemies Lights all in a right line; which done, prime and give fire.

div.head: How you may make a Shot at a party of Hor≈øe or Foot, as they pa≈øs by; as al≈øo at a Ship Sayling up or down a River.
div.p: Your piece being charged, let it be laid in the Carriage at little or no elevation, that it may ≈øhoot about bre≈øt-high; then di≈øpart it, and direct it again≈øt ≈øome Mark that lies ju≈øt in the way they are to pa≈øs: if the ground they are to pa≈øs be higher then your platform, mount your Gun accordingly; if lower, depre≈øs it; if level, then as before: your Gun thus prepared, in their pa≈ø≈øage you may give fire at plea≈øure: and in the ordering of your Gun for this Stratagem, let it (if po≈ø≈øible) be parallel with the plain of the Horizon, that ≈øo it may ≈øhoot ≈øhort, e≈øpecially if the place be ≈øtony; for the grazing of the bullet among the ≈øtones, may do more execution then the ≈øhot it ≈øelf: but above all, have a ≈øpecial care you ≈øhoot not wide nor over.

What hath been ≈øaid concerning an Enemies pa≈ø≈øing by Land, the like may be done by an Enemies Ship ≈øayling along a River. For, if you plant your Gun, and direct it to ≈øome mark, as Tree, Beakon, &c. on the other ≈øide of the River; then when the fore-part of the Ship ≈øhall come between your ≈øight and the mark you ob≈øerved, immediately give fire.
And thus much for ≈øhooting in great Artillery.

div.head: The compo≈øition, making, and u≈øe of the two Principal Fire-works belonging to WAR, viz. THE GRANADO and PETARD.
I. Of the Granado.
div.p: OF Granadoes there are ≈øeveral ≈øorts; ≈øome to ca≈øt with mens hands, others to be ≈øhot out of great Guns, and others ≈øo large that they require a Morter-piece on purpo≈øe for the di≈øcharging of them.

The Shell is made of Copper ca≈øt in form of a Sphere or Globe, allowing half an inch, and ≈øometimes more (according as the Shell is in bigne≈øs) for the thickne≈øs of the Metal, which ought to be ca≈øt very exactly, to be equally thick in all parts. They are to be filled with fine powder; they are to have a pipe ≈øcrewed into them, which is to be filled with a ≈ølow compo≈øition to prime it, the compo≈øition of which I ≈øhall ≈øhew you anon.

The≈øe Granadoes are made proportionable to the weight of the bullet belonging to the piece out of which they are to be ≈øhot; and if they in bigne≈øs exceed the bore of a Cannon, then they are to be ≈øhot out of a Morter-piece.

div.head: II. Of the Petard.
div.p:
THe≈øe Petards are made of Copper and bra≈øs mixed; and their dimen≈øions are fitted according to the u≈øe for which they were prepared; there being
three chief u≈øes of them, and ≈øo many ≈øorts there are, viz. Some for blowing up and breaking of bridges. Others, for Gates that have Perculles belonging to them. And the third ≈øort for ordinary Gates.

1. Tho≈øe for Bridges are commonly eleven inches long, and at the breech ≈øeven inches and an half about, and five inches wide within: the Metal at the breech mu≈øt be one inch and a quarter thick, and at the neck half an inch thick, be≈øides the muzzle-ring. The mouth mu≈øt be ten inches wide, and to the Touch-hole mu≈øt be added a pipe, as in the Figure.

2. The ≈øecond ≈øort for Gates with Perculles, mu≈øt be nine inches long, almo≈øt half an inch thick at the neck, and an inch thick at the breech; the mouth mu≈øt be about ≈øeven inches wide, and the out≈øide of the breech mu≈øt be ≈øix inches wide, and the in≈øide four inches.

3. The third ≈øort, which is for Gates and Pali≈øadoes, mu≈øt be ≈øeven inches long, one fifth part of an inch thick at the neck, and three quarters of an inch thick at the breech: the mouth mu≈øt be four Inches wide; at the out≈øide of the breech it mu≈øt be three inches and an half, and at the in≈øide thereof three inches.

The Charges for the≈øe Petards are to be of the fine≈øt powder that can be got, beaten hard into the Petard, yet not to break the Gun; then mu≈øt it be ≈øtopped clo≈øe in with a Wooden board of about an Inch thick; ju≈øtly fitted thereunto, with wax melted to ≈øtop the crevi≈øe about to keep out water. You mu≈øt not charge it up to the top, but leave the breadth of almo≈øt two inches empty, which mu≈øt be filled up with tow clo≈øe ≈øtopped in, and a linnen Cloath bound about the Petards neck to keep it clo≈øe in.
The Touch-hole mu≈øt be ≈øtopped with a Cork, and over that a Sear-Cloath to keep it from wet.
The charge for the greater ≈øort of Petards, is five or ≈øix pound of powder. Tho≈øe of the ≈øecond, from three to four pounds. And for the ≈ømalle≈øt, from one pound and an half to one pound.

div.head: To prime your Petards and Granadoes, u≈øe this following Compo≈øition.
div.p: TAke of fine Powder three parts, of Sulphur ≈øix parts, and of Salt-Peter nine parts: beat all of them ≈øeverally into fine powder, and mix them together, putting to them Oyl of Peter by little and little till it become a pa≈øte; dry this lea≈øurely but throughly, and with it lade your pipe.
